abstract: A very meritorious, and in some respects remarkable,picture will be placed on exhibition to-day at the Institute of Art, (Derby Gallery,) No. 625 Broadway. It represents WASHINGTON IRVING and his friends at Sunnyside the "friends" being fourteen of the most prominent literary men of the country.
lead_paragraph: A very meritorious, and in some respects remarkable,picture will be placed on exhibition to-day at the Institute of Art, (Derby Gallery,) No. 625 Broadway. It represents WASHINGTON IRVING and his friends at Sunnyside -- the "friends" being fourteen of the most prominent literary men of the country. There can be but little novelty in the design of such a work. Several artists have essayed to give the world an idea of its cotemporary statesmen, authors, &c., and the world has generally been interested in their efforts, notwithstanding that some of its friends thus congregated together looked as though they were stubborn mobs that ought to be dispersed by the Police. Since the war we have necessarily been inundated with military chieftains and heroes, all standing or sitting in painful positions, and all more or less oppressed by a sense of buttons and arms. It seems, indeed, that masses of men can only be treated in one way, and that way as stereotyped as the allegory of the old masters. When we say that the proprietors of "Washington Irving and his Friends" have succeeded in presenting the best group of figures which we have seen for many years, it will be perceived that our remarks are not intended to depreciate their work. On the contrary, the composition of the Irving picture is unusually free and good; a little full, perhaps -- as the library at Sunnyside must have been with fifteen persons in it -- but not crowded. The attitudes of the figures are remarkably natural. These results have not been obtained without forethought and much labor. In the first place, Mr. F.O.C. DARLEY, the well-known draughtsman, was called upon for the design, and the success we have referred to is entirely owing to this gentleman. Then special photographs were taken of all the leading characters; each individual being place in the exact position required by Mr. DARLEY. In this way wonderful accuracy of face and figure has been insured. After the results of these separate sittings had been incorporated in the whole, the design was twice photographed and finished with the greatest care. The engraving, which is nearly ready, is executed from this photograph and promises to be one of Mr. T.O. BARLOW's greatest successes. Mr. C. SCHUSSELH has since reproduced it in oil, being assisted in his task by additional sittings on the part of the principal figures. He shares with Mr. DARLEY the merit of having produced the best national picture ever painted in America. The portraits are excellently preserved, the flesh tints being delicate and truthful, the positions easy and pleasing, and the whole effect unlabored and interesting. Compared with those well-known engravings "Walter Scott and his Friends" and "Shakespeare and his Cotemporaries," the present work is absolutely animated.

abstract: There is very little news from the Army of the Potomac this morning. The probabilities are that a general engagement was fought yesterday, somewhere near Orange Court-house, as officers who arrived in Washington last evening report very heavy and continuous cannonading heard at Bealton Station from early in the day until they left, at 3 P.M. No reports whatever, of any kind, had been received in Washington up to last night, so all the rumors afloat yesterday, both good and bad, were without foundation. If a battle began yesterday, news cannot well reach here before this evening.

abstract: The position of affairs in Virginia, now that the campaign at Chattanooga has subsided, is one of absorbing interest. That
lead_paragraph: The position of affairs in Virginia, now that the campaign at Chattanooga has subsided, is one of absorbing interest. That the Army of the Potomac should have literally abandoned its communications with Washington, is a circumstance so new to the army, and so startling to the country, that there is really something quite refreshing in contemplating it. Gen. MEADE has packed up his rations and forage for a ten days' campaign, and, without regard to his flank or his rear, has struck out boldly for the enemy. The march of the first two days, of which only we have details, was in every respect successful. The enemy's strong line on the Rapidan was successfully turned, and the concentration of our army was prompt at the appointed place on Friday night. Our advices only come down to Saturday forenoon, at which time the enemy was drawn up in line two miles beyond our advance, with the apparent intention of giving battle. Our dispatch from Washington states that the cannonading heard at Bealeton Station yesterday, was so heavy as to leave no doubt a general engagement was going on.

abstract: Speech at New-York Polish Meeting
lead_paragraph: Yesterday being the anniversary of the Polish Revolution of 1830, the Polanders of this City celebrated the day in a becoming manner, and in the evening held a mass meeting in the large hall of the Cooper Institute. The hall was well filled with ladies and gentlemen, three-fourths of whom were Americans and the remainder Polish exiles now residing in this City and representatives of Young Europe from the various Continental nations. The hall was handsomely decorated with American and Polish flags, and in the rear of the speaker's desk hung a large allegorical painting representing Poland, in the form of a female just released from her broken chains and rising up as the radiant Goddess of Liberty. After several patriotic airs by the band, the meeting was organized by the election of Ex-Judge JOHN W. EDMONDS as President, assisted by a long list of Vice-Presidents, among whom were Peter Cooper, William Cullen Bryant, Wm. Curtis Noyes, Robert Emmet, Horace Greeley, Herr Ottendorfer, Frederick Kapp, James Gordon Bennett, Moses H. Beach, Richard O'Gorman, Jos. Hoxie, and many others.

abstract: Those who fancy that Gen. GRANT will pursue BRAGG from the hills of Georgia down to its plains, or down to the seaboard, will most likely find themselves mistaken.
lead_paragraph: Those who fancy that Gen. GRANT will pursue BRAGG from the hills of Georgia down to its plains, or down to the seaboard, will most likely find themselves mistaken. It is a painful necessity of our Western heroes that each hero of them requires his "pound of flesh" every day, not to speak of an equal weight of "hard tack;" and those who will for a moment reflect on the amount of solid victual required to sustain the heerts of fifty or sixty thousand men for a week, will at once see the difficulty of sending them on a campaign, which, at its best, would occupy them for months, through a region bare of food, and into which it is impossible for Gen. GRANT to convey supplies. We do not think it would be feasible to maintain the army of Gen. GRANT even at Atlanta during the Winter; for, though the forces of BRAGG may be pretty thoroughly demolished or dispersed, there would still be bodies of them left to roam through the country, who would operate on our lines after the style of MOSBY in Virginia, and with a hundredfold the effect. We doubt whether, even if the rebels had but ten thousand men in Northern Georgia, against ten times that number on the Union side, it would be possible for GRANT to plant his army fifty miles south of Chattanooga and maintain his communications with it. On this account, we do not entertain the idea that Gen. GRANT will, at this time, push on his victorious columns, as many seem to imagine he must do.
headline: {'main': "Gen. Grant's Operations What Next?", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Gen. Grant's Operations What Next?", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Case of the Bark Empress
lead_paragraph: Our Navy officers will take interest in a decision which we publish this morning, made by Judge NELSON, in the United States Circuit Court, in the case of the bark Empress. The bark, as it appears, was captured as a prize, and was condemned by the District Court, but that decree was, on appeal, reversed by the Circuit Court, which declared that the vessel was not a lawful prize, but that the seizure of her was illegal, and she must be restored to her owners. The owners thereupon applied to the Court for an order that the captors should pay the costs and damages occasioned by this illegal seizure. The Court denies the motion, holding that the prize suit, which is brought by the United States to obtain the condemnation of the vessel, is a proceeding to which the captors individually are not parties, and they are not, therefore, responsible for its result, and the Court has no jurisdiction to award costs and damages against them in that suit.

abstract: Army officers from Bealton Station to-night report that heavy cannonading was heard since early this morning in the direction of Orange Court-house. The firing was so heavy and continuous as to preclude the possibility of its being a skirmish. It was their opinion a general engagement was in progress at the time they last heard the firing, which was at 11 o'clock this forenoon.

abstract: By the Scotia, off Cape Race yesterday, we have advices one week later from Europe. The news is not specially important. The English reply to the proposition of LOUIS NAPOLEON for a Congress had been announced. It does not comply unqualifiedly, but rather calls for further information. The English Press generally opposed the proposition -- some of them very strongly -- and the correspondent of the London Times, writing from Paris, asserts that the project was losing ground every day. A bill had been submitted to the French Council to supply MAXIMILIAN with ninety-one millions of francs, as the bone and sinew of the new Empire in Mexico. The tone of the Paris Press on Polish matters was more reserved, under instructions. The Moniteur was only publishing the Russian version. Sweden was preparing for war. The steamship City of New-York, from Liverpool on the 18th inst., also arrived at this port at an early hour this morning, but not in season to admit of our making extracts from our files.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- It would have been contrary to the natural order of things if the weather last night had been favorable -- that night having been set apart for the benefit of Mr. MAX MARETZEK. Notwithstanding the first snow of the season, however, the house presented a most brilliant appearance. The opera was "Faust," which thus brought the season to a successful close. Mr. MARETZEK goes to Philadelphia.

abstract: Government and the Citizens--the "Ring'
lead_paragraph: The support given by the working classes of this City to the politicians of "the ring," and which alone enables the latter to keep the Administration in their hands, is a remarkable illustration of the way in which workingmen sometimes assist in their own robbery and oppression. We venture to say that nine-tenths of those who vote to sustain "the ring" chuckle over the rapid increase of taxation, in the full belief that it comes entirely out of the pockets of the rich men, and that as long as it is not levied in the form of an octroi, on meat and bread, the poor man need not care what figure it reaches. We thus find that the most popular Aldermen and Common Councilmen are those who are most energetic in voting money for shows, processions, donations, banquets, and other forms of riot and waste.
headline: {'main': 'The City Government and the Citizens.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The City Government and the Citizens.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We do not suppose it is of much use to remind the public that the election which takes place to-day is one of great importance, and deserves the attention of every voter. A large portion of our citizens are disposed to believe it, and to act accordingly: but with the great mass of our people, it is useless to disguise the fact, it excites but little interest. At the outset of the canvass there was a general conviction that BOOLE, being the nominee of both wings of the Democratic party, was sure of his election: and this feeling prevented the adoption of those means of preparation which are essential to success in any contest. As the canvass proceeded, GUNTHER's friends have grown more and more confident, and they now claim, with a great show of confidence, that GUNTHER will receive more votes than BOOLE.

abstract: New-York Central; Election of Directors
lead_paragraph: The election for Directors of the New-York Central Railroad takes place next week. The indication of a purpose on the part of the stockholders to effect a reform in its management, has aroused its present officers to unusual and remarkable efforts to retain their places. The President, who receives no salary, has spent a good deal of his time in this City for the last few days, backed up by the Vice-President, the Treasurer, the Superintendent, and other officers, and aided by a formidable corps of outside agents, buying stock, contracting for the use of proxies at so much per vote, and in every possible way striving to perfect and perpetuate his tenure of office. This of itself is rather a remarkable spectacle, and might well excite some little anxiety on the part of those whose property is invested in the road. It finds a satisfactory explanation in the fact that the President has the right of supplying the road, at his own prices and under his own supervision, with all its iron, and that agents appointed by himself are the sole judges of what the road wants. And it is perfectly notorious that this privilege, which is without a parallel in the management of any other work of equal magnitude on the face of the earth, is worth to the President not less than $250,000 per annum. Every dollar of this comes out of the pockets of the stockholders. If they are content to pay it, very well. No one else can fairly object.
headline: {'main': 'The Central Railroad.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Central Railroad.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Gen. HITCHCOCK, the officer who has had the general direction of matters referring to the exchange of our prisoners, has written to the TIMES a highly important letter upon the subject, to which we give place this morning.
lead_paragraph: Gen. HITCHCOCK, the officer who has had the general direction of matters referring to the exchange of our prisoners, has written to the TIMES a highly important letter upon the subject, to which we give place this morning. The mystery which has enveloped the question, and the confused and contradictory statements which have been made about it, are for the first time cleared up by this letter. Our authorities, it would seem, are not to blame for the stoppage of exchanges. They have proposed to the rebel Commissioner to exchange, man for man, all the prisoners now held in the South, but this the rebels have refused to agree to. In all, we hold forty thousand rebel prisoners, while the rebels hold but thirteen thousand Union prisoners; and they insist, as appears from Gen. HITCHCOCK's letter, as well as from the correspondence between Commissioners MEREDITH and OULD, which we lately published, that the exchange shall be general; that is to say, that we shall deliver up to them all of the 40,000 prisoners in our possession, and receive in return about 13,000 men, leaving about 27,000 men who might, for a few days, be considered on parole not to take arms unless duly exchanged; "and then," asks Gen. HITCHCOCK, "what would Mr. OULD do with those men? Judging by what he has actually recently done, he would undoubtedly assume to discharge those men from all obligations under their parole, and put them into the field to fight against. National troops, standing under an unstained National flag -- the very troops who gallantly captured those men upon bloody battle-fields, within the past few months." In this charge Gen. HITCHCOCK is not unjust; for in another place he states that "already the question has come up from Gen. GRANT's glorious battle-field at Chattanooga, as to what shall be done with a body of the enemy, who, having been paroled as prisoners of war at Vicksburgh, have been recaptured in arms at Chattanooga, without having been properly exchanged," -- and this notwithstanding the explicit denial of Mr. OULD that any of the Vicksburgh prisoners had been sent into the field.
headline: {'main': 'The Exchange of Prisoners.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Exchange of Prisoners.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Every day is written this little sentence -- "Died yesterday." Every day a flower is plucked from some sunny home -- a breach is made in some happy circle -- a jewel is taken from some treasury of love by the ruthless hand of the angel of death. Each day from the Summer fields of life some harvester disappears. Yes, every moment some cherished sentimental drops from the rugged ramparts of time into the surging waves of eternity. Even as we write, the church-bell tolls the doleful funeral knell of one who "died yesterday" -- its solemn tones chill the blood in our veins and make the heart sad indeed.

abstract: The canvass for Speakership continues active, but in good feeling. As members come in, the preponderance in favor of COLFAX is very manifest. His friends claim three-fourths of the vote of the entire caucus. It is probable that a caucus of Union members will be held on Saturday night to nominate a candidate for the Speakership. Other officers of the House may not be nominated until Monday night.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Dec. 1.

abstract: News from the Army of the Potomac, to Monday noon, has been received at Washington. The explanation of the heavy cannonading heard on that day was an attempt on our part to feel the lines of the enemy, who was found in force, whereupon orders to cease firing were issued,
lead_paragraph: News from the Army of the Potomac, to Monday noon, has been received at Washington. The explanation of the heavy cannonading heard on that day was an attempt on our part to feel the lines of the enemy, who was found in force, whereupon orders to cease firing were issued, and at latest dates no general engagement had occurred. Both armies are in position for conflict on the opposite sides of Mine Run Valley, at the crossing of the Orange and Fredericksburgh Plankroad, at Verdiersville, and that a battle would occur yesterday was considered very probable. LEE is strongly intrenched on high ground, and is evidently determined to make a decisive stand. MEADE's line of battle is formed with the Sixth Army Corps on the right, the Second supported by the First in the centre, the Third on the left, and the Fifth in reserve. Our special correspondent furnishes highly interesting details of operations concerning the movements of the Army of the Potomac to Sunday morning last.

abstract: The Commercial's Cumberland Gap correspondent telegraphs to-night that all available force has been sent from there to intercept LONGSTREET'S retreat into Virginia. He says a courier from Knoxville brings intelligence of the enemy's attempt to cross the river on Sunday, bringing on a general engagement, and resulting in the defeat of the enemy and the capture of Gen. WHEELER'S division of 5,000 rebels.

abstract: Elected Mayor of New-York; Charter Election; G. C. Gunther Elected Mayor
snippet: Elected Mayor of New-York; Charter Election; G. C. Gunther Elected Mayor
lead_paragraph: The election was spiritedly conducted, yesterday and without disturbance, notwithstanding the feeling existing in many of the wards and districts. Early in the day people awoke to the fact that Mr. GUNTHER was a formidable candidate, and as the election progressed it was evident that he would poll a very heavy vote. As the time for the closing of the polls was nearing, the probability of his election was discussed, but the result was a great surprise, and the decisive majority a greater.

abstract: Mayor Gunther's Election
lead_paragraph: GODFREY GUNTHER was elected Mayor of this City yesterdays by a very large majority. This result, we confess, takes us by surprise, as we presume it will a very large portion of the community. In common with the public at large, we had assumed that the Democratic party was substantially united in support of the nominee of both its factions. Alderman BOOLE, Mozart and Tammany had both made him their candidate. Both went earnestly and vigorously at work to secure his election. The entire machinery of the party was used for his benefit -- and we had very little doubt, so accustomed had we become to the docile manner in which the masses of both these factious obey the dictation of their leaders, that BOOLE would receive the votes of the main body of the Democratic party. Nor had we any more doubt that in this event he would be reasonably sure of his election.

abstract: -- OPENING of MR. ANSCHUTZ's SEASON OF GERMAN OPERA. -- Mr. CARL ANSCHUTZ commences his season at the Academy of Music to-night. FLOTOW's romantic opera of "Stradella," is selected for the occasion. It is an attractive work, and is rendered unusually interesting by the cast, which includes the names of Mme. JOHANSSEN, Herr WEINLICH, Herr GRAFF and Mr. ANSCHUTZ's new tenors, Herr HIMMER and Herr HABELMANN.

abstract: By telegraph from Cumberland Gap, via Cincinnati, last night, we have news of a victory over LONGSTREET by the gallant forces under BURNSIDE. LONGSTREET, it seems, endeavored to cross the Tennessee, near Knoxville, on Sunday last, with the
lead_paragraph: By telegraph from Cumberland Gap, via Cincinnati, last night, we have news of a victory over LONGSTREET by the gallant forces under BURNSIDE. LONGSTREET, it seems, endeavored to cross the Tennessee, near Knoxville, on Sunday last, with the apparent purpose of retreating into Virginia, but was defeated with the loss of one whole division five thousand strong. The news is not yet confirmed from official sources, but it may be quite authentic, as the muddled situation in East Tennessee has for several days given promise of a speedy solution, and news from Knoxville was confidently expected in Washington yesterday. LONGSTREET, thus defeated and held at bay by BURNSIDE in front, with reinforcements from GRANT coming upon his rear, will be in a decidedly "tight place."

abstract: CONSTRUCTION OF NEW WAR VESSELS. -- There has been a general conviction in the public mind from the very outset, that there is some radical defect in the administration of the Navy Department. It has been found impossible to secure from it a degree of efficiency at all comparable with other departments. In the matter of speed, especially, every attempt made has been a dismal failure -- and we have consequently been utterly unable to capture a single one of the rebel privateers that for the last year and a half have been roaming the sea and preying on our commerce, at their own sweet will. We have heard it said, on very good authority, that there are two hundred steam vessels in the English navy that are faster than the Alabama, while as yet we have failed to find or build a single one. This is not because we have not the ability or the means to do it, but simply because the Navy Department will not employ them. There is a blind, obstinate adherence to theory in the Bureau which controls all these matters, that has thwarted every attempt on the part of our shipping merchants and shipbuilders to secure faster vessels for our naval service.

abstract: An extensive conflagration occurred early Wednesday morning on Seventh-avenue, which resulted in the destruction of over $160,000 worth of property. One entire block on the west side of the avenue, between Twenty-eight and twenty-ninth streets, was destroyed. Thence the flames extended across Twenty-ninth-street, where several large tenement houses were burned, and over forty families were thereby rendered homeless. Sixteen buildings were entirely destroyed, and several others partially. A fireman named JOHN BROWN performed a most heroic act by entering a house and rescuing a child from the Second story, after the building was completely enveloped in flames.

abstract: Re d'Italia, Ironclad, Description of
lead_paragraph: An elegant entertainment was given last evening on board the new Italian frigate Red'Italia, now lying at her dock in Hoboken. This magnificent vessel, the finest probably of all the naval structures of our great American shipbuilder, WILLIAM H. WEBB, Esq., is now completed, and will sail for the bay of Naples in l5 days. Her officers and crew arrived here from Naples in the line-of-battle ship Galantuomo on the 5th of November, and are now comfortably settled on board their new vessel, with which they all express themselves highly delighted. Before leaving New-York they were desirous of seeing something of our Metropolitan society, and Mr. WEBB anticipating their wishes, arranged for, and provided at his own expense the superb entertainment given last evening. Cards of invitation were issued to several hundred of our prominent citizens, who responded in large numbers to the invitation. Among the guests present were the Italian Minister. Signor Bertinatti, Signor Anfoie, the Italian Consul General, Capts. Boukatoff, Federoffski, and Croun, of the Russian fleet, Commander Baldwin, U.S.N., Capt. Worden, U.S.N., Engineer Steimers, U.S.N., Judge Daly, Judge Woodruff, Judge Roosevelt, Postmaster Wakeman, Collector Barney, Jas. W. Gerard. Jos. Hokie, Capt. Chas. H. Marshall, Jas. W. Beekman, Rev. Dr. Cummings, D.D. Field, Dr. Sayre, Dr. Gardner, Wm.V. Brady, Horatio Allen, and others, together with a large number of ladies. The frigate was thrown open for visitors at 3 P.M., and from that time until late in the evening was thronged with ladies and gentlemen, who came to pay their respects to the Italian officers and to view their magnificent vessel. At 7 o'clock in the evening a most luxurious supper was provided for the guests in the ward-room, under the supervision of the famous caterer of the Maison Doree, Mons. MARTINEZ, assisted by his chief steward, FRANCIS SCHMIDT. There was no formal speechmaking on the occasion, though several gentlemen, on being called on for a toast, prefaced their sentiments by appropriate remarks. Mr. GERARD, among others, congratulated the company upon the fact that the elegant vessel which they all so much admired, was going to that beautiful and classic land. Italia, the foremost among the nations in art and song, and the furthest advanced in freedom. He closed by offering the following: "The King of Italy and the King of Shipbuilders" -- which was drank with great applause. After supper the guests repaired to the gun-deck, where dancing commenced, and was kept up till midnight, to the music of Dodworth's Band. The officers of the Re d'Italia were all dressed in full uniform, and it was the unanimous expression of the ladies that they were the handsomest lot of men, taken as a body, they had ever seen. The decks of the vessel were brilliantly illuminated during the evening with calcium lights, and the engines were kept constantly in motion to enable the guests to witness the beautiful working at her machinery. The Re d'Italia has two engines, each of 800-horse power. They are similar to those of the Russian frigate Grand Admiral, built by Mr. WEBB in 1860. The cost of the Re d'Italia was $1,500,000. Her armament will be supplied after she reaches the Mediterranean. She carries with her from here only eight guns, furnished from the Galantuomo, which brought her officers and crew to this port. She will go into commission today, and it is in contemplation to give her a trial trip down the Bay previous to her departure for the Mediterranean. The following is a

abstract: There is one ominous circumstance for the rebels in the recent victory of Chattanooga, as well as very favorable to the loyal cause  and that is, that our opponents did not fight at all as they have been accustomed to fight.
lead_paragraph: There is one ominous circumstance for the rebels in the recent victory of Chattanooga, as well as very favorable to the loyal cause -- and that is, that our opponents did not fight at all as they have been accustomed to fight. It is true that the manoeuvering on our side showed a most skillful hand, and the daring assault up different sides of a mountain, against large numbers of troops, defended by earthworks, and by at least fifty pieces of artillery, was one of the most brilliant exploits of modern history. Still, all this is not sufficient to explain this very complete victory. No army is "surprised in open daylight," as our telegrams have pictured; nor can mountains, with fifty pieces of artillery on the summits, be taken by assault, if the defenders are united and fully in earnest. We know by this time that the Southern soldiers are quite as brave as our own, and yet we find this most important battle -- perhaps to be called by history the life-and-death battle of the rebel Confederacy -- having been fought by our men under the most disadvantageous circumstances, gained without apparently a greater loss in killed and wounded than has followed many an unimportant reconnaissance in force. At Chicamauga, where we lost but few prisoners, our losses footed up to some 17,000; at Chattanooga we captured over 6,000 prisoners, more than forty pieces of artillery, and an immense quantity of small arms, breaking up (so far as we can learn) BRAGG's army completely, and yet lose supposing this telegraphic estimate to be a correct one, only 3,200 in killed and wounded. We do not hear, also, that the rebels suffered any heavy loss in killed and wounded. Apparently, a great army, just after a victory, was beaten and broken to pieces with but very little hard fighting on its part.
headline: {'main': 'The Lesson of Our Victory.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Lesson of Our Victory.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: If any simple-minded individual entertained the belief that JOHN MORGAN and his half-dozen lucky fellow-knaves escaped from the Ohio State Penitentiary unsided by outside confederates, we refer them to a statement of the Toronto Leader denying the fact, that the guerrilla was in that city on Tuesday. It is plain enough now that the dispatch making that announcement was sent over this country with the simple purpose of throwing from the scent the officers in search of the fugitive. In all probability the ruse was successful, but would it not be worth while to ascertain who in Toronto has the power to prostitute the telegraph to such base uses? Certainly if the fact of MORGAN's arrival in Canada was worth telegraphing, a denial of the statement, when its falsity was ascertained, was quite as interesting to the people of the United States, and, indeed, a little more so. Who is the guilty "Kanuck?" Or, to go still further back, did no cipher messages pass between Columbus and Toronto on the day of MORGAN's escape from "durance vile?" Here is a clue, which it may be profitable for Gov. TOD or the authorities at Washington to follow up.

abstract: -- Gen. SPINOLA is actively engaged in recruiting, and is meeting with good success. He has energy, intelligence and enthusiasm, and these of themselves form a most excellent guarantee for efficiency. An effort is also being made to raise a Metropolitan cavalry regiment, under command of Col. JULIUS B. HERMAN. A number of our prominent and influential citizens have given it their aid. As a general thing, volunteering is much more brisk at the close of this year than it was at the close of last.

abstract: -- As has been mentioned in the TIMES, on the night of the 27th ult., the safe in the store of MICHAEL RUPP & CO., No. 120 Water-street, was broken open and robbed of eighteen gold hunting-cased watches, eleven silver watches, scarf-pins, sleeve-buttons, gold studs, and various other articles of jewelry, valued in all at about $3,500. The firm not suspecting any of their employes, supposed that the robbery was committed by some thieves and burglars who infest that section of the City. A handsome reward was offered for the recovery of the property, and on Tuesday evening Mr. RUPP was waited upon by Wm. RYAN, a young man in his employ, who stated that he knew who stole the watches and jewelry from the safe, RYAN further stated that if Mr. RUPP would give him the reward he would ensure him the goods the following morning. At this time Officer OBER, of the First Precinct, was called in and arrested RYAN, who, on becoming alarmed, confessed that JOHN GERMAINE, a youth 17 years of age, also employed in the store, had robbed the safe of its contents and hid them away till a large reward should be offered for the jewelry. He furthermore confessed that GERMAINE had sent him to Mr. RUPP for the reward, promising, if successful, to give him half the money. GERMAINE's arrest speedily followed this revelation, and he also confessed to the theft, and told where the goods were secreted. Officer OBER, who managed the case, shrewely went as directed, and soon had the satisfaction of recovering all the stolen watches and jewelry with the exception of two or three valuable watches which could not be found, and for the absence of which the prisoners were unable to satisfactorily explain. Yesterday afternoon, the accused parties were arraigned before Justice DOWLING and committed to the Tombs without bail. Both the prisoners are opticians by trade. Goods had been previously missed from the store, but up to the time of this discovery no suspicion had rested on the defendants.

abstract: -- More than the usual number of arrests for illegal voting were made on Tuesday, but many of those apprehended made such explanations to the magistrates before whom they were arraigned as to secure their liberation. A young man named PETER FRANK was arrested by Officer WOGAN, of the Fourth Precinct, charged with having voted illegally at the Fourth Election District of the Fourth Ward. FRANK's vote was challenged, when he produced a voucher in the person of PATRICK MURPHY, an English seaman. The latter made oath before the Inspectors that FRANK was a resident of that Election District, that he lived at No. 10 James-slip, and that he was a legal voter. On inquiry it appeared that FRANK lived at No. 320 Cherry-street (Seventh Ward,) MURPHY was promptly arrested for perjury, and Justice DOWLING committed him to the Tombs for trial in default of $1,000 bail. FRANK being unable to proccure a bondsman in the sum of $500 was also locked up for trial.....JOHN GORMLEY, an Irish laborer, was arrested by Officer DOYLE, of the Seventeenth Ward, for Illegal voting. Justice OSBORN committed the accused for examination....Officer MYERS, of the Twenty-third Precinct, arrested JOHN O'HOLLAND, an Irish laborer, for a violation of the election laws. O'HOLLAND was held for a hearing before Justice DODGE....On the complaint of WM. MEEHAN, No. 87 Pike-street, GEORGE DUNCAN, a Scotch seaman, for attempting to vote illegally, Justice OSBORN held the accused for examination....Officer JENNESS, of the Twelfth Ward, arrested MICHAEL ROU[???], an Irish teamster, charged with attempting to vote illegally at one of the poll districts of that Ward. Held for a hearing before Justice DODGE....Mr. W.E. SMITH, of No. 104 Vesey-street, caused the arrest of one THOMAS GORMAN for attempting to vote illegally. Officer BROWN, of the Third Precinct, made the arrest, and Justice DOWLING committed GORMAN for examination....RICHARD HALLWOOD and JOHN WELLSTED were arrested in the Eighteenth Precinct, charged with voting illegally. Held for a hearing before Justice KELLY.

abstract: Joseph H. Wiggens vs. E.S. Allen. -- The defendant in this case is patentee and inventor of Brand & Allen's breech-loading rifle and smoothbore musket. In February, 1863, the plaintiff alleges that he was employed by defendant as book-keeper and general clerk, and in that capacity performed certain services for defendant, and paid out and incurred certain expenses for him, for which defendant has neglected to pay him, and for which he seeks to recover the sum of $217 25. The evidence of the defendant would show that he employed the plaintiff to accompany him to Washington, and to the Army of the Potomac, to conduct his correspondence and assist him in procuring testimonials from different officers and officials to the efficiency of Brand & Allen, and that after being in his service for about two months, plaintiff abandoned him and left him at a time when it was inconvenient to do without his services, and that defendant had paid plaintiff in full up to the time that he left his employment. The Judge reserved his decision.

abstract: The hope of a victory over LEE in Virginia may as well be given up, at least until next Spring, if the very unexpected news which comes to us from Washington must be credited. Last night's dispatches say that Gen. MEADE has led his army again to their old camping grounds on the line of the Orange and Alexandria Railroad, where the brave fellows will probably settle at once into Winter quarters. The friends of Gen. MEADE explain this last advance of the Army of the Potomac as having been made to prevent reinforcements from LEE reaching LONGSTREET -- an object which they claim to have successfully achieved.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- We have not had occasion of late to speak heartily of any of Mr. TOM TAYLOR's dramatic productions. It seemed, indeed, as if that better vein of domestic story which first made him popular, and finds its throbbings in all communities, has been permanently laid aside by him, and that henceforth his able pen would be used merely in transcribing superfluous pieces from the French. We are glad to know that this impression is erroneous. The drama called the "Ticket of Leave Man," produced at this house, on Monday evening, is in many respects one of Mr. TAYLOR's best works. If it does not create a profound sensation it must be because in many of its details it is still exceedingly local. But, notwithstanding this drawback, the situations are so powerful, the leading incidents so touching, the action so direct and the language so concise and appropriate, that a long career is certain. A better piece has not been put on the stage for many years. And, whilst thus commending it, let us add that Mr. JACKSON has displayed both liberality and taste in the m[???]se en scene. The scenery and dresses are good and appropriate, with the exception of the dress of the English policemen, who are sorely libeled and degraded by their American representatives.

abstract: SIGISMUND ZSULAVSKY, Second Lieutenant Fifth United States Volunteers, died recently at Port Hudson, in the 19th year of his age. Lieut. ZSULAVSKY was a son of the late Mme. ZSULAVSKY, and nephew of LOUIS KOSSUTH. He entered the service as a private in the Eighth New-Hampshire Volunteers, then attached to Gen. BUTLER's command. After having faithfully discharged his duty for nearly two years, he was promoted to a Second Lieutenancy in the Fifth United States Volunteers, formerly a part of Gen. WILLIAMS' brigade. He was a young man of high principles, marked talent and cultivation, of great refinement and dignity of character, and exceedingly beloved by all who knew him.
lead_paragraph: SIGISMUND ZSULAVSKY, Second Lieutenant Fifth United States Volunteers, died recently at Port Hudson, in the 19th year of his age. Lieut. ZSULAVSKY was a son of the late Mme. ZSULAVSKY, and nephew of LOUIS KOSSUTH. He entered the service as a private in the Eighth New-Hampshire Volunteers, then attached to Gen. BUTLER's command. After having faithfully discharged his duty for nearly two years, he was promoted to a Second Lieutenancy in the Fifth United States Volunteers, formerly a part of Gen. WILLIAMS' brigade. He was a young man of high principles, marked talent and cultivation, of great refinement and dignity of character, and exceedingly beloved by all who knew him.

abstract: Groans from the Rebels
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning a very interesting speech, delivered before the Georgia rebel Legislature, by ROBERT TOOMBS, who has been, from the beginning, one of the most prominent and influential leaders in the rebel Confederacy. It is a very significant indication of the drift of things in rebeldom. Although Mr. TOOMBS affects still to hold the language of confidence and hope, his speech is only a prolonged howl over the dismal prospects of the rebellion. It is an extorted prediction of its speedy and hopeless collapse.

abstract: The country will be astonished and confounded on reading the dispatch which announces that the Army of the Potomac has again fallen back fallen back without having tested its own power or that of its rebel adversary and was probably last night encamped in its old quarters at Brandy Station, on the line of the Orange and Alexandria Railroad.
lead_paragraph: The country will be astonished and confounded on reading the dispatch which announces that the Army of the Potomac has again fallen back -- fallen back without having tested its own power or that of its rebel adversary -- and was probably last night encamped in its old quarters at Brandy Station, on the line of the Orange and Alexandria Railroad. It was on Thursday last that the great host, with high hopes, steady step, and ten days' rations, crossed the Rapidan to measure swords with the enemy, and before one-half of the ten days have passed away, it has wheeled round, retraced its steps, and is now promenading or encamping in the wretched desert that fronts Washington, where it can fight to its heart's content the hornets of MOSBY -- having in the meantime fought no battle, achieved no victory, and subserved no respectable purpose. On Monday, Gen. MEADE captured two corps, or the whole, of LEE's army, by the Philadelphia telegraph, and on Tuesday LEE captured the whole of Gen. MEADE's army by a telegram from Philadelphia; and this, with the heavy cannonading that the public heard for several days over the wires, and the gallant skirmishing of Friday and Saturday, constitutes the sum total of visible results from the late campaign. This morning's dispatch avers that Gen, MEADE's friends (we are all "Gen. MEADE's friends") claim that the object of the advance was not to give battle to LEE, but to prevent his sending reinforcements to LONGSTREET in Tennessee; and that the movement has consequently been a success. But we fear that those who argue in this manner do not study the newspapers with sufficient assiduity; for Gen. BURNSIDE crossed swords with LONGSTREET as far back as the 14th, or two weeks before Gen. MEADE began his advance, and during the whole of that fortnight he was in imminent peril until the 26th ult., the day of MEADE's advance, at which date telegrams were received from Gen. BURNSIDE, announcing that he was fully able to resist, the enemy until such time as aid was received from Gen. GRANT; and as BURNSIDE was under GRANT's command, and GRANT was then just putting the finishing touches upon his great victory, we may be sure that that energetic officer would not delay relief for a moment. Reinforcements were also hastening to BURNSIDE's help, via Cumberland Gap. Beside these all-sufficient aids, we cannot believe that the Army of the Potomac entered upon such a large and comprehensive campaign merely on the supposition that thus it might prevent LEE from sending some regiments to aid LONGSTREET in extricating himself from a position from which he bids fair to extricate himself without each aid.
headline: {'main': 'The Army of the Potomac Its Mysterious Manoeuvres.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Army of the Potomac Its Mysterious Manoeuvres.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: On the Back Track
lead_paragraph: It will be remembered that Gov. SEYMOUR'S main pretext in justification of his opposition to the draft last Summer, at the period of the riots, was an alleged system of fraud in the enrollment, whereby undue levies were imposed upon certain Democratic Congressional Districts, among which the Second and Third were specially designated. The President, with characteristic complaisance, answered the Governor that, in consideration of his charges, only a fraction of the quota should be drawn from these districts, until a reenrollment should be had to verify whether the first was correct or not, and invited the Governor to appoint an agent to assist at that reeenrollment, so as to guard against any possibility of doubting its fairness. This reenrollment was accordingly ordered. But it seems that the Governor disrelishes being subjected to the practical test, and has notified the Washington authorities that he now withdraws all objection to the first enrollment, being convinced, on examination of the lists and the returns of the draft already made, which show very few non-residents, that that enrollment is "as near correct as it is possible to make one." The Governor thus owning himself satisfied, the orders for the reenrollment have been countermanded.

abstract: Between two and three o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out in the rear portion of the second floor of building Nos. 292 and 294 Seventh-avenue, on the premises of M.S. CURTIS, steel-wire temperer.
lead_paragraph: Between two and three o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out in the rear portion of the second floor of building Nos. 292 and 294 Seventh-avenue, on the premises of M.S. CURTIS, steel-wire temperer. The flames were first seen issuing from the skylight and bursting out at the roof. In a brief space of time the entire building was in flames, and, despite the most active exertions of the firemen, who were very promptly on hand, the entire block on Seventh-avenue, west side, between Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth streets, was destroyed, with the exception of the corner building on Twenty-eighth-street. In addition to this, three buildings on the block above, north side of Twenty-ninth-street, were wholly destroyed, three others partially, and also three large brick houses, Nos. 302, 304 and 306, on Seventh-avenue, above Twenty-ninth-street, were mostly burned.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met pursuant to law as City Canvassers at noon yesterday, to canvass the returns of the Charter election. Mr. CHIPP was chosen Chairman. The returns from several Districts were reported by the Clerk, Mr. VALENTINE, to be missing. The Sergeant-at-Arms was ordered to look after the delinquents. The returns from Alderman FARLEY's District -- the Sixteenth -- were read off by himself. The figures are about the same as heretofore reported. The vote for Mayor is as follows: Gunther, 1,793; Boole, 1,351; Blunt, 906; Gunther's majority over Boole, 442. For Alderman the vote is as follows: Farley, 1,910; McGinniss, 1,702; Gregory, 408; Farley's majority over McGinniss, 208. A portion of the Eighth Ward returns were read off by Alderman MCCOOL, and afterward the Board adjourned till 10 o'clock this morning.

abstract: The new Congress, which assembles next Monday, will begin with comparatively light duties. The task of elaborating all the great novel measures which the rebellion made necessary, devolved upon its predecessor; and ...
lead_paragraph: The new Congress, which assembles next Monday, will begin with comparatively light duties. The task of elaborating all the great novel measures which the rebellion made necessary, devolved upon its predecessor; and was accomplished, in the main, with great sagacity and success. Of course, experience has developed some imperfections, which it will be the early business of the present Congress to remedy. But this improving and amending is very different sort of work from constructing -- particularly where the one is done in the light of experience, the other without any such help. There is no real toil in it; it is pastime in comparison. Undoubtedly there are some new measures to be matured and passed upon at an early day. But these all must be of minor magnitude, and will not be very difficult. The principal means for putting down the rebellion are already in successful operation; and the main concern now is to work them fairly out, which, of course, is the business of the executive, and not of the legislative branch of the Government.
headline: {'main': 'The Approaching Session of Congress.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Approaching Session of Congress.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Much having been recently said and written about our iron-clad navy, it is worth while to give some comprehensive account of it. The facts relating to the vessels composing it are not by any means so difficult of access as some persons have imagined.
lead_paragraph: Much having been recently said and written about our iron-clad navy, it is worth while to give some comprehensive account of it. The facts relating to the vessels composing it are not by any mean so difficult of access as some persons have imagined. We have from time to time published the ships of each fleet as orders for their construction were issued, and occasionally a recapitulation of them all. Within the last six or eight months, however, a large addition has been made to our armored fleet, which will be found below. It maybe added that the following list contains the name of every armored vessel now constructed or in course of construction for the United States Navy. The two classes of ocean iron-clads, one of 7,000 tons burden, and the other of 3,500 tons burden, which the Government asks proposals for, have not advanced any further than the mere propositions to build them. The only vessel of either class contracted for is an immense craft, the keel of which has just been laid by Mr. CRAMP, of Philadelphia. It is said that she is to resemble the New Ironsides. Excepting the Dictator, Puritan, Dunderberg, Roanoke and the New Ironsides, we have no first-class armored frigates. Besides all the iron-clads building, there is a fleet of iron double-enders, the hulls of which are to be entirely of iron; but as they are not of such magnitude as our armored ships, it is not considered worth while to print their names in this connection. We append a list of vessels, commencing with the frigates:

abstract: By the arrival of the schooner Oliver S. Breeze, from Vera Cruz on the 26th October, we have been put in possession of some late and important facts in regard to Mexican affairs. When the Breeze left Vera Cruz a report was prevalent in the city among the French that the Mexicans had recaptured Puebla. There was no doubt of the truth of the report, although no particulars are given.
lead_paragraph: From the New-Orleans Era, Nov. 22.

abstract: KNOXVILLE, Monday, Nov. 30.  During Saturday night, Nov. 28, the enemy made a general attack in force on a large portion of our skirmishing line, and about midnight succeeded in driving in our pickets. This was intended as a defat, to confuse us, and conceal the real point of the contemplated assault. Cannonading and skirmishing continued all night.

abstract: The meeting called for last evening at Cooper Institute by citizens, without distinction of party, to respond to the call of the President for additional volunteers, and also to celebrate the glorious victories of GRANT, was a triumphant success.
lead_paragraph: The meeting called for last evening at Cooper Institute by citizens, without distinction of party, to respond to the call of the President for additional volunteers, and also to celebrate the glorious victories of GRANT, was a triumphant success. Long before the hour for organization the immense hall was filled to overflowing, there being not an inch of room that was packable being unpacked. A very large proportion of the assemblage was composed of ladies, and there was a heartiness and interest shown in the main purpose of the call which promises more good than has hitherto been effected by such meetings. The stage was very handsomely draped with the American flag, and the following mottoes were displayed upon it.

abstract: ANDREWS THE RIOTER. ANDREWS, the man who was arrested for exciting the mob to deeds of violence during the July riots, and who has since been confined in Fort Lafayette, is to have his case  submitted to the Grand Jury of the United States District Court, which will be in session next week.
lead_paragraph: ANDREWS THE RIOTER. -- ANDREWS, the man who was arrested for exciting the mob to deeds of violence during the July riots, and who has since been confined in Fort Lafayette, is to have his case submitted to the Grand Jury of the United States District Court, which will be in session next week. There are two charges against the prisoner, one for treason, and the other for inciting resistance to the draft. The evidence in the case will be submitted to the Grand Jury, and the indictment will be drawn in accordance with their finding. District Attorney HALL is prepared to try him for the violation of the State laws in exciting a riot, whenever the prisoner shall be placed in the custody of the City authorities, accompanied by sufficient evidence on which to base a prosecution, but he objects to taking the responsibility of the; prisoner's four months' imprisonment in Fort Lafayette, and prefers that the National authorities shall dispose of their case first.

abstract: Emperor, the, Proposal for European Congress
snippet: Emperor, the, Proposal for European Congress
lead_paragraph: There could not be a better proof of the long distance which still separates us from anything like a "parliament of man," than the objections which are made to the proposition of the French Emperor, to hold a Congress at Paris to settle the affairs of Europe. There is nothing new in the idea of a Congress, for one is held after every great war; but the Congress he wishes for is peculiar, from the fact that it is to be held before war, and instead of war. The Congress of Vienna, and that of Paris, met simply to carry out certain principles which had been laid down by military force; or in other words to take official notice on paper of certain facts which had been already shaped by the sword. It gave nothing to anybody, but confirmed everybody in the possession of what he had already won in the field.
headline: {'main': "Napoleon's Proposition for a European Congress of Sovereigns.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Napoleon's Proposition for a European Congress of Sovereigns.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Well, the enemy has assaulted Lookout Mountain to-day, sure enough, as was intimated in my letter of last night he probably would do. Having accomplished a part of the object of his demonstration yesterday, to wit: the transfer of a portion of our forces ...
lead_paragraph: Well, the enemy has assaulted Lookout Mountain to-day, sure enough, as was intimated in my letter of last night he probably would do. Having accomplished a part of the object of his demonstration yesterday, to wit: the transfer of a portion of our forces on the mountain to the extreme right, he attacked the mountain with a confidence which the sequel will show was not misplaced. The great rise in the Tennessee had carried away his pontoon bridges the night before, but his positions were so well taken, and had been so strongly fortified, that he did not hesitate to make the assault. He opened at 11 o'clock with his batteries in Lookout Valley, directing his fire against our lines along the western side and northern face of the mountain. Our own batteries on the mountain could take no part in the engagement, owing to a dense fog which enveloped Lookout Point and the crest above. At 12 1/2 o'clock the infantry became engaged, and the battle was then fully joined.

abstract: As Secessionists, we supposed we were out of the Union. We went out to protect Slavery. We failed. We now come back. For what purpose? To protect Slavery? The absurdity is too monstrous to tulerate for a moment. We went out to protect the negro. We come back to protect the white man.
lead_paragraph: As Secessionists, we supposed we were out of the Union. We went out to protect Slavery. We failed. We now come back. For what purpose? To protect Slavery? The absurdity is too monstrous to tulerate for a moment. We went out to protect the negro. We come back to protect the white man. We regard the negro question as definitely settled by the last source of appeal, and we say there let it rest.

abstract: the rebel General, whose spirited and able address in favor of the Union we published a few weeks since, has recently made a speech at Little Rock, Ark., before a Union club. He reiterates his assertion that the rebellion has proved an utter and a hopeless failure, and that the only course for the rebels to pursue is to acknowledge their defeat and get back into the Union on the best terms possible. He discusses also the question of Slavery -- insisting that it is absolutely dead in Arkansas, and that the people of that State should loss no time in disposing of its remains. "The people of Arkansas," he says, "are the proper ones to act in its final extinction." And he warns them that unless they do so promptly, they will be very likely to be held by the General Government in the position of a territory for an indefinite time. Gen. GANTT speaks very strongly of the Union sentiment that pervades the State, and declares the purpose of its people to return to the Union at the earliest moment possible.

abstract: The County Volunteer Committee will soon be seriously impeded in their good work, if the public do not come forward and subscribe to the loan upon which they depend for success. They have enlisted about 600 men, and have less than $200,000 at their command now, when they are sure of at least 100 men a day, if the prospect of getting the needed supply of funds can be made good. The Committee issued orders on Wednesday to the Provost-Marshals, prohibiting the further acceptance of men for the county bounty till new blanks should be made out; these were completed and issued yesterday, with the information that payments would not be made on any other blanks. This step was taken in order to register the blanks given out, by which to prevent their getting into improper hands, and to enable the Committee at any moment to know precisely how many are out.
lead_paragraph: The County Volunteer Committee will soon be seriously impeded in their good work, if the public do not come forward and subscribe to the loan upon which they depend for success. abstract: Details of operations at Knoxville, up to Monday, Nov. 30, are given this morning, from which it appears that LONGSTREET, at that date, was still making strong efforts for the capture of that place.
lead_paragraph: Details of operations at Knoxville, up to Monday, Nov. 30, are given this morning, from which it appears that LONGSTREET, at that date, was still making strong efforts for the capture of that place. On Sunday morning, Nov. 29, the rebels made a furious assault on Gen. FERRERO's position, Fort Saunders, but was gallantry repulsed with heavy loss -- 700 killed and wounded, and 234 taken prisoners. Their killed and wounded were left on the field, and afterward removed under a flag of truce, which Gen. BURNSIDE granted for that purpose. On Monday morning, Nov. 30, everything was quiet.

abstract: Collision of Ships
lead_paragraph: It has been said that the increased facilities in navigation have been followed by a great increase in the number of the collisions which occur between vessels, notwithstanding all the improvements which have been made in their mechanical working, and all the legislation which has aimed to prevent these accidents by regulating the courses which vessels should pursue, the lights they should carry, &c. The records of our Admiralty Courts for the last month tend to confirm this idea, for we find that during that month there have been tried in those Courts in our City no less than six cases arising out of collisions, and still the calendar is full of other cases awaiting their turn.

abstract: The rebel papers thus  far received seem to be at a loss to account for the overwhelming disaster which the Confederates have just sustained at Chickamauga, and in their consternation perhaps it is not strange that they should have overlooked an extraordinary document issued by BRAGG just before the conflict was joined.
lead_paragraph: The rebel papers thus far received seem to be at a loss to account for the overwhelming disaster which the Confederates have just sustained at Chickamauga, and in their consternation perhaps it is not strange that they should have overlooked an extraordinary document issued by BRAGG just before the conflict was joined. On Nov. 16 he informed his men, by special order, that the enemy did not intend to carry out the cartel for the exchange of prisoners. This cruel proceeding he declared to be "opposed to the laws of humanity and an enlightened civilization," while "it shows a craft and cunning worthy of the Yankees in imposing upon us the maintenance of thousands of his prisoners, that they may consume the substance which should go to the support of our gallant men and their families." Then he proceeded:

abstract: This new projectile, invented and perfected by Gen. ROBERTS, has been tested in a series of experiments by order of the Ordnance Department, under the direction of Maj. KINGSBUEY, of the Ordnance corps, on Rock Island.
lead_paragraph: This new projectile, invented and perfected by Gen. ROBERTS, has been tested in a series of experiments by order of the Ordnance Department, under the direction of Maj. KINGSBUEY, of the Ordnance corps, on Rock Island. Several of the experiments have been witnessed by us, and the last trial having been made yesterday, we are gratified to be enabled to announce the complete success of this most important invention that must materially change the prevailing system in our armies of using, almost exclusively, the Minie ball for rifle ordnance.

abstract: TIMOTHY McEVOY, the merchant, who, last Sunday morning, made so desperate an attempt to murder his wife, at No. 380 Grand-street, by shooting at her three times with a ravolver, was yesterday sent to the Bloomingdale Lunatic Asylum.
lead_paragraph: TIMOTHY MCEVOY, the merchant, who, last Sunday morning, made so desperate an attempt to murder his wife, at No. 380 Grand-street, by shooting at her three times with a ravolver, was yesterday sent to the Bloomingdale Lunatic Asylum. An investigation has been made by Justice DOWLING, and, from all the testimony, the magistrate came to the conclusion that he was insane. Two prominent physicians, after a full examination, have given certificates that he was of unsound mind. Since his arrest, it has transpired that upon two previous occasions he had attempted to take the life of his wife. At one of these times he drew a revolver upon his wife, while the two were in a bedroom, and was about to fire when her screams brought a third person into the room. The husband then quietly put up his pistol, at the same time remarking that he was about to shoot himself. The unfortunate man, it will be remembered, was a clothing merchant, doing business at No. 380 Grand-steet. The injuries of the wife are so serious that it is thought she will not recover. Justice DOWLING received information from her physician that it would not be prudent to take her deposition as to the assault made upon her by her husband. He has, therefore, been sent to the Asylum until a further investigation can be had.
headline: {'main': 'The Attempt at Wife-Murder in Grandstreet.; THE HUSBAND SENT TO THE LUNATIC ASYLUM.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Attempt at Wife-Murder in Grandstreet.; THE HUSBAND SENT TO THE LUNATIC ASYLUM.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The high character, echolaetic attainments, erudition and social qualifications of American Clergymen, are in strong contrast with the narrow prejudices and limited resources which hove marked the history of other nations, and of earlier periods of the world. Coming directly in contact with the theories of the most enlightened ...
lead_paragraph: The high character, echolaetic attainments, erudition and social qualifications of American Clergymen, are in strong contrast with the narrow prejudices and limited resources which hove marked the history of other nations, and of earlier periods of the world. Coming directly in contact with the theories of the most enlightened minds, as well as the customs of common life, they are better calculated to judge of popular opinion and current ideas, than any other class of men. Their influence is unbounded. Their opportunities for directing practical reforms and progressive developments impose many obligations. In acknowledgment of the many complimentary indorsements and favors which DR. DRAKE has received from Clergymen in behalf of his PLANTATION BITTERS, he has directed his Agents, Messrs. BARNES & CO., No. 202 Broadway, N.Y., to present a bottle gratis, to every Clergyman who may personally call during the remainder of this year, 1863.

abstract: Judge BEAUMAN yesterday found $1,000 damages against Capt. R.H. PEARSON in favor of CHAS. P. DUANE. The latter was exiled by the Vigilance Committee in 18[???]6, and Capt. PEARSON subsequently forced him to leave the steamer after he came on board at Acapulco, designing to return to this city. Had he succeeded in returning he would undoubtedly have been hung, as the Vigilance Committee was in session, and he was banished to return on pain of death. The case will be appealed on the ground of excessive damages.

abstract: Consumptives in the
lead_paragraph: We read with great astonishment, in article 6 of Circular 100, just issued from tho Provost-Marshal-General's office, that "incipient consumption does not exempt" a drafted man from service. It is not necessary to be a medical man to know that as soon as incipient consumption is detected in anybody, it needs the most extraordinary precautions and exertions on the part of the patient to prevent its passing into the next stage. We know that it requires an amount of care as regards air, exercise, diet and mode of life to prevent its becoming confirmed consumption, which, unhappily, only a very small number of those who are attacked by this terrible disease, are able to take. In short, owing to the fact that the mass of the community cannot either travel, or take horseback-exercise, or drink good wine, or give up their ordinary occupations and devote themselves entirely to the care of their health, the per centage of recoveries from the first stage of the disease is so small as to be not worth counting.

abstract: ROBBERIES A large number of robberies have of late been perpetrated in East Brooklyn, and considerable property stolen from houses temporarily unoccupied. It is known that these thefts are perpetrated by young men and boys, a number of whom...
lead_paragraph: ROBBERIES. -- A large number of robberies have of late been perpetrated in East Brooklyn, and considerable property stolen from houses temporarily unoccupied. It is known that these thefts are perpetrated by young men and boys, a number of whom have frequently been arrested by the Forty-fourth Precinct Police, but in consequence of the youth of some of them, and the alleged respectability of the parents of others, the Justices discharged them with reprimands. They are no sooner let loose than more robberies are committed. They are again arrested, and the same farce is repeated by the Justices. At one time no less than seventeen of these fellows were arrested by Officers SQUIRES and CARR, after a search of three weeks. It was proven that they had robbed at least a dozen houses, but, after a few weeks' detention in jail, they were discharged. They are now again at work as lively as ever.

abstract: COUNTY VOLUNTEER COMMITTEE. A glaring attempt to defrud a recruit out of $270 was laid before Mr. BLUNT, the Chairman of this Committee, yesterday. Complaint was made by the wife of an enlisted man that the broker who had induced her husband to enlist had given him only $30, after positively promising to give him the full County bounty of $300.
lead_paragraph: COUNTY VOLUNTEER COMMITTEE. -- A glaring attempt to defrud a recruit out of $270 was laid before Mr. BLUNT, the Chairman of this Committee, yesterday. Complaint was made by the wife of an enlisted man that the broker who had induced her husband to enlist had given him only $30, after positively promising to give him the full County bounty of $300. The broker, named MALLOY, appeared and attempted to justify his conduct, but under the searching inquiries put by Mr. BLUNT, he prevaricated and finally stultified himself. Mr. BLUNT quickly gave him the alternative of paying the balance of $270, due to the wife of the cheated recruit, or of not being allowed to transact business any further with the Committee. The latter condition involved the possibility of a suit against the broker by the wife of his victim. The broker speedily made up his mind to refund the money he had wrongfully withheld, and with considerable perturbation paid it over to the complainant. Mr. BLUNT is fully determined that no recruit shall be wronged of a cent, if he can help it.

abstract: The Brooklyn Common Council certainly deserve the thanks of the community for having made the first move toward reforming the car and omnibus abuses. But we are sorry to see that there is some hesitation amongst the Aldermen as to the greatest abuse of all, and that is the crowding of the cars. As compared with this every other sinks into insignificance. It is an offence of the rankest kind against public decency and the public health -- we will say nothing of the public comfort -- and there is not a particle of excuse for it. The only thing that can justify the grant of a monopoly of the principal public streets to these railroad companies, is their undertaking to carry all who seek it, in a proper manner, on a seat, and with a sufficiency of good air, and room for their legs, and comfortable ingress and egress. The monopoly has been granted without exacting a single condition on these points. Nobody else is allowed to meet the public requirements by competition, and those who are in possession of the tracks, are allowed to do as they please.

abstract: Gen. LEE does not seem inclined to permit the Army of the Potomac to settle quietly down for the Winter in the location where Gen. MEADE has led it. On Thursday night, telegraphs our correspondent, an attempt was made by the enemy, in force of cavalry infantry and artillery, to cross the Rapidan at Raccoon Ford. The movement was detected, and the cavalry division under Gen. CUSTER turned them back in confusion.
lead_paragraph: Gen. LEE does not seem inclined to permit the Army of the Potomac to settle quietly down for the Winter in the location where Gen. MEADE has led it. On Thursday night, telegraphs our correspondent, an attempt was made by the enemy, in force of cavalry infantry and artillery, to cross the Rapidan at Raccoon Ford. The movement was detected, and the cavalry division under Gen. CUSTER turned them back in confusion. This incident gave rise to a rumor that the whole rebel army was advancing to offer battle, and Gen. MEADE made preparation for the emergency.

lead_paragraph: -- In our present issue will be found, copied from a Georgia newspaper, a curious dialogue which took place between the gallant Gen. LYTLE, of Ohio, who fell at the battle of Chickamauga, and the rebel narrator. It seems that the General had a "strange, unwavering, fanatical faith" that the Union forces would crush the rebellion, that our army would now strike at the heart of the Confederacy, which is Georgia, and that we would make short work of it. The rebel advised him to restrain boasting until he got "beyond the shadow of yonder mountain," (Lookout Mountain,) but afterward granted, for argument's sake, that our army would subjugate the South and restore the Union, and then asked what sort of Union it would be? adding, however:

abstract: IN RICHMOND. -- Letters should be written on a half sheet of note or letter paper, and only on one side. They should relate solely to matters purely domestic. Inclose the letter in an unsealed envelope, and put in five cents for postage. Address it to the person for whom it is intended, giving his company, regiment, and the prison in which he is confined at Richmond, Va. On the left hand corner mark, "Via Flag of Truce, care of Brig.-Gen. S.A. MEREDITH, United States Commissioner of Exchange, Fortress Monroe, Va." Then inclose it in a sealed envelope, addressed to "Brig.-Gen. S.A. MEREDITH, Fortress Monroe."

abstract: FATAL ACCIDENT TWO MEN FATALLY INJURED. Yesterday afternoon, about 4 o'clock, the cellar of CHARNELLIN  Co., corner of Washington and Adams streets, caved in, burying two men beneath it. It was intended for the cellar of a brewery, and was 27 feet in depth.
lead_paragraph: FATAL ACCIDENT -- TWO MEN FATALLY INJURED. -- Yesterday afternoon, about 4 o'clock, the cellar of CHARNELLIN & CO., corner of Washington and Adams streets, caved in, burying two men beneath it. It was intended for the cellar of a brewery, and was 27 feet in depth. Strange to say, no side support had been afforded. The contracting mason, Mr. WM. ROUTH, residing at the corner of Graham-avenue and Meserole-street, was buried, and when taken out from the ruins life was found to be extinct. He leaves a wife and children. Mr. ROUTH had been at work only half an hour at the time of the accident. GEO. WINSELL, a laborer, was so seriously injured about the head and breast that it was thought last night he would die. He is 45 years of age, and resides at No. 162 Montrose-avenue. Coroner BARRETT will hold an inquest on the body of ROUTH this morning.

abstract: -- Miss WARNER's new work gives little clue, by its title, The Old Helmet, to its nature or character, though something of a less peaceful and domestic description than Queechy, or The Wide, Wide World, seems implied. From the present difficulty in manufacturing books, through the over-demand on the energies of paper-makers, printers and binders, it is almost impossible to fix, with precision, the time of publication of a work for which the orders are large and constantly coming in, as in this case; but Messrs. CARTERS hope to issue The Old Helmet, in the beginning of December. Messrs. NISBIT & CO. are the London publishers of the work, and a Liepsic edition will also appear simultaneously.

abstract: Seasons of intense activity, with alternations of comparative repose, form the ebb and flow of all great wars. We have just passed through one of the grand climacteric periods, resulting in a series of great operations in the West, and at least of portentous movements in the East; and the fact that the season naturally fitted for field-work is passed, and Winter and the...
lead_paragraph: Seasons of intense activity, with alternations of comparative repose, form the ebb and flow of all great wars. We have just passed through one of the grand climacteric periods, resulting in a series of great operations in the West, and at least of portentous movements in the East; and the fact that the season naturally fitted for field-work is passed, and Winter and the "skyey influences" adverse to military operations are upon us, gives plausibilty to the opinion that we may now have a period of comparative quiescence, and that our armies will go into Winter quarters. This of itself, to be sure, would not absolutely determine the cessation of active work; and if we should judge by the history of last year, when the month of December witnessed two of the greatest battles of the war -- that of Fredericksburgh, in Virginia, and Murfreesboro, in Tennessee -- there would be little to indicate such an intermission of operations. But the circumstances of December, 1863, and of December, 1862, are widely different. In the West a great aggressive army, threatening the invasion of Kentucky, fronted ROSECRANS, and it was in the last degree desirable to foil that intention by dealing the rebels a telling blow. In Virginia the spirit of "On to Richmond" still controlled our military policy. No such necessity and no such prompting now weigh upon us. Our great army of the West holds a position which makes all attempts at the offensive on the part of the rebels madness. Gen. GRANT is master of the situation, and the mastery, too, is of a kind that makes military operations in Virginia of quite subordinate moment. Both our armies have secured coignes of vantage where they can securely rest for the Winter; and there is no commanding military necessity to instigate a Winter campain.

abstract: The London Times, in its City article, says mercantile advices show that the difficulties of the French intervention had been greatly increased, owing to the fatal error committed by the Emperor NAPOLEON in giving license to the ecclesiastical and reactionary party the moment his army had succeeded in occupying the capital, while the name of France also suffered an incalculable loss of prestige from the honors conferred upon such persons as MIRAMON and MARQUEZ. At one time the consequences of this course seemed to be most threatening, as respects the impulse to resistance. The arrival of Gen. BAZAINE seems to have been regarded as opening up a better prospect.

abstract: Recruiting in this City, under the new call for volunteers is getting to be quite brisk, the number enlisting being daily on the increase. The war meeting held at the Cooper Institute will doubtless give an impetus to the business, the effects of which will be seen during the coming week. The City bounty of $300 was stopped on Wednesday, the funds having run out, but Mr. BLUNT replenished the coffers so as to be able to resume payment on Thursday. The Assistant Provost-Marshal Gen. HAYES yesterday read a dispatch from the War Department, saying that enlistments for the regular army in this City would be credited to the quota of New-York, and that the usual premium of $15 and $25 would be paid to those furnishing recruits for the regular army as well as for the volunteer regiments. There is a difficulty, however, about recruits for the regular army getting the City bounty of $300. Mr. BLUNT declines paying the bounty except upon the certificate of one of the Provost-Marshals that the man was duly enlisted, while Gen. HAYES has issued an order to the Provost-Marshals not to enlist soldiers for the regular army. This order was necessary to prevent confusion in the discharge of the duties properly belonging to the Provost-Marshals, but some arrangement will be made by which soldiers enlisting for the regular service can receive the City bounty. The Government has consented to the enlistment of soldiers for the new regiments now in process of formation in this City, although the call for volunteers was to fill up old regiments in the field. There are three new artillery and four new cavalry regiments now recruiting in the City, but no more new regiments will be authorized.
