abstract: Butler, Gen., in New-Orleans; In New-Orleans; Review of a Book on; Ansted, D. T.; Great Stone Book of Travel
snippet: Butler, Gen., in New-Orleans; In New-Orleans; Review of a Book on; Ansted, D. T.; Great Stone Book of Travel
lead_paragraph: The remarkable series of occurrences detailed in this portly and beautifully executed volume, is yet too little removed from us by time, and still too closely connected with the hot and angry passions of political partisanship, to be susceptible of purely literary, or indeed of scientific historical treatment. All we can do is to bear witness to the zeal, industry and intelligence displayed by Mr. PARTON in the fulfillment of his task. Based on the most authentic documentary sources, and fortified at every step by copies of the original papers supplied to him by the great actors in the scene, the author has enjoyed for his book the advantage of unreserved personal intercourse with Gen. BUTLER and his military staff. All practicable sources of information were thrown open to him, with the sole stipulation that a faithful, honest, and not an apologetic use should be made of them, and it will therefore surprise no one acquainted with Mr. PARTON's previous writings, to be told that he has produced a work perfectly exhaustive of the subject in hand. He commences with the youth of his hero, Gen. BUTLER, whose professional career is briefly and pleasantly sketched, until the day when the sword and the camp superseded the pen and the court-house. The military narrative then begins, and details with minuteness the events of Gen. BUTLER's career, from his leaving Boston at the head of the Massachusetts regiments, until the successful attack on the Mississippi forts placed New-Orleans at his command, and afforded an opportunity for the display of administrative talent more momentous than the world has often seen. How the exigency was fully met, and how quickly it was proved that "the right man was in the right place," the world knows, every page of the book tells, with a particularity that rarely trespasses on good taste, through a constant stream of laudation. The author has been anxious to preserve as much as possible, the writings of Gen. BUTLER, who is placed by him in a classification that will not meet with universal consent as chief among "the three great writers of the war, Gen. BUTLER, President LINCOLN, and Mr. WILKES, of the Spirit of the Times!" They are fine specimens of nervous English, hitting at once the point aimed at, and entirely free from the prolixity often attributed to legal papers and writers. As materials for the future Macaulay or Bancroft who shall, about A.D. 1950, produce the classic "History of the Great Rebellion," Mr. PARTON's book will be invaluable, his natural bias as a hero-worshiper being allowed for, and far more than counterbalanced by his exertions and labors for the discovery of historical truth. The book is illustrated by a fine steel portrait of Gen. BUTLER, and military maps and plans. Its general effect is creditable to both author and publisher.

abstract: The war, as prosecuted against the rebels, is usually talked of as simply preservative of our Government and free institutions. Of course, that is its direct object, without which it would never have been waged. But there never was a great war yet, the effect of which was limited by its design.  A great war is the greatest shock human society ever sustains; and it is sure to unlock agencies and causes, both material and...
lead_paragraph: The war, as prosecuted against the rebels, is usually talked of as simply preservative of our Government and free institutions. Of course, that is its direct object, without which it would never have been waged. But there never was a great war yet, the effect of which was limited by its design. A great war is the greatest shock human society ever sustains; and it is sure to unlock agencies and causes, both material and moral, of tremendous force, which before were entirely unthought of, or, at all events, uncared for. Perhaps there may occasionally have been, in history, a barren and sterile war -- a war which literally left a people in statu quo ante bellum; but if they have ever existed at all, they have been very rare. At all events, it is certain that throughout all modern history, war has ushered in every great step of national progress. Modern England was made what it is by the civil war which carried CHARLES I. to the scaffold; modern Germany by the thirty years' war of the seventeenth century; modern France by the civil and foreign wars of the French Revolution; and modern Italy by the internal wars which have taken place within the last fifteen years. It is impossible to name a nation in Europe, great or small, that has experienced a real regeneration but by the baptism of blood. And in Asia too, so far as there have been any important national changes, the sword has invariably opened the way for them. It was the bloody force of England that broke up the dreadful religious and civil despotisms that had held India down for centuries and ages. It was the same violence that has opened the gates of China to every redeeming influence. And it is that also which alone promises to make Japan fairly accessible to civilization and Christianity. It is not the war itself that regenerates -- for that may spring from the most unjustifiable motives and be conducted in the most unwarrantable manner -- but the regeneration comes from the agencies which the war necessarily takes with it, or draws in its train.

abstract: The contest for the Speakership has ceased to be exciting. COLPAX has it all his own way. He goes into caucus with about eighty-five votes pledged. The chief contest now is for the Clerkship, between GREEN ADAMS, of kentucky: McPHERSON, of Pennsyrlvania; FESSENDEN, of Maine; and BUFFINTON, of Massachusetts.

abstract: All are agreed that taxation must be employed as ameans to uphold the credit of the currency and reduce prices. But taxation alone will not suffice. abstract: It was at Pensacola, Fla., that Gen. BRAXTON BRAGG began fighting for the rebellion, and if he keep on retreating, he is likely soon to be back somewhere in that vicinity. In the Fall of last year, he and his army were in Northern Kentucky, and fought a battle at Perryville. His present position, if he has a position, is about midway between Perryville and Pensacola. BRAGG's perpetual order to his army is "Backward march." Nothing but the Atlantic Ocean or the Gulf of Mexico will give him pause.

abstract: To the Editor of the New-York Times:  A well-planned and fortunate cavalry expedition from this place on Tuesday of this week resulted in the capture of a company of guerrillas belonging to WHITEY'S battalion. The expedition consisted of three companies or cavalry: Company L, of the First North Carolina, commanded by Capt. GRAHAM; Company G, of the Twelfth New-York, Capt. abstract: At SNEDICOR's gallery, Broadway, will be found a picture by GEORGE INNES, which claims attention as much from the pretentious manner in which its merits are set forth in an accompanying pamphlet, as from its intrinsic excellence. It is a landscape painted on a canvass some twelve feet long. It Is called the "Sign of Promise." This title, we suppose, refers especially to a shabbily painted rainbow, which spans a dark mass of retiring rain-clouds. The pamphlet, which seems intended to forestall the observer's impression; says: "That the public taste in art has been led to desire what is called the real in landscape -- that is to say, the local and particular, and not the universal and ideal." Mr. INNES, on the contrary, holds the opinion that only the elements of the truly picturesque exist externally in any local scene, and that the highest beauty and truest value of the landscape painting are in the sentiment and feeling which flow from the mind and heart of the artist." He "offers the picture as the visible expression of a strongly felt emotion of Hope and Promise. If the picture presents not more than one sees on the canvass, it is a failure, at least to him. It is intended also to embody certain combinations of scenery on the Delaware River, Outwardly, it is a beautiful composition of mingled stream, meadow, field, hillside and forest, with its rich associations of harvest and human labor; overcast by storm through which gleams the rainbow of hope; inwardly, an eloquent symbol of struggling soul."

abstract: The steamship Columbia, bringing two days' later advices from Europe, arrived at St. Johns, N.F., at 6 o'clock last evening. There is nothing of importance in the news. The European Congress still hangs fire, and it seems to be definitely settled that England will take no part in it. The London Morning Post asserts that the rumor of Earl RUSSELL's resignation is totally unfounded in fact. At Madrid a story was current that two American vessels had been sunk by Spanish men-of-war off the Island of Saint Domingo, for attempting to supply the insurgents with arms. The Poles continue the prosecution of their war for independence with unflagging ardor.

abstract: Among the conscripts from the New-England States sent to the Army of the Potomac were discovered many deserters from the rebel army and rebel prisoners, who had been released on condition of taking the oath of allegiance and pledging themselves to remain North during the war.
lead_paragraph: Among the conscripts from the New-England States sent to the Army of the Potomac were discovered many deserters from the rebel army and rebel prisoners, who had been released on condition of taking the oath of allegiance and pledging themselves to remain North during the war. It is supposed that some of these men were induced to enter the Union army from the want of other employment and the tempting bounties offered to recruits. Others, however, are believed to have entered our army for the purpose of deserting to the rebels upon the first opportunity. To prevent any evil consequences resulting from the presence in our army of either class of these men, all those ascertained to have been previously in the rebel army are ordered to be detached from their regiments, and will be sent to the Northwest to fight the Indians.

abstract: Refused a Court Martial
lead_paragraph: -- John Jones, Esq., father of the Hon. John Glancy Jones, died at Morgantown, Pennsylvania, on Sunday last, at the advanced age of 86 years. He was a native Caernarvon township, Berks County, and served as a private in the war of 1812. He received a classical education, and studied law, but never practised. He was a son of Col. Jonathan Jones, a soldier of the Revolutionary War, who fought at Ticonderoga in the Eleventh Pennsylvania Line of the Continental Army.

abstract: The Emperer of the French, determined not to allow the Powers much time for considering the nature of his naw project, addressed autograph letters to fifteen of the Sovereigns of Europe, immediately after the delivery of his speech, inviting them to accede to his proposition, and to send representatives ...
lead_paragraph: The Emperer of the French, determined not to allow the Powers much time for considering the nature of his naw project, addressed autograph letters to fifteen of the Sovereigns of Europe, immediately after the delivery of his speech, inviting them to accede to his proposition, and to send representatives to Paris to take part in the contemplated Congress. To these notes, England, Austria and Russia have already replied. England and Austria, by asking for information as to the "precise points" which are to be made the subjects of discussion, and Russia, by intimating, through her Ambassadors, that she will have no objection to participate in the drama as soon as Poland is pacified. That is to say, England and Austria will not refuse their assent, provided no questions that can possibly affect their interests are brought forward, while the Czar will be happy to gratify his august brother the moment he has settled the Polish question to his own satisfaction.

abstract: But, then it will be said, what of Gen. GRANT'S army? Has he not dealt a crushing blow to the South? By no means. BARGG'S army, it is true, has suffered a reverse one of those reverses to which every army is exposed. Comparatively weak, as are the armies of the South, they cannot always hope to be on the winning side.
lead_paragraph: But, then it will be said, what of Gen. GRANT'S army? Has he not dealt a crushing blow to the South? By no means. BARGG'S army, it is true, has suffered a reverse one of those reverses to which every army is exposed. Comparatively weak, as are the armies of the South, they cannot always hope to be on the winning side. BRAGG was strongly entrenched on Lookout Mountain, and, probably, expected to have held his position there until, at least, LONGSTREET had driven BURNSIDE from Knoxville. His position was unexpectedly taken by assault, and he was compelled to retreat some miles with the loss of a few thousand prisoners and thirty pieces of artillery. The artillery had probably been captured from the Federal army, which does nearly as much toward supplying the armies of the South as the Southern Government. It was unfortunate for the South that BRARG had not been able to hold Lookout Mountains; for, iddependent of the advantages this position gave the Southern army, it would have enabled LONGSTREET to have driven BURNSIDE out of Knoxville. As it was, the greater part of the town was burned; but, judging by present accounts, the Southern General was compelled, by the retreat or BRAGG, to leave his work there unfinished. Gen. GRANT, it is now announced, will remain inactive during the Winter months. It is, therefore, too soon to claim that, even in Georgia, where the only single success of the Fall campaign has been gained, very much has been done toward "breaking the backbone of the rebellion."

abstract: The London Star has been favored with a view of "the Alexandra vase," the wedding gift about to be presented to her Reval Highness the Princess of Wales by the Danes resident in Great Britain.
lead_paragraph: The London Star has been favored with a view of "the Alexandra vase," the wedding gift about to be presented to her Reval Highness the Princess of Wales by the Danes resident in Great Britain. The vase, which, with its base, is three feetsix inches in height, is designed and wrought in oxydized silver, by Mr. JES BARKENTIN, of No. 23 Berners-street. The design itself is Danish in all respects. Subjects from Scandinavian history and mythology cover almost the entire surface of the vase, in the form of medallions on the sides, or in low, subdued relief on the intervening spaces; while the very chasing and minute ornamentation is in strict harmony with the wild, legendary character of the chief figures. Among the principal personages sculptured are the Fates, Deities and Heroes of the Walhalla, not forgetting those famous artificers the dwarfs. Among the historical subjects appear. "Queen Thyra Dannebod superintending the building of the Dannervirke," and "Queen Dagmar interceding with her husband, Waldemar the Victorious, on behalf of the imprisoned peasants." The cover supports a statuette of Canute. On the stem of the vase are medallions of their Royal Highnesses the Prince and Princess of Wales; on the base are representations of "The Vikinger Fleet," a landscape in which are beheld a group of barrows and Druidical circles. Such are only a few of the subjects ingeniously designed and carefully elaborated by the Anglo-Danish artist. An explanatory inscription round the vase in Danish runs thus: "Brudegave til Danmarks Datter fra Danske mand og kvinder I Storbritanien," which means, when rendered into English, "Bridal gift to Denmark's daughter from Danish men and women in Great Britain."

abstract: Morgan, John; Particulars of his Escape
snippet: Morgan, John; Particulars of his Escape
lead_paragraph: There were seven prisoners, including JOHN MORGAN, who escaped. The following are their names: Gen. John H. Morgan, Capts. J.C. Bennett, L.D. Hockersmith, T.H. Hines, G.S. Magee, Ralph Sheldon, and S.B. Taylor. All these prisoners, with the exception of MORGAN, had their cells on the first range, or ground floor of the east wing of the prison, on the south side. MORGAN's cell was on the second range, on the same side of the wing. An air-chamber, built and arched with brick, runs the whole length of the wing, directly under the cells. This air-chamber, or ventilator, as it is sometimes called, is seven feet in width and four and a half feet high, and at the end, and fastened into the foundation of the main wall, strong bars of iron were placed. We are informed that this chamber was built for the purpose of keeping the cells dry. The air passed in at the end where the iron bars were fastened, and communicated from this chamber out at the top of the building by means of flues built in the middle or partition wall. The floors of the cells were made, first by the brick arching over the air-chamber, about nine inches thick, then a heavy layer of mortar made from sand and lime, and then the last coating, or that which served as a floor, was a cement about two and a half inches thick. Perhaps the whole thickness is two feet.

abstract: As the war rolls on, one's pity for the man who is to write its history increases. Whoever he may be, he has before him the heaviest task that ever fell to the lot of an historian. There has never been a war so conscious as this one since wars first began.
lead_paragraph: As the war rolls on, one's pity for the man who is to write its history increases. Whoever he may be, he has before him the heaviest task that ever fell to the lot of an historian. There has never been a war so conscious as this one since wars first began. Hardly anybody engaged in it, from the Commander-in-Chief to the private, pulls a trigger, or draws a sabre, without taking all possible pains to have it properly recorded. Every man in the army fights and marches, as on a stage, in a full blaze of light, with the whole nation, and, for that matter, the whole world, filling the parquet and the boxes, and watching his minutest gestures, taking note of his dinner, his camp-fire, his horsemanship, his skirmishing and assaulting. In other wars the most distinction that any soldier hoped for was "mention in general orders," a step in promotion, or perhaps a cross, or star. Other fame than this was not to be had, or was only to be looked for in the pages of a quarto, long after the hero had been reduced to common dust. Of the great wars of MARLBORO, or NAPOLEON, or WELLINGTON, we know absolutely nothing beyond the general movements of the great corps, and the exploits of the leaders. All below the Generals of division marched and fought and died in the cold shade of obscurity. The great crowd of Colonels, and Captains, and privates who went into every action "burning with high hope," and eager for distinction, have passed away from the scene after thousands of daring deeds, and there is hardly a line to-day that preserves the memory of their exploits. Half a dozen private memories, half a dozen collections of "reminiscences," a few allusions in military novels, give us all we know of the, soldiers of the past days, except what can be found in the cold and stately narratives of the great historians. Over the romance of war, or, in other words, over the moving incidents and hair-breadth escapes which checquer the lives of the individuals who compose an army, history has hitherto drawn a thick vail.
headline: {'main': 'The War and Its History.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The War and Its History.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: For the first time in a great battle Confederate troops have been put to flight by the enemy. There is no doubt we were greatly outnumbered, but this disadvantage was largely compensated by our superiority of ground. We held Lookout Mountain and Mission Ridge, positions very strong naturally, and ...
lead_paragraph: For the first time in a great battle Confederate troops have been put to flight by the enemy. There is no doubt we were greatly outnumbered, but this disadvantage was largely compensated by our superiority of ground. We held Lookout Mountain and Mission Ridge, positions very strong naturally, and rendered, we presume, still stronger by art. Gen. BRAGG must have considered them well nigh impregnable, else he would not have chosen the occasion when the enemy all along superior to him in numbers, had been heavily reinforced, to send off a large detachment of its own army on a distant expedition. There will hardly be any division of opinion as to the cause of the unwonted and most painful spectacle of a whole wing of a Confederate army giving way under the onsets of their Yankee assailants, and breaking into a disorderly flight.

abstract: A man who during the past month or two has attracted the notice of the Police, having been suspected of obtaining recruits for the United States Army, was arrested about 5 o'clock on Thursday evening on the Champlain and St. Lawrence whart, ...
lead_paragraph: A man who during the past month or two has attracted the notice of the Police, having been suspected of obtaining recruits for the United States Army, was arrested about 5 o'clock on Thursday evening on the Champlain and St. Lawrence whart, by Detective COALLIER, who had laid a trap for his detection, and by the agency of an intended recruit secured him almost in the act of sending said recruit to Portland. The man's name is GEORGE WASHINGTON WAITT, and he was stopping at the Eagle Hotel. A man named HAMEL received a proposal from him to enlist in the United States Army, with promises of liberal bounty. HAMEL consulted the Police authorities and was told to entertain the proposition and to keep the detective informed of his movements. The preliminaries having been arranged, HAMEL was to receive $150 on reaching the States, $300 on passing medical examination, and in the meantime to proceed to Portland to an address to be given by WAITT. According to the arrangement, HAMEL was to meet WAITT at the Champlain Wharf, out Detective Coallier being also in the secret, proceeded to the wharf, and finding WAITT there, took him into custody before HAMEL came, and HAMEL arriving soon after, WAITT was taken to the Police Station House, where he was searched. There was found upon him $11 in United States Treasury notes, a counterfeit $5 bill on the Saybrooke Bank, which he said he received at some railway station and the original of the subjoined letter. This letter was mailed in Portland on the 24th and was received at Montreal Post-office on the 25th inst. The letter is quite explicit, although written in very bad English:

abstract: If the nervous imaginations of English journalists furnish the correct rule of interpretation of NAPOLEON'S speeches if, like dreams, this declarations are to be interpreted in a contrary sense, and his silence to be construed as indicative of dark and deep designs ...
lead_paragraph: If the nervous imaginations of English journalists furnish the correct rule of interpretation of NAPOLEON'S speeches if, like dreams, this declarations are to be interpreted in a contrary sense, and his silence to be construed as indicative of dark and deep designs -- then, in his recent address at the opening of the Legislative Chambers we may behold the augury of bloody wars in Europe, and draw hopeful deductions as to the probability of his interposition in our own affairs. The studious reserve with which he abstains from any allusions to that subject might be supposed, in the popular theory which regards the French Emperor as the Sphynx of the century, to cover a well-laid plan, with which the world is to be astonished, as by a coup d'etat. * * * * It is perfectly proper, without indulging in any nonsense about French sympathy for us, or dreaming, of an absurd coalition of Southern against Northern power, to anticipate that the march of events may eventually force him, in the prosecution of a deliberate and determined plan, to assist the establishment of a Republic absolutely essential to his success. The mode and the extent to which he may desire or find it necessary to do this, depend, of course, greatly upon circumstances, which are mutable and uncertain. Time may greatly modify his views, and they may fall greatly short of our wishes. His silence at present affords as grant of his intention to abstain altogether from activity on this side of the Atlantic. It arises from his indecision as to future course in the present immature state of affairs, or from a desire to await the proper occasion before committing himself. Whatever may be his plans in the matter, they are no longer regarded by the South as even an element of calculation. In her own exertions her confidence is reposed, and any extraneous influence which may come to her assistance will be regarded as a lucky windfall, hastening the consumamation she is determined to achieve at all hazards and at any cost. * * *

abstract: Bounties and Pay-rolls; Comparisons
lead_paragraph: It is the argument of non-reformers that now, with the great bounties that are being given to men enlisting, the time and manner of paying them off is of little consequence, as the bounty enables them to provide ahead for their families and themselves. The argument only shows how little the real position of the soldier has been studied. First, it must be taken into consideration that a reform of the pay-roll is intended not only to benefit those men who are now going into the service, but more especially those who have already done good work for the country, and who are suffering under the present imperfect method. The recruit certainly gets his three or four hundred dollars on the start, a sum which we will venture to assert a large portion of those who are now enlisting never owned at one time before. The result of this achievement of such a pile is extravagance in nine cases out of ten, and in an equal number of cases, at least in the City, two weeks does not elapse before the newly-made soldier is penniless. The rule is the same whether he has a family or not, only that in the latter case it is supposable that a large share of it has gone toward adding to their comfort. This weighty matter off his mind, and out of his pocket, he stands ready for his pay, the prompt reception of which at short periods, will tend greatly toward making him a better soldier, discouraging extravagance, and leading him to realize what his income really is. Upon this point we cannot make any distinguishment between the soldier and the laborer, mechanic or clerk, who is dependent for his living on his weekly or monthly wages, and who would be seriously embarrassed were the payment delayed a week beyond the expected time, or made at uncertain periods.

abstract: The enlistments of soldiers in this City during the past week numbered nearly 800 about the same as the week previous. The payment of the City bounty of $300 was stopped one day for want of funds, and there is reason to fear that further delay may be occasioned from the same cause, unless our capitalists bestir themselves in the matter.
lead_paragraph: The enlistments of soldiers in this City during the past week numbered nearly 800 about the same as the week previous. The payment of the City bounty of $300 was stopped one day for want of funds, and there is reason to fear that further delay may be occasioned from the same cause, unless our capitalists bestir themselves in the matter. The subscriptions to the new Bounty loan of $2,000,000 had only reached $117,200 at the time of closing the books yesterday afternoon. The advertisement for this loan was published on the 16th of November, twenty days ago. Had it not been for the surplus remaining of the former loan, the Committee would have had to stop paying the bounties long ago. The subscriptions to the loan yesterday were $30,000. The Comptroller, in view of this state of affairs, has issued the following circular to our capitalists and business men. The number of men can be had if those to whom the circular is addressed should promptly respond. It is hoped that ere noon on Monday the required amount will have been subscribed.

abstract: -- The Abingdon Virginian learns from good authority that a small body of Yankees came up to Jonesville on Friday, the 6th, from the Gap, and committed all sorts of depredations. They burnt the Academy and Masonic Hall, set fire to a church, and stole all the horses, cattle, grain and negroes they could find. "When it is remembered," remarks the Petersburgh Express, "that there are abundant, supplies in Lee -- enough to Winter a division of our army -- it is almost criminal to permit these degradations -- especially when a battalion of men could prevent it."

abstract: Walker, Commodore W. S.
lead_paragraph: Commodore W.S. WALKER, who died in Boston on the 23d ult., was a native of Portsmouth, N. H., and entered the navy as a Midshipman in 1814, before the close of the war with England. He had previously served in the Quartermaster's Department of the army during the war, under his brother, who was Quartermaster of the troops stationed in and about Portsmouth.

abstract: Had the Yankees quietly followed up the strategic advantages which they had gained in the long prelude to actual hostilities, we should have been bound hand and foot, without the possibility of effective resistance, and it was only the foolish unpatience with which the merely cunning are so often cursed that saved us from anhilation, or, what is worse, assimilation to the meanest of mankind. They had compassed sea and land to make prose[???] among us, and, mortifying as the confession is, subsequent experience has shown that we should have been two-fold more the children of hell thatn the Yankees themselves. Witness the Union men of East Tennessee and Western Virginia; witness the Southern renegades in the Northern army. Witness our extortioners, who out-Yankee Yankeedom.

abstract: Speech at Philadelphia Anti-Slavery Convention; Anti-Slavery Convention in Philadelphia
snippet: Speech at Philadelphia Anti-Slavery Convention; Anti-Slavery Convention in Philadelphia
lead_paragraph: At the Anti-Slavery Convention in Philadelphia, on Friday morning, Rev. H.W. BEECHER made a few remarks. He said that he would not detain the Society long, but wished merely to felicitate the Society upon the unprecedented success within the past few years of the principles which they represented. For twenty-five years he had lived on faith tolerably well; but sight was comforting occasionally, and he was glad to have enjoyed sight of late. Some of those who need sight to strengthen their faith are now falling into line in the Anti-Slavery army. [Applause.] He spoke of the heroism so long displayed by the members of the Anti-Slavery Society. We shall see in the future a repetition of the old story -- men mobbed while they lived, and splendid tombs for them when they die. All the signs of the times indicate that God is now in earnest, and determined to emancipate Slavery. [Applause.]

abstract: LIVERPOOL. A meeting was held on Wednesday afternoon at the Rooms of the Board of Trade in this city, by invitation of a Committee of the Board, to consider the expediency of establishing an American line of steamships between Boston and Liverpool.
lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL. A meeting was held on Wednesday afternoon at the Rooms of the Board of Trade in this city, by invitation of a Committee of the Board, to consider the expediency of establishing an American line of steamships between Boston and Liverpool. Mr. E.S. TOBEY, Chairman of the Committee, presided. Speeches were made by the Chairman, by His Excellency Gov. SMITH, of Vermont; Gen. STARK, of the Consolidated Railroad Line to Ogdensburgh; Mr. TWICHEL, President of the Boston and Worcester Railroad; Mr. GEORGE WARREN, of Liverpool, and by Messrs. J.C. CONVERSE, J.S. RODES, ISAAC RICH, HAMILTON B. HILL., and other gentlemen of this city. The statements submitted to the meeting were in substance as follows: That our present means of communication with Liverpool are altogether disproportionate to the wealth and importance of our city, and inadequate to the requirements of our commerce; that our European imports are reaching us by way of other cities, and that in our exports of Western produce we are seriously falling behind hand, it was urged that the recent strengthening of our various railroad connections with the West, the advantages offered by the wharves, warehouses, and elevators at East Boston now completed, and the prominent position which Boston at this time occupies before the country, eoncur in rendering of the first importance immediate and energetic action on the subject. While Boston has precisely the same number of steamships in the Liverpool trade as twenty years ago, viz: two a month; New-York has on the average a daily steamer to and from that great transatlantic port; and even Portland, in the Winter season, has two and sometimes three arrivals a week from Europe. Being one day's sail nearer to Liverpool than New-York, and upward of a hundred miles nearer to Upper Canada and the West than Portland, Boston would seem in its situation, and with its present and projected facilities, to possess peculiar advantages for sustaining a line of first-class freight steamships such as it is proposed to place on the Liverpool route; and as similar vessels have done a profitable business at other ports, it was argued that where others have succeeded so well, we should not be likely to fail. The railroad gentlemen present not only expressed their decided conviction that the time has fully arrived for initiating this mrvement, but they promised such Cooperation on the part of their respective companies as will ensure prompt and rapid transportation, and as will enable Boston to compete successfully in the vital question of rates of freight, for its full share of business between the West and Great Britain. We understand that another and larger meeting will be shortly convened to further consider the establishment of an enterpise which promises to be so remunerative to those engaged in it, and so advantageous to all the interests involved. -- Boston Journal, Dec. 4.

abstract: Women and Other Employers
lead_paragraph: We fear that one of the fatal errors that will be made by the working women, in their effort to obtain better remuneration for their labor, will be that of trusting their cause into the hands of professional agitators end demagogues, who will start with the idea of creating an antagonism between the employer and the employed. No more fatal start than this can be made. There is no antagonism; and, with solitary exceptions, the employer has always sufficient tact to know when he has profitable labor upon his premises, and wishes to keep it, though, of course, at as remunerative prices to himself as possible. Labor is to be looked on in the same light as we look upon a piece of goods offered for sale. It is bought at the lowest buyable rate, and sold, by its products, at the highest obtainable.
headline: {'main': 'Women and their Employers.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Women and their Employers.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A dispatch was recieved at the Central Office at 7 o'clock last evening from the Thirty-second Precinct, stating that a steamboat was blown up and on are off Fort Washington Depot. In a few moments afterward another dispatch was received, stating that the steamer had reached Tubby Hook, and her name was ascertained to be the Isaac Newton.
lead_paragraph: A dispatch was recieved at the Central Office at 7 o'clock last evening from the Thirty-second Precinct, stating that a steamboat was blown up and on are off Fort Washington Depot. In a few moments afterward another dispatch was received, stating that the steamer had reached Tubby Hook, and her name was ascertained to be the Isaac Newton. One of her flues burst, causing her to take fire, and she burned to the w[???]er's edge. No one was injured but the fireman. The passengers, though greatly alarm ed, were all safely taken off by other steamers, and landed at Yonkers in season to take the Hudson River train for Albany. A valuable bay horse, which swam ashore from the steamer, is at the Thirtieth Precinct. The Isaac Newton was valued at $250,000, and is said to be fully insured.

abstract: We have always made light of the hopes of foreign intervention, or even recognition; and have endeavored to turn away the minds of our people from speculations of this kind, to fix and concentrate them upon the only real hope we have our own steadfast and determined resistance.
lead_paragraph: We have always made light of the hopes of foreign intervention, or even recognition; and have endeavored to turn away the minds of our people from speculations of this kind, to fix and concentrate them upon the only real hope we have our own steadfast and determined resistance. Still we see in some newspapers urgent and irrefragable demonstrations addressed to the conscience or to the interests of foreign nations, especially France; clearly showing that France is bound by her policy in Mexico, by her traditions, hopes, everything she holds dear, to recognize the Confederacy and make alliance with it. The Emperor's speech on the opening of the Chambers has been thought likely to shadow forth this policy, so essential to him and so useful to us.

abstract: The literature of African discovery will maintain during the present season the prominent place it has of late years assumed in the publishing world.
lead_paragraph: The literature of African discovery will maintain during the present season the prominent place it has of late years assumed in the publishing world. At least three works of importance on the subject will make their appearance before Spring. Most eagerly looked of them is Capts. SPEKE and GRANT's narrative of Nilotic discovery. This will be brought out by Messrs. BLACKWOOD & SONS. The travels of Mr. WINWOOD READE (nephew of CHARLES READE, the novelist,) embrace a portion of the ground traversed by M. DU CHAILLU between the rivers Senegal on the North and the Angola on the South. It will be remembered Mr. READE visited Africa with the express purpose of verifying the accounts of the French traveler, and though obliged to return without being so fortunate as to meet with a gorilla, (as he has the honesty to confess,) his testimony is strongly in favor of the general correctness of DU CHAILLU'S book, as is also that of the veteran traveler, Capt. BURTON, whose forthcoming work shows him to have been busily employed on the Western coast, while his late companions were unraveling the mystery of the Nile, and contains an account of his ascent of the Cameroom Mountains and a visit to Abbeokuta.

abstract: The Port of Spain Gazette calls attention to the fact that the population of Trinidad receives an addition of about 2,000 persons every year from the neighboring Colonies, without apparently causing any increase in the industrial population of the Island, and accounts for their disappearance by the fact that squatting prevails to a considerable extent in the woods at a long distance from the cultivated part of the Colony, and that these squatting settlements are "brothels of vice, crime, and disease," and that the people occupying them are gradually degenerating into barbarism, whilst the mortality amongst them is very great at all times, particularly among the infants, and on occasion of epidemic disease their fate is dreadful, as they are far beyond the reach of medical aid. They simply become exterminated as soon as the settlements are formed, and are alike useless to the State and to themselves.

abstract: The removal of the Yankee prisoners is exceedingly opportune, not only on account of the obvious consideration of the relief afforded to the city in the matter of supplies; not merely that it guards against the danger of revolt, by which we were startled a few days ago, but because it nips in the bud a new and brilliant conception for the capture of Richmond.
lead_paragraph: The removal of the Yankee prisoners is exceedingly opportune, not only on account of the obvious consideration of the relief afforded to the city in the matter of supplies; not merely that it guards against the danger of revolt, by which we were startled a few days ago, but because it nips in the bud a new and brilliant conception for the capture of Richmond. The harrowing tales of the eloquent parsons, who have lately thrilled the "loyal" States relating to the unlucky captives now suffering in the cause of the "glorious Union," have produced upon that humane and enthusiastic people the same startling effect that the stories of the pilgrims to Jerusalem did upon the chivalry and populace of mediaeval Europe. A new crusade is called for. Though nearly six centuries have elapsed since the last flickerings of fanaticism, which gave birth to the "world's debate," have expired; though the nineteenth century is considered essentially prosaic and devoid of enthusiasm, and the Yankees, above all other nations, regarded as entirely practical, and free from the picturesque follies of past ages; yet, strange to say, it is in the City of New-York, in the year 1863, that a crusade is proclaimed for the liberation of the Yankee prisoners and the taking of Richmond.

abstract: THE CHRISTIAN ALLIANCE A WORK FOR THE BENEVOLENT AND PATRIOTIC. The above is an association of our city organized for the purpose of cooperating in any and all movements for the elevation and best interests of the masses; and to engage ...
lead_paragraph: THE CHRISTIAN ALLIANCE A WORK FOR THE BENEVOLENT AND PATRIOTIC. The above is an association of our city organized for the purpose of cooperating in any and all movements for the elevation and best interests of the masses; and to engage in acts of home benevolence and charity, preaching the Gospel, feeding the hungry and clothing the needy. This organization designs to give an entertainment to the needy families of those who have gone forth to fight our battles, on New-Year's Day. From a circular issued by the Association the following is quoted in explanation: We propose to open our ball, No. 720 Broadway, on New-Year's Day, from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M., for the purpose of furnishing refreshments to the needy families of our volunteers and to poor persons generally. The design of this movement is to afford these families an opportunity of mingling socially in the festivities of the day, and partaking of such cheer as the Society may be able to provide; to offer something to relieve the monotony of the long hours -- shut up, as a vast majority of these families are, in the compressed apartments of tenant houses. The tables will be under the management of a Committee of ladies, who have volunteered for the occasion, and a volunteer choir will discourse some music during the day." Amid our reunions and festivities let us not forget those who have been left behind by the men who have gone forth to battle -- enduring privations and suffering in our behalf. Money could hardly be devoted to a more worthy object than the above, and the benevolent would do well to send a contribution, for this purpose, to the Treasurer, Mr. CHARLES FANNING, Nos. 4 and 6 Burling-slip, New-York.

abstract: Ribaldry on Gettysburgh Cemetery
lead_paragraph: The dramatic exhibition of Gettysburgh is in thorough keeping with the Yankee character, and its minor incidents admirably suited to their present condition and to the usual dignity of their chosen chief. There was the wonted Yankee line of theatrical display the substitution of glittering foil and worthless paste for real brilliants and pure gold. Stage play, studied attitudes, and effective points were carefully elaborated and presented to the world as the honest outpourings of a nation's heart. In spite of shoddy contracts, of universal corruption, and cruel thirst for Southern blood, these people have ideas of the great virtues and lofty qualities which ennoble a nation. Though not suggested by their own feelings, they have read of them in books; know they commanded the admiration of the world, and determined accordingly to have a great imitation of them, suitable to the magnitude of the occasion, and appropriate to the natural promptings of generous hearts, warmed into sympathy and feeling by the incidents of the war.

abstract: On Friday afternoon the rebel troops, in considerable force, again crossed the Rapidan, at a point above Raccoon Ford, with the object, doubtless, of reconnoitering Gen. MEADE's position. After news of the rebel advance reached the Union camps very heavy cannonading was heard in the direction of Raccoon Ford, and it was reported that the light artillery, attached to the cavalry arm of the service, had succeeded, as on Thursday, in driving the rebels back again. The accounts from the Army of the Potomac, received yesterday, represent matters quiet, but give no further explanation of the firing on Friday.

abstract: The new steamboat Eliza Hancox, Capt. JOHN A. POST, left the foot of Beach-street yesterday morning at 11 o'clock, on a trial trip down the Bay. Her performance fully equaled the expectations of all parties, and gave great satisfaction to the many guests on board. She is admirably adapted for a seagoing vessel, and is calculated to be used as a tug in towing vessels to and from sea. Her owner is Capt. JOHN POST. She is thoroughly coppered and extra fastened. Her hull was built by M.S. ALLISON, Esq., of Jersey City, and the engines by Messrs. MURPHY, MCCURDY & WORDEN, of New-York. She has the following dimensions: length on deck, 162 feet; breadth over all, 57 feet; depth of hold, 8 feet 10 inches; has a beam engine of 9 feet stroke, the diameter of the cylinder being 46 inches. The rate of speed attained was nearly equal to sixteen miles per hour, making the trip from the Barge office to the Light-ship in one hour and thirty-three minutes, and on the return from Light-ship to Barge office, in one hour and thirty-six minutes.

abstract: MY DEAR FRIEND JOHN: You will be surprised somewhat, I imagine, at getting a letter from me in these foreign parts; but the war turns up wonders sometimes. I would have been very glad to have seen you once more before my departure, but was hurried off a month before I expected to leave; which, by d , scarcely gave me time to pack my trunk.

abstract: Gen. EWING, in command of the Department of Kansas, has issued an order discharging from service all scouts, spies and detectives lately employed from headquarters of the district of the border or of the frontier.
lead_paragraph: Gen. EWING, in command of the Department of Kansas, has issued an order discharging from service all scouts, spies and detectives lately employed from headquarters of the district of the border or of the frontier. Hereafter, whenever any civilian shall make an arrest, or seize property, he must, when called on, exhibit his authority from the General-Commanding, or of some officer acting under his orders, and give the claimant a memorandum describing the property. No seizure of property for "disloyal acts or practices" will hereafter be made except where such property is being used, or is about to be used, by persons in arms against the Government, or when such seizure is specially ordered from headquarters.

abstract: Breckinridge, John C.,the Reported Death of
snippet: Breckinridge, John C.,the Reported Death of
lead_paragraph: If it be true, as is now positively declared, that a loyal bullet has sent this traitor to eternity,every loyal heart will feel satisfaction and will not scruple to express it. Ordinarily, enmity is disarmed before death; reproach is silenced, and even the sternest justice makes way for pity. The form that is shrouded is a sacred thing, and the grave itself is an altar on which every bitter feeling should be sacrificed forever. Human censorship does not presume to follow the spirit that has gone to its Eternal Judge; and even the most rigid [???]eels constrained to remember his own frailties, and forgive. But where Death strikes such a public enemy as this, it exacts no such silent obeisance. Personal feeling has no part in the matter. It is to be regarded purely as a public event; and if it really has the shape of a public deliverance, it is just as right to welcome it as any other public blessing. It is just as proper, too, to speak the truth of such a criminal when dead as when living. Humanity has a just reckoning with guilt of this peculiar dye that can never be satisfied without posthumous infamy.

abstract: Lester L. Robinson et al. vs. Edward P. Flint et al. -- This was an action brought by the late firm of Robinson, Seymour & Co., of San Francisco, against the firms of Glidden & Williams, of Boston, and Flint, Peabody & Co., of San Francisco, for fraud in a contract for the delivery of railroad iron. The trial was commenced on the 19th of November, and occupied the Court until to-day. It attracted considerable attention, not only at the bar but in the mercantile community generally, owing to the high commercial standing of the defendants, the large amount of damages claimed, ($202,000,) and the distinguished counsel engaged in the trial. The plaintiffs rested yesterday, upon which the defendants moved for a dismissal of the complaint. Judge ALLEN to-day granted the motion, holding that no cause of action existed against the defendants.
lead_paragraph: Lester L. Robinson et al. vs. Edward P. Flint et al. -- This was an action brought by the late firm of Robinson, Seymour & Co., of San Francisco, against the firms of Glidden & Williams, of Boston, and Flint, Peabody & Co., of San Francisco, for fraud in a contract for the delivery of railroad iron. The trial was commenced on the 19th of November, and occupied the Court until to-day. It attracted considerable attention, not only at the bar but in the mercantile community generally, owing to the high commercial standing of the defendants, the large amount of damages claimed, ($202,000,) and the distinguished counsel engaged in the trial. The plaintiffs rested yesterday, upon which the defendants moved for a dismissal of the complaint. Judge ALLEN to-day granted the motion, holding that no cause of action existed against the defendants.

abstract: There is no room for doubt that the rebels employ bloodhounds to track and catch Union men for the purpose of forcing them into the rebel army. Hon. LUCIEN ANDERSON, of Kentucky, Congressman elect, who was recently captured by rebel guerrillas and afterward released by exchange, says the rebels had bloodhounds with them. He saw the dogs. He conversed with conscripts who had been chased, caught and lacerated by them, their wounds being yet unhealed.

abstract: Mr. CARL ANSCHUTZ's German experiment commenced at the Academy of Music on Wednesday last. Three performances in all have been given -- on the night we have named, on Friday and on Saturday. If it were the province of journalism to refer to management, we might find in these three entertainments a theme for comment. We might ask, is it good policy to have the house half empty on the opening night? Is it judicious to try to revolutionize the entire system of management, simply because inexperienced persons, with theoretical ideas, happen to find themselves in authority? Mr. ANSCHUTZ requires a large and hearty background of supporters. He is attempting a severe task -- the education of the public in a particular kind of music. To increase the numbers of that public should be an object with him; not to oppress or weary those who are already on his side. There is no bore so intolerable as an empty house; yet this affliction has been suffered by every one visiting the German opera on the nights we have named. There were a certain number of subscribers and a few outsiders -- sufficient, we hope, to pay expenses -- on every night, but the general effect of bare benches was calculated to make the average mind regret its kid gloves. But these matters are for the managerial judgment. Beyond briefly glancing at these we desire nothing better than to leave them alone.

abstract: Congress meets to-day, and will unquestionably proceed at once to the transaction of business. SCHUYLER COLFAX will be elected Speaker with the general acquiescence of the House. His position as one of the most experienced members, his familiarity with the rules and proceedings of the body over which he is to preside, his personal intelligence,
lead_paragraph: Congress meets to-day, and will unquestionably proceed at once to the transaction of business. SCHUYLER COLFAX will be elected Speaker with the general acquiescence of the House. His position as one of the most experienced members, his familiarity with the rules and proceedings of the body over which he is to preside, his personal intelligence, courtesy, and popularity, have made him by general consent the candidate of the Union men. The first thing to be done will be the appointment of the Committees of the House, and in this delicate and important task we have no doubt Mr. COLFAX will meet the general expectations of the country. We do not believe he will surrender the control of the public business to extremists of any kind, or favor in his selections the efforts of any faction to advance the Presidential aspirations of any man or of any party. He will recognize unquestionably the paramount claims of the loyal men of Congress and the country to direct the general course of public affairs: but he will also see the wisdom and propriety of giving all shades of the loyal sentiment of the Union full and fair representation in the public councils.

abstract: A colored man,  RECKLESS USE OF FIREARMS. A colored man,  named BRUCE, was arrested at his residence No. 100 Sands-street, on Saturday night, by Officers BOURNE and BEDELL, of the Forty-second Precinct, charged with felonious assault with a pistol. It appears that BRUCE, who is a seaman, came out of a drinkingsaloon in High-street, also kept by a colored man, and being somewhat under the influence of liquor,
lead_paragraph: A colored man, named BRUCE, was arrested at his residence No. 100 Sands-street, on Saturday night, by Officers BOURNE and BEDELL, of the Forty-second Precinct, charged with felonious assault with a pistol. It appears that BRUCE, who is a seaman, came out of a drinkingsaloon in High-street, also kept by a colored man, and being somewhat under the influence of liquor, drew out a pistol, and fired it in three different directions, utterly regardless of consequences. One of the shots struck a young lady named MARY ANN WILLIAMSON in the knee, inflicting a severe wound. She was accompanied by her father, who conveyed her to their residence, No. 147 Jay-street. Although the affair was witnessed by several persons, BRUCE was allowed to walk away. He was subsequently taken in charge by the above-named officers, and locked up to await examination.

abstract: As a War Force
lead_paragraph: The belief that the South would find Slavery a source of weakness in case of war, was generally current at the North before this struggle commenced. It was supposed that in a conflict with the North, avowedly undertaken for the purpose of confirming and extending the institution, the negroes would rise against their masters and paralyze the operations of the rebel armies in the field by recalling a large portion of them to the defence of their own firesides; and if this did not happen, it was supposed that at least the fear of its happening would cause a very large augmentation of the precautions usually taken against insurrection, and would thus diminish the number of white men available for service on the frontier. More overseers would, it was thought, be needed on the plantations, stronger guards and patrols in the towns, and larger reserves at central points, ready to march to scenes of possible disturbance; and this alarm would, it was thought, be maintained and stimulated by the attitude of the slaves themselves, who, though they might not actually rise in revolt, would be sufficiently mutinous and insubordinate in their manner to prove that the traditional reverence for the ruling race was weakened, and the bonds of the captive relaxed.

abstract: A HOTEL THIEF IN CUSTODY. Mr. JOHN GALLAGHER, night watchman at the Merchants' Hotel, in Cortlandt-street, detected one of the lodgers in the house, named THOMAS RILEY, in the attempt to enter the room of Mr. JOHN PINKERTON, another lodger, at about two o'clock yesterday morning. Mr. GALLAGHER observed RILEY leaving his room and saw him attempt to open the door of his fellow-lodger's room, by means of a false key.
lead_paragraph: A HOTEL THIEF IN CUSTODY. -- Mr. JOHN GALLAGHER, night watchman at the Merchants' Hotel, in Cortlandt-street, detected one of the lodgers in the house, named THOMAS RILEY, in the attempt to enter the room of Mr. JOHN PINKERTON, another lodger, at about two o'clock yesterday morning. Mr. GALLAGHER observed RILEY leaving his room and saw him attempt to open the door of his fellow-lodger's room, by means of a false key. As Mr. PINKERTON gave an alarm. RILEY started down stairs, where he was met by Mr. GALLAGHER, to whom he offered a bribe to release him. Officer RHODES took RILEY to the Station-house and upon searching him discovered a small "jimmy" on his person. He was taken before Justice DOWLING yesterday morning, and committed in default of $1,000 bail. The prisoner is alleged to be a noted hotel thief. Mr. THOMAS D. WINCHESTER, of the Western Hotel, and Mr. BENJ. LYNDE, of the Howard Hotel, both stated that RILEY was a lodger at their houses at a certain time when some thefts were committed there to which they could obtain no clue, and they have no doubt now but that the accused was the guilty party.

abstract: The rebels, after burning their stores at Chicamauga Station, continued their march southward. At every mile they left deserters, and the road was strewn with guns, haversacks, and blankets, which they could not carry. It was supposed that as they were going tolerably far South, they would not need their blankets. It is certain they went in great haste. Their march was very different from that of this army when it fell back from Chickamauga.

abstract: UNION FAIR. -- The Union Fair, which has been in progress four days, at the City Hall, in Jersey City, under the auspices of the Ladies' Relief Society, for the benefit of families of soldiers, has been a decided success. Up to Saturday night there had been upward of 6,000 visitors, and the receipts exceed $3,500. The commodious Common Council Chamber on all sides is lined with tables, on which are displayed, articles of the choicest description. The Mayor's office and other City offices are occupied for refreshments, and DODWORTH's band, are present every evening. The fair will continue until Tuesday night, and from present indications will be quite as successful as the one previously held.

We made brief mention of it yesterday.

abstract: BY FIRE -- $20,000 DAMAGE. -- The ship St. Louis, for New-Orleans, lying at Pier No. 21 East River, took fire last evening about 9 1/4 o'clock and was partially destroyed, together with her cargo. The damage is estimated at $20,000, and is said to be insured. The vessel was loaded with corn, oats, hay and other stores for the Government, and was all ready to haul out into the stream. The fire originated in the fore hold near the kelson, but the cause is at present unknown. Messrs. WM. & ALBERT NELSON, of No. 66 South-street, are the owners of the vessels.
lead_paragraph: BY FIRE -- $20,000 DAMAGE. -- The ship St. Louis, for New-Orleans, lying at Pier No. 21 East River, took fire last evening about 9 1/4 o'clock and was partially destroyed, together with her cargo. abstract: ALLEGED SWINDLING BY A NEW-YORK MERCHANT. GOVERNMENT CONTRACT. Mr. WILLIAM J. WILLIAMS, of the firm of WILLIAMS  KENNEDY, doing business at No. 58 Liberty-street, yesterday appeared before Justice DOWLING, at the Toombs Police Court, and made an affidavit against EDGAR D. SEELY, whom he charges with having defrauded their firm of the sum of $650.
lead_paragraph: ALLEGED SWINDLING BY A NEW-YORK MERCHANT. GOVERNMENT CONTRACT. Mr. WILLIAM J. WILLIAMS, of the firm of WILLIAMS KENNEDY, doing business at No. 58 Liberty-street, yesterday appeared before Justice DOWLING, at the Toombs Police Court, and made an affidavit against EDGAR D. SEELY, whom he charges with having defrauded their firm of the sum of $650. From the complaint it appears that on the 25th ult. SEELY called upon the firm of WILLIAMS & KENNEDY, and represented to them that he had an extensive Government contract; that for the sum of $450 they could have a part of this contract (which would nett them about $2,000) trasferred to them. Mr. WILLIAMS being desirous to secure a share in the contract, advanced the sum of $450 to SEELY, with the understanding that it should be consummated at once. SEELY was not seen again until the 1st inst., when he again appeared at the store of Messrs. WILLIAMS & KENNEDY, and stated that he had been unable to effect the arrangement at as cheap a rate as he had supposed. He therefore proposed that $200 additional should be paid to secure the contract. Mr. WILLIAMS paid the last-named sum, when SEELY left, and was not seen again until Sunday last, when WILLIAMS met him in the street. With the aid of Officer TEEHAN, of the Second Precinct, he was arrested, and yesterday he was taken before Justice CONNOLLY, at the Tombs, where he was committed for examination. SEELY is a very respectable appearing man, and claims to be a merchant of this City.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday the Mayor sent in the recent presentment of the Grand Jury of the Court of General Sessions in relation to the foul odors and gases arising from the sewer outlets on the river, with the recommendation that the Common Council look into the subject with the view of effecting some improvement in the discharge of sewer contents. The communication was referred to the Committee on Public Health. The proprietor of the Bull's Head line of omnibuses sent in a petition setting forth that the railroad lines are ruining his business, and asking permission to substitute cars for his stages, to run over the Third-avenue and Bowery tracks of the Third and Second-avenue and Harlem companies, upon agreement with them, and also paying license fees for the cars, as required by the City ordinances. A resolution giving the desired privilege, and to construct necessary turnouts, was offered by Mr. MITCHELL, and adopted by 10 to 4. The Board adjourned to 1 o'clock P.M. to-day.

abstract: -- Major FELIX AGNUS, of the One Hundred and Sixty-fifth Regiment New-York Volunteers, (the Second Duryea's Z[???]uaves,) now on duty at New-Iberia, Louisiana, is in this City for the purpose of recruiting the battalion, which is for the present under the command of Lieut.-Col. GOUVERNEUR CARR. He desires to increase is to a full regiment. It has rendered splendid service throughout the war, having been engaged in nearly all the important battles, and distinguished itself in all. Major AGNUS ought to have no difficulty in at once recruiting it ranks.

abstract: Both Houses of Congress met yesterday. In the Senate proceedings were opened by a prayer of Rev. Dr. SUNDERLAND, when the credentials of new members were presented. Mr. DAVIS raised a question as to the right of Messrs. WILLEY and VAN WINKLE, Senators-elect from West Vir-...
lead_paragraph: Both Houses of Congress met yesterday. In the Senate proceedings were opened by a prayer of Rev. Dr. SUNDERLAND, when the credentials of new members were presented. Mr. DAVIS raised a question as to the right of Messrs. WILLEY and VAN WINKLE, Senators-elect from West Virginia, to take seats, arguing against their admission upon the ground that the division of the State was an unconstitutional proceeding, and moved the matter be referred to the Judiciary Committee. After some discussion, in which precedents and the rules applying to their case were cited, Mr. DAVIS moved as a test question that the oath be administered to these gentlemen, which was carried by Yeas 36, Nays 5. A Committee was appointed to wait upon the President to inform him of the readiness of the Senate to receive his Annual Message, and, upon motion of Mr. FOOTE, the Senators from West Virginia were classified in the usual manner by drawing lots, and the long term fell to Mr. VAN WINKLE. Mr. LANE, of Indiana, gave notice of a bill to repeal the $300 commutation clause of the enrollment act, and to increase the pay of non-commissioned officers and privates in the army 50 per cent. The daily hour of meeting was fixed at 12 M., and the Senate adjourned.

abstract: The pavement in Broadway is really becoming intolerable. Every day makes it smoother and smoother, until now it is almost impossible for any but the most agile and experienced horses to keep their footing. A horse will soon require as much training to stand up in Broadway as to dance on a tight-rope. One cannot walk down at any time of day without seeing at least half a dozen falling down. It seems a great shame that our streets should need such constant tinkering, but in this case there really seems to be no help for it. Steps ought immediately to be taken to replace the present pavement with the Belgian, which is the best kind that has yet been introduced.

abstract: Etheridge, Mr., the Case of
lead_paragraph: We beg our new Congress to keep cool. This starting life with such a high fever is not a good sign. It really don't look as if Mr. ETHERIDGE is guilty of treason. Sure enough, he is a rather strict constructionist, but that hardly will justify his being sent to Fort Lafayette. Perhaps he strained a point in holding the credentials of members to the absolute language of the law, but the result proved that the House had an easy remedy. Beside, if the Clerk is to err at all, it is well that he should err on the side of strictness. In the anomalous condition of so many Southern Congressional Districts, from which representatives, or those who claim to be such, have come or will come, it is more than ever important that the laws bearing upon the authentication of membership should be very closely conformed to; and if the Clerk, in accepting credentials, is allowed any latitude at all, there is danger that it will lead to misjudgment, if not to intentional abuse.

snippet: Alexandra, the Arguments; Neutrality--Alexandra Case, The Arguments
lead_paragraph: The arguments in the Alexandra case are concluded. It is not easy to make up one's mind, from reading the reports of the speeches, upon which side of the case the weight of the argument lay, for they are not reported in full, and often we find only suggestions of points which must have been fully brought out, and which, when thus fully displayed in all their relations, may have presented themselves to the mind with great force.

abstract: -- The election for Directors of the Central Railroad takes place to-morrow at Albany. We now draw attention to the ticket which will be supported by those Stockholders who desire reforms in the management of this immense property. What the reforms are which they consider desirable, we have already taken occasion to indicate and to advocate. It certainly does not seem either just or wise that the high officers of a corporation which expends ten or twelve millions of dollars per annum, should have the privilege of selling the articles which it needs as a compensation for their services, instead of a stipulated salary. This is the case with the Central road, and with no other corporation of equal magnitude on the face of the earth. Mr. CORNING, the President, is an iron merchant, and whatever iron the road requires, and whatever repairs its engines need, he has the right to furnish. Without any impeachment of his personal character, it is impossible that such a double relation should be profitable or safe. As President of the road, his duty to the Stockholders, whose money he disburses, requires him to purchase as little as possible, and at the lowest rates. As an iron merchant, it is for his individual interest to sell to the road as much as possible, and at the highest rates. Mr. CORNING must be something more than human, if, under such circumstances, he can discharge such an extraordinary trust with perfect and unswerving fidelity.

abstract: East, the President's Proclamation of Victory
snippet: East, the President's Proclamation of Victory
lead_paragraph: President LINCOLN has been one of the very few men in the United States who has steadily and always appreciated the essential military importance of East Tennessee. In his first Message to Congress, he urged the making of an appropriation to build a railroad through Eastern Kentucky as far as Cumberland Gap, with the view of securing possession of the mountain ranges, and of the region as far as Knoxville; and ever since that time, so far as his influence and orders could go, he has not ceased his earnest efforts to secure successful military operations on that vital line. Whether these views were the result of instinctive common sense, or whether he obtained them from some far-seeing strategist, we know not, and it matters not. But they were correct views; they were all-important views; and they are now approved by every military head in the country.

lead_paragraph: The President, in view of the retreat of the insurgent forces from Tennessee, under circumstances which render it unlikely that the National forces can hereafter be dislodged from that position, has issued a feeling and appropriate recommendation that on the receipt of the news, all loyal people do assemble at their places of worship, and give thanks to Almighty God for this great advancement of the National cause.

abstract: -- It has just been discovered by somebody that it was not Gen. GRANT who drove BRAGG from Lookout Mountain and Missionary Ridge, and compelled him to fly in confusion to Ringgold or Rome. It has been found out that Gen. BRAGG had intended to retreat from in front of Chattanooga, and that his hastily doing so was only in execution of a long-contemplated plan. The simple and final answer to all this, is the situation of Gen. LONGSTREET. Had BRAGG purposed retreating, he would assuredly never have sent LONGSTREET's column into East Tennessee, for the only support of LONGSTREET, his only safety from destruction, was in the army of BRAGG, and BRAGG could only avail him by holding the position in front of Chattanooga. He there protected LONGSTREET's flank and rear, and held open for him a feasible line by which, after effecting his work in East Tennessee, he could again make a junction with the main army he had left, and then proceed in the expulsion of our forces from Chattanooga. When the facts and justifications in the case are taken into account, it is ridiculous to say that BRAGG's retreat was but the carrying out of a premeditated project of his own. It might as well be said that he intended also to get rid of a great part of his worthless artillery and troops, by permitting them to fall into our hands.
lead_paragraph: -- It has just been discovered by somebody that it was not Gen. GRANT who drove BRAGG from Lookout Mountain and Missionary Ridge, and compelled him to fly in confusion to Ringgold or Rome. It has been found out that Gen. BRAGG had intended to retreat from in front of Chattanooga, and that his hastily doing so was only in execution of a long-contemplated plan. The simple and final answer to all this, is the situation of Gen. LONGSTREET. Had BRAGG purposed retreating, he would assuredly never have sent LONGSTREET's column into East Tennessee, for the only support of LONGSTREET, his only safety from destruction, was in the army of BRAGG, and BRAGG could only avail him by holding the position in front of Chattanooga. He there protected LONGSTREET's flank and rear, and held open for him a feasible line by which, after effecting his work in East Tennessee, he could again make a junction with the main army he had left, and then proceed in the expulsion of our forces from Chattanooga. When the facts and justifications in the case are taken into account, it is ridiculous to say that BRAGG's retreat was but the carrying out of a premeditated project of his own. It might as well be said that he intended also to get rid of a great part of his worthless artillery and troops, by permitting them to fall into our hands.

abstract: CHECK. -- Yesterday afternoon two young men entered a barber's shop, at No. 120 Cedar-street, where they employed a lad named FRANK BISCHOFF, to get a check cashed for them. The check was for $270, and purported to have been drawn by Mr. J.C. MEEKER, payable to C.S. MARSTON, at the Shoe and Leather Bank. It was stipulated that if the lad was successful in getting the money he was to meet his unknown employers two blocks below the Bank. FRANK, presented the check to Mr. CRANE, the paying teller, -- who is well acquainted with Mr. MEEEER's signature, -- and it was at once pronounced by him to be a forgery. He however, detained the boy and consulted with Mr. STOUT, the President of the Bank. They resolved to detect the forgers if possible. Capt. THORNE, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, was called in, and a bundle of small bills were delivered; to the boy. The latter immediately started for the appointed rendezvous, followed by the Captain and one or two others. Just as the lad was delivering the money into the hands of one of the forgers, the officer stepped up and took him into custody. When arraigned before Justice CONNOLLY, he gave his name as JOHN BRADY, Jr. He was committed to the Tombs for examination. The Police are endeavoring to arrest his accomplice.
lead_paragraph: CHECK. -- Yesterday afternoon two young men entered a barber's shop, at No. 120 Cedar-street, where they employed a lad named FRANK BISCHOFF, to get a check cashed for them. The check was for $270, and purported to have been drawn by Mr. J.C. MEEKER, payable to C.S. MARSTON, at the Shoe and Leather Bank. It was stipulated that if the lad was successful in getting the money he was to meet his unknown employers two blocks below the Bank. FRANK, presented the check to Mr. CRANE, the paying teller, -- who is well acquainted with Mr. MEEEER's signature, -- and it was at once pronounced by him to be a forgery. He however, detained the boy and consulted with Mr. STOUT, the President of the Bank. They resolved to detect the forgers if possible. Capt. THORNE, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, was called in, and a bundle of small bills were delivered; to the boy. The latter immediately started for the appointed rendezvous, followed by the Captain and one or two others. Just as the lad was delivering the money into the hands of one of the forgers, the officer stepped up and took him into custody. When arraigned before Justice CONNOLLY, he gave his name as JOHN BRADY, Jr. He was committed to the Tombs for examination. The Police are endeavoring to arrest his accomplice.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. WILSON, of Massa chasetts, submitted a resolution to inquire what further legislation is necessary to facilitate the payment of back pay and pensions to deceased soldiers. He also gave notice of a bill to increase the bounty of soldiers.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. WILSON, of Massa chasetts, submitted a resolution to inquire what further legislation is necessary to facilitate the payment of back pay and pensions to deceased soldiers. He also gave notice of a bill to increase the bounty of soldiers. Mr. CLARK introduted a bill to grant a pension to JOHN BURNS, the heroic citizen of Gettysburgh. A resolution was introduced by Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, declaring, in effect, that the refusal of the rebels to exchange colored soldiers and their white officers, should not prevent the exchange of our other officers and soldiers on just terms. The resolution was laid over. A discussion occurred upon the right of Mr. WILSON, of Missouri, to hold his seat, his successor having been chosen by the State Legislature. A resolution was finally passed declaring him not entitled to the seat. The Senate then adjourned.

abstract: -- What a pity it is that diplomatic language, or lingo, is always, to say the least, so utterly unintelligible. Take the Mexican matter for example. When the triple alliance sent its forces to that country, it was proclaimed to the world that the Powers had no intention of subverting or changing the Government of the Mexican people. And yet the French, the leading Power in the alliance, has undertaken to overthrow the Mexican Republic, and change entirely the character of the Government. After the French had secured a firm foothold in Mexico, the Emperor proclaimed that the object of the intervention was to secure the supremacy of the Latin race, and limit the growth and power of the United States; and it was evident that, if this could be effected at all, it could only be by a permanent military occupation of Mexico. And now, beside all the above, we get, through the French "Yellow Book," a couple of dispatches from DROUYN DE LHUYS on this Mexican business, which are not less unintelligible than former utterances. One of them, addressed, in September last, to the Emperor's Minister at Washington, states explicitly that the French Government "did not seek, either for itself or others, any territorial acquisition in America," and another dispatch, addressed, in October, to the commander of the French forces in Mexico, says, in speaking of the indemnity to be demanded from Mexico: "We had to consider the expenses which will also be incurred before our [French] forces have completely evacuated the Mexican territory."
lead_paragraph: -- What a pity it is that diplomatic language, or lingo, is always, to say the least, so utterly unintelligible. Take the Mexican matter for example. When the triple alliance sent its forces to that country, it was proclaimed to the world that the Powers had no intention of subverting or changing the Government of the Mexican people. And yet the French, the leading Power in the alliance, has undertaken to overthrow the Mexican Republic, and change entirely the character of the Government. After the French had secured a firm foothold in Mexico, the Emperor proclaimed that the object of the intervention was to secure the supremacy of the Latin race, and limit the growth and power of the United States; and it was evident that, if this could be effected at all, it could only be by a permanent military occupation of Mexico. And now, beside all the above, we get, through the French "Yellow Book," a couple of dispatches from DROUYN DE LHUYS on this Mexican business, which are not less unintelligible than former utterances. One of them, addressed, in September last, to the Emperor's Minister at Washington, states explicitly that the French Government "did not seek, either for itself or others, any territorial acquisition in America," and another dispatch, addressed, in October, to the commander of the French forces in Mexico, says, in speaking of the indemnity to be demanded from Mexico: "We had to consider the expenses which will also be incurred before our [French] forces have completely evacuated the Mexican territory."
