abstract: Between 10 and 11 o'clock last night, Officer JOHN BARRETT, of the Sixth Precinct, discovered a fire on the first floor of the premises No. 356 Broadway. The flames spread throughout the building with great rapidity, and in a short time the entire...
lead_paragraph: Between 10 and 11 o'clock last night, Officer JOHN BARRETT, of the Sixth Precinct, discovered a fire on the first floor of the premises No. 356 Broadway. The flames spread throughout the building with great rapidity, and in a short time the entire building was destroyed. It was owned by the Lorillard estate; was valued at about $25,000; and is said to be fully insured. It was a five-story brown-stone edifice.

abstract: The biennial election for seven Assistant Engineers in the western District Fire Department took place last evening at the different engine houses in the city. The voting commenced at 7, and concluded at 9 o'clock, after which the ballots were conveyed to Firemen's Hall in Henry-street, where they were counted. The canvass was not concluded till after 1 o'clock. The tellers appointed to canvass the returns were Messrs. MASSEY, of Engine No. 14; TURNER, of Hook and Ladder No. 1, and SCOTT, of Hose No. 3. The successful candidates, as near as could be ascertained before the official result was announced, are as follows; Wm. Taylor, Engine No. 6; Peter Fitzpatrick, Engine No. 5; H.J. Whiting, Engine No. 9; Robert Barr, Engine No. 3; Dennis Doroney, Hose No. 7; Chas. Wetherell, Engine No. 4; David Simpson, Engine No. 20. A great deal of interest was manifested in the result by all connected, with the Department.

abstract: -- Commodore VANDERBILT was quite seriously injured Monday afternoon. He was driving on the Bloomingdale Road, his buggy coming in collision with another vehicle. He was picked up insensible, but soon recovered consciousness, and was conveyed to a house near by, where he received every attention.

abstract: -- A correspondent of the Montreal Witness denounces in very sharp and decided terms the conduct of certain public men in Canada, in openly sympathizing with the Southern rebellion. He states that on one occasion a telegram was read in Parliament, announcing the defeat of the national forces, and that a dozen members greeted it with loud applause, Hon. G.E. CARTIER, late Premier, being among them. Many of these members have maintained a regular correspondence with leading rebels, have furnished them arms and munitions of war from Canadian ports, and acted as the medium of communication between them and Europe. The Grand Trunk Railway gave Mr. VALLANDIGHAM an extra train on his visit to Montreal. In the face of all these demonstrations, mainly led on by the Opposition party, the course of the Canadian Government has been moderate, friendly and conservative. We observe, by the way, that notice has already been given in Congress by Mr. MORRILL, of Vermont, of a bill to abolish the Reciprocity Treaty with Canada.

abstract: The Orpheus Club, a private organization, gave their first invitation Fancy Dress Masquerade Ball last evening -- Chanucka night -- at Irving Hall. It was a very creditable and enjoyable affair. The guests were numerous, and a large proportion were in masquerade, the costumes being of every conceivable character, from grave to gay, and some rich and very beautiful. Up to 12 o'clock this portion of the company had the floor exclusively, and fun and enjoyment was supreme. After that hour the masks were removed, and the lookers on had an opportunity to join in the dance. It was an evening of pleasure to all, and the manner in which it was perfected and conducted was most creditable to the Committee.

abstract: Coroner WILDEY yesterday held an inquest at the New-York Hospital, on the body of NANCY E. VINCENT, a native of Tennessee, aged 22 years, who died on Monday from the effect of stab wounds received at the hands of CHARLES H. WALTERS. The case, as our readers may remember, was reported in...
lead_paragraph: Coroner WILDEY yesterday held an inquest at the New-York Hospital, on the body of NANCY E. VINCENT, a native of Tennessee, aged 22 years, who died on Monday from the effect of stab wounds received at the hands of CHARLES H. WALTERS. The case, as our readers may remember, was reported in the columns of the TIMES at the time it occurred, Nov. 30. The testimony has, however, disclosed some additional facts of interest. The homicide was committed at a low dance-house, in the basement of No. 96 Centre-street, nearly opposite the Tombs. The physician who made the post mortem examination testified that there were eighteen distinct wounds -- some on the body, some on the arms, one on the head, and others on the lower limbs. The stabs were inflicted with the blade of a common jack-knife, and from their nature and position, there can be no doubt that they were given in rapid succession, and by a man who had no idea of what he was doing. WALTERS, so far as is known, has hitherto borne a good reputation. He is respectably connected, well educated, and of good appearance. He is about 31 years of age, and by occupation a carpenter and joiner. He was born in the State of New-Jersey, but for several years past has resided in St. Louis. When, after the rendition of the verdict, he was arraigned by the Coroner, and asked what he had to say to the charge of homicide preferred against him, he answered: "I have no knowledge of the act at all." He was much depressed in spirits, and expressed deep regret at the occurrence, but made no attempt at justification. He had been drinking to excess that night, and said if the deed was committed by him it was when he was deeply under the influence of liquor. Coroner WILDEY committed the accused to the Tombs, to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, a petition was received from the trustees of the Colored Orphan Asylum, (which was destroyed by the mob during the riots,) asking to be relieved from the conditions imposed upon them by the City in the lease of the site of the late buildings of the institution, and that the ground...
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, a petition was received from the trustees of the Colored Orphan Asylum, (which was destroyed by the mob during the riots,) asking to be relieved from the conditions imposed upon them by the City in the lease of the site of the late buildings of the institution, and that the ground be donated to them, in order that they may sell it and use the proceeds to reestablish the institution elsewhere. Mr. FARLEY presented a resolution embodying the wishes of the petitioners, which was referred to a Special Committee. The Comptroller reported the Treasury balance last Saturday to have been $3,152,648 84. The Street Commissioner replied to a resolution of inquiry that, many of the up-town streets which have been ordered to be gas-lighted at night, are not lighted because they are not graded or have not curb and gutter stones set in them; and it is deemed inexpedient to fit up new lamp-posts in such places, except in very urgent cases. The Board adjourned to 1 o'clock P.M. to-day.

abstract: On Monday the Common Council adopted a resolution granting Mr. JOHN T. MILLS, owner of the Bull's Head line of omnibuses, the right to substitute horse-cars for his stages, and to run them over the Bowery and Third-avenue tracks of the Second and Third-avenue and Harlem Railroad Companies, on...
lead_paragraph: On Monday the Common Council adopted a resolution granting Mr. JOHN T. MILLS, owner of the Bull's Head line of omnibuses, the right to substitute horse-cars for his stages, and to run them over the Bowery and Third-avenue tracks of the Second and Third-avenue and Harlem Railroad Companies, on paying these Companies a proper remuneration for the privilege, and also paying to the City the license fee for each car he may use, as prescribed by the City ordinances. The resolution passed each Board without debate by a large vote, and is now before the Mayor for his consideration. Mr. MILLS petitioned for the privilege, and the resolution granting it was introduced by Alderman MITCHELL. In his petition, Mr. MILLS gives us his main reasons for asking so extraordinary a franchise -- that the railroad lines on his stage route were ruining his business, and that the railroad tracks, being laid down by municipal authority, are public property as much as the highway on which they are built, and cannot be monopolized by a single grant.

abstract: We are glad to see the prompt movements in Congress to increase the soldiers' pay, and to abolish the three hundred dollar draft commutation. It is plain that the time has come when property must take upon itself some of the burdens of this war.
lead_paragraph: We are glad to see the prompt movements in Congress to increase the soldiers' pay, and to abolish the three hundred dollar draft commutation. It is plain that the time has come when property must take upon itself some of the burdens of this war. If we are not to have the contest drag on for years, the supreme necessity is to keep the ranks of our armies full. This can be done only by stronger inducements than have hitherto been presented; and those inducements must take the shape of money -- the same stimulus which imparts energy and success to every other department of American activity. To admit this is not at all to admit that the service is assuming a mercenary cast.

abstract: We learn by the last mail that England has refused to give in her adhesion to the proposed Congress, while fifteen of the twenty Powers, who, in all, have been invited to take part in it, have signified their intention of...
lead_paragraph: We learn by the last mail that England has refused to give in her adhesion to the proposed Congress, while fifteen of the twenty Powers, who, in all, have been invited to take part in it, have signified their intention of doing so. There is a touch of the ludicrous in this ready acquiescence in the scheme, of all those who have either nothing to lose by any change and some chance, of gaining something, or else who, having nothing either to hope or fear, enjoy the prospect of being allowed to sit at the same table, and share in the deliberations of "the Great Powers." Those who have refused to be present, or hesitate in accepting, are the ones whose "manners and excesses" the Congress is intended to correct, and they not unnaturally are rather shy about offering to sit in a court of inquiry on their own conduct. For instance, one of the questions to be debated, perhaps the chief one, is that of the future of Poland, and the influence which the Congress would exert in this would certainly be in favor of a reestablishment of Polish nationality, at least in a state of quasi-independence. Russia has, however, clearly made up her mind on this subject. She is determined to keep Poland as a Russian province, cost what it may. According to present indications, she will, unless prevented by interference from without, convert it into a howling waste sooner than lose her hold on it. On this point there is no wavering at St. Petersburgh. A year ago there was wavering. There was at that time some uncertainty as to the course the Western Powers would pursue; and their desire to meddle was evident; but all doubt was soon removed by the headlong diplomacy of Earl RUSSELL. He managed to say all that could be said, short of a threat of war, in three or four dispatches, and then astonished everybody, and probably nobody so much as Russia herself, by informing her at the close of a good deal of very strong writing, that if Russia did not mend her ways, she would be visited with the disapproval of other countries. This was by no means all that she looked for, and was doubtless considerably relieved when she knew the worst. It is needless to say that Lord RUSSELL would have served the Poles vastly better by remaining totally silent, than by saying just enough to make Russia sure of impunity. And the notion that this Power is likely to be influenced in her dealings with a conquered province by the moral suasion of the West, is a strange one for a statesman who has sat at the feet of those who witnessed the great partition of 1772, and who himself actually took part in the debates arising out of the "reconquest" of 1832.
headline: {'main': 'Chances of a European Congress The Great Powers and Other Powers.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Chances of a European Congress The Great Powers and Other Powers.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The ship St. Louis, long and favorably known as one of the staunchest vessels sailing out of this port, took fire, as was stated yesterday morning, about 11 o'clock Monday night, at Pier No. 21 East River, and was, before daylight, nearly "burned out." The St. Louis was owned by several parties, among the number the Messrs. NELSON, No. 66 South-street. The estimated value of the vessel, at the time of the accident, was $40,000. The loss to the ship and cargo occasioned by water and fire will hardly fall short of $25,000, most of which is covered by insurance. The origin of the fire has not been ascertained, although it is supposed to have been the result of accident or spontaneous combustion. The latter is probably the true solution, as when the flames were first discovered they were proceeding immediately from a mass of hay. which the watchman asserts could not have been fired by accident or an incendiary. About 4 o'clock yesterday morning the ship was scuttled on her port side, and in less than an hour sank in three fathoms of water. That depth, however, was not sufficient to cover the vessel, and the fire continued to burn furiously all day yesterday, and was burning at a late hour last night. At the time the fire was discovered there were a large number of canal-boats lying abreast the St. Louis, most of which were loaded with grain. There were also several ships in close proximity which, it was thought, would be destroyed, as, at one time a general conflagration seemed imminent. The sails and most of the top hamper of the burning vessel were secured and removed. The Underwriters were doing everything they could, assisted by the Fire Department, to save property not reached by the fire. At high water the St. Louis may "list over" sufficiently to put out the fire between decks. If such shall prove to be the case the hull of the vessel and the main rigging may be saved. The St. Louis, at the time of the accident, was being loaded and was nearly ready for her departure for New-Orleans. The cargo of the St. Louis was composed of Government stores and merchandise generally, valued at upwards _____.
lead_paragraph: The ship St. Louis, long and favorably known as one of the staunchest vessels sailing out of this port, took fire, as was stated yesterday morning, about 11 o'clock Monday night, at Pier No. 21 East River, and was, before daylight, nearly "burned out." The St. Louis was owned by several parties, among the number the Messrs. NELSON, No. 66 South-street. The estimated value of the vessel, at the time of the accident, was $40,000. The loss to the ship and cargo occasioned by water and fire will hardly fall short of $25,000, most of which is covered by insurance. The origin of the fire has not been ascertained, although it is supposed to have been the result of accident or spontaneous combustion. The latter is probably the true solution, as when the flames were first discovered they were proceeding immediately from a mass of hay. which the watchman asserts could not have been fired by accident or an incendiary. About 4 o'clock yesterday morning the ship was scuttled on her port side, and in less than an hour sank in three fathoms of water. That depth, however, was not sufficient to cover the vessel, and the fire continued to burn furiously all day yesterday, and was burning at a late hour last night. At the time the fire was discovered there were a large number of canal-boats lying abreast the St. Louis, most of which were loaded with grain. There were also several ships in close proximity which, it was thought, would be destroyed, as, at one time a general conflagration seemed imminent. The sails and most of the top hamper of the burning vessel were secured and removed. The Underwriters were doing everything they could, assisted by the Fire Department, to save property not reached by the fire. At high water the St. Louis may "list over" sufficiently to put out the fire between decks. If such shall prove to be the case the hull of the vessel and the main rigging may be saved. The St. Louis, at the time of the accident, was being loaded and was nearly ready for her departure for New-Orleans. The cargo of the St. Louis was composed of Government stores and merchandise generally, valued at upwards _____.

abstract: During the next four weeks there will be a very large sum, we dare not guess how much, spent here and elsewhere in the purchase of books, jewelry, pictures and ornaments to make a merrier Christmas for children and friends, and relatives of all degrees.
lead_paragraph: During the next four weeks there will be a very large sum, we dare not guess how much, spent here and elsewhere in the purchase of books, jewelry, pictures and ornaments to make a merrier Christmas for children and friends, and relatives of all degrees. There is no period of the year at which the sale of luxuries is so great, and in which money is spent with such an open hand; and this lavish outlay is intended, and rightly intended, to mark the glow which, in all Christian countries, the season and its associations are sure to communicate -- the best and tenderest passions of the heart. There are very few -- and these few must be strangely constituted -- who do not find their sympathies enlarged and quickened, their asperities smoothed down, and all their affections warmed as the great Feast of Peace and Good Will draws near. Against marking it by as costly gifts as people's purses may bear, or their feelings prompt, we should, in ordinary years, have not a word to say.

abstract: The high character, scholastic attainments, erudition and social qualifications of American Clergymen, are in strong contrast with the narrow prejudices and limited resources which have marked the history of other nations, and of earlier periods of the world. Coming directly in contact with the theories of the most enlightened minds, as well as the customs of common life, they are better calculated to judge of popular opinion and current ideas, than any other class of men. Their influence is unbounded. Their opportunities for directing practiced reforms and progressive developments impose many obligations. In acknowledgment of the many complimentary indorsements and favors which DR. DRANK has received from Clergymen in behalf of his PLANTATION BITTERS, he has directed his Agents. Messrs. BARNES & CO., No. 202 Broadway, N.Y., to present a bottle gratis, to every Clergyman who may personally call during the remainder of this year, 1863.

abstract: The Provost-Marshal having received authority to raise five colored regiments, has given permission to Mr. R.D. KENNEY, whose headquarters are at No. 178 Prince-street, to recruit a regiment. Mr. KENNY is acting under the auspices of the Committee for Colored Volunteers, appointed at the late mass meeting at Clinton Hall, called for the purpose of taking the matter into consideration. This corps will be known as the New-York. Colored regiment of National Volunteers, and those desirous of aiding it, by contributions or influentially, can do so by applying or sending to the treasurer, Mr. JAMES RODGERS, NO. 421 Broadway, who will furnish them with the requisite instructions.

abstract: Speaker COLFAX is busily engaged in making up his Committees. There is a great pressure for positions on the Committee of Ways and Means. It will be selected with unusual care. Mr. COLFAX is alive to the importance of placing upon it the best financial
lead_paragraph: Speaker COLFAX is busily engaged in making up his Committees. There is a great pressure for positions on the Committee of Ways and Means. It will be selected with unusual care. Mr. COLFAX is alive to the importance of placing upon it the best financial and business talent in the House. It is quite probable that HENRY G. STEVENS, elected as a Democrat, and conceded to be one of the most skillful bankers in the City of New-York, will be offered the place on the Committee made vacant by ERASTUS CORNING's resignation; that STEVENS will retain his position as Chairman.

abstract: -- The report of the Naval Ordinance Bureau, which accompanies that of the Secretary of the Navy, is full of interest to the country, as showing the remarkable progress made within the last two years in the fabrication of guns and projectiles. The statistics showing the increase in the manufacture of the heaviest class of ordnance are worthy of especial note. So rapidly have the resources of the country, both public and private, been developed, that the department, with all its great demands, has never been restricted in its supply of the proper guns or projectiles. We recommend everybody to read the report; for now that we are becoming a military nation, the question of ordnance is one for discussion in every drawing-room and in all polite circles.

abstract: President LINCOLN delivers himself, in this document, with all his characteristic clearness and simplicity. The rhetorical flourishes and sentimental generalities, with which the later Presidents were accustomed to stuff out their State papers of this class,
lead_paragraph: President LINCOLN delivers himself, in this document, with all his characteristic clearness and simplicity. The rhetorical flourishes and sentimental generalities, with which the later Presidents were accustomed to stuff out their State papers of this class, have no place here. It is the shortest Message we have had for a generation; and yet, this year has been the most eventful since the Government began. There never has been one thousandth part so much to spend words upon, and yet there has never been so little indulgence in words. ABRAHAM LINCOLN is one of the few men who believe that words stand for things; he economizes them accordingly.

abstract: New-York; Isaac Newton, steamship, verdict
lead_paragraph: Between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon one of the most fearful and destructive conflagrations, which for many years past has occurred to the shipping in our harbor, took place on the North River. The fire broke out on a barge named the Cora Campbell, lying at the foot of Perry-street. It was laden with hay, and other combustible material, belonging to the Government, and was about being towed out into the stream when the flames were discovered. The wind at the time was blowing a gale. Those of our readers, who yesterday afternoon had occasion to walk the streets of New-York, can appreciate the remark when we say there was a "stiff breeze." On the river, in the neighborhood of the fire, where the wind had an unobstructed sweep, its force and effect were far greater. The alarm was promptly given for the Third District, and the firemen rallied speedily around the scene. Before any streams of water could be brought to bear on the barge, the flames had extended to several boats and barges lying alongside. The most of these were loaded with hay, straw, wood, grain and other combustible material. The gale swept the flames from one to another of these craft with great rapidity, and the numerous boats, barges, schooners, brigs, &c., which lined the shore for the distance of about four blocks down the river were soon enveloped in the fiery element. The spectacle about this time became highly exciting. The firemen of the Third District were, as we have said, on hand. They worked manfully amid the flame and smoke, and at times they had to throw themselves face downward upon bales of hay and boxes in order to get their breath. Although from more than a score of hose large streams of water were playing on the burning boats and their contents, the fire was spreading with such alarming rapidity that the order was given to ring the bells for the Fourth District for more assistance.

abstract: The Command of; Gen. Meade
lead_paragraph: There is a report, which is not unlikely to prove true, that Gen. MEADE is to be removed from the command of the Army of the Potomac, and Gen. PLEASONTON put in his place; the reason being, we suppose, the failure of the former in the recent movement against LEE. We shall regret this extremely, for several reasons. We believe, in the first place, that no army could fail to be injured, and seriously injured, by such frequent changes of commanders as have taken place in the Army of the Potomac; the General's confidence in himself, and the soldier's confidence in the General, are both weakened by it. Each General who steps into the vacant place is, of course, warned by the fall of his predecessors of the insecurity of his position. He feels that he is only on his trial, and that the presumptions of the Government, and it may be of the public, are against him. He knows that the least error in judgment will probably lead to his dismissal. If under these circumstances, he did not become over-nervous and over-sensible of his responsibility, he would be either more or less than human; and being nervous, he naturally becomes timid. Feeling satisfied that he will have to bear the whole burden of the blame of any reverse that may occur, he shrinks, and naturally shrinks, from running any risk; and at last, by way of being perfectly secure against miscarriage, he refuses to do anything in which miscarriage can possibly occur, and this, in war, means total inaction. Now, we will not say no modest man, with ordinary doubts of his own genius, but no man with ordinary self-respect, likes to accept any position, however high, which is surrounded by drawbacks of this kind. Nobody can do his best if he is conscious that his superiors are watching his work with hostile eyes, and are ready to make the first indication of moral or mental infirmity the signal for his dismissal. A generous confidence, and generous appreciation of difficulties on the part of the Government, is absolutely necessary to secure the display of his highest qualities on the part of the General. We do not mean by this that a blockhead is to be allowed to blunder on month after month out of one scrape into another as long as a regiment remains to follow him: but we do think that a man like Gen. MEADE, who won a great battle within three days of his assuming the command of the army, and who is the first officer opposed to LEE who has proved himself his match in marching and manoeuvring, is entitled to more than six months' trial.

abstract: Post-office; Postmaster-General Blair's Report
lead_paragraph: The duties of the Postmaster-General in the management of his department do not furnish him the occasion or opportunity for any of those displays of eloquence and statesmanship, or any of those great and striking expositions of gigantic operations which is furnished by other departments of the Government, as the State, Finance, War and Navy. Yet the management and working of the Post-office Department are matters of profound and perpetual interest to every inhabitant of the United States. And the duties of its conduct are such as require a high order of administrative ability, and conscientious, laborious and ceaseless devotion. These qualifications are found to an eminent degree in the present head of the department.

abstract: Interior Department; Secretary Usher's Report
lead_paragraph: The Report of the Secretary of the Interior, which we present in full, is a clear and comprehensive document. Secretary USHER reviews the operations of his Bureau in the fullest detail, and, in general, shows very satisfactory results, accompanied by sensible suggestions. One of these suggestions is that a moderate tax be levied on the product of the gold mines, which are now unburdened in that respect. Indian affairs are reviewed at length, and the setting apart of new and larger reservations is urged; the Pension Bureau is rapidly increasing in its number of pensioners, which now reach 13,659 from the army, and 1,132 from the navy, requiring an annual outlay of fully $1,500,000 per annum; the Patent Office has issued nearly four thousand patents during the past year; the Government Asylum for the Insane has greatly enlarged its sphere of usefulness by affording a refuge for many of the unfortunates of the war, and the Institution for the Deaf, Dumb and Blind has been managed with great success; good progress has been made on the Capitol extension, and nearly all the works of art designed to embellish the Capitol building have been completed and put in their places. In reference to the African Slave-trade, the Secretary says not a siugle vessel is known to have been fitted out for that purpose in our own waters during the past year. An indisposition on the part of the negroes to colonize is noted, and in view of the new policy of the Government toward them it is now questionable whether the effort should be kept up. It is suggested that thousands of free colored laborers may be profitably employed in the construction of the Pacific Railroad. The establishment of a Bureau of National Statistics is earnestly recommended, because it will contribute to the advancement of all the public interests -- commerce, agriculture, finance, &c. -- and enable the Government to permanently preserve the experience and statistical knowledge it has gained. The rest of the Report treats mainly of affairs in the District of Columbia, all of which are represented as in commendable shape.

abstract: -- The library of the late JOHN MCCLENAHAN, of the New-York Herald, comprising 2,000 volumes of ancient and modern literature, selected with unusual care, will be sold at auction, by BANGS, MERWIN & Co., Nos. 594 and 596 Broadway, commencing this evening. The catalogue embraces many of the choicest works, and in Irish history especially, the collection is celebrated as being one of the best of the kind perhaps in the country. The sale will occupy two evenings, at least.

abstract: We have from Washington the news that the two armies in Virginia are in a state of quiescence, MEADE on the Rappahannock and LEE on the Rapidan. The pickets are friendly, and bushwhackers are again plenty. The report of the
lead_paragraph: We have from Washington the news that the two armies in Virginia are in a state of quiescence, MEADE on the Rappahannock and LEE on the Rapidan. The pickets are friendly, and bushwhackers are again plenty. The report of the removal of Gen. MEADE is again revived, with a still stronger degree of positiveness. The choice as to his successor is said lie between Gens. HOOKER and THOMAS, the President and Secretary CHASE preferring the former, and Secretary STANTON undecided between the two. The army is to be reorganized.

abstract: War Department; Ordnance Bureau Report; War Department; Secretary Stanton's Report
snippet: War Department; Ordnance Bureau Report; War Department; Secretary Stanton's Report
lead_paragraph: Secretary STANTON has issued a terse and business-like document. He opens with a brief glance at the operations of the year, and congratulates the country upon our military achievements, the brilliancy of which he says, has not been surpassed in any age. The forces of the National Government are now firmly planted on the soil of every rebel State. The question of the exchange of prisoners is reviewed, but no new light is shed upon the subject. The statements regarding the bad faith and violation of cartel on the part of the enemy are very plainly made, and the case is now fully understood. The Secretary confirms the statement lately made by Gen. HITCHCOCK that we have now over forty thousand prisoners of war in our hands, while the enemy hold but thirteen thousand of ours. Because the enemy demand that we shall liberate our possessions for theirs, and because they refuse to deliver up the colored soldiers and their white officers, the exchange is suspended. Mr. STANTON says, in substance, that our Government declines to furnish the rebels with a fresh army of forty thousand men, on their own terms.

abstract: Navy Department; Secretary Welles' Report
lead_paragraph: Secretary WELLES' report this year, like that of last year, is of very great length; but less space is taken up in this than was in that, by detailed reports of the operations of the various naval expeditions, as he judiciously leaves the officers themselves to narrate their labors and achievements. After referring in general terms to the arduous labors of his department in enforcing a blockade covering a distance of over three thousand five hundred miles, and carrying on naval operations upon the rivers and other internal waters of the Southern States, he reviews rapidly the different squadrons into which our naval force is divided -- the North Atlantic Squadron, the South Atlantic Squadron, the Eastern Gulf Squadron, the Western Gulf Squadron; the Mississippi Squadron, the Pacific Squadron, the Potomac Flotilla, and the vessels in the East India and China Seas -- and shows that each of them has done important work. An exhibit of the present strength of our navy, as compared with last year, is furnished, and an exhibit of its prospective strength when the vessels under construction shall be completed. Everybody in the land will certainly study these tables with minute attention. The Secretary discusses various desirable improvements in naval vessels, and, we are glad to see, refers more than once to speed as a necessity of them. He again urges, at length and strongly, the necessity for a new Navy-yard on a large scale. Great delay has arisen from the inability of our public yards and shops to execute the necessary repair and refitment of vessels. He also refers to the fact that while we have several Navy yards for building wooden vessels, the Government possesses not a single yard and establishment for constructing those of iron, nor even for making plates and shafting; and says that there are no parties in this country fully prepared to build iron vessels of the magnitude and description required. Beside the necessity of a fit Navy-yard on the Atlantic seaboard, he again urges the expediency of establishing a naval depot, yard and foundry at some accessible and suitable point on one of the rivers in the valley of the Mississippi.

abstract: Report of the Commissioner
lead_paragraph: The Report of the Commissioner on Indian Affairs is full of interest, but does not exhibit the condition of Indian affairs in a very favorable light. In Oregon the Indians west of the Cascade Mountains are at peace, but east of those mountains they are all engaged in active hostilities. In California the condition is not satisfactory. The reservations are nearly worthless. The mining operations of the whites are constantly encroaching upon the rights of the Indians, which gives rise to frequent hostilities. The Commissioner urges Congress to harmonize the conflicting interests of the Indians and whites. In New-Mexico the Indians are mostly hostile, and their government is very expensive, $3,000,000 being fruitlessly expended every year, without any adequate results. In Colorado there have been slight disturbances, due only to small, roving bands. The Indians are much divided, and it has been found very difficult to make any general binding treaty with them. The Cheyennes and Arapahoes are especially nomadic.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Etna, from Liverpool, and Bremen from Southampton, at this port yesterday, we have one day's later news from Europe. Earl RUSSELL would not withdraw from the British Cabinet. England has announced a courteous declination of the invitation to the French Emperor's Congress, and it was believed other Governments would follow its example. The Schleswig-Holstein question continued to create uneasiness. Austria and Prussia were said to have raised objections to the claims of the Duke of Augustenburg. It was thought Russia would interfere. It was further said that Prussia had agreed to send troops into Holstein immediately. The London Times admits the possibility of a successful insurrection in Holstein, but demands that there shall be no invasion on the part of Prussia or the German Powers. Mr. COBDEN made another speech on American affairs, on the 24th of November, in which he expressed renewed faith in the success of the National arms. The rebel correspondent of the London Times writing from Chickamauga Oct. 8, speaks of that battle as being the most fruitless victory of modern times, and the blame of which is directly imputed to Gen. BRAGG. Cotton closed buoyant and a trifle higher. Breadstuffs firm and unchanging.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Etna, from Liverpool, and Bremen from Southampton, at this port yesterday, we have one day's later news from Europe. Earl RUSSELL would not withdraw from the British Cabinet. England has announced a courteous declination of the invitation to the French Emperor's Congress, and it was believed other Governments would follow its example. The Schleswig-Holstein question continued to create uneasiness. Austria and Prussia were said to have raised objections to the claims of the Duke of Augustenburg. It was thought Russia would interfere. It was further said that Prussia had agreed to send troops into Holstein immediately. The London Times admits the possibility of a successful insurrection in Holstein, but demands that there shall be no invasion on the part of Prussia or the German Powers. Mr. COBDEN made another speech on American affairs, on the 24th of November, in which he expressed renewed faith in the success of the National arms. The rebel correspondent of the London Times writing from Chickamauga Oct. 8, speaks of that battle as being the most fruitless victory of modern times, and the blame of which is directly imputed to Gen. BRAGG. Cotton closed buoyant and a trifle higher. Breadstuffs firm and unchanging.

abstract: The President's Plan; His Plan of Reconstruction
snippet: The President's Plan; His Plan of Reconstruction
lead_paragraph: We long ago took decided ground against all schemes of provincializing the rebel States -- maintaining that they were radically wrong in principle, and would prove calamitous in result. The President's plan of restoring our Federal system to its normal operation, therefore, finds us already thoroughly committed to it in every essential particular. But, apart from our own foregone conclusions, we cannot help feeling the convincing power of the mere enunciation of the President's programme. Feasibility, justice, consistency, and security, are so patently met by it, in the fullest measure, that it challenges at once the acquiescence of all truly loyal men. Of course Faction will bark at it. It is the very nature of Faction to fly at any public good. But this manifestation of instinct will only be corroborative of the intrinsic excellence of the plan. There has not been a great efficacious measure in this war whose first appearance was not assailed thus. Could this prove an exception, we should at once surmise there must be something wrong about it.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different department from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European sews, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Richmond journals to the 9th have been received at Fortress Monroe. The reason given for the raising of the siege of Knoxville by LONGSTREET is, that BURNSIDE had received heavy reinforcements. The rebel loss in the late assault upon the city was 600. The failure of the movement is charged to the issuing of a forged order recalling ANDERSON's brigade. A body of our cavalry is reported to have revisited Ringgold, Ga., on the 7th inst., and to have been driven away by GRIMSBY's troopers. From Charleston Harbor the only new fact is, that GILLMORE refrains from wasting more ammunition against Sumter's ruins, and is intrenching his Morris Island works to render them safer in case the rebels should advance upon them from James Island.

abstract: Hitchcock, Gen.; Further Vindication of United States Government on Exchanges
snippet: Hitchcock, Gen.; Further Vindication of United States Government on Exchanges
lead_paragraph: When the Secretary of the Treasury made his last annual report, there was a more pressing obligation upon him for the display of financial ability and far-reaching statesmanship than on the present occasion. The duty then devolved upon him, by reason of the peculiar condition of the country, in respect to the great rebellion, and the unsettled question of the volume of national legal tender currency, required for the future conduct of the war, was alike complicated and perplexing. He met the emergency by a statesmanlike review of the resources of the nation, and an urgent recommendation that the direct issue of legal tender notes should be confined to a very moderate increase on the previous aggregate of two hundred and fifty millions authorized by Congress at its preceding session. For the rest he preferred to rely upon loans, temporary or permanent, bearing a rate of interest not to exceed 6 per cent. per annum. Coupled with these views he again submitted -- and, it must be confessed, in advance of the state of financial sentiment on the subject -- his plan for a National Free-Banking system, secured by the pledge of the Public Stocks of the United States, which, by a fair distribution through the States, would give a uniform national circulation of three hundred millions, after the general return of the country to specie payments, and after the emergency which gave rise to the more direct legal tender issues of the Government shall have passed away.

abstract: In the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, a resolution was adopted asking the Street Commissioner to estimate and report the probable cost of replacing the piers on the North River recently destroyed by fire. The Comptroller reported that of the $8,126,350 07 appropriated for 1863, $6,733,340 92 had been expended on the 1st inst. ...
lead_paragraph: In the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, a resolution was adopted asking the Street Commissioner to estimate and report the probable cost of replacing the piers on the North River recently destroyed by fire. The Comptroller reported that of the $8,126,350 07 appropriated for 1863, $6,733,340 92 had been expended on the 1st inst. -- leaving a balance of $1,393,009 15 unexpended at that date. The Board concurred in adopting the resolution to pay Mr. STETSON, of the Astor, for the Russian banquet, and also for entertainments to regiments that returned from the seat of war last Summer. The amounts of the several bills were fully stated in yesterday's TIMES. The Board adjourned to 1 P.M. to-day.

lead_paragraph: The Army of the Potomac will be immediately reorganized and made larger and better in every way than it has been at any former period. Its chief command will probably be tendered to either HOOKER or THOMAS. It is believed that THOMAS would prefer remaining where he is HOOKER's reputation, since the battle of Lookout Mountain, stands higher than ever. He is considered here, by some folks, as the next commander of the Army of the Potomac. The present corps commanders, with one exception, will be relieved.

abstract: The Democratic  Party in Congress does not make a very harmonious beginning. They failed to unite on any candidate for Speaker, and broke up into half a dozen squads, the largest numbering 52, (forty less than were necessary to a choice,)...
lead_paragraph: -- The Democratic Party in Congress does not make a very harmonious beginning. They failed to unite on any candidate for Speaker, and broke up into half a dozen squads, the largest numbering 52, (forty less than were necessary to a choice,) and the smallest consisting of Mr. BENJAMIN WOOD. This was a sad falling off from the sanguine expectations in which they indulged at one time of being able to elect a Speaker of their own -- and does not hold forth any strong promise of union and harmony in their own ranks during the session.

abstract: Gen. Halleck's Official Report of Campaigns of 1863; Synopsis; Official Report of 1863 Campaigns, Synopsis; Gen. Halleck's Official Report. Synopsis
snippet: Gen. Halleck's Official Report of Campaigns of 1863; Synopsis; Official Report of 1863 Campaigns, Synopsis; Gen. Halleck's Official Report. Synopsis
lead_paragraph: Gen. HALLECK opens his very lengthy report by taking up the Army of the Potomac at the time Gen. McCLELLAN was relieved by Gen. BURNSIDE, at Warrenton, Va., on the 7th of November, 1862. Gen. HALLECK urged Gen. BURNSIDE to continue his pursuit of LEE toward Richmond, but Gen. BURNSIDE declined, desiring to move to Falmouth, but finally consented to cross the Rappahannock by the upper fords and occupy Fredericksburgh. Gen. BURNSIDE's final march to, and occupation of Falmouth, was never authorized or approved by the authorities in Washington. The plan which the President assented to was to cross the river by the upper fords and occupy the town. This Gen. BURNSIDE did not do. Gen. SUMNER asked permission to do so when he arrived at Falmouth, the river being fordable, but it was refused. In the meantime LEE got there and intrenched. The delay of the pontoons, which should have been at Falmouth when Gen. BURNSIDE arrived there. Is explained by the fact that instead of being in Washington, where they were supposed to be, they were at Berlin and Harper's Ferry, and had not been moved, because the officers in charge did not receive Gen. BURNSIDE's order to move them to Washington. The battle of Fredericksburgh occurred Dec. 13. Through an alleged misinterpretation of orders, Gen. FRANKLIN's attack on the left was only a reconnoissance in force, and the attack of SUMNER and HOOKER on the right was unsupported. We were repulsed with a loss of 1,138 killed, 9,105 wounded, and 2,078 missing. Gen. BURNSIDE has never made any official report of these operations. He says:

abstract: The United States vs. Ten Cases containing Calfskins. -- This was an action brought to forfeit the foods for an alleged fraudulent undervaluation. When the goods were imported by the claimant, Mr. Didier, a case or two of them were advanced in value by the appraisers at the Custom-house to such an amount that the Government seized the invoice. The question turned on the correct value of the goods, as to which evidence was given on both sides.

abstract: -- It will be seen by a correspondence which we publish elsewhere, that the public has escaped the annoyance of a verbal debate on the favorite crotchets of the ultra Abolitionists. Rev. Mr. CHEEVER invited Mr. BEECHER to discuss with him a variety of propositions on the subject of Slavery, -- proposing on his own part to prove that under the Constitution it was the highest duty of the United States Government to interfere against Slavery in the States. Mr. BEECHER very sensibly and properly declines any such discussion. He reminds Mr. CHEEVER that he edits a newspaper, and can urge his own views at pleasure in its columns, -- and that as he himself edits another, he can comment on those views whenever he thinks it worth while. No good could possibly result from such a debate as Dr. CHEEVER proposed. The celebrity of the disputants would draw a large audience, and their intellectual ability would, doubtless, interest their hearers. But practically nothing would, be settled and no real good accomplished. These questions are not to be decided, when we come to the practical readjustment of our political affairs, by the niceties of metaphysical debate. They will be taken up by the common sense of the people at large, and such disposition will be made of them as the substantial welfare of the country may require. Times of civil commotion and of revolution are always very inviting for extremists and fanatics of every sort -- but there never was a time when they were likely to do more hurt, or less good, than now.

abstract: Diplomatic Correspondence, Lhuys and Mr. Dayton on Mexican Affairs
snippet: Diplomatic Correspondence, Lhuys and Mr. Dayton on Mexican Affairs
lead_paragraph: In the collection of French diplomatic papers just published by the Government twelve documents concern American affairs. The first three are the sequel of those inserted in the collection for 1862, and give the conclusion of the negotiations on the proposal of mediation which emanated from the French Government. The first, addressed by M. DROUYN DE LHUYS, on Jan. 9, to M. MERCIER, the French Minister at Washington, dwells on the wish to see the North enter upon pacific conferences with the South; another, dated Feb. 26, is equally urgent on the same subject. Then comes an exchange of dispatches on the Mexican question. M. MERCIER writes, on April 3, that the Government of Washington will avoid giving France any cause of discontent. Then comes a very energetic letter of M. DROUYN DE LHUYS to M. MERCIER, protesting against a letter of Mr. ADAMS, the American Minister in London, and some dispatches of M. MERCIER, which relieve the Washington Cabinet of the responsibility for the same. Another dispatch of M. DROUYN DE LHUYS (Sept. 13,) gives an explanation of French policy in Mexico; France has not desired a cession either of Texas or Louisiana, or of any other territory in America. As to the recognition of the South, said to be the price of those concessions, nothing has been decided on the subject, and consequently no treaty concluded. The following is the text of the dispatch.

abstract: Review of Gen. Meade's Late Campaign; Late Campaign, Review of
snippet: Review of Gen. Meade's Late Campaign; Late Campaign, Review of
lead_paragraph: It is essential to the best interests of the country that the public should at once be made thoroughly acquainted with all the facts connected with the late movements of this army -- the many obstacles which presented themselves to the Commanding-General, and the frequent disappointments to which he was subjected from the commencement of the march to the final withdrawal of his forces to this side of the Rapidan. To faithfully place these facts before the public, in order that it may approve or disapprove with an intelligent judgment, is the object of this communication.

abstract: Chanuka, Jews, Masquerade Ball
lead_paragraph: A successful masquerade is an incident in the records of a metropolis, upon which chroniclers may well dilate with pride and satisfaction. The difficulties naturally attending an entertainment of this character have probably deterred the usually enterprising Gothamites from naturalizing the bal masque here, as has been the case with pleasure-loving Paris. They say New-York resembles Paris, yet where, among the many particulars in which a metropolis should excel provincial cities, and in which we claim especial credit for our rising town, do we observe this delightful institution?

abstract: Two days' later advices from Europe reach us by the steamship Canada, which arrived at Halifax, N.S., yesterday afternoon. The news is interesting. The rebel agents in London have recently purchased four steam vessels, which were formerly British men-of war, and three of them are said to be refitting in the Thames, to be used as privateers. The fourth, which has been rechristened the Rappahannock, left Sheerness on the 26th ult. and arrived the same day at Calais, where she was taken in charge by the French Customs Officers, who detained her, however, a very short time. She is pierced for eight guns. The privateer Georgia was at Cherbourg repairing. The American residents in London duly observed the day appointed by President LINCOLN for National Thanksgiving, and a grand banquet, presided over by Hon. ROBERT J. WALKER, was given at St. James' Hall, where Minister ADAMS Was among the speakers. The Court of Exchequer were to give judgment in the case of the Alexandra on the 7th inst. The formal reply of Russia to the proposition for a European Congress was received on the 26th, and it is denied that she demands that the programme of the Congress shall be drawn up. It is hinted that England's refusal to take part in the Congress will lead France to form a new and intimate alliance with some other nation. The French deficit, owing to the Mexican and Cochin-China wars, is estimated at Â£10,000,000, and it was said that a loan of 300,000,000 francs would be proposed. The agitation in the German States was unabated.
lead_paragraph: Two days' later advices from Europe reach us by the steamship Canada, which arrived at Halifax, N.S., yesterday afternoon. The news is interesting. The rebel agents in London have recently purchased four steam vessels, which were formerly British men-of war, and three of them are said to be refitting in the Thames, to be used as privateers. The fourth, which has been rechristened the Rappahannock, left Sheerness on the 26th ult. and arrived the same day at Calais, where she was taken in charge by the French Customs Officers, who detained her, however, a very short time. She is pierced for eight guns. The privateer Georgia was at Cherbourg repairing. The American residents in London duly observed the day appointed by President LINCOLN for National Thanksgiving, and a grand banquet, presided over by Hon. ROBERT J. WALKER, was given at St. James' Hall, where Minister ADAMS Was among the speakers. The Court of Exchequer were to give judgment in the case of the Alexandra on the 7th inst. The formal reply of Russia to the proposition for a European Congress was received on the 26th, and it is denied that she demands that the programme of the Congress shall be drawn up. It is hinted that England's refusal to take part in the Congress will lead France to form a new and intimate alliance with some other nation. The French deficit, owing to the Mexican and Cochin-China wars, is estimated at 10,000,000, and it was said that a loan of 300,000,000 francs would be proposed. The agitation in the German States was unabated.

abstract: Order on Negroes in Virginia and North Carolina
snippet: Order on Negroes in Virginia and North Carolina
lead_paragraph: GENERAL ORDERS, No. 46. -- The recruitment of colored troops has become the settled purpose of the Government. It is therefore the duty of every officer and soldier to aid in carrying out that purpose, by every proper means, irrespective of personal predilection. To do this effectually, the former condition of the blacks; their change of relation; the new rights acquired by them; the new obligations imposed upon them; the duty of the Government to them; the great stake they have in the war; and the claims their ignorance, and the helplessness of their women and children, make upon each of us, who hold a higher grade in social and political life, must all be carefully considered.

abstract: izes, at this present moment, the annoyances and responsibilities of his position. A mass meeting is held every day and evening before his residence, East Fourteenth-street, and smaller, but not less interested or persistent efforts to "make things square," in the way of outside gatherings, are visible in and about the effices and residences of all those of his friends who took a prominent interest for him against Tammany in the canvass.
lead_paragraph: It is quite probable that the Mayor elect realizes, at this present moment, the annoyances and responsibilities of his position. A mass meeting is held every day and evening before his residence, East Fourteenth-street, and smaller, but not less interested or persistent efforts to "make things square," in the way of outside gatherings, are visible in and about the effices and residences of all those of his friends who took a prominent interest for him against Tammany in the canvass. It is astounding how Mr. GUNTHER's majority has increased at a rate not according to count, since the night of Dec. 1, 1863. Men who were never before known to take to themselves the credit of departing from their customary glories of "always supporting the regular, or 'ring' nominations," now openly and hilariously boast that they betted upon, and worked and voted for the "honest and indefatigable Kriss" from sunrise even unto sunset. They further declare, with a most attractive modesty, that he could not have been elected without their aid. The fact is, so bewilderingly unendurable is the pressure, that C. GODFREY GUNTHER, the irrepressible depoiter of BOOLE and BLUNT's anticipated honors, has been compelled to declare himself "out of town" to avoid it. Although to a certain degree, not unexpected, yet it has exceeded all expectations, and neither mentally or physically could man stand it. It is rumored, as an excuse for his disappearance, that he is perfectly worn out by the labors of the campaign and the preliminary duties attendant on his success. It is further rumored that he has deputed. In consequence, a committee of three from the McKeon General Committee, to listen to, probe into, and share in the decision on, such applications for place and pelf as have been and will be preferred by the most active and influential outside members of the Sinclair House organization. It is also rumored that the head man of this Committee, very properly, is Hon. JOHN MCIKEON, the father of the new -- or restorer of the old: -- Democracy, and that he, too, has suddenly and imperatively found it necessary to seize his carpet-bag and hurry to Auburn, to try a long pending law-suit there; in which he was some time since retained as counsel, or at some future time will be.

abstract: The New-England Society of this City will celebrate their fifty-eighth anniversary by a public dinner at the Astor House, on the 22d inst. It is understood that the following distinguished gentlemen have already accepted invitations to be present as guests on the occasion, namely: Senator John P. Hale, of New-Hampshire; Hon. Henry Winter Davis, of Maryland; Rev. Henry Ward Beecher, Hon. James T. Brady, Major-Gen. John A. Dix, Rev. Dr. Francis Vinton, Prof. Roswell D. Hitchcock, Mayor Opdyke, Commodore Meade, Rev. Dr. Weston. The occasion promises to be one of unusual interest, and the gathering a numerous one.
lead_paragraph: The New-England Society of this City will celebrate their fifty-eighth anniversary by a public dinner at the Astor House, on the 22d inst. It is understood that the following distinguished gentlemen have already accepted invitations to be present as guests on the occasion, namely: Senator John P. Hale, of New-Hampshire; Hon. Henry Winter Davis, of Maryland; Rev. Henry Ward Beecher, Hon. James T. Brady, Major-Gen. John A. Dix, Rev. Dr. Francis Vinton, Prof. Roswell D. Hitchcock, Mayor Opdyke, Commodore Meade, Rev. Dr. Weston. The occasion promises to be one of unusual interest, and the gathering a numerous one.

abstract: We give this morning a letter from a correspondent in the Army of the Potomac, which brings to light the authentic facts in the late abortive campaign of Gen. MEADE. The writer's opportunities for obtaining information are of a character not inferior to the highest official authorities, and his statements may be implicitly relied upon.
lead_paragraph: We give this morning a letter from a correspondent in the Army of the Potomac, which brings to light the authentic facts in the late abortive campaign of Gen. MEADE. The writer's opportunities for obtaining information are of a character not inferior to the highest official authorities, and his statements may be implicitly relied upon. The public hopes and expectations on the opening of the campaign had been wrought up to a very high degree, and the popular disappointment at its termination was correspondingly great. We ourselves took occasion to give a very decided expression to the feeling which was entertained by every patriot and soldier. The preposterous statement that was put forth that the whole campaign, with all its gigantic preparations and manoeuvres, was intended as but a diversion in favor of Gen. BURNSIDE in East Tennessee, could be credited by no intelligent man. Our correspondent shows that Gen. MEADE had a purpose altogether different from this. His purpose was precisely what the public understood it to be when it was announced that the Army of the Potomac had crossed the Rapidan and taken up its line of march southward. It was to fight LEE and destroy his army, as GRANT had fought BRAGG and destroyed that army.
headline: {'main': "Gen. Meade's Late Campaign.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Gen. Meade's Late Campaign.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: JEFFERSON DAVIS has sent a very important message to the Confederate Congress, which began its sessions in Richmond on Monday last. It is quite as interesting here as it will be there, and we give it, therefore, at length in another part of this morning's TIMES. It can scarcely be called a cheerful document, but it certainly shows, to a very high degree...
lead_paragraph: JEFFERSON DAVIS has sent a very important message to the Confederate Congress, which began its sessions in Richmond on Monday last. It is quite as interesting here as it will be there, and we give it, therefore, at length in another part of this morning's TIMES. It can scarcely be called a cheerful document, but it certainly shows, to a very high degree, the courage of desperation. Mr. DAVIS does everything in his power to put a bold face on the prospects of the rebellion; but we doubt whether he will succeed in inspiring the great mass of his own people with any great amount of hope in its fortunes.

abstract: Chester W. Chapin et al. vs. The Propeller Hypodame. -- This was a libel filed by the owners of the schooner Chester W. Chapin, to recover the damages occasioned to her by a collision with the propeller on the Hudson River, about off Dunderberg Point, on the morning of Dec. 1, 1862, before daylight. The night was dark. The schooner bound down the river and the propeller up. The wind was light from the southeast, and the schooner was west of the middle of the river, heading southwest, moving very slowly. She saw the steamer's light just after the latter rounded Verplanck's Point. The steamer after rounding the point passed a tow, going to the eastward of it. As she neared the Race, she saw another tow going down the river, and her master determined to go to the east of that also, but on discovering the lights of a vessel at anchor to the east, he concluded to go to the west, and starboarded his wheel for that purpose. As he got her head turned he heard a hail, but saw nothing; ordered the pilot to slow, then to stop, then ported his wheel, and then the head-light shone on the schooner's sails and disclosed her just ahead, but the collision could not then be avoided. The Captain was in the wheelhouse looking out, but had no lookout forward.
lead_paragraph: Chester W. Chapin et al. vs. The Propeller Hypodame. -- This was a libel filed by the owners of the schooner Chester W. abstract: Dates by private letters from Guayaquil are to the 15th November. Great indignation was felt throughout the Republic at the "insults heaped upon it and President GARCIA MORENO by Gen. MOSQUERA," Provisional President of the United States of Colombia. Congress, after authorising President MORENO to declare war against us, closed its sittings on the 24th of October. The newspapers are full of acrimonious official correspondence on both sides, which is but a repetition of that already furnished you. There does not seem to be the least chance of avoiding a war. In fact, active operations may be said to have already commenced.

abstract: Murder of Women and Children in a Cab
snippet: Murder of Women and Children in a Cab
lead_paragraph: Paris has no monopoly of mysteries. Nothing that EUGENE SUE has imagined can surpass the story of the triple murder in a four-wheeled cab at the door of a public house, in a crowded thoroughfare, on a busy Saturday night. If there was a Morgue in London, what would have been the sensations of the public at the exhibition of these three bodies, unowned and unknown, taken out of a hackney carriage by a Policeman and a Surgeon! It does, however, speak well for society that this murder should have been discovered by the simplest and most natural of means -- by the gap which the victims left in their own little circle of friends. At any rate, a mother and two children were not made away with without being missed. The poor creatures had their own place in the society of this city, vast as it is, and when that place was empty suspicion was aroused. But for this, it is terrible to think how complete the mystery might have remained. The murderer had time to put hundreds of miles between himself and the scene of his crime. The contents of the cab, strange to say, would have furnished no clue to the perpetrator of the atrocity. There lay three dead bodies, with the luggage which women and children might carry for a short journey -- a small bundle, a leather box containing a few eatables for the children on the road, shawls, &c. Yet it happened that in all this there was nothing to put the Police on the track. Only one article of linen was marked, and that not with the initials of the owner. No accurate impression had been left even of the appearance of the murderer. The cabman thought he had worn a moustache, but it seems that he was mistaken. Nothing led to the discovery except the published description of the bodies, which answered all the purpose of those horrible exposures in the Morgue. The neighbors of the victims recognized the sketch, the more readily, perhaps, from the juxtaposition of the three figures, and then the truth became known. Upward of a century ago a most barbarous murder was discovered by similar means, though after a shocking fashion. A woman killed her husband, cut off his head to prevent the identification of the body, and threw it into the Thames. There it was found floating the next morning, and employed to bring the guilt home to the offender. But in those days there were no organs of publicity disseminating information through every grade of society, and so the magistrates extemporized, as it were, a Morgue for the occasion. They ordered the head to be washed and combed, and stuck upon a pole in the churchyard of St. Margaret, Westminster. By the side of the ghastly object was stationed an officer charged to observe the countenances of all who came to gaze on it, and arrest those who evinced any suspicious emotion. It was not in that primitive fashion, however, that evidence was obtained, but in the course of a day or two the neighbours of the victim did recognise his features, and the woman expiated her crime, according to the law of those days, at the stake. We must now observe that this is not the only, perhaps not the most extraordinary story of mystery lately disclosed. In the middle of the Summer, while happy tourists were enjoying themselves, and great towns were half emptied of their industrious inmates, a discovery was made which almost exceeds in horror the spectacle at the bottom of that railway cab. In a small house at Wolverhampton the corpse of a man was found lying on a bed in an upstairs room. The head had been frightfully battered, and was soaking in a pool of blood. The body had been coated with tar, for the obvious purpose of retarding decomposition, but so much time had elapsed before it was found, and the heat of the weather had been so great, that the corrective had failed, and the sight was a dreadful one. There was no living occupant of the house, the door had been fast locked, and was broken open by the Police. Exactly at the same time, in another house, also unoccupied, at Dudley, half a dozen miles off, was found the corpse of a woman. This body, too, lay on a bed, shockingly decomposed, but the dress and the hands of the woman were stained with tar, and in the pocket of her dress was discovered the key of the house which contained the body of the man. A laudanum bottle seemed in this case to tell the tale of suicide, but was the suicide the sequel of a murder? That was the natural inference, but beyond such inference the conclusion could not be carried. It was proved that the woman had once cohabited with the man; that she had quarreled with him, and that she had cohabited with others. These revelations suggested a belief that she had been at least an accomplice in the murder, and that she had destroyed her own life afterward, but no proofs of the facts could be obtained, and an open verdict of the Coroner's jury terminated the case of the Wolverhampton and Dudley mysteries. But how many mysteries are there without even that much of a clue to their solution? Did the reader observe what appeared in our successive reports of this deed of murder in the cab? It seemed to be conjectured that such an act might very probably be followed by suicide, and so inquiry was instantly made for the latest self-murders discoverable. It was answered on the spot. The bodies had hardly been taken out of the cab when a suicide was announced from Southwark. A man had just been found dead in a bed at a coffee-house with poison by his side, and the time appeared to fit so exactly that the cabman was hurried off to the house to look at the body. It was not the body sought; but fresh chances turned up every minute. All through Sunday and Monday the cabman was taken about to various parts of the Metropolitan Police district that he might "identify bodies supposed to include that of the missing man." But to render this proceeding of the slightest utility, all these "bodies" must have been discovered under circumstances consistent with the hypothesis entertained -- in other words, they must have been bodies of men who had come by an untimely and unexplained end since 9 o'clock on Saturday evening. Is there usually such a crop of mysteries? Are we really to suppose that on any day of the week a dozen or half-a-dozen fresh corpses may be produced, each of which, for all that anybody knows, may represent the perpetrator of a murder twenty-four hours before? It deserves notice, however, that the present mystery, now that it has been revealed, contains nothing but the most ordinary story of domestic jealousies and unhappiness. A more commonplace tale, except for the catastrophe, could not be imagined. A man conceives an aversion for his wife, whether with or without reason it is impossible to say. He determines to rid himself of what he considers a burden, but then he devises the strangest, the boldest, and most incredible scheme ever known. He makes arrangements with his wife to drive with the children to a railway station in a cab and pick him up on her way. At the station he takes another cab, stops at a public house in a crowded street for a pint of porter, in which he administers poison to mother and daughters together, sits beside them till they are quite dead, and then gets out with directions to the cabman to go on with his load to the other end of London! Such a murder, so planned and executed, may well astound the public mind, and account for a sensation which we have not seen exceeded since the days of RUSH or MANNING.

abstract: The Freedmen's Village, at Greene Heights, Arlington, Va., recently established by Col. GREENE, Chief Quartermaster of the Military Department of Washington, for the use of the colony of contrabands who are cultivating the Arlington estate for themselves, and not for its former owner, Gen. LEE, the leader of the rebel army, was dedicated with appropriate exercises Dec. 3.
lead_paragraph: The Freedmen's Village, at Greene Heights, Arlington, Va., recently established by Col. GREENE, Chief Quartermaster of the Military Department of Washington, for the use of the colony of contrabands who are cultivating the Arlington estate for themselves, and not for its former owner, Gen. LEE, the leader of the rebel army, was dedicated with appropriate exercises Dec. 3. In connection with it, the school-house and chapel erected by friends for the American Tract Society, and the Home for the Aged and Infirm Freedmen, erected by contributors in Providence, R.I., and also to be under the care of the Tract Society, who will here make many comfortable and happy who have spent long years of unrequited toil, were also dedicated.

abstract: It is unfortunate that the first views of European questions are gained in America through the English press. We have all had full opportunity of testing the untrustworthiness and the malignant falsehood of the leading English journals with regard to American questions. Why should we expect greater accuracy or honesty with respect to conti...
lead_paragraph: It is unfortunate that the first views of European questions are gained in America through the English press. We have all had full opportunity of testing the untrustworthiness and the malignant falsehood of the leading English journals with regard to American questions. Why should we expect greater accuracy or honesty with respect to continental? It is a pleasing habit of the London journalists to speak of the Schleswig-Holstein question as a kind of intellectual "muddle" -- a purely technical dispute -- under cover of which the German Powers are trying to despoil a weak state of her principal provinces. The facts are quite otherwise, and, as the question may at any moment inaugurate a European war, they ought to be understood by all intelligent men.

abstract: Report for 1863
lead_paragraph: The Postmaster-General Reports, that during the last fiscal year the financial condition of his Department has been one of unusual prosperity. The revenue has nearly equaled the expenditures -- the latter amounting to $11,314,266 84, and the former to $11,163,789 59. There is good reason to believe that the department will be self sustaining in a brief period of time.

abstract: -- Lieut.-Col. TREPP, of the First regiment U.S. S.S., (BERDAN's sharpshooters,) was killed while in the advance skirmishers, on the 3d of December, on the battle-field of Mine Run. Lieut.-Col. TREPP was a Swiss by birth, and was a Lieutenant and military instructor in the Swiss army. On the breaking out of the Crimean war he joined the Foreign Legion, and served faithfully and with distinction throughout the whole of that campaign. Immediately after the closing of that war he emigrated to this country and carried on his profession as architect. When the rebellion broke out he joined the first company of United States Sharpshooters, which was recruiting in Weehawken, N.J., of which he was Captain. During the campaign he was promoted to a Lieutenant-Colonel for his bravery and gallantry while leading his regiment. He served in all the battles, except in the second Bull Run, until he was pierced by a musket ball at the late engagement on Mine Run. He leaves a wife and three children to mourn his loss.

abstract: George St. Seabrook vs. John Hecker. -- This was a case growing out of the falling of HECKER's Bakery in November, 1862, and was reported in the TIMES of the 10th. At the conclusion of the evidence for the plaintiff, Mr. CURTIS NOYES, for the defence, moved to dismiss the complaint on the ground that, by the showing of plaintiff's own witnesses, there was not and could not have been any negligence by defendant in erecting the stack of ovens which fell. The motion was granted. W.A. COUSSEN and Mr. CLARK for plaintiff; JOHN N. LEWIS, BENS. V, ABBOTT and WM.C. NOYES for defendant.

abstract: The Raising of Armies
lead_paragraph: The proposed change in the Enrollment Act, striking out the $300 commutation clause, will, if carried into effect, place our Copperhead brethren in a very awkward predicament. Their great objection to the clause as it stood was that it created a discrimination in favor of the rich, and against the poor. It left it in the power of drafted men who were able to pay the $300 to stay at home, while it forced those of them who were not able to pay it to enter the ranks, and encounter all the risks and hardships of active service. So they preached night and day that the act was a device of the Republicans to throw on the poor Democrats the actual fighting, while they themselves stayed at home and made money, and their preaching was so far successful that it produced the utmost discontent amongst the poorer classes all over the country.

abstract: Important news from Texas was received yesterday at Washington, Gen. BANKS announces that our forces under Major-Gen. WASHBURNE have seized the approaches to Matagorda. The rebel garrison of Fort Esperanza, consisting of 1,000 men, fled at the approach of our troops, first blowing up the magazines.
lead_paragraph: Important news from Texas was received yesterday at Washington, Gen. BANKS announces that our forces under Major-Gen. WASHBURNE have seized the approaches to Matagorda. The rebel garrison of Fort Esperanza, consisting of 1,000 men, fled at the approach of our troops, first blowing up the magazines. A high gale prevented the cooperation of the gunboats with the land forces, or the enemy would most likely have fallen into our hands. Ten guns were captured, ranging from 24 to 108-pounders. The command of Matagorda Bay substantially gives us the control of Central and Western Texas, and all the important points on the east coast, except Galveston. The town of Matagorda, situated on the bay, at the mouth of the Colorado River, has a large trade, and is the depot for the produce of the Colorado Valley, which is one of the richest parts of Texas, producing cotton, sugar-cane, rice, indigo and maize.
