abstract: A large audience assembled Thursday, in the Academy of Music to listen to a delightful concert given by one hundred and twenty-five children from the Union Home School, situated on Fifty-seventh-street, west of Eighth-avenue. Several distinguished guests were present -- among the number Gen. ANDERSON and Gen. WALLACE. The programme included fine selections from some of the most celebrated composers. Many of the songs, duets and choruses were admirably executed by mere infants. The skill and training of the children was truly wonderful. The song, "Do they think of me at home," by Miss SOPHY MACHMAN, could not have been better rendered by any professional of her age. A medley sung by the school and choir was loudly applauded. During the evening Gen. WALLACE was called on for a speech. He appeared and made a few remarks, applicable to the occasion, which were loudly cheered. The entertainment was projected by the managers of the Union Home School, to raise sufficient funds to enlarge their institution, which has been established especially for the maintenance of the children of our volunteers. Great credit is due to the managers for the thoroughly systematic arrangement of the "business" of the stage. At a late hour the audience dispersed, highly pleased with the evening's entertainment.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- MOZART's opera of "Don Giovanni" was given here on Friday night by Mr. ANSCHUTZ's company, and the house, we are glad to say, was densely filled. The performance was a spirited one in many respects, and, as far as the orchestra was concerned, we do not remember to have ever heard the work better rendered. There are not many opportunities for the chorus, but the few demonstrations that occur were given with great spirit. Mr. ANSCHUTZ played the opera without curtailment, and restored the tenor aria in the first act, which was effectively rendered by Mr. HABELMAN.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- MOZART's opera of "Don Giovanni" was given here on Friday night by Mr. ANSCHUTZ's company, and the house, we are glad to say, was densely filled. abstract: About 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon a murder was committed in Worth-street, between Missionplace and Centre-street. JOHN KANE, a native of Ireland, aged about thirty years, was the victim. From the testimoney, so far as adduced, we learn that about the time named above, JOHN KANE, the deceased, met a colored man, named HARKLESS LITTLE, in Worth-street, near Cow Bay.
lead_paragraph: About 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon a murder was committed in Worth-street, between Missionplace and Centre-street. JOHN KANE, a native of Ireland, aged about thirty years, was the victim. From the testimoney, so far as adduced, we learn that about the time named above, JOHN KANE, the deceased, met a colored man, named HARKLESS LITTLE, in Worth-street, near Cow Bay. A quarrel ensued, and after some skirmishing, KANE chased the colored man into his own house, in Worth-street, near Missio.-place. KANE here commenced an indiscriminate abuse, not only on LITTLE, but also on his wife and another female who were present. After some words had passed between the belligerents, KANE went up to LITTLE, and alter various demonstrations around his face, he finally knocked him down. About this time one of the females undertook to leave the house for the purpose of procuring the assistance of the Police. She was also prostrated to the floor by KANE. The latter then went outside and commended throwing brickbats at the windows. After breaking all the glass in the windows of the house on one side, KANE again went inside, where he made a sudden assault on LITTLE by striking him several times on the face and head with his fist. LITTLE became so incensed toward KANE for his re-attack upon him, that he caught hold of a carving-knife, the blade of which was about fourteen inches in length, and plunged it into KANE's left side, nearly to the handle. It passed entirely through the heart, and the victim fell to the floor dead. LITTLE fled through the rear yard of his premises immediately after having committed the deed. At a late hour last night he had not been arrested. Capt. JOURDAN, of the Sixth Precinct, has dispatched several men in search of him, and that officer says he has no doubt but that he can effect the arrest of the murderer.

abstract: The War in
lead_paragraph: The war in New-Zealand is a war of race against race, and both natives and colonists are straining every nerve to make adequate preparation for carrying on the deadly conflict. The Waikatoes are the prime movers in the insurrection, and their influence has drawn in most of the other tribes. The success of Gen. CAMERON, some months ago, seems not to have been of a very decisive character, since the natives have taken up a strong position on the banks of the Waikato River, where, in a place most difficult of access, they have constructed a network of rifle-pits. This pah has been twice shelled by a small steamer, which has recently been stationed on the Waikato, but this mode of attack has merely served to annoy the Maori stronghold, which, to be captured, must be assailed in a very different manner. Most important results depend on the issue of Gen. CAMERON's assault on this native stronghold; for should he fail to carry it, his failure would be a signal for the tribes that have not yet risen, to arm in support of the native cause. It is doubtless the conviction of the disastrous consequences which would follow from his repulse, that has kept the British General so long inactive. He still occupies the redoubt which his forces threw up beyond the Mauvgawhirri Creek, previously to the fight at Kohivoa, and there he awaits reinforcements from Australia and India, ere he ventures to resume operations. The expected Sikh reinforcements may be dilatory in making their appearance, but the mission of the military agent to Sidney and Melbourne, has been eminently successful, and already large numbers of Australian auxiliaries have arrived at Duckland, while still larger numbers are daily looked for.

abstract: The Aldermen, as City canvassers, met at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, the ninth day of the session. It was expected that Alderman WALSH would as present to read off the returns from the Sixth Ward, which were all the returns that remained to be canvassed, but illness, which had prevented his attendance on the previous day, still kept him confined to his house.
lead_paragraph: The Aldermen, as City canvassers, met at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, the ninth day of the session. It was expected that Alderman WALSH would as present to read off the returns from the Sixth Ward, which were all the returns that remained to be canvassed, but illness, which had prevented his attendance on the previous day, still kept him confined to his house. Alderman HARDY was therefore elected to read off the returns from the Sixth Ward, which he did, and afterward he called attention to the protest from Alderman WALSH, which had been presented and laid over a few days before. Mr. HARDY said Mr. WALSH protested that the election in the Sixth District of the Sixth Ward, in the Fourth District of the Fourth Ward, and also in two or three other election districts in those Wards, had not been conducted fairly, and that frauds of various kinds had been committed. In support of these allegations, he would present affidavits of various parties, which had been intrusted to to him by Mr. WALSH. These affidavits showed that properly-made challenges had been disregarded by the Inspectors of Election; that in one case, a ballot for Mr. WALSH for Alderman had been received by an Inspector and thrown away upon the floor; and that in the Sixth District of the Sixth Ward, where Mr. WALSH had but 145 votes allowed him, over 200 persons had voted for him. The protest thus supported, he argued, should prompt the Board to investigate the alleged frauds, and if they should prove to be actual frauds, that the returns for Alderman in the Districts where the frauds were committed should be thrown out. This course, he continued, would be in accordance with the precedent given by the Board of County Canvassers in the case of BOSWORTH and MCCUNN. He thought the Board owed it to themselves and to the public to investigate the alleged frauds, and, being largely of the Democratic party, they owed a duty to that party to make the investigation. He believed that an investigation would be welcomed by Mr. JONES, the Alderman elect for the District, and also the powerful clique in it, of which Comptroller BRENNAN is the leader, in order that Mr. JONES might come into the next Board of Aldermen without any cloud of fraud hanging about his election.

abstract: Servants
lead_paragraph: Complaints in regard to servants reach us from every side. Their "ingratitude," their "stupidity," their "fickleness and uncertainty;" the poor work which they do, and the bad temper they show; their unreasonable demands, their eye-service to mistresses and peculations behind their backs -- the general untrustworthy character of the whole class all this is drummed into our ears from innumerable correspondents and indignant readers.

abstract: -- Whatever else the rebels may have lost by reason of GRANT's defeat of BRAGG, they have not as yet wholly lost hope, though the foundations of it may be somewhat different now from what they have been. The Richmond Whig, for instance, at the close of an article, in which the writer gives full play to his imagination in making out a scheme of universal Yankee conquest, which, as he says, "would prove no vision, but an actual attempt, if the South were subjugated," still holds on to the belief that the South will not be subjugated; although he says, "That the South will be overrun seems now not impossible." He admits that the way of the rebels "is exceedingly dark at this time," but he keeps up hope, for, says he, "the overruling power which inspired us to attempt the achievement of our independence will not desert us at the last moment, but will open a way to peace and final success where we least expect to find it."

abstract: Gov. STANFORD delivered his annual message to the State Legislature to-day. It exhibits a state of finances more favorable than was anticipated. It represents the agricultural, mining and manufacturing interests in an improving conditton, and confidently predicts that the first fifty miles of the Pacific Railroad will be completed within the time required by the act of Congress. Concerning Federal relations, it advocates reconstruction of the Union by treating the seceded States as Territories.

abstract: -- The Mobile Register has discovered one good result from the war, which entitles it to the credit of ingenuity at all events. It says that one of the leading objects of the rebellion was the cheapening the price of negroes. They had become so dear that none but rich people could afford to own them. The great mass of the whites at the South were completely shut out from the invaluable privilege of slaveholding. Independence and the opening of the Slave-trade, it was believed, would remedy this calamitous condition of affairs. The Register thinks the object has been pretty well accomplished already. Nearly a million of slaves have left the Border States and gone down to the Gulf States, and the surplus thus created has lowered the market price of negroes very essentially, so that they are now sold every day at ruinous sacrifices. The Register does not think it so important now as it has been hitherto, to continue the war. It makes very little difference what reasons the rebels may invent for abandoning the rebellion; the main thing is to have them do it -- and the quicker the better for them as well as for the rest of mankind.
lead_paragraph: -- The Mobile Register has discovered one good result from the war, which entitles it to the credit of ingenuity at all events. abstract: -- The remarkable Message which JEFF. DAVIS sent to the rebel Congress on Monday last, and which we published in full in the TIMES of yesterday, will furnish as entertaining reading in Europe as it has done in this country. Mr. DAVIS delivered his Message to his Congress in Richmond on Tuesday, and President LINCOLN delivered his Message to the National Congress in Washington on Wednesday, and both of these documents will reach Europe simultaneously. We hope that, though DAVIS' Message is very long, foreigners will read it first, and then follow up the course by perusing LINCOLN. In this way, they will be able to form a tolerably accurate judgment upon several things.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen, yesterday, unanimously adopted a resolution by Mr. HARDY, tendering the use of the Governor's Room to the Mayor elect, to receive his friends on New-Year's Day. The Comptroller reported that, during the fortnight ending Nov. 30, $58,362 were disbursed from the Relief Fund to 30,460 families. A resolution to increase the pay of Corporation laborers from $1 75 to $2 per day, was lost for want of a three-fourth vote, but the unfavorable vote was reconsidered, and the paper was then laid over. The Board adjourned to Monday, at 1 o'clock P.M.

abstract: -- After every grand defeat of the rebel army the Northern public turn their anxious gaze southward, to see if they cannot discern some promising sign of rebel repentance, some desire on their part to give up the wretched job they have undertaken -- some symptom of their returning and suing for their "rights," in another manner and in another direction from those in which they have so long been hopelessly pursuing them. We have looked always in vain. Not after Antietam or Gettysburgh -- not after Vicksburgh or Chattanooga -- not since the shutting up of the whole coast of the Confederacy, or its rending in twain by the opening of the Mississippi, or the piercing of its vitals at Knoxville -- not though they have been floored again and again, and been driven back until they now fight in a corner, with their ramshackle edifice tumbling about their ears, -- have we had any hopeful indication that the Confederates were prepared even to listen to proffers of peace. The rebels swore they would fight to the last ditch, and it looks as if, at least, some of them meant to carry out their threat. Chattanooga was the key of the last ditch, but still they show fight.

abstract: A DRUG EXCHANGE. In addition to the numerous business centres, already established in this City, namely: The Regular Stock Exchange, Public Stock Board. Evening Stock Board, Mining Exchange, Produce Exchange, Coal Exchange, Petroleum Exchange, Builders' Exchange, Gold Exchange, and two or three Merchants' Exchanges, we will soon have a Drug Exchange.
lead_paragraph: A DRUG EXCHANGE. -- In addition to the numerous business centres, already established in this City, namely: The Regular Stock Exchange, Public Stock Board. Evening Stock Board, Mining Exchange, Produce Exchange, Coal Exchange, Petroleum Exchange, Builders' Exchange, Gold Exchange, and two or three Merchants' Exchanges, we will soon have a Drug Exchange. A meeting to organize one was held Thursday afternoon at the Merchants' Exchange, Pine-street. The call had been numerously signed, and there was quite a number of importers of, dealers and brokers in drugs, dyes, chemicals, &c., present. The meeting was called to order by Mr. C. RECKNAGLE, and organized by the election of Mr. S.B. SCHIEFFELIN as Chairman and Mr. B.W. BULL as Secretary. A resolution, by Mr. J.H. BAKER, that it was expedient to establish a Drug Exchange, as proposed in the call, was unanimously adopted. It was resolved that the first regular meeting be held on Monday, Dec. 14, at 12 o'clock M. On motion of Mr. BAKER, or H.J. BAKER & BROTHER, it was resolved that the Chair appoint a Committee of three on Permanent Organization and on Arbitration. The Chair appointed Messrs. H.J. BAKER, Y.B. MERRICK and J.L. RIKER such Committee; after which the meeting adjourned.

abstract: Nurses for the Army
lead_paragraph: It is safe to presume that the time of inaction has come to our armies -- a time when the campaigns are necessarily closed for the season, when, resting upon their wearied arms, each soldier looks forward to the enjoyment of whatever reforms and benefits are to be initiated or carried out, and for the aid of legislators and civilians in any practical method of alleviating such hardships as he may labor under. In suggesting these reforms and benefits, those which bear upon the event of a battle take first importance. Whatever of manhood there may be in the soldier while in the flush of health, when wounded or sick, he is but a child, and, considered as such, should be the recipient of the most studied and delicate attentions. The letters of our correspondents on the field have told some sad tales of the suffering that has been endured by our brave men from a lack of ambulance and hospital accomodation after a battle. There is no department in our army in which there has been so great a lack of efficiency as in this last -- the hospital accomodation, especially that of field hospitals, having been always defective, and in some instances immediately following a battle, criminally so. From the very commencement of this rebellion there has been too great a stretch for high surgery, and too little attention to the after part. It is easy to relieve a man of a leg or arm, but the life of the wounded man is dependent on something more than surgery. Without skillful nursing, his chances would have been almost as good had he retained his maimed or crushed limb, and this nursing can only be got by a more perfect organization of our field hospital system, and by the introduction of responsible nurses. To the sick or wounded man, there is as much in the ideal as the real, and with this fact before us, we shall not leave him to the tender mercies of those who may only regard him as an object of professional interest, or to the hands of male nurses, whose very sex is a depressing circumstance, and not calculated to call forth that repose necessary to recovery. In a word, some organized system of women nurses is required for the army. Our field, if not the general hospitals, should have women nurses, and these, not of the moment, but of an organized and skilled responsibility. We know well the objections that will be cited against the introduction of women within the lines, but the very authorities who raise this objection, and are most vehement for shutting out amateur female nurses, are also the strongest indorsers of an organized system. Dr. LETTERMAN, who was medical director of the Army of the Potomac, and induced the issue of the famous order of Gen. HOOKER, in which every woman, without distinction, was sent away from the army, was at the very moment of having this order issued, and always has been, an advocate of employing women in these dirties, if any proper system could be inaugurated; but in common with every surgeon of the army, he would prefer to be without such aid if it was to be incumbered with the burden of amateurs who were unable to take care of themselves, to say nothing of taking care of the sick or wounded.
headline: {'main': 'Nurses for the Army.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Nurses for the Army.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: This journal has held the ground, from the beginning of the civil war, that there was one and especial mode of ultimately retaining the South in the Union and that was, by destroying the present rebellious class of...
lead_paragraph: This journal has held the ground, from the beginning of the civil war, that there was one and especial mode of ultimately retaining the South in the Union -- and that was, by destroying the present rebellious class of slave-aristocracy, and substituting for it a democracy, loyal to the Government. The President's Proclamation of Amnesty is the official recognition of this evident fact. With those shrewd instincts which render Mr. LINCOLN a statesman, though still a man of the people, he sees and accepts the logic of events -- that it is now "war to the knife" with the slave-aristocracy -- that those determined men who have staked their all on the success of their caste can no more retreat than can we. He strikes at them without fear or favor. He destroys their so-called "property;" he undermines the sole foundation of their aristocratic position; he pardons them only on condition of their acknowledging (in effect) that they have been all wrong, and of their giving up the privileges and the power for the sake of which they have devastated half a continent.

abstract: Message; The Blockade and the British Government
snippet: Message; The Blockade and the British Government
lead_paragraph: The charges made by JEFFERSON DAVIS against the British Government, touching its treatment of the Confederacy, are evidently intended rather to produce an effect at home than abroad. In England, as well as at the North, they have all been so effectually refuted twelve months ago that there is not one of them which will probably elicit more than a moment's attention. The first one, and that on which he lays most stress, is the recognition of the blockade by the British Government, in spite of his allegations of its insufficiency, and it is a model of absurdity. He declares that the blockade is simply "a paper blockade;" but it this is the case, it cannot seriously injure the Confederacy. If the various ports are not effectually guarded, or, as he asserts, are not guarded at all, why the traders of the world can send their cargoes as freely, or nearly as freely, as ever, and the Confederacy suffers nothing, or next to nothing, and he has no ground for complaint. If the blockade be notoriously ineffectual, and United States cruisers, nevertheless, in virtue of its having been declared, capture British ships on their way to Southern ports, the party aggrieved is certainly not the Confederacy, but the British Government. The message before us is, we believe, the first case on record of a belligerent's making a great uproar about a wrong inflicted on a neutral, of which the neutral himself takes no notice whatever. Mr. DAVIS seems to labor under the extraordinary delusion that the adhesion of Great Britain to the rules touching maritime rights, laid down by the Congress of Paris, lay it under an obligation to defend and enforce those rules on all possible occasions. International law is, however, intended for the benefit of those who choose to avail themselves of it, and whether it will do so or not is peculiarly a matter which each nation must decide for itself. Each Power has certainly the right to submit to such violations of it as it pleases, just as much as each man has the right, to submit to be insulted with impunity, if he be so disposed, without its causing offence to his neighbors. All the restrictions on blockades are made for the benefit of neutrals, and if neutrals do not insist upon their being enforced, nobody but neutrals has any right to complain. "A paper blockade" means a blockade which exists only on paper. If our blockade be of that nature, it cannot, therefore, be any bar to the trade of the South with other countries, and Great Britain's submitting to it affects Mr. DAVIS in about the same degree as would Earl RUSSELL's unmanly readiness to have his nose pulled.
headline: {'main': 'Jeff. Davis and the Blockade.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Jeff. Davis and the Blockade.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mr. ANSCHUTZ'S performances, during the past week, were singularly successful in point of artistic effort, but the houses were seldom good. "Der Freischutz," on Friday evening, was perhaps the best performance of that work ever given in America.
lead_paragraph: Mr. ANSCHUTZ's performances, during the past week, were singularly successful in point of artistic effort, but the houses were seldom good. "Der Freischutz," on Friday evening, was perhaps the best performance of that work ever given in America. "Fidelio" was selected for the matinee on Saturday. It was very powerfully interpreted, but what could be expected of the public on such a day? To-night Mr. ANSCHUTZ takes his benefit. The opportunity will we hope be improved, not only by our German friends, but by the American community. A musician who has done so much for German music ought certainly to be remembered on such an occasion by Germans. The opera selected for the occasion is MOZART's "Magic Flute" -- a work which was popular last season, when, with far inferior resources, Mr. ANSCHUTZ completed a series of over one hundred performances. During the present week GOUNOD's opera of "Faust" will be produced. This work will, we trust, be the turning-point in Mr. ANCSHUTZ's fortunes.

abstract: -- A letter published in the Louisville Journal, dated Marrowbone, Cumberland County, Dec. 7, says: "Gen. John H. Morgan and five of his officers have just passed through our little town, on route for Tennessee, to cross the river at Mud Camp. They dismounted their horses and warmed at the fire, inquired for Yankees first, and then for whisky. They rode all night. They seemed in great haste."

abstract: A letter received by an officer at the New-York Naval Station, from one of the officers of the iron-clad Weehawken, states that Admiral DAHLOREN had entered into definite arrangements with Mr. WHITSEY and his partner, who had gone down from this city to raise the iron-clad Keokuk. The contract completed by the Admiral, stipulates that, the Weehawken is to be raised, and the Government is to pay the parties what is right. The letter further states, that before the pumps had got into operation on board the ship, her bows were below water-mark, rendering the pumps, of course, useless. The Weehawken is one of the nine iron-clads first constructed for the navy.

abstract: The re  sult of the election for Directors of the NewYork Central Railroad probably takes no one who has watched the course of events by surprise. The officers in place had possession of all the books, including the list of stockholders...
lead_paragraph: The re sult of the election for Directors of the NewYork Central Railroad probably takes no one who has watched the course of events by surprise. The officers in place had possession of all the books, including the list of stockholders, and steadily refused to permit any one else to make copies of them. They had possession also of an immense number of proxies representing stock held abroad, and for the last ten or twelve days they made the most vigorous and persistent efforts, by buying stock, by hiring the use of proxies, and in every other way, to control votes enough to enable them to retain their position. In this they succeeded, and so far they have achieved a triumph.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Adam Roediger vs. Maria S. Roediger. -- In this case, reported in the TIMES of the 8th, the jury found the defendant not guilty on the charge of adultery preferred against her, and found the plaintiff guilty of adultery with one of the parties charged in defendant's answer. The effect of the verdict is to deny a divorce to the plaintiff, and grant it to the defendant.

abstract: Message; The New Peace Movement
lead_paragraph: JEFF. DAVIS closes his Message with a tirade against the people of the North for "refusing to listen to proposals for the only peace possible -- a peace which should recognize the impassable gulf which divides us, and leave the two peoples separately to recover from the injuries inflicted on both by the causeless war now waged against us." FERNANDO WOOD loses no time to show his readiness for peace overtures. He presented a resolution, yesterday, to send Commissioners to Richmond, to negotiate with the authorities for the termination of this "bloody, destructive and inhuman war," and the restoration of the Union under the Constitution. No less than fifty-nine of the Opposition members of the House voted to entertain that proposition.

abstract: Byers E. Morland vs. Charles Brown. -- This was an action to recover $400, the value of one gold watch and chain. The plaintiff claims that defendant received the watch from him at Buffalo, in June, 1859, and though plaintiff has often demanded the return of the watch defendant has wrongfully detained it, and still refuses to deliver it. The defense says that about that time in 1857, one Weaver came to defendant, and wanted to borrow $100, offering as collateral in pledge the gold watch and chain, mentioned in the complaint; that both the plaintiff and Mr. Weaver told him that the watch was the property of Weaver. Defendant, upon these representations, loaned Weaver $100, and afterward, relying upon the same representation, he gave Weaver a further loan of $50, upon the same security. This loan not being repaid, the defendant notified Weaver, and had the watch sold at auction. The evidence shows that for the first loan of $100. Weaver acted as the agent of Moreland, who was the real owner of the watch. That the second loan of $50, Weaver got on his account and it would appear applied to his own use, it having been authorized by Moreland. Defendant, owing to previous representation, did not know or recognize Moreland as the owner of the watch and gave him no notice of sale. Case still on.

abstract: Charles Peterson vs. The Chemical Bank. -- Aaron Cohen, domiciled in New-Haven, where he had resided for six years, died and was buried at that place in July, 1862, leaving assets there, and a last will and testament, which was admitted to probate by the Probate Court within and for the district of New-Haven [???] the executors named in the will having failed to accept and discharge the trust, a grant of administration, with the will annexed, was made to William J. Peck, City Judge of New-Haven, at the request of the next of kin, and upon his giving a bond, with approved sureties, in the sum of $200,000.

abstract: Memminger's Report
lead_paragraph: The Finances of the so-called Confederacy are are a subject of intense interest among the rebels themselves, and of curious interest to the loyal public. A full exposition of the working of the rebel money-making machine is given in the report of Secretary MEMMINGER, of the rebel Treasury Department, which was laid before their Congress last week. As the pressure of public documents upon our columns has been so great lately, we can only furnish a brief synopsis of this plan for raising the ways and means of the rebellion.

abstract: Revival of the Grade; captured by Union troops
snippet: Revival of the Grade; captured by Union troops
lead_paragraph: The proposition now before Congress to revive the grade of Lieutenant-General in the army, refers to the specific application of that title in recognition of preeminent services rendered to the country in the field. For this reason it was conferred upon the two illustrious officers -- and the only two officers, who, thus far in our history, have been honored with it -- WASHINGTON and WINFIELD SCOTT. The suggestion which Gen. HALLECK makes in his report, that two new grades be established in the army -- those of "General" and "Lieutenant-General" -- is quite another thing. In the latter case, the Lieutenant-General is to be simply the commander of an army corps -- as the Major-General or Brigadier-General would be the commander respectively of a division or of a brigade -- while the highest rank, that of General, is to be used to designate the commanders of armies.

abstract: John Hoops vs. Monroe Crane and Wm.H. Hull. -- The plaintiff in this action is the owner of a house and lot in Fortieth-street, near the Ninth-avenue, and defendants occupy the adjoining lots where they carry on the business of slaughtering animals. Plaintiff alleges that defendants have recently carried on the business of killing hogs, to the great annoyance and damage of the plaintiff, notwithstanding his frequent remonstrances; that by reason of the filth and the noisome smell arising from the slaughter-yard, plaintiff has not been able to rent his house or premises; that it has been unoccupied for a long time, and he claims damages to the amount of $2,000.

abstract: Yesterday a meeting of naval sailors took place at the Blue Anchor, in Cherry-street. There were over seventy-five sailors present and a goodly sprinkling of landsmen. The objects of the meeting, as stated in a printed circular sent to our reporter was, "to unite the opinion of American naval sailors on the course of the Secretary of the Navy relative to prize money, stopping the grog, &c.; and to pass resolutions for the guidance of seamen generally." Notwithstanding the fact, that the meeting received only the publicity to be derived from a few dozen posters, pasted around the walls of Cherry. Water and Front streets, the large room of the Blue Anchor was well filled before one o'clock. The following is a copy of the poster pasted upon the wall:

abstract: Adrien Iselin et al. vs. Samuel H. Peck et al. -- In September, 1861, as alleged by the plaintiffs, Peck & Co. became insolvent when indebted to them in about $7,000 for goods sold. On the 25th of that month they sold their entire stock of goods to Geo. V. House for $1,000 in cash, and his nine notes for $1,022 each, payable in from six to fourteen months. On the 28th of the month Peck & Co. assigned those notes and other bills receivable to John Mack. Mack was spoken to about the assignment, as alleged, on the day of the sale, and it was not claimed by the defendants, Peck and Mack, who were witnesses, but that the sale was made with a view to the assignment. The plaintiffs proved that House had been discharged under the insolvent law two and a-half years before the sale in question, and that the notes he gave were each protested as they fell due, and were now in suit.

abstract: John E. Williams vs. The Steamtug Vanderbilt and the Derrick Collins. -- SHIPMAN, J. -- This case is a very simple one, and the witnesses differ very little in their narrative of facts. The suit is brought by the owners of the ship Chancellor, to recover damages to her inflicted by a blow from the derrick Collins, while the latter was in tow by the steamtug Vanderbilt, on the 29th of September, 1862. The Chancellor was lying at the dock of the Brooklyn Gas Company, in Brooklyn, below the Navy-yard, and the derrick was being towed out from the Navy-yard by the tug, on her way to the neighborhood of Sandy Hook. As the tug and derrick pushed out from the Navy-yard into the East River, and by where the Chancellor lay, the ebb-tide caught the derrick, and swung her down against the stem of the ship, doing the damage complained of, which was considerable, inasmuch as she had to be taken on to dry dock for repairs.

abstract: In the Senate the election of Standing Committees wss entered upon, resulting in much the same organization as the last Congress. The credentials of Mr. B. GRATZ BROWN, of Missouri, were presented, when that gentleman was qualified and took his seat. Mr. MORGAN presented resolutions commendatory of Major-Gen. MEADE and the officers...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate the election of Standing Committees wss entered upon, resulting in much the same organization as the last Congress. The credentials of Mr. B. GRATZ BROWN, of Missouri, were presented, when that gentleman was qualified and took his seat. Mr. MORGAN presented resolutions commendatory of Major-Gen. MEADE and the officers and soldiers of the Army of the Potomac for their part against the rebels in the campaign which resulted in our victory at Gettysburgh. Mr. WILSON presented similar resolutions respecting Major-Gen. BANKS and his command for their services at Port Hudson. Both matters were referred to the appropriate Committee. Mr. LANE, of Indiana, gave notice of a bill to amend the Enrollment Act by striking out the $300 commutation clause and to increase the pay of the soldiers. Mr. HALE, by unanimous consent, introduced a bill to more effectually repress the rebellion by prohibiting Slavery. Various other matters were considered and the Senate adjourned.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen yesterday laid over, under the rule, a resolution by Mr. RYERS, to donate $250 to JOHN BROWN, Assistant Foreman of Hose Company No. 30, for his heroic action in rescuing two children from a burning building recently. A resolution, by Mr. LONG, was adopted, authorizing the Corporation Counsel to appoint a counselor-at-law and a clerk to assist him, to make a complete digest of the laws and ordi-...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen yesterday laid over, under the rule, a resolution by Mr. RYERS, to donate $250 to JOHN BROWN, Assistant Foreman of Hose Company No. 30, for his heroic action in rescuing two children from a burning building recently. A resolution, by Mr. LONG, was adopted, authorizing the Corporation Counsel to appoint a counselor-at-law and a clerk to assist him, to make a complete digest of the laws and ordinances relating to the City Government, with notes of all decisions of the Courts, and the Corporation Counsel and the Mayor to fix the compensation of the compilers, and publish an edition of 1,000 copies of the compilation. The Board also adopted a resolution, by Mr. FARLEY, directing the Harlem Railroad Company to extend their tracks over Fourth-avenue to Forty-second-street, and to run the cars to that point without extra charge, and also permitting them to run double tracks through Thirty-fourth-street to the East River, or through Thirty-second-street, Lexington-avenue and Thirty-fourth-street to the river. The Board adjourned to 1 o'clock P.M. to-day.

abstract: Financial Report by
lead_paragraph: -- We invite especial attention to the report of Mr. MEMMINGER, the rebel Secretary of the Treasury, an extended synopsis of which we give this morning. In its statements and developments concerning the condition of the Confederacy, it is a far more important document than the Message of JEFF. DAVIS himself. It is more despondent, more gloomy, and far more significant and positive in its assertions. The South is admitted to be bankrupt, the currency is worth nothing, and the amount is rapidly becoming uncontrollable; there are no values to anything; the Government must repudiate all its contracts, and beg its creditors to accept "a new way to pay old debts." This failing, "the country must succumb." Read what Mr. MEMMINGER himself says:

abstract: Our correspondent from Portsmouth, Va., informs us of an important expedition, undertaken by Brig-Gen. WILD, commanding the negro brigade in Gen. BUTLER'S Department. Starting out from the vicinity of Portsmouth on Saturday, the 5th inst., and marching in two columns by different routes, the brigade united at Hintons
lead_paragraph: Our correspondent from Portsmouth, Va., informs us of an important expedition, undertaken by Brig-Gen. WILD, commanding the negro brigade in Gen. BUTLER's Department. Starting out from the vicinity of Portsmouth on Saturday, the 5th inst., and marching in two columns by different routes, the brigade united at Hintonsville, N.C., whence an advance was made on Elizabeth City, which was occupied on the 10th without opposition, the rebels being taken by surprise. Artillery and cavalry, as well as a considerable naval force have left to co-operate with Gen. WILD, and Elizabeth City is likely to be made the base of important operations.

abstract: -The sixty-fifth annual election of the Fire Department was held on Monday evening, at Firemen's Hall, the President, A.J. DELATOUR, in the chair. After the regular routine business, the annual report of the Trustees was proceeded with by Mr. P.Y. EVERETT, the Secretary. This document showed that the principal sources of revenue for the past year were: $6,320 from the Chief Engineer of the Fire Department for certificates; $6,298 60 from the agents of the foreign fire insurance companies doing business in this City; $5,275 13 from the gentlemen composing the Firemen's Ball Committee of the thirty-fourth annual ball. They had also received the following donations and appropriations: $2,000 from the Common Council; $1,000 from PETER COOPER, Esq.; $500 from Messrs. HECKER & BROS.; $100 (a portion of a legacy bequeathed by a lady to the charitable institutions of this City) from Mr. R.F. LEE; $50 from Mr. R. CARNLEY. At the last annual meeting there was a balance in the Butchers' and Drovers' Bank to the credit of the department, amounting to $391 33. Since that period there has been paid to the Treasurer the sum of $62,677 99, making in the aggregate the amount of $62,997 32. In the above amount there was received for bonds and mortgages canceled, $14,300; also $15,000 from temporary loans, making the actual receipts $33,177 99. The disbursements for the same period have, in the aggregate, amounted to $62,338 85. The following is the result of the election for officers for the ensuing year: A.J. DELATOUR, Pxresident; John R. Platt, Vice-President; Charles A. Gray, Secretary; John S. Giles, Treasurer; Zophar Mills, Charles O'Conner, Peter Masterson, Fred. Ridabock, Trustees.

abstract: The final report of the Ladies' Union Bazaar Society was published in the TIMES yesterday, and it presented a record upon which the managers of the laudable undertaking have a right to congratulate themselves. It appears from the statement that while the fair which was held in this City some months ago brought $23,000 into the Treasury of the Society, $32,000 was disbursed before its accounts were closed. The managers were enabled to accomplish this result by a judicious use of their fund, and by executing some Government work under contract. The charities were disbursed in three ways: 1. Those who were able to work at remunerative prices were furnished work by taking Government contracts at six cents, the Society paying thirteen cents. 2. The Society purchased material, and allowed those making it up to have it at cost price, without regard to the cost of making. 3. The utterly destitute were relieved by the Society free of cost. Clothing ready made was given them, and food when necessary. The amount of good thus accomplished cannot of course be measured by the standard of dollars and cents. But the exhibit of the Society's operations speaks for itself, and shows that the undertaking was one of the most successful of the kind which has ever been inaugurated in this City.

abstract: When the news reached this City that the Weehawken had gone down with four engineers and thirty of her crew, the cold, concise manner of the announcement may have caused it to be passed over with a casual sigh by many of our fellow-citizens; but in one home, how deep, how awful were those words! What a knell tolled in every heart as they were read, and the happy, peaceful home plunged in a moment into the deepest despair. Still, hope would live, and faint as the spark, it cheered, not only this sad family, but many sympathizing friends. Last night, however, this little light went out -- heading the list of the lost was that dear name, the son, the brother, the friend, the true, noble young patriot.

abstract: the New European Quarrel
lead_paragraph: The clouds of war in regard to the question of the Duchies, are gathering more thickly and ominously in Western Europe. By the last arrival, we learn of the deep and increasing popular excitement in Germany in favor of Duke FREDERICK, of Augustenburg, whom the English Press have already, with characteristic fairness, dubbed the "Pretender," though he is not only the legal, but the popular claimant of the Sovereignty of the Duchies. Public meetings are held through all the great cities of Germany, to support the Holsteiners. The press abounds with appeals against Denmark and in advocacy of the German party. The "National League" has voted that the subscriptions for the Federal fleet shall be turned to raising volunteers, who shall march in to uphold the rights of the Confederacy. Many of the Princes and the smaller States have already recognized the claims of FREDERICK, or denounced those of CHRISTIAN; among them are the Free City of Frankfort, the Chambers of Darmstadt, Wurtemburg and Saxony, the Dukes of Baden, Saxe-Coburg and Saxony, and Saxe-Weimar, Saxe-Altenburg and others.

abstract: Rebel Finances The Collapse of
lead_paragraph: The plans proposed by JEFFERSON DAVIS in his Message for the reform of the Confederate finances, and the recruiting of the Confederate armies, promise to produce, if carried out, a state of things at the South which will form an exceedingly interesting subject of study to the sociologist and political economist. He declares that the paper currency issued by the Government exceeds the wants of the community by $400,000,000, (Mr. MEMMINGER says $500,000,000,) and he proposes to reduce it to the required quantity by direct taxation. He says that the consequences of the enormous expansion are "ruinous." He thinks it throws "difficulties in the way of the operations of the Government and of the efficient conduct of the war;" that no measures directed toward its reduction can be too prompt or too stringent.

abstract: Col. G.W.B. TOMPKINS, formerly of the Eighty-second regiment, was arrested yesterday, by order of the Assistant Provost-Marshal, Gen. HAYS. It appears that a deserter from the Eighty-second regiment fearing arrest, applied to G.C. HAWTHORNE to get his discharge, when HAWTHORNE promised to procure his discharge for the sum of one hundred dollars. HAWTHORNE procured a Surgeon's certificate of disability, and between him and the Colonel gave the man his discharge, dating the discharge back two years. The facts coming to the ears of Gen. HAYS, caused the arrest of the parties, both of whom were committed and held to bail in the sum of $1,000.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. LANE, of Kansas, introduced an important bill to restrict the speculative traffic in gold, silver and exchange. It prohibits the sales of such articles, except at the regular banking-house, or broker's office; prohibits purchases or operations upon a margin; prohibits sales unless actually delivered and ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. LANE, of Kansas, introduced an important bill to restrict the speculative traffic in gold, silver and exchange. It prohibits the sales of such articles, except at the regular banking-house, or broker's office; prohibits purchases or operations upon a margin; prohibits sales unless actually delivered and paid for; penalty on conviction, a fine of not less than one nor more than ten thousand dollars, and imprisonment for not less than twelve months for each offence. Senator SUMNER introduced a resolution to simplify, codify and arrange the statutes of the United States. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, introduced a bill placing the volunteer officers of the navy on the same footing as those of the regular force. Mr. ANTHONY, of Rhode Island, introduced a resolution tendering a vote of thanks to Gen. BURNSIDE. The President's Message was referred. Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, called up his resolution on the exchange of prisoners, and proceeded to denounce the Administration in violent language, charging the party in power with seeking to prolong the war for political purposes. This called out Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, who administered a severe rebuke to the gentlemanfrom Kentucky, and eloquently defended the President and Congress from DAVIS' base imputations. Mr. JOHNSON, of Maryland, and Mr. LANE, of Indiana, also replied to Mr. DAVIS. A vote of thanks was passed to Capt. JOHN RODGERS, of the navy, for distinguished services in the capture of the Atlanta.

abstract: Sewing has been and still is a great resource for woman, in her hour of need. The introduction of the sewing-machine has beggared many a hand-sewer. With its nimble, tireless iron finger, making hundreds of stitches a minute, she cannot compete.
lead_paragraph: -- Sewing has been and still is a great resource for woman, in her hour of need. The introduction of the sewing-machine has beggared many a hand-sewer. With its nimble, tireless iron finger, making hundreds of stitches a minute, she cannot compete. As well might the courier match his feet against the telegraph. The poor we still have with us, and our charity should be suited to the times. They should be provided with sewing-machines. In the language of Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER to Messrs. WHEELER & WILSON:

abstract: A meeting of the General Committee of the above Association was held at the office of Mr. HENRY O'REILY, the Secretary, on Friday evening last, at 3 o'clock. Gen. W.K. STRONG presided.
lead_paragraph: A meeting of the General Committee of the above Association was held at the office of Mr. HENRY O'REILY, the Secretary, on Friday evening last, at 3 o'clock. Gen. W.K. STRONG presided. Various Sub-Committees reported, as did likewise the Treasurer, showing the amount of the receipts and expenditures. Several applications for positions in the colored regiment to be raised were received and referred to the appropriate Committee. Col. WHITE MORRIS, who had been accredited by the Association, and had presented his credentials to the Secretary of War, was informed by him that it was the intention of the Government to authorize the organization of only one regiment of colored troops in New-York City, though hereafter others will be authorized. Col. MORRIS was also informed that his name would be sent to the Senate of the United States, for confirmation as a Brigadier-General, to command the brigade to be raised in this State. This information was telegraphed to the Committee from Washington by Col. MORRIS.

abstract: Another lively affair has issued from Gen. BUTLER'S department. Yesterday we announced the capture and occupation of Elizabeth City, N. C., by the negro brigade of Brig.-Gen. WILD, and to day we record the official report of an expedition under command of Brig.-Gen. WISTAR.
lead_paragraph: Another lively affair has issued from Gen. BUTLER'S department. Yesterday we announced the capture and occupation of Elizabeth City, N. C., by the negro brigade of Brig.-Gen. WILD, and to day we record the official report of an expedition under command of Brig.-Gen. WISTAR, which penetrated the rebel lines to Charles City Court-house, within eighteen miles of Richmond. The enemy's camp at this point was surprised by our cavalry, who captured eight officers and eighty-two men, 58 horses and mules, besides destroying arms, ammunition and provisions. Our loss was 2 killed and 5 wounded. Gen. WISTAR commends the New-York mounted rifles and Thirty-ninth New-York infantry for excellent marching, gallantry and endurance.

abstract: Recruiting in this City, under the new call for volunteers, has been very brisk for the last two weeks, the number reaching over one hundred per day. The bounties paid by the City, State and General Government amount in the aggregate to so large a sum, that men of moderate incomes are beginning to discover that, even in the matter of pecuniary gain, the army holds out better inducements than the majority of mechanical trades. Supposing the war to cease within one year, there are few men engaged in the ordinary avocations of life who could make as much money as by entering the army, with the bounties that are now paid.

abstract: OLYMPIC THEATRE. The success of this bright and beautiful little establishment will be assured if Mrs. WOOD its charming lessee will adhere to such light and effervescent programmes as she gave the public last night. The serious drama is a thing that comedians always essay.
lead_paragraph: OLYMPIC THEATRE. -- The success of this bright and beautiful little establishment will be assured if Mrs. WOOD -- its charming lessee -- will adhere to such light and effervescent programmes as she gave the public last night. The serious drama is a thing that comedians always essay. It is their hobby -- but a lame one at that. Mr. BURTON -- that great comic actor, whose place, we fear, wilt never be filled -- interrupted his best successes by experiments in this direction. They were invariably failures. Mrs. WOOD will do well to profit by this experience, and, at all events, to understand that her presence in the bill is absolutely essential. At a theatre like the Olympic, the usual managerial contrasts are not needed. The habitues demand a continual feast of fun, and if the table is well supplied, they will never object that the viands are pretty much of the same character.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Supervisors, yesterday, a mandamus by Justice LEONARD, of the Supreme Court, was presented, requiring the Board to show cause why the bill of District Attorney HALL, presented to the Board in May last, amounting to over $18,000, should not be paid.
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Supervisors, yesterday, a mandamus by Justice LEONARD, of the Supreme Court, was presented, requiring the Board to show cause why the bill of District Attorney HALL, presented to the Board in May last, amounting to over $18,000, should not be paid. The bill is for fees paid by Mr. HALL and his predecessor, Mr. WATERBURY, to the present and the former Sheriff, arising out of suits against Sunday liquor selling, prosecuted under a section of the Police Act. abstract: The artists of the Brooklyn Art Association gave their first reception of the season last evening at the Academy of Music. There was as usual a large and brilliant attendance. Brooklyn, even more than New-York, seizes these pleasant occasions for a display of its beauty, and this leads naturally to the suave concomitants of brilliant toilettes, agreeable conversation and for the younger sort -- alas! that it should be for them only -- of downright flirtation. It would be difficult to select a better place for the full enjoyment of these various phases of an Art Reception. The concert room of the Academy is a pleasant and lofty apartment, scant in superfices, perhaps, but of happy proportions when the crowd is composed of ladies. It is only necessary to revolve once around it. After this ceremony the distracted admirer of art generally finds himself in a comfortable arm-chair in the theatre, listening to the moderate strains of an orchestra, and, perhaps, to something far more musical; -- all, except the gentlemen who are tied to red string, and who, for their many sins, are condemned to stand in the middle of the apartment. They -- wretched committeemen -- are not permitted to leave their posts until all the pretty girls have left, and the gas has been turned off.

abstract: The Small pox, which has sensibly abated in this city, but only from lack of subjects, has carried off in six months 1,600 persons out of a population of about 9,000! Over 1,000 victims have been buried ...
lead_paragraph: The Small pox, which has sensibly abated in this city, but only from lack of subjects, has carried off in six months 1,600 persons out of a population of about 9,000! Over 1,000 victims have been buried within the city precincts, and 600, whose friends were too poor to pay the $4 ground fee, have been interred outside. Of these not a dozen were whites, and none that I know of were Americans. With the dry season, which will be along in two weeks more, we expect a total cessation of the plague.

abstract: Major-Gen. JOHN BUFORD, who died at Washington yesterday, was a graduate of the West Point Military Academy, and in the Regular army held the rank of Major in the Inspector-General's Department.
lead_paragraph: Major-Gen. JOHN BUFORD, who died at Washington yesterday, was a graduate of the West Point Military Academy, and in the Regular army held the rank of Major in the Inspector-General's Department. He was appointed Brigadier-General of Volunteers on the 27th of July, 1862, and assigned to the command of a cavalry brigade under Gen. POPE, in his Virginia campaign of that year. When that army was merged with the Army of the Potomac, Gen. BUFORD was assigned to the command of the regular cavalry brigade, which he held until the formation of the cavalry corps into three divisions, when he was placed in command of the First division, and served throughout the severe campaigns of the past ten months with the most distinguished gallantry. He was considered the best field cavalry commander in the service, and was noted for his coolness and judgment under fire. He was about forty years of age, of full habit a man of generous nature and warm impulses. Before his death the President rewarded him with the commission of Major-General. The country has lost a noble spirit and a brave defender.

abstract: By the arrival at this port last evening of the steamship Champion, from Aspinwall on the 7th, inst., we have our usual Central and South American correspond.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port last evening of the steamship Champion, from Aspinwall on the 7th, inst., we have our usual Central and South American correspondence. Full and interesting particulars are given concerning the escape of Captain-General BARRIOS, Ex-President of Salvador, from the country, after the occupation of the City of San Salvador by the Gautemalian forces, and our correspondent says that the fugitive chief had taken passage for this port. Preparations for the expected war between New-Granada and Ecuador arc continued. At Panama the small-pox was causing frightful mortality among the natives, of whom 1,600 had died, out of a population of 9,000. The Champion brings $299,899 in specie.

abstract: Isaac Nortschilt vs. Timothy Cunneen and William Morton. -- Plaintiff sued the defendants for $500 damages for an alleged assault committed upon him on the 22d of September fast. Plaintiff charged the defendant with striking him in the face with a pistol, and mutilating his body in a tearful manner. Defendant Cunneen denied that he ever touched plaintiff; that he had been sick for months past, and on the day of the assault was unable to walk about. Defendant Morton also denied hitting plaintiff, but admitted that he shoved him away from Cunneen with only such force as was necessary and in order to preserve the peace. The complain, was dismissed with costs.
lead_paragraph: Isaac Nortschilt vs. Timothy Cunneen and William Morton. -- Plaintiff sued the defendants for $500 damages for an alleged assault committed upon him on the 22d of September fast. Plaintiff charged the defendant with striking him in the face with a pistol, and mutilating his body in a tearful manner. Defendant Cunneen denied that he ever touched plaintiff; that he had been sick for months past, and on the day of the assault was unable to walk about. Defendant Morton also denied hitting plaintiff, but admitted that he shoved him away from Cunneen with only such force as was necessary and in order to preserve the peace. The complain, was dismissed with costs.

abstract: Halleck's, Gen., Criticisms of
lead_paragraph: Gen. HALLECK is certainly not a man given to flattery. In his recent somewhat pungent report of military operations for the year, the public will find but two general officers -- Gen. GRANT and Gen. GILLMORE -- spoken of with praise, and the most of our leading Generals criticised in a very brief but sufficiently pointed manner. They will discover there none of that official covering up of defeats and exaggeration of victories with which we have been charged so often in Europe. On the contrary, many minor disasters, about which we had no accurate reports, for the first time are brought clearly to light. It is a somewhat singular spectacle in American public life to behold a prominent official deliberately sitting in judgment on most of the leading military men of the day, and dealing out his criticisms with no sparing hand. And it is still another novel experience for the American people, to know that not one of these distinguished persons, writhing under the public criticism from Washington, is permitted to reply a single word.

abstract: An effort is being made to give to Gen. BUTLER full authority to negotiate the exchange of our prisoners now languishing in Richmond. It is understood here that he has expressed his willingness ...
lead_paragraph: An effort is being made to give to Gen. BUTLER full authority to negotiate the exchange of our prisoners now languishing in Richmond. It is understood here that he has expressed his willingness to undertake it, and his confidence in his ability to effect it. It is, moreover, understood that he will be acceptable to the Richmond authorities as a negotiator, and that they will be disposed to treat on the basis of considering all our captured negro soldiers not claimed as slaves by their owners on the same footing as our white soldiers.

abstract: -- By recent legislation of Congress, the Supreme Court of the United States has been enlarged, and its Circuits reorganized. We published, a few days ago, a list of the reorganized Circuits, with their Judges, and we give this morning a list of decisions rendered by the Court at its present session, which commenced on Monday of last week. The Court of Claims, which has also been reorganized, is now in session at Washington. By an Act of Congress of March last, the number of Judges was increased to five, of whom one, Hon. JOSEPH CASEY, of Pennsylvania, has been appointed Chief Justice, by the President. The other Judges are HUGHES, of Indiana; LORING, of Massachusetts; WILMOT, of Pennsylvania, and PECK, of Illinois. Members of Congresss are not allowed to practice in this Court.

abstract: The flag-of-truce boat New-York arrived here to-night, bringing Southern news up to to-day.  The city has been shelled at intervals during the day. abstract: THE SECOND PHILHARMONIC CONCERT, (BROOKLYN.)?The second concert of the seventh season of this popular and eminently successful organization was given on Saturday night, at the Academy of Music, before an audience which literally filled the spacious house from orchestra to amphitheatre.
lead_paragraph: THE SECOND PHILHARMONIC CONCERT, (BROOKLYN.) -- The second concert of the seventh season of this popular and eminently successful organization was given on Saturday night, at the Academy of Music, before an audience which literally filled the spacious house from orchestra to amphitheatre. A more brilliant assemblage has rarely been seen on any occasion. The programme presented an attractive variety of orchestral and individual performances, the former consisting of SCHUMAN's Symphony No. 2, "Oscari," WAGNER's introduction to "Lohengrin," and KREUTZER's refreshing overture to the "Night in Granada." The symphony was deemed an experiment, nearly all of the Directors and very many of the members objecting to it, on account of its authorship. Thanks to the perseverance of Mr. EISFELD, however, the audience were permitted to listen to one of the most scholarly and sympathetic productions of the age, which was rendered with great delicacy and a heartiness of appreciation by the orchestra, who felt the double inspiration of love for the music, and vindication of the composer. "Lohengrin" is probably the most singular work yet presented by WAGNER to the public. The introduction, with the exception of a single passage, is one prolonged squeak, which penetrates like the point of a needle so very far into the future, that the faculty of the present fails to appreciate it. It is fashionable in Brooklyn just now to be desperately in love with the music of the future, hence this selection. It fell dead upon the audience, and its rest was in no way disturbed by plaudit or encore. The overture, a musical gem which is always welcomed by the professional or the popular audience was eminently successful in its interpretation on this occasion. Mme. VIRGINIA LORINI, the vocalist of the evening, was received with genuine applause. This lady's operatic endeavors on the same stage have always been miserably supported and fearfully botched, by the illiberality of managers and the inefficiency of her associates, with the single exception of a recent appearance. Her individual merit and desire to do right have produced their normal effect, and no prima donna is more welcome in Brooklyn than LORINI. She sang a cavatina from "Semiramis" and a polacca from "Puratini" with all the freshness of voice and beauty of expression which characterize her operatic efforts. Hearty encores rewarded each appearance, and there is no doubt the people would have gladly remained in the Academy till this blessed minute, had she not thoughtfully retired. The sensation of the concert was the debut of a young resident of the City, Miss BLANCHE CARPENTER, a pianist. The fact that a girl of seventeen, pretty and all that sort of thing, who had never struck a note in public, and was entirely innocent of the mysteries and miseries of an orchestral accompaniment, had been invited to play before the Philharmonic Society, was of itself sufficient text for a moderate wonderment; but that the Directors were willing to intrust the interpretation of WEBER's famous "Concert-stuck," with its four movements, its intricacies of manipulation, its bewildering orchestral combinations and its breadth of thought, to a novice, was something so unusual, that people, particularly those whose daughters know a thing or two, shook their heads and looked solemn. However, Mr. MASON, her teacher, indorsed her, the Philharmonic conductors who had heard her in private said she would do. The solid men of Brooklyn who manage all these little things, followed in the wake, and the time of trial was announced. No one who was present can doubt the result. A more genuine success we have never witnessed. The work, though not always reckoned a popular one, is nevertheless one which a musically educated community, like that before which she played, cannot fail to admire and appreciate. It abounds in refreshing combinations, is supported by orchestral passages of great breadth and beauty, and contains a march of unexcelled grandeur. The debutante proved equal to the emergency. Her touch is clear and crisp, her trill distinct and marked, her time perfect, her facility of manipulation most remarkable. As she rose from her seat, the audience, which had sat spell-bound for the moment, broke forth in a display of enthusiastic applause, like that of an operatic furore; wave after wave of popular approval followed her from the stage, and demanded her reappearance. With great good sense, Miss CARPENTER refrained from a repetition and contented herself with a courteous acknowledgment of the applause. This was not satisfactory to the audience, who had worked themselves into the condition of Oliver Twist, and were frantically calling for more. The President, Mr. WYMAN, then announced that he had prevailed upon Miss CARPENTER to play during the second part of the programme, with which the audience subsided.

abstract: The Richmond Whig, of to-day, in an editorial, says: "The Atlanta Confederacy asserts that our cavalry advanced on the 10th above Ringgold, finding the country clear of the enemy.
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Whig, of to-day, in an editorial, says: "The Atlanta Confederacy asserts that our cavalry advanced on the 10th above Ringgold, finding the country clear of the enemy. They proceeded thence to Lookout Mountain and Missionary Ridge. Here they found nothing but the debris of the enemy's camp. The position seemed to have been deserted on Saturday last. In the town of Chattanooga and below the enemy had visibly decreased his force. The presumption is that a heavy column has gone after LONGSTREET, and an expedition has started into East Tennessee to look after FORREST, who has taken advantage of the absence of SHERMAN's corps.

abstract: Josephine M. Hall vs. Eliphalet Stratton.  The plaintiff is sole owner of the premises known as  No. 9 Boorman-place, Thirty-third-street, in this City, and the defendant was the owner of the adjoining ...
lead_paragraph: Josephine M. Hall vs. Eliphalet Stratton. -- The plaintiff is sole owner of the premises known as No. 9 Boorman-place, Thirty-third-street, in this City, and the defendant was the owner of the adjoining premises No, 8 Boorman-place. Plaintiff alleges that since the month of August. 1861, the defendant has carelessly and willfuly permitted the service-pipe from the water-closet or Croton pipe of his building to leak or overflow in each a manner that the flith and contents of the water-closet ran through the party wall and destroyed the celling, plaster, paper and decorations of the side hall wall and the smell arising from this leakage was unendurable, and has produced an aggravated disease, and has rendered the plaintiffs premises uninhabitable, and defendant has neglected to repair or obviate this damage.

abstract: There are now in process of construction in this City, Brooklyn and Jersey City, twelve iron-clads, most of which are modeled after the first monitor.
lead_paragraph: There are now in process of construction in this City, Brooklyn and Jersey City, twelve iron-clads, most of which are modeled after the first monitor. With a few exceptions, our iron-clads vary from each other only in size and number of turrets. It is thought by many there are several vessels being built similar to the Galena. This is a mistake, which arises from the fact that when that gunboat was launched, it was thought she would prove a far greater success than the monitors. Experiments, however, have shown that no regular sea-going vessel can be made sufficiently strong to withstand the modern armament of forts. The Italian iron-clad Re Don Luizidi Portogallo, twin sister of the Red'Italia, which is being built at Mr. W.H. WEBB's ship-yard, foot of Sixth-street. East River, will probably come as near perfection, as far as strength and speed are concerned, as any vessel now afloat. But even the Portogallo and the Red'Italia are not to be fully plated, according to the original design, until they reach Indian waters, clearly showing that it is believed they will be more seaworthy without their armor than with it. The Dunderburg, another of Mr. WEBB's creations, now rapidly approaching completion, has the appearance of a sea-going crate, but when finished will probably only be used for harbor defence. The construction of this vessel, which is peculiar, has already been described. It is now determined that she is to have an engine of 6,000 horse power, and is to be clad with iron plates of a thickness sufficient to withstand the penetrating of explosive power of any shot or shell now in use. A large number of hands are employed on her, and it is expected she will be ready to launch the early part of next Spring. The unsuccessful attempt to launch the Dictator at the Delamater Iron Works, foot of Thirteenth-street, East River, has resulted in a partial suspension of work on the vessel. The attention of her builders is now being turned to the manner of getting her successfully into the water. There are many who assert that if a greater inclination is given to the ways than they now have the vessel when launched will founder. All opinions to the contrary not withstanding, the ways are to receive additional inclination, when the Dictator will go into if not under the water. The work on the iron-clads at the yard of Messrs. SECOR & CO., Jersey City; also at Green Point and the Navy-yard is progressing in the most rapid manner possible. Probably all of the vessels ordered by the last Congress will be ready for service by the middle of next Summer.

abstract: Exchange; Gen. Hitchcock's Letter
lead_paragraph: News from Richmond as late as yesterday morning, has been received at Fortress Monroe. Charleston telegrams give an account of operations in that vicinity, from which it appears that Gen. GILLMORE continues to fire upon the City -- Greek fire -- that burns fifteen minutes after explosion of the shell. A great many houses are damaged. A fire of accidental origin had occurred at Sumter, destroying the wood-work of the bomb-proofs and some ammunition. The casualties one day in the fort were ten killed. Information from LONGSTREET's command puts a brighter face on his prospects. He is reported to have formed a junction with several scattered bands of rebels in Northeastern Tennessee, and, with this additional strength, is capable of keeping possession of that region. The rebels say that reconnoissances of HARDEE's cavalry to Ringgold and beyond, in the direction of Chattanooga, resulted in ascertaining that Gen. GRANT has materially contracted his lines. This is interpreted as meaning that a heavy force has been sent against LONGSTREET, and another heavy force to check FORREST's conscripting and guerrilla fighting in Western Tennessee.

abstract: Great excitement was created last evening by the issuing of an extra purporting to detail the fight between HEENAN and KING, making HEENAN victorious in one hundred and sixty-nine rounds.
lead_paragraph: Great excitement was created last evening by the issuing of an extra purporting to detail the fight between HEENAN and KING, making HEENAN victorious in one hundred and sixty-nine rounds. That it was entirely unreliable, the knowing ones knew, as the fight was fixed for the 8th inst., and by no possibility could the details reach here at this date. Still it had its effect -- put money into the purse of the proprietors -- was a capitally worded and embellished affair, and was about as successful a "sell" as has been perpetrated since the "moon hoax."

abstract: There no longer remains room to doubt that the rebel authorities have refused to allow any further supplies of provisions and clothing to go forward to our prisoners in Richmond.
lead_paragraph: There no longer remains room to doubt that the rebel authorities have refused to allow any further supplies of provisions and clothing to go forward to our prisoners in Richmond. Gen. HITCHCOCK, Chief of the "Bureau of Exchange," has received from Gen. MEREDITH, our Commissioner at Fortress Monroe, a copy of a letter addressed to him on the 11th inst. by Mr. Commissioner OULD, announcing this determination of the rebel War Department. This policy, if persisted in, will bring our authorities face to face with that grave alternative conveyed by Secretary STANTON in his official report in the following terms:

abstract: By the regular monthly British steamer from Carthagena, we have dates from that city to the 1st inst. The dates from Bogota are nearly a fortnight older, and are of no interest.
lead_paragraph: By the regular monthly British steamer from Carthagena, we have dates from that city to the 1st inst. The dates from Bogota are nearly a fortnight older, and are of no interest. The whole country was quiet; but such portions of it as had received the orders of the Provisional President MOSQUERA, now in the Pacific State of Cauca, was preparing for war with Ecuador. Gen. MOSQUERA having decided to command the army in person, or at least to remain at the theatre of action, has signified his intention of not resuming immediately the Presidential chair, but has delegated the Executive command to the Procurador, or Attorney-General of the nation, URICOECHEA. Gen. SANTOS GUTIERREZ, to whom the supreme power was intrusted incase of a prolonged absence of Gen. MOSQUERA, has been ordered to Cauca to take a command. Our next news from Guayaquil or Buenaventura, unless an unexpected settlement has been brought about with Ecuador, may bring us our account of the first collision between the Ecuatorian and Colombian troops now on the frontier of Ecuador. The Ecuatorians have probably about 5,000 men on the frontier ready for action, while MOSQUERA has only half that number, but will soon have 10,000 men to lead to Quito.

abstract: There was no important business transacted in either House yesterday. Numerous resolutions and bills were introduced in the Senate, the most important of which was Mr. WILSON'S bill for amending the Enrollment Act.
lead_paragraph: There was no important business transacted in either House yesterday. Numerous resolutions and bills were introduced in the Senate, the most important of which was Mr. WILSON'S bill for amending the Enrollment Act. The speedy passage of this bill will be urged upon both Houses, is it goes into effect on the 1st of January, so as to affect the forthcoming draft. Mr. WILSON reported a bill to facilitate the payment of back pay and pensions of deceased soldiers. The resolution for the codification of the public laws was adopted.

abstract: The case of WM. HAUGHY, indicted for having in his possession counterfeit money, with intent to alter the same, was continued in this Court yesterday. It appeared from the testimony that, in April last the Police of the Eighteenth Precinct received information that the prisoner, who was keeping a feed-store in the Third-avenue, near Twentieth-street, had counterfeit money in his possession, and, on going to his place of business, they found him just driving up from down town with a load of hay. One of the Policemen told him he wished to speak with him a moment, whereupon the prisoner got off the load of hay, and on reaching the ground was discovered to take from his pccket a parcel, which he thrust into one of the bales of hay. He was immediately arrested, and the parcel, on being examined, was found to contain several counterfeit bills on the Central Bank of Troy and other banks. An examination of the prisoner's premises discovered another roll of counterfeits concealed in a bale of hay, and also several counterfeit 25-cent coins, and various implements for manufacturing the same.
