abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. HALE arose to a privileged question, and made a lengthy explanation with reference to an indirect charge of bribery which had been made against him by a public print in New-England. He appealed to Mr. JOHNSON, of Maryland, who was cognizant of the circumstances, and whose testimony was that Senator HALE was not guilty of the charge, hav-...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. HALE arose to a privileged question, and made a lengthy explanation with reference to an indirect charge of bribery which had been made against him by a public print in New-England. He appealed to Mr. JOHNSON, of Maryland, who was cognizant of the circumstances, and whose testimony was that Senator HALE was not guilty of the charge, having done nothing that any Senator, who was a lawyer might not do. Mr. HALE offered a resolution requiring the Judiciary Committee to investigate and report upon the matter, which was agreed to. Mr. WADE, of Ohio, offered a resolution calling upon the Secretary of the Navy for all the documents and reports in extenso, pertaining to the iron-clad monitors and frigates, in all their various actions, from the first fight of the monitor with the Merrimac, to the sinking of the Weehawken. Mr. LANE, of Kansas, introduced a bill to indemnify the people of Kansas for losses by a grant of public lands. The Senate refused to concur in the House resolution to adjourn over the holidays. It adjourned till to-day.

abstract: Round Table, the First Number of
snippet: Round Table, the First Number of
lead_paragraph: -- The first number of the "Round Table, a Weekly Record of the Notable, the Useful and the Tasteful." appeared yesterday. It has sixteen good sized pages, printed on a sheet of paper the size of the TIMES, and taken up with discussions of the political, military and literary topics of the day. Everybody confesses that there is a splendid opportunity in this City and country for the successful establishment of a weekly organ of independent criticism and elevated thought; and every one has hoped that the character of the Round Table might be such as to satisfy the public demand. Whether or not it will be so, and do so, time must tell.

abstract: Coroner WILDEY held an inquest yesterday at No. 34 Jackson-street on the body of JOHN DOUGHERTY, the man who was murdered on Wednesday evening by ALEXANDER FERGUSON, as published in the TIMES of Thursday. The testimony in the case went to show that between 7 and 8 o'clock on Wednesday evening the prisoner entered the rooms of the deceased, situated on the upper floor of No. 34 Jackon-street; he pretended to deceased that he...
lead_paragraph: Coroner WILDEY held an inquest yesterday at No. 34 Jackson-street on the body of JOHN DOUGHERTY, the man who was murdered on Wednesday evening by ALEXANDER FERGUSON, as published in the TIMES of Thursday. The testimony in the case went to show that between 7 and 8 o'clock on Wednesday evening the prisoner entered the rooms of the deceased, situated on the upper floor of No. 34 Jackon-street; he pretended to deceased that he went there to find his wife; high words ensued between the two, and soon prisoner ran down to his own premises on the floor below, obtained a large knife, and returned with it to deceased's rooms. A scuffle then took place, but it does not appear that any injury was inflicted with the knife. FERGUSON again went down, and this time he obtained a navy sword. With this he met deceased at the door of his own room, and gave him a stab on the inside of his left thigh, nearly severing the femoral artery. He also stabbed him twice in the head.

abstract: ANDRE FROMENT, Alderman of the Twenty-first Ward, Fifteenth Aldermanic District, died yesterday, of consumption, in the forty-third year of his age. For a long time Mr. FROMENT has been known in this City as a man of sterling integrity, generous disposition and untiring energy. He was born in New-York in 1820, and soon after arriving at his majority rose to prominence in politics. During the Administration of President PIERCE he was appointed agent for the Government to distribute stamp envelopes, and held the office under President EUCHANAN, in all for a period of seven years. He was first elected Alderman of the Twenty-first Ward in the Fall of 1860, and was reelected to the office in 1862, consequently his term would not have expired until the Fall of 1864. In 1862 the State Legislature paid a high compliment to deceased in selecting him as the only member from either Board of the Common Council to revise the City Charter. Mr. FROMENT, at the time of his death, was a Sachem of the Tammany Society, and held the position of Grand Master of the Odd Fellow's Lodge of Southern New-York. In the same Order deceased acted as the representative from this State to the Grand Lodge of the United States. His death will be mourned by a community who knew him to be the noblest work of God -- "an honest man." The Grand Lodge will hold a meeting and attend his funeral in a body.

abstract: Died in this City, on the 17th day of December inst., Edward White, formerly of the city and county of Limerick, Ireland, but for more than forty years a resident and citizen of the United States. Born in Limerick in 1784, he was in the 80th year of his age at the time of his death. He emigrated with his family to the United States in April, 1823, and settled in Susquehannah County, Penn., which was just then being reclaimed from the wilderness; and he subsequently became a resident of Binghamton, Broome County, in the State of New-York. An ardent Catholic, and a devoted and indefatigable friend of his native countrymen, he succeeded in laying the foundations of the thrifty and intelligent settlements of citizens of Irish birth and Catholic faith, which are now numerous in that section of Northern Pennsylvania and the adjoining borders of New-York. Like the patriarchs of old, wherever he moved an altar to God was raided; and the Catholic Churches of Silver Lake; Friendsville, Towanda, Binghamton and other places, bear evidence of the zeal, and faith, and good works that distinguished him. While solicitous, almost to an excess, in promoting the welfare of the laboring classes of his native fellow-countrymen and country women, there was, at the same time, no one more popular and respected than he was among his fellow-citizens and neighbors of American birth. Aided in all his duties and undertakings by the gentle, enduring sympathy and wise counsel of the saintly partner of his life, who has gone before him to enjoy her infinite reward, he was a loving husband, a devoted father, a faithful friend and just man, of whom it might be truly said that "even his failings leaned to virtue's side;" and to those who have known him best and longest, this memorial of affection will not seem exaggerated. May he rest in peace!
lead_paragraph: Died in this City, on the 17th day of December inst., Edward White, formerly of the city and county of Limerick, Ireland, but for more than forty years a resident and citizen of the United States. He emigrated with his family to the United States in April, 1823, and settled in Susquehannah County, Penn., which was just then being reclaimed from the wilderness; and he subsequently became a resident of Binghamton, Broome County, in the State of New-York. An ardent Catholic, and a devoted and indefatigable friend of his native countrymen, he succeeded in laying the foundations of the thrifty and intelligent settlements of citizens of Irish birth and Catholic faith, which are now numerous in that section of Northern Pennsylvania and the adjoining borders of New-York. Like the patriarchs of old, wherever he moved an altar to God was raided; and the Catholic Churches of Silver Lake; Friendsville, Towanda, Binghamton and other places, bear evidence of the zeal, and faith, and good works that distinguished him. While solicitous, almost to an excess, in promoting the welfare of the laboring classes of his native fellow-countrymen and country women, there was, at the same time, no one more popular and respected than he was among his fellow-citizens and neighbors of American birth. Aided in all his duties and undertakings by the gentle, enduring sympathy and wise counsel of the saintly partner of his life, who has gone before him to enjoy her infinite reward, he was a loving husband, a devoted father, a faithful friend and just man, of whom it might be truly said that "even his failings leaned to virtue's side;" and to those who have known him best and longest, this memorial of affection will not seem exaggerated. May he rest in peace!

abstract: GERMAN OPERA. The desire to attend the funeral of this enterprise has been so great, that it must be rather embarassing to the principal newspaper mourner to hear that it is not yet dead. On the contrary, it is probable that it will enter upon a new and healthy career to-night, when GOUNOD'S opera of...
lead_paragraph: GERMAN OPERA. -- The desire to attend the funeral of this enterprise has been so great, that it must be rather embarassing to the principal newspaper mourner to hear that it is not yet dead. On the contrary, it is probable that it will enter upon a new and healthy career to-night, when GOUNOD'S opera of "Faust" will be produced for the first time in German. The worst has been said of Mr. ANSCHUTZ's artists, but not the best of his orchestra and chorus. This will be reserved for to-night, when the delicate orchestral tracery of Mr. GOUNOD, and his fine broad choral effects, will be interpreted with the skill, precision and force that seem to reside only in Mr. ANSCHUTZ's baton. It may be added, too, as a matter of interest, that the whole of the music will be given. The Italian version is defective, and some cuts were even made in that by Mr. MARETZEK.

In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: ORED TROOPS. -- Under an authorization granted to the Union League Club of the City of New-York, the above regiment is to be raised and mustered into the service of the United States. This is the only regiment of colored soldiers authorized by the War Department to be raised in this State. All colored people who have been, or may be enlisted, will be sent to the rendezvous on Riker's Island to join this regiment. A Committee has been appointed, consisting of Mr. GEORGE BLISS, Jr., and others, the special duty of which will be to see that recruits are protected from impositions, and that they receive the full amount of bounty soldiers are entitled to. Most of the expenses incident to enlistments are paid by the Committee. Under such circumstances it will not be long before the Twentieth regiment of United States colored troops will be full.

abstract: Caleb H. Shipman vs. Thomas T. Ferris impleaded, &c. -- This was an action to foreclose a mortgage for $10,000 on property in Madison-avenue and to enforce an alleged liability of Ferris as a guarantor. Several defences were interposed -- among others usury and a claim that the mortgage was in fact extinguished, inasmuch as the plaintiff had accepted a deed of the equity of redemption of the mortgaged premises. The plaintiff now offered to show that Ferris, who now pleaded usury, had for years been in the habit of receiving usurious interest. This evidence was excluded by the Court. It was also claimed on the part of plaintiff that Ferris being a mere guarantor was not entitled to interpose the defence of usury. That this right belonged to the borrower alone. As against Ferris the plaintiff claimed judgment for the sum actually advanced with legal interest. The case has been on trial for two days, and the evidence being all in, it was submitted on written points.

abstract: Nine days' later advices from Europe are telegraphed from Cape Race, having been brought thither yesterday by the steamship Hibernia, from Galway on the 8th inst. There is nothing of importance politically. The news of Gen. GRANT's victory at Chattanooga had been received, and even the London Times did not pretend to doubt our complete success. The United States corvette Kearsage was off Queenstown on the 7th, and relanded sixteen men recently shipped at that port. Judgment was not rendered in the Alexandra case by the Court of Exchequer on the 7th inst., and the decision was not looked for now until the 11th of January. The Schleswig-Holstein question presented a more hopeful aspect. The steamship City of Cork, from Liverpool on the 28th instant, and bringing Cork journals to the 30th, arrived at this port yesterday. No intelligence respecting the prize-fight between HEENAN and KING has been received.

abstract: Financial Fallacies
lead_paragraph: The financial delusion which has brought the Confederacy into its present unhappy plight is one which is well worthy of our attention, inasmuch as it is one in which a large number of people at the North also are rather prone to indulge. It consists in the belief that a nation can pledge its whole property for the payment of a large debt, and that such a pledge is a good and substantial security. Nothing has been more common here as well as at the South than to see in print elaborate summings up of the value of the whole real and personal estate of the citizens of the United States, followed by an assurance that this was the exact amount of the fund on which the Government was at liberty to draw for the expenses of the war, or of any other undertaking that public liberty or security might require. At the South the same calculation was made much more gradually and with much greater confidence, owing to the fact that it possesses a monopoly of the commodity and all but a monopoly of some others of which the whole civilized world is greatly in need. The value of the Southern cotton and tobacco crop, were, we were told, so much; and of its naval stores so much; and these two added together presented the exact amount of the security which the Confederacy is able to offer to anybody who is shrewd enough to lend it money.
headline: {'main': 'Financial Fallacies.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Financial Fallacies.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A rare and valuable collection of paintings, comprising ancient and modern works, by masters of all the schools of art, will be sold at auction this evening by DANIEL A. MATTHEWS & CO., at Gibson's Building, next door to Wallack's Theatre. The most noticeable feature of the sale is the famed original portrait of WASHINGTON, painted by C.W. PEALE in 1778, and formerly the property of LAFAYETTE. We understand that a very large sum has been offered for this valuable memento at private sale; but the owner refuses to dispose of it except at public auction, believing that the competition for its possession will result in still handsomer offers.

abstract: Some time back Admiral FARRAGUT has been in this City by orders of the Navy Department awaiting the completion of his flagship, the Hartford, which, it will be remembered, returned here some months since, after one of the most active naval campaigns of the war. On her arrival, the Navy Department ordered a board of officers to survey her, for the purpose of accertaining the amount of repairs necessary. The result of the survey showed that she was terribly hacked, and needed a very extensive overhauling, which would require some months to finish. She was immediately put in dock, and all the facilities of the Navy-yard brought into operation to repair her. Some of her masts were condemned, and new ones were put in their places. Her bulwarks were badly shattered with balls; many rotten planks were on her decks; her bottom was very foul and somewhat out of repair, and her engines sadly needed looking after. In fact, the entire ship from, keel to mast-head was out of order and in need of extensive repairs. The vessel is now completely fitted up, and although she is not rebuilt, as she ought to be, as much has been done under the circumstances as could be accomplished.
lead_paragraph: Some time back Admiral FARRAGUT has been in this City by orders of the Navy Department awaiting the completion of his flagship, the Hartford, which, it will be remembered, returned here some months since, after one of the most active naval campaigns of the war. abstract: Longstreet's Retreat
lead_paragraph: LONGSTREET's action in his retreat from Knoxville has upset all the anticipations that could reasonably have been formed of what he would do. It was natural to suppose that, having withdrawn, foiled, from before Knoxville, he would make post haste into Virginia. Morever, when we reflect that he is cut off from all base of supplies, and is without any line of communications, it is difficult to see what other course was open to him. And yet he has not done so. Having succeeded in getting to a point where he is free from the danger of having his retreat cut off by a Union column moving through Cumberland Gap, he turns about at Rodgersville -- a point on the railroad about forty-five miles east of Knoxville -- takes up a position at bay, and repulses the attack of our advance cavalry force under Gen. SHACKLEFORD. At Rodgersville LONGSTREET has been joined by several detached hands of troopers, and cavalry and all included, he may now muster a force of twenty thousand men. It is needless to remark, that with this force in a strong position he has it in his power to give bloody pause to any too adventuresome pursuit.

abstract: While President LINCOLN was confined to his house with the varioloid, some friends called to sympathize with him, especially on the character of his disease. "Yes," he said, "it is a bad disease, but it has its advantages. For the first time since I have been in office, I have something now to give to everybody that calls."

abstract: -- The Anti-Slavery sentiment of Kentucky has not yet become, throughout the State, an organized political power like the Anti-Slavery sentiment of Missouri, Maryland, Tennessee, Louisiana, West Virginia, and Arkansas. It has no newspaper organs, such as it has in all these States. But it exists and grows, nevertheless, and in the elections last Fall, gave signs that in some districts it was formidable. Mr. WM.S. BAILEY, who many years ago printed and published an Anti-Slavery newspaper called the Free South (at Newport, opposite Cincinnati,) which was once destroyed by a Pro-Slavery mob and subsequently by fire, proposes to reestablish that paper, if the public will aid him, and has come to the East to procure a press and other necessary material. He has just been released from an old indictment for felony, in publishing an Anti-Slavery newspaper in Kentucky and is now free to devote himself to his work. His boldness and persistency in advocating the doctrines of Free-soil in bygone years deserve recognition now and, as he will be for some time in this City, those who would assist him may address him through the Post-office.

abstract: Both Boards of the Common Council met in special session at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, to take suitable notice of the death of Alderman ANDRE FROMENT. A message from Mayor OPDYKE, Officially announcing the sad event, and highly eurogistic of the personal character of the deceased, was first presented to the Board of Aldermen ...
lead_paragraph: Both Boards of the Common Council met in special session at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, to take suitable notice of the death of Alderman ANDRE FROMENT. A message from Mayor OPDYKE, Officially announcing the sad event, and highly eurogistic of the personal character of the deceased, was first presented to the Board of Aldermen whereupon, Alderman OTTIWELL offered a series of resolutions of respect to his memory, and of condolence with his family in their bereavement; and, also, that the Common Council would attend his funeral, drape his seat in the Board with emblems of mourning, and take charge of the funeral through a joint special committee of six. The resolutions were adopted after remarks by Aldermen OTTIWELL and HARDY, eloquently praising the character of Alderman FROMENT. The message and resolutions were then transmitted to the Board of Councilmen, and on their presentation in that Board, Councilman BRANDON made a brief but very feeling speech of regret at the loss which the public sustained in the death of Alderman FROMENT, and of warm eulogy of his many virtues as a public officer and private citizen. The resolutions were then concurred in. This was the only business transacted, and both Boards immediately adjourned out of respect to the memory of their deceased associate. The funeral will take place at 2 o'clock P.M., on Sunday, from the deceased's late residence.

abstract: The excitement relative to this contest is increasing, and the betting runs wild and unprecedented. Two to one are freely offered on HEENAN, and freely taken. It is said that MORRISSEY is betting heavily against HEENAN, and whether the report is ...
lead_paragraph: The excitement relative to this contest is increasing, and the betting runs wild and unprecedented. Two to one are freely offered on HEENAN, and freely taken. It is said that MORRISSEY is betting heavily against HEENAN, and whether the report is correct or not, it has gained currency, and made many more takers than otherwise there would have been on KING A private letter from HEENAN, received by last steamer, is full of confidence, and announces an "easy" success. KING, he says, is in splendid condition, but he (HEENAN) was never in so good. KING's tactics are to fight low -- body blows --and HEENAN is prepared for this, by, from the waist up, being a "mass of iron." Above his hips there is nothing but cords, muscles, bones. English residents are willing to take even bets, but the odds are so freely offered that they do not make the proposition. HARRY CLIFFORD, of Broadway and Eighth-street, has 83,000 placed in his hands to bet on KING. He is authorized to bet even, and awaits takers. A singular bet was made on Wednesday evening -- $150 even that HEENAN would win in thirty minutes. This is merely throwing away money, the knowing ones say; HEENAN's "quick fight" will not avail him with one who knows his tactics, is an old stager and an acknowledgedly courageous and enduring man. A chance blow, it is true, may early decide the contest, but, saving that, it will be iron muscle against iron muscle, iron will against iron will, and thorough training against thorough training. The matter of a "prize fight" is offensive even in its suggestion, but this is occupying a prominence in the public mind which fully justifies reference to it. That it is "international" is a mistake. The English papers have combatted this idea in order if HEENAN wins, to qualify the character of the defeat. This side of the water it can be claimed as not "international," because there is neither a liking for, an approval or recognition of this most brutalizing, disgusting exhibition of the "manly art of sell-defence." HEENAN fights on his "own hook." and is likely to have a much fairer chance than he had with SAYRES. He has made many friends in England. The bets on him there are heavy and "fair play," compulsorlly, must be the order.

abstract: Last night, about 8 o'clock, ROSSER'S brigade of STUART'S rebel cavalry came upon the Orange and Alexandria Railroad from the south, near Sanger's Station, and destroyed two bridges over Pope's Run. abstract: By the arrival of the Arago at this port yesterday, we have advices from the Department of the South up to Tuesday afternoon, Dec. 15. Gen. GILLMORE again shelled Charleston on the night of the 10th inst., which provoked a general ...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the Arago at this port yesterday, we have advices from the Department of the South up to Tuesday afternoon, Dec. 15. Gen. GILLMORE again shelled Charleston on the night of the 10th inst., which provoked a general bombardment from the rebel batteries, to which ours replied for several hours. Rebel accounts of this affair we printed on Thursday. A magazine had exploded in Sumter, doing considerable damage. A tremendous gale had been blowing for several days, and had been so severe that the rebel obstructions in the harbor of Charleston were very seriously injured, sufficiently so, it was believed, to render them ineffective against our fleet. Large masses of timber bolted together firmly with iron, were floating down the channel and washing ashore on Morris Island. The sinking of the Weehauken, our special correspondent states to have been the result of carelessness.

abstract: GERMAN OPERA. The production of "Faust " last evening, by Mr. ANSCHUTZ'S company, was, in every way, a success. All the principal pieces of the opera were rendered with intelligence and good effect, many of the choruses being given with very remarkable ensemble and force.
lead_paragraph: GERMAN OPERA. -- The production of "Faust " last evening, by Mr. ANSCHUTZ'S company, was, in every way, a success. All the principal pieces of the opera were rendered with intelligence and good effect, many of the choruses being given with very remarkable ensemble and force. This was especially the case in the second act, (the Kerinesse,) and in the fourth, where, with the aid of the Arion Society, the soldiers' chorus brought down the house. The principal soloists were in excellent voice, Mme. FREDERICK distinguishing herself, and, in the third act, meriting all the applause that could be bestowed upon her. The fresh and charming voice of this lady needs but the ripening which singing will bring to it, because not only enjoyable in the highest degree, but in some respects remarkable. The music of Margaret lays easily within its compass, and was delivered with great good taste and skill. Her HIMMER sang the Cavatina with clearness, and was generally painstaking and acceptable as Faust. Indeed, the performance, in all leading respects, was so good that we cannot help expressing the regret that the opera was not produced at an earlier period of the season. The house was magnificent -- probably the largest that has ever assembled in the Academy. A few such would have insured the success of Mr. ANSCHUTZ's season. "Faust" will be given on Monday, for the second and last time.

abstract: Christmas Books
lead_paragraph: -- The diligent reader of the publishers' advertisements in the NEW-YORK TIMES, will have little to learn respecting the attractions set forth by our Book Houses in anticipation of the business requirements of that time-honored period, dear to old and young -- the Christmas Holidays. Still, it may be useful to group in one view some of the leading novelties which they now offer in great abundance to the oftentimes bewildered purchaser. The gradual encroachment of Christmas, as a social festival, on the old Knickerbocker anniversary of New Year's Day, is a noticeable fact of recent growth. Within the memory of many storekeepers it was but little regarded, and the establishment of Messrs. STANFORD & SWORDS, the Episcopal booksellers, was the only one that was closed in Broadway. Now it is as a business holiday kept as the most important of the year, and the purchases of books, fancy articles, &c., for presents at "Christmas Tyde," far exceed those made in the following week, in anticipation of New Year's Day. A walk in Broadway at this season is a high aesthetic treat, so lavish is the wealth of ornamental art displayed to tempt the varying tastes of the buyers, whether intent upon securing some token for the one beloved object that shall speak -- more eloquently than words -- in the giver's absence, of what most he wishes yet fears to say, or with a less romantic purpose of filling the children's stockings with gifts from Santa Claus. Leaving to more imaginative chroniclers the task of celebrating the rainbow-tinted, silken and satin tissues -- the gorgeous-hued porcelain -- the glittering bullion and sparkling gems -- and the perfect wilderness of toys that attract one at every step in this far-famed thoroughfare, we shall briefly note some of the leading "specialties" of the different publishing and bookselling houses.

abstract: We have received several communications concerning the discomforts connected with our omnibus and city-railroad management. It will do no good to publish them. The public authorities are utterly indifferent to the rights of the people in regard to these conveyances, and the Companies that own them are becoming daily more and more insolent in their exactions. The payment of fare gives no one a recognized right to any accommodation whatever. We never saw a car so full that the conductor would not cram half a dozen more into it, without the slightest regard to the comfort of those already in, -- and we have seen policemen thrust four or five women into an omnibus already full. In Paris or in London, if a conductor were to admit an additional passenger after his vehicle is full, he would be liable to arrest. There is an officer in this City called Superintendent of the City Railroads. He receives a salary of $3,000 a year, and it is his duty to enforce all the rules and regulations upon the subject. Is there a man in New York who ever knew this officer to do a single act toward the performance of his duty? We venture to say that nine-tenths of the community did not know that there was such an officer in existence.

abstract: A hearing was had before Commissioner OSBORN, yesterday, in the case of The United States vs. Michael Hurley, Henry E. Sorrenso, Evan Edwards, and William Smith. These men are charged with murder on the high seas, under the following circumstances: They were all sailors on the American ship Lone Star, on a voyage from the East Indies, to Falmouth, England, via St. Helena. On the 3d of September, 1863, being off the Cape of Good Hope, about three o'clock in the morning, Mr. GILL, a steward on the ship, heard a scuffle on deck in the forward part of the vessel, and went up to see what was the matter. He found the first mate missing, and asked the prisoners what had become of him. They declared that he had fallen overboard in trying to harpoon a porpoise, and they had been unable to save him. It was a clear, starlight night, and no vessels in sight, but the steward on looking astern could see or hear nothing of the unfortunate man. These circumstances being reported to the Captain he put the prisoners in irons, on suspicion that they knew something more about the matter than they had told. While they were thus confined the steward was in the habit of taking their meals to them, and they subsequently confessed to him that they had knocked the first mate down with a belaying-pin, and thrown him overboard. The ship touched at the Cape of Good Hope, and from there these men were sent to New-York for trial, together with GILL, the steward, as a witness. There being no evidence against HURLEY, he was discharged. The others -- SORRENSO, EDWARDS and SMITH -- were committed for further examination.

abstract: Dickens', Charles, Works; Illustrated by Darley
snippet: Dickens', Charles, Works; Illustrated by Darley
lead_paragraph: This is emphatically the season to welcome a new and sumptuous edition of the works of CHARLES DICKENS, which Messrs. SHELDON & CO. are giving to the public, arrayed in the choicest elegance of the Riverside Press, and illustrated by some of the most felicitous designs of the forcible pencil of DARLEY. It is consoling to find in these evil days of rebellion that literature is not particularly suffering with the times. Indeed, so far from this being the case, we have noticed, within the last year or two, a growing improvement -- a higher standard adopted by our publishers. There may be fewer books issued, but they are of more value; and they are certainly better presented in print and paper. If something more is charged for there, the purchaser gets more in proportion for his money. We have noticed in these times a recurrence to the old standard literature of the seventeenth century, in the republication of the works of BACON, Sir THOMAS BROWN, FULLER, and others of that class, which is a most favorable sign of the moral cultivation and intellectual development of the country; for with the worthies of the past, to think is to feel, and to feel is to think. There is a healthy manliness -- a bracing tone in their writings suited to a period like the present. These men knew the pressure of civil conflicts -for England was nurtured to greatness by such periods of trial; and now they speak to us as if no centuries were intervening. Old FULLER's Good Thoughts in Bad Times, republished the other day, reads as if some thoughtful spiritual counselor had just written it for our meditations. Taking up not long since HOWELL's letters, a volume full of the best table-talk of a gentleman of the age of CHARLES I., we came upon an epistle which we rubbed our eyes at reading -- it seemed so like an expression of our own situation, such as we may find in the correspondence of to-day. The war, evidently, is not injuring sound literature. Our publishers, more than ever, devote themselves to standard authors; and the times are likely to produce authors who in their turn will become standard.

abstract: -Rev. J.C. FLETCHER, describing his entertainment by that Model Emperor of Brazil, Don PEDRO II., writes: "The Empress is amiability itself, while the Princesses are receiving such an education -- practical and accomplished -- as would make all sensible parents in the United States rejoice, and desire that their daughters, too, might be so wisely trained. In reference to practicality, I may mention that each of the Princesses possess a beautiful sewing-machine of the WHEELER & WILSON patent, and busy needle music is heard in the palace each day at the appointed hour for such recreation." -- Journal of Commerce.

abstract: Lamar Scheme for Breaking Blockade
lead_paragraph: -- Our readers probably recollect the letter we published some weeks since from G.B. LAMAR, of Savannah, to Ex-Mayor WOOD, of this City, in which he proposed a partnership in a scheme for running the blockade, he to furnish the capital and WOOD to bribe some authorized officer of our Government to grant permission for the vessel to enter -- the profits to be equally divided. Mr. WOOD denounced the letter as probably fictitious, but Mr. LAMAR acknowledged that it was genuine, and was vehemently abused in the Georgia papers for having sought to purchase favors of the Lincoln Government. We find in the Savannah Republican a card from Mr. LAMAR, in which he claims great credit for patriotic motives in making this proposition. It seems his object was not to make money, but to secure from the blockading Government permission for the passage of a single vessel, because that would at once destroy the blockade. He seems to think it would not have made the slightest difference how this permission was obtained. We think he would have been greatly mistaken in his calculations; indeed, we doubt whether he ever had any such hope or purpose. It seems much more like an afterthought to protect himself against the bitter censures of the rebel journals. His course in the matter involved him in a very sharp quarrel with two gentlemen of Savannah, who publish long cards in reply to his.

abstract: Several demonstrations have already been made in Congress against the Reciprocity Treaty with the British Provinces, with a view to secure its entire abrogation, or very material modification.
lead_paragraph: Several demonstrations have already been made in Congress against the Reciprocity Treaty with the British Provinces, with a view to secure its entire abrogation, or very material modification. A privilege was secured to each party in the treaty to discontinue it after a period of ten years, on due notice. That period expires in 1864. The question as yet has received no discussion in Congress; but it is plain that the body is in a temper to give our relations with Canada a complete overhauling.

snippet: Card on his Letter to Fernando Wood; G. B. Lamar's Letter to, Card on
lead_paragraph: Some weeks ago we published a letter from Mr. G.B. LAMAR to Hon. FERNANDO WOOD, proposing to enter into a joint stock blockade-running operation for running the blockade. The letter found its way to the South and gave rise to a heated controversy in the Savannah papers, which has just come into our possession. The following card, which Mr. LAMAR caused to be inserted in the News, professes to give the motives which actuated him in undertaking the operations alluded to:

abstract: Message; British Injustice to Rebels
lead_paragraph: JEFF. DAVIS devoted a part of his message to considering what should be an "adequate remedy" for the injustice which he claims that the rebels have suffered at the hands of England. That which occurred to him first was to declare all our coasts under blockade, but this plan, he says, he cannot recommend, although in doing so the rebels "would but follow the precedent set by Great Britain and France in the Berlin and Milan decrees, and in the British orders in council at the beginning of the present century" -- and the reason why he cannot recommend the rebel Congress to follow these precedents is that, as he says: "We ourselves protested against these very measures as signal violations of the law of nations."

abstract: The "gaiety" at the Confederate capital forms the subject of a paragraph in a recent letter to the Mobile Register from its Richmond correspondent. He says that "the gaiety is confined mainly but not exclusively to the loose classes, who find no better use for their superabundent Confederate notes than spending them at the theatre and the nightly balis ...
lead_paragraph: The "gaiety" at the Confederate capital forms the subject of a paragraph in a recent letter to the Mobile Register from its Richmond correspondent. He says that "the gaiety is confined mainly but not exclusively to the loose classes, who find no better use for their superabundent Confederate notes than spending them at the theatre and the nightly balls which are given in various suburbs of the city. The haut ton, on the other hand, evince a holy horror at the vulgar theatre and the vile balls of tbe butchers, but compound for sins they are not inclined to by attending tableaux vivants, where divers beauties, contrary to every principle of good taste and Southern feminine delicacy, display their charms through picture frames or stretch their finely moulded limbs on the floor or on sofas and lounges in the picturesque attitudes of famous pieces of sculpture. These model artist exhibitions -- if that be not too harsh a name for them -- are extolled in rapturous terms by those who witness them, but the gentlemen declare that the living statuary is by no means so ravishing as the low-bosomed dresses which are now in vogue. The importation of stunning manners and astounding costumes, is one of the most deplorable results of the war, and one is not surprised to hear that marriages of very doubtful authenticity have occurrred in certain circles of the unfortunate Confederate Capital.

abstract: An evening or two since, as the wife of Police Captain MILLS, of the Second Precinct, was riding up town in a Broadway stage, she was robbed of her pocketbook, containing a small sum of money, under the following circumstances: When Mrs. MILLS entered the stage there were three men inside. Two of them were apparently young gentlemen of good address, and for a time they behaved toward her with much politeness -- passing up her fare and rendering her other little attentions. The third gentleman soon left the stage, and Mrs. M. immediately thereafter noticed that one of the young men was trying to attract her attention by throwing out his handkerchief, and by various other actions, to which she gave no heed. About this time the other one took his seat near her, and she soon after lapsed into a state of half-consciousness, from which she did not recover until she reached her home. Arrived there, she found that her pocket-book was missing. The sensation felt by her was such as to leave no doubt in her mind, that chloroform was used by these men for the purpose of putting her in such a condition that it would be safe to steal her purse. The pickpockets, of course, made their escape, and they have not yet been taken into custody. Mrs. MILLS states that she cannot be mistaken about the fact that chloroform was administered to her. She had previously taken it under the direction of a physician, and knows well the taste and scent of it, as well as the effects it produced upon her.

abstract: Clark vs. Brooks' Express Newspaper
lead_paragraph: The Case of Stephen T. Clark vs. James & Erastus Brooks, all proprietors of the New-York Evening Express, has reached the point where a sale has been ordered. The points are briefly thus: The plaintiff on the 30th of November, 1855, bought of James Brooks one-sixth of an interest in the Express for $13,333 33, and was, until July 1, 1863, the publisher and financial editor of the paper. At the close of January, 1863, the parties, for the first time made a formal partnership, (marked A in the pleadings,) which, by consent, was ante-dated Jan. 1, 1863, in which the interests of the parties were thus set forth -- that the paper is owned as follows: James Brooks, one-half part thereof; Erastus Brooks the one-third part thereof, and the said Stephen T. Clark the one-sixth part thereof, and as such owners and proprietors have heretofore published the said New-York Express under the name of J. & E. Brooks. At the same time was also delivered to Clark by James Brooks a bill of sale of the interest bought by Clark, Now. 30, 1803, and the bill of sale was by consent ante-dated Nov. 30, 1855, marked (B) in the pleadings. Very soon after making the partnership, and obtaining a formal bill of sale, the plaintiff gave the legal notice [???] the termination of the partnership, and proceeded to close the business under the articles of partnership and bill of sale, asking for a receiver and a sale of the common property.

abstract: The Richmond correspondent of the Atlanta Appeal describes a recent visit to the Hotel d'Libby. He says that he found the passages and ante-rooms of the prison piled up with boxes and bales of clothing and provisions which had just been received from the North by flag of truce. Upon ascending to the upper stories of the building occupied by the prisoners, ...
lead_paragraph: The Richmond correspondent of the Atlanta Appeal describes a recent visit to the Hotel d'Libby. He says that he found the passages and ante-rooms of the prison piled up with boxes and bales of clothing and provisions which had just been received from the North by flag of truce. Upon ascending to the upper stories of the building occupied by the prisoners, he saw the greatest profusion of comforts and luxuries in the way of provant that even a riotous imagination could conceive. Hams, smoked beef, Bologna sausages hung from the rafters; tin cans of potted meat, oysters, sardines, green peas, etc., etc., were arranged on shelving against the walls; while the finest pippins rolled along the floors. Immense packages of new publications, sets of chessmen, backgammon boxes, etc., which had apparently just been opened for distribution, proved that the Yankees did not intend their unhappy brethren should die of ennui. The prisoners themselves were variously occupied, some lying at full length on the floor, deeply involved in the tragic incidents of Miss BRADDON's novels; others playing whist and euchre, or deeply pondering the gambits; others asleep; others again eating their dinners. Brig.-Gen. NEAL DOW was lapping up the soup furnished by the prison cook with evident satisfaction. One man only was reading the Bible. All looked in fine health and seemed remarkably cheerful. The receipt of boxes from home had no doubt something to do with their good spirits, but before these creature comforts had begun to arrive, they were contented and hearty. Maj. TURNER informed the writer that several of the officers of the highest rank had handed him a statement which they had voluntarily drawn up for publication in the New-York Herald and Tribune, denying in the fullest and strongest manner the infamous lies about Confederate cruelty which have recently been circulated at the North.

abstract: The new members of Congress seem determined, before doing anything else, to define their political positions. From the first day of their meeting there has been a steady flow of "resolutions " on the war, upon which members are called to vote. They have very little practical importance, and no member, ...
lead_paragraph: The new members of Congress seem determined, before doing anything else, to define their political positions. From the first day of their meeting there has been a steady flow of "resolutions " on the war, upon which members are called to vote. They have very little practical importance, and no member, whenever any distinct and definite measure is proposed, will feel in the least degree controlled by any vote he may have given on these resolutions. And yet the general tone and temper of the House may be inferred with a reasonable degree of accuracy from the action taken upon them. Mr. WOOD's proposal to send Commissioners to Richmond, in the face of the distinct declaration of the rebel authorities, that peace was impossible except on the basis of independence, was not even allowed to come to a vote -- being laid on the table very promptly, and by a large majority. Fifty-six members voted against the disposition of it, -- many among them desiring its rejection without evasion of any sort. But the action of the House at that time probably settled the fate of all similar schemes for the remainder of the session. Mr. WOOD, himself, will not be likely to press his attention again upon the notice of Congress and the country. Indeed it is asserted that he has given in his adhesion to the decision of a Democratic caucus, that the Democracy shall sustain the war, and that all peace propositions will be abandoned. If they had taken this position at the outset of the war and maintained it consistently, the Democrats would have retained the confidence of the country. As it is, they have hopelessly lost it.

abstract: Of all places in the world to generate sensations, our City may well claim precedence. Some goose is constantly laying the golden egg of wonder and astonishment, ad captandum vulgus, and if there be occasionally an apparent dearth in the way of excitement, ...
lead_paragraph: Of all places in the world to generate sensations, our City may well claim precedence. Some goose is constantly laying the golden egg of wonder and astonishment, ad captandum vulgus, and if there be occasionally an apparent dearth in the way of excitement, it is only the calm which precedes the storm. There would seem to be a sort of substratum -- a layer beneath the surface of our daily life -- ever and anon welling up at given points, but exhausting itself for the moment like the whale spouting up the entire contents it had gathered in a breath. We chronicle this morning the last new thing -- "a mysterious arrival" at one of the most popular and fashionable hotels in our City.

abstract: The Baltic Gazette announces that the house of MEIR & CO., of Bremen, have purchased for the Prussian Government the two steam-rams which were built at Glasgow [this is, no doubt, a mistake for Birkenhead] for the Confederates, and which had been stopped by the English Government. The price was a million thalers. "The news," says the Gazette, "has been received with much satisfaction, for, with these two steamers, there would be no reason to fear that the Danes could blockade the German coasts."

abstract: It was intimated yesterday, in circles likely to be well informed, that the gallant raider, Gen. JOHN MORGAN, whose recent escape from prison in Ohio, ...
lead_paragraph: It was intimated yesterday, in circles likely to be well informed, that the gallant raider, Gen. JOHN MORGAN, whose recent escape from prison in Ohio, sent a thrill of satisfaction through thousands of hearts in the Confederate States, has arrived within the Confederacy, and is consequently safe from recapture. He is expected to arrive in Richmond in a few days, when he will receive a welcome such as his bravery deserves.

abstract: -- A man named WILLIAM FROEHLICK committed suicide last night, in one of the cells of the Seventeenth Precinct Station-house, by hanging himself to the door of his cell. He came into the Station-house about 3 o'clock in the afternoon, intoxicated, and was locked up for safe keeping. When the body was found life was extinct. The Coroner was notified to hold an inquest.

abstract: Capt. FISKE and his party have arrived at St. Paul from their journey over the plains. His party consisted of but fifty-three men, three of whom deserted on the 26th of July and went to Pembina, where they deliberately concocted the story of the massacres which we received some time since.
lead_paragraph: Capt. FISKE and his party have arrived at St. Paul from their journey over the plains. His party consisted of but fifty-three men, three of whom deserted on the 26th of July and went to Pembina, where they deliberately concocted the story of the massacres which we received some time since. They report that Bannock City is being depopulated by the rush to the Virginia City mines. At the Virginia City mines the miners averaged $15 per day, and some as high as $50, $55 and even $100. The inhabitants of this gulch number some 4,000 or 5,000, and the average product is from $250,000 to $300,000 per week.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, as the officers of the Chemical Bank were about closing their business for the day, a young man of good address, presented a check to the paying teller and demanded payment.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon, as the officers of the Chemical Bank were about closing their business for the day, a young man of good address, presented a check to the paying teller and demanded payment. The check purported to have been drawn by the firm of Messrs. COFFIN, BRUCE, BISHOP & CO., of No. 39 Warren-street, dealers in hardware, for the sum of $400. It was made payable at the Chemical Bank, to A.Z. or bearer, and dated Nov. 20, 1863. The paying teller, Mr. JOHN C. PARSONS, being acquainted with the signature of the above named firm, made a careful examination and at once pronounced the check a forgery. One messenger was forthwith sent for a policeman, and another to secure the attendance of a member of the firm. Meantime, the young man who presented the check, was detained at the bank on the pretence that the business of the day being over, it would require a little time to get at the funds requisite to cash the check. Officer MCARTHUR, of the Broadway Squad, soon made his appearance, and about the same time Mr. JOHN B. COFFIN entered the bank and made an examination of the check, which he immediately pronounced a forgery. The young man was thereupon taken before Alderman HALL, acting magistrate at the Toombs. A preliminary examination was there held, during which the accused stated that his name is ROBERT KARPELS, that he was about 19 years old, by occupation a broker, and resided at No. 367 Fourth-street. He further alleged that he had received the check from GEORGE O. MARSDEN, in the regular course of his business as a broker. Who MARSDEN is, or what business he follows, did not transpire. KARPELS is a native of Germany. Alderman Hall committed him in default of $2,000 bail.

abstract: Congress; Test Vote on the War
snippet: Congress; Test Vote on the War
lead_paragraph: Well, the House has taken a test vote on the really vital principle of the war. It has long been plain to discerning minds that behind all this talk about habeas corpus, emancipation, State rights, and other questions which mere party men have sought to keep in the foreground, there has been a controlling influence quite distinct from anything that appeared in the controversy. It was something that shaped and colored the opinions of men, and predisposed them in advance to approve or denounce -- something that was "the master light of all their seeing." Between the supporters and opponents of the Administration there has been a higher issue, not so palpable as the others, because abstract, and yet that dominated all the others. The leaders of the Opposition have in general tried to keep it from view, and to this mainly they are indebted for the little success they have ever achieved.

abstract: Gen. WADSWORTH's report of his tour of inspection in the West will afford fresh proofs of the capacity of the freedmen of the Mississippi Valley to take care of themselves, to make the plantations more productive than when they were tilled by slaves, and to fight for their country. Gen. WADSWORTH concludes, from a personal examination of all the plantations and camps on the Mississippi, that everything is working as well as could reasonably be expected by those who consider the necessity incident to the suddenness of the radical change in the social system of the South, and the neglect and exposure from which the freedmen necessarily suffer upon their first arrival in the depots. The plantations on the Lower Mississippi are more productive than those above, because they have been less troubled by guerrillas and been longer in operation.

abstract: The weather, up to Monday, was quite unfavorable for the pork trade, being much too warm for slaughtering and curing; still packers seemed willing to assume the responsibility, and generally managed to dispose of the great bulk of the offerings. Since Monday the weather was quite favorable on ...
lead_paragraph: The weather, up to Monday, was quite unfavorable for the pork trade, being much too warm for slaughtering and curing; still packers seemed willing to assume the responsibility, and generally managed to dispose of the great bulk of the offerings. Since Monday the weather was quite favorable -- on Monday and yesterday -- but the faith of packers is not as strong as is necessary to give the market that briskness, which it would exhibit did that confidence exist necessary to encourage buyers that the position of the trade was a safe one beyond probable contingency. The receipts have not been as large as they were the previous week, but have been more liberal than had been expected by a large number of those deeply interested in the trade. The course of the market during the week has been as follows: Wednesday, the market opened rather dull, but there was no decided change in prices as compared with the previous day. Thursday, the market continued to rule steady, with a fair demand -- 200 pounds averages, even lots, seiling at $7 25. Friday, bad weather flattened the market somewhat, and packers not being anxious, prices ruled somewhat irregular. $7 10 was offered and $7 25 asked for 200 pound averages. The receipts were quite large, which helped to depress the market. Saturday, the weather was so warm that nothing was done, and prices were entirely nominal. Monday, the weather having changed suddenly and decidedly during the previous night, was quite favorable, and there was a better demand and a firm market, some of the foreign packers buying quite freely. Yesterday the demand was quite active, and prices advanced 10c. -- 200 lb. averages selling at $7 25@$7 30 quickly.

abstract: The regular weekly meeting of the Association was held on Thursday evening, at their room in Cooper Institute, Prof. S.D.TILLMAN in the Chair. Prof. BENJAMIN GARVEY, Secretary. During the hour devoted to miscellaneous subjects the Chairman read ...
lead_paragraph: The regular weekly meeting of the Association was held on Thursday evening, at their room in Cooper Institute, Prof. S.D.TILLMAN in the Chair. Prof. BENJAMIN GARVEY, Secretary. During the hour devoted to miscellaneous subjects the Chairman read an exceedingly interesting paper, giving a summary of scientific news. He said: A new metal had been discovered by Messrs. RICH and RITTER, in a mineral composed chiefly of sulphur, arsenic, iron, and lead. The new metal is distinguished in the spectroscope by an indigo ray, and has received the name of INDIUM OZONE, and according to the views of M.J.L. SORET, before the French Academy, has a different composition from that ascribed to it by M. SCHONBIEN, and the leading scientists. It is conceded to be an allotropic condition of oxygen. The ozonized atom expressed by prefixing the plus sign to the symbol and the deozonized atom, by the minus sign, were supposed to form a molecule of ordinary oxygen.

abstract: The remains of this gallant officer, who was killed at Missionary Ridge, in one of the battles before Chattanooga, arrived in this City on Tuesday. His family having declined the funeral honors proposed by the Common Council, the services were ...
lead_paragraph: The remains of this gallant officer, who was killed at Missionary Ridge, in one of the battles before Chattanooga, arrived in this City on Tuesday. His family having declined the funeral honors proposed by the Common Council, the services were performed in St. Mary's Church yesterday morning, and his remains placed in the vault in Calvary Cemetery. Col. O'MEARA, at the time of his death, was in command of the Ninetieth Illinois regiment, (the Irish Legion of Chicago.) Soon after the present war broke out he joined the Forty-second New-York Volunteers, (Tammany Regiment,) and from his superior knowledge of tactics was at once made Adjutant, He was promoted to the Captaincy of Company E; but at the disastrous battle of Bail's Bluff was taken prisoner, and spent eleven months in a Southern dungeon, during seven of which he was held as a hostage for a spy captured by FREMONT in the Mountain Department. On his release and exchange, Capt. O'MEARA was appointed to the Colonelcy of the Ninetieth Illinois, "Irish Legion," which he soon placed in a high state of efficiency. The regiment was ordered to join the Army of the Southwest, and was engaged at the fight of Cold-water, where it earned its first laurels. Col. O'MEARA was several times complimented by his commanding Generals for the courage and efficient conduct of himself and his men. In the attack on Missionary Ridge, on the 25th ult., by which BRAGG's forces were routed, the "Irish Legion" led the advance of SHERMAN's column. Col. O'MEARA's horse was killed; but seizing a musket in one hand, and waving his cap with the other, he cheered on his men, and was pressing up the steep, when a minie ball passed through his body, inflicting a wound from the effects of which he died at 6 1/2 o'clock next morning.

abstract: An obliging correspondent at Chippawa sends us an account of a melancholy occurrence which took place on the Niagara River on Monday last, which resulted in the death of one man by being carried over the Falls and caused imminent peril to five others, as ...
lead_paragraph: An obliging correspondent at Chippawa sends us an account of a melancholy occurrence which took place on the Niagara River on Monday last, which resulted in the death of one man by being carried over the Falls and caused imminent peril to five others, as well as the loss of a small vessel. About eleven o'clock in the morning the steam tug A.D. Griffin, of Buffalo, reached that port, having in tow two scows, the Abby and the A. Murray, of Port Robinson. The Captain of the steamer, not knowing the depth of water, kept too far into the river with not sufficient steam to keep headway on the scows. One of the latter, the A. Murray, striking against the "spites" at the entrance of the harbor, swung around with the current almost into the jaws of the mighty cataract. The Captain and four men who were on board, seeing the helpless position into which the vessel had got, and the great peril with which they were threatened -- being within less than five minutes' distance of the great fall -- leaped from the vessel and boldly struck for shore. Four of them, the Captain included, succeeded by great exertions in maintaining themselves above the surface; but, sad to relate, the fifth sank amid the leaping and boiling waters and was carried over the cataract. In the meantime a boat manned by two brave men shot out from the mouth of Welland River, to the assistance of the helpless beings in the scow. The oarsmen, Messrs. F. LAUZAN, JR., and GEORGE MORSE, pulled boldly and swiftly out, rescued the men from their perilous position and succeeded in reaching the shore just above the first rapid. One minute more and they would have been carried over the Falls to the great gulf below! Too much praise cannot be given to the men by whose presence of mind and courage four human beings were thus rescued from certain destruction. The scow glided along the stream till it reached a rock almost on the brink of the cataract, where its course was stopped, and where if will probably remain till broken up by the ice in the Spring." -- Toronto Leader, Dec. 16.

abstract: THE CONDITION OF THE STREETS AND THE GAS.  It is a shame and a disgrace to any City that its streets and its lamps are permitted to be in such a state as those in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: THE CONDITION OF THE STREETS AND THE GAS. -- It is a shame and a disgrace to any City that its streets and its lamps are permitted to be in such a state as those in Brooklyn. The citizens cannot expect much from its present Mayor, owing to his other engagements, but they can and do from Mr. WOOD, the Mayor elect, and the Aldermen who are to (after Jan. 1,) sign the contractor's orders before he gets his pay. At this time, in the Third and Sixth Wards, not more than one-quarter of the lamps are in condition to burn. The glasses are broken and the wind blows them out very soon after they are lighted. The lamp-lighter does his duty by turning the gass on and off as ordered, and on a windy night the city has all the benfit of this escape of gas. The air is impregnated with it, and the Corporation bill is much larger than if it was consumed and not wasted so. If any person will take the trouble to walk in Henry-street, from Remsen to Harrison-street, and count the broken lamps, he will be astonished, to say nothing of those in cross streets, say Warren, Congress, Harrison, and many others.

abstract: China, The Civil War in
lead_paragraph: The talents and daring of BURGEVINE have not been able to turn the scale in favor of the insurgents. The condottieri, who support the Imperialist cause, are too numerous and too enterprising to be checked by the genius and strategy of one man, and, despite his presence, the tide of fortune still runs against the Taepings, who have recently suffered several reverses. The important city of Fo-Yang has been captured after a siege of nearly four months. During all this period the Governor of Chekiang vainly endeavored to reduce it with his mandarin troops; but at length becoming sensible of his inability to make any impression on the place with the native forces, he condescended to solicit assistance from Gen. D'AIGABELLE, the commander of the Franco-Chinese legion. The Frenchman promptly responded, crossed the Tsien-Tang with 850 infantry and some artillery, effected a breach in the walls in two days, and, after five hours' hard fighting, carried Fo-Yang by storm, which, of course, passed into the hands of the Imperialists.

abstract: Adams, Mr., United States Minister; Speech in London on Thanksgiving Day
snippet: Adams, Mr., United States Minister; Speech in London on Thanksgiving Day
lead_paragraph: In pursuance to the Proclamation of the President of the United States, inviting his "fellow-citizens in every part of the United States, and also those who are at sea, and those who are sojourning in foreign lands, to set apart and observe the last Thursday of November, as a day of thanksgiving and prayer to our benificent Father who dwe[???]eth in Heaven," a number of Americans resident in London, assembled at an elegant banquet at St. James' Hall, under the Presidency of Hon. R.J. WALKER. The day was observed as a holiday by the Americans in London, and in all parts of the country, and business was suspended at the Legation and at the Consulates. The banquet last night was attended by his Excellency the American Minister, Mr. ADAMS, and by the Secretaries of the Embassy, Mr. WILSON and Mr. MORAN.

abstract: Memminger's Report
lead_paragraph: The most complete exposition of the true condition of the rebellion, in a financial and material respect, is the report of Mr. MEMMINGER, rebel Secretary of the Treasury, a synopsis of which the punished Tuesday. The document is by far the plainest and most positive in its assertions of any to which rebel statesmanship has yet given birth. Mr. MEMMINGER deserves credit for his boldness. He doesn't mince his words; he knows just how near the verge of ruin the Confederacy stands, and he tells the ill-starred rebels, in plain phrase, that there is but one possible hope of escape, and if that fails they must succumb. No doubt Mr. MEMMINGER will be berated by the "last ditch" gentry for his frankness and his exposure of the weakness of the rebellion. But he has the sense not to attempt to disguise the fact that the rotten hulk is sinking, and says, virtually, that they must make one more attempt to buoy themselves up with paper and rags, and if that fails, they must surrender. He presents a plan, on which he builds high hopes, and then notifies the rebel Congress that there is no time for discussion; the necessities of the case, and the perils of the situation, are so great, that the plan must be adopted and put in operation forthwith. Every day of delay, he says, is making the matter worse; and so if Congress stops to inquire or haggle about it, they will all be swamped in the abyss of financial ruin.

abstract: The Toronto Leader tells with great gusto the story of a Canadian who enlisted in our army and entered service in the Army of the Potomac. abstract: It is quite likely, after all, that the band of murderers who stole the steamer Chesapeake will escape the hangman's rope. The three who were made prisoners when the vessel was captured are now at liberty with the rest of the band. A howling crowd of blue-nosed Secessionists yesterday wrested them from the custody of the British officers at Halifax, to whom our authorities had intrusted them, pending the filling up of the extradition papers. Dispatches from Halifax say that the affair has excited the town beyond measure, and that the Provincial Government will make every effort to recapture the criminals. Mr. JOHNSON, the Engineer of the Chesapeake, whom the pirates impressed in their service, furnishes a statement of the movements of the vessel while she was in their possession. They did not have a comfortable time of it. Their brief career seems to have been about equally divided between hunting up supplies of indispensable coal, and devising means to escape the haunting presence of the inevitable gunboats.

abstract: The news from the West continues to be most discomforting. It appears that GRANT is doing his best to fu1fill the arrogant orders of his masters, and that BRAGG has been getting himself whipped again near Ringgold.
lead_paragraph: The news from the West continues to be most discomforting. It appears that GRANT is doing his best to fu1fill the arrogant orders of his masters, and that BRAGG has been getting himself whipped again near Ringgold. A column or mounted infantry have been allowed to reach his rear and take another battery. He has abandoned his position on the Chickamauga, and is retreating to Dalton on the road to Atlanta. The enemy are now said to have interposed between LONGSTREET and BEAGO, so that a junction is no longer possible. Where is Longstreet? Repeating Suffolk at Knoxville, it seems; piddling with batteries; investing the place; trusting to starvation. Had that fine corps of the Virginia army been in line at Lookout Mountain these disasters would never have saddened and crippled the country. It was their accession to the often beaten host of the Southwest which won Chickamauga; had they staid with it, Chickamauga would not have been disgracefully lost. But Mr. DAVIS had boasted that East Tennessee should be cleared of the Yankees before Christmas; and while Grant was concentrating Bragg dislocated.

abstract: A CASE OF CONSPIRACY EXPLODED. A few weeks since, there was published in the Police reports, a statement that one J.R. BASSETT had made a complaint against Messrs. RIESENBERGER  J.R. CARRERAS for an alleged conspiracy to defraud. The proceedings were taken on the affidavits of BASSETT ...
lead_paragraph: A CASE OF CONSPIRACY EXPLODED. -- A few weeks since, there was published in the Police reports, a statement that one J.R. BASSETT had made a complaint against Messrs. RIESENBERGER & J.R. CARRERAS for an alleged conspiracy to defraud. The proceedings were taken on the affidavits of BASSETT and one J.M. FERREIRA, the latter a former clerk of Mr. RIESENBERGER. The defendant at once gave bail for his appearance, and since then has repeatedly appeared in court and demanded an investigation of the case, but the complainant and his witnesses have never been ready. About two weeks since, Justice KELLY, of the Jefferson Market Police Court, before whom the matter was pending, received a letter from the complainant's principal witness, which among other things contained the following statement: "I have very sincerely regretted that in a fit of anger I was induced by BASSETT to sign the affidavit I made before you against RIESENBERGER & CARRERAS. The most of my knowledge of the affair came from BASSETT, and not from any knowledge of my own." Upon this Justice KELLY set down the case peremptorily for the 18th inst., on which day neither the complainant nor his witnesses appeared. The matter was therefore dismissed, and the defendant honorably discharged.

abstract: The journeymen shoemakers employed on work furnished them by the various large shoe firms of the city have demanded an advance. They have been receiving $16 per pair, but demand $18, and that for merely putting on the soles, thread and everything else being furnished. One of the largest shoe firms in the city have refused to give the advance, and will withhold work from all those who demand the advance. It is not known what action the other firms will take, but they are generally opposed to giving the advance, which, if awarded, will increase the price of boots and shoes very materially. For that reason it should be withheld, for to purchase any kind of a pair of shoes now an outlay of money is required sufficient, in former times, to comfortably clothe a person from head to foot.

abstract: In a few weeks, perhaps in a few days, the question of the redemption or repudiation of our currency  will be defintely settled.
lead_paragraph: In a few weeks, perhaps in a few days, the question of the redemption or repudiation of our currency will be defintely settled. The levity with which the former alternative has been regarded in too many sections and too many circles of the Confederacy, is already giving way to a certain fearful looking forward to the consequences of a possible restoration of the currency to a healthy tone. The more experienced gamblers are beginning to hedge, and as soon as this becomes fully evident, the amateurs, who have merely followed the lead of shrewder operators, will hasten to imitate the example of their file-readers. The line once broken, the retreat will be a rout. The prospect is not pleasant to those who are interested, however serene may be the contemplations of the lookers on, who behold the tempest from the shore on which they have been stranded by the storm of war, or from which they have not been swept by the tide of speculation.

abstract: Dr. GORDON WINSLOW, having completed the work of the Sanitary Commission at Gettysburgh, is now at the front with the Army of the Potomac. He enters at once upon the duties of his office as Inspector of the Army for the Sanitary Department. He writes: "I have come safely through, in the midst of rain and deep mud The army is quiet, except an occasional move of artillery and cavalry. The veteran Fifth New-York Volunteers are in charge of the trains from Alexandria down to the extreme front -- a very hard and exposed business. Col. WINSLOW thinks his present force quite as effective, and under better discipline even, than ever the old Fifth was. This is saying a great deal. He was never in better health or spirits."

abstract: British Accusations Against the North
lead_paragraph: Mr. BEECHER, in his speech at the Academy of Music, alluded to one matter which is familiar to all who read the English journals; we mean the reports of the Northern cruelties which have gained such credence in England. Nothing has ever shown the success which the persistent repetition of a slander may gain, as the popular belief of the middle classes of Great Britain in these imaginary stories. The denial of them, and the proving of their falsity over and over again, does not seem to produce the slightest effect. The organs, or the agents who circulate them, of course never spread these replies, and the great unthinking English public remains as firmly convinced of our enormities as ever. No American supposes that the Saturday Reviewers or the Times' correspondent can ever be governed in the slightest degree by any sense of honor or truthfulness in the case of these infamous slanders. They are paid to decry the Union cause. But when a gentleman like Mr. BUXTON, in a letter most honorable to himself, rebuking the horrible cruelty at Kagosima, alludes to the crimes of Gen. TURCHIN as a historical fact, it shows how little accurate knowledge of cotemporary events even a fair-minded and philosophical looker-on may have. The whole myth of TURCHIN and the "boarding-school rape" was never heard of here except by the few who read the Saturday Review. The acts of plunder and violence in Rome, (Ga.,) which gave a foundation to it, were fully explored by a Court-Martial and justified by the laws of war. A trustworthy correspondent of this journal exposed the story last Summer, and showed that the only act of violence committed was on a negro strumpet, whose character left it doubtful whether she was most "sinned against or sinning." Yet this explanation will doubtless never reach either Mr. BUXTON or any other misinformed Englishman.
headline: {'main': 'Northern "Cruelties."', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Northern "Cruelties."', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Chesapeake Pirates, The
lead_paragraph: The City of Halifax has struck a vigorous blow in vindication of monarchical institutions. It has proved the infinite superiority of English authority over the democratic Government of the United States, in the maintenance of law and order. A gang of mutineers, who had gone on board an American steamer as passengers, rise upon the officers and crew, kill some and overpower the rest, and take possession of the vessel. The ship is recaptured in British waters and the offenders handed over to the British authorities, for such disposition as justice may require. And a mob in the streets of Halifax rescues them from the officers of the law and sets them at liberty. So far as we can see thus far, the authorities were utterly powerless, and did not even attempt to maintain themselves against the mob. If an affair of this sort had taken place in the United States we should have had no end of British diatribes against a Government which at any moment a mob could thus overthrow.

abstract: We have received our Havana correspondence by the steamship Morning Star, and  are thus put in possession of highly interesting details of recent operations in Mexico and St. Domingo. In the former place the French army of occupation was advancing by slow stages toward the interior, and experiencing great annoyance from guerrillas, who made com-
lead_paragraph: We have received our Havana correspondence by the steamship Morning Star, and are thus put in possession of highly interesting details of recent operations in Mexico and St. Domingo. In the former place the French army of occupation was advancing by slow stages toward the interior, and experiencing great annoyance from guerrillas, who made communication with the base of supplies at Vera Cruz very precarious. A report was current that VIDAN, Governor of the State of Monterey, had turned traitor to the Juarez Government, refusing to allow Monterey to be made the Capital; and that in going over to the French the States of Chihuahua and Durango went with him. Gen. DIAZ had made a famous raid through Queretaro, Michoacan, Guerrero and Oaxaca, to Puebla, capturing 271 Reactionist prisoners, a field-piece, and quantities of arms and ammunition. The death of COMONFORT is confirmed.

abstract: Longstreet's Position in East Tennessee
lead_paragraph: The late campaign of LONGSTREET in East Tennessee, has presented many peculiar features, but not one of them is more peculiar than the fact, that after having been virtually cut off by the National forces advancing upon his rear, he deliberately marches past the stronghold he is endeavoring to reduce, a distance of forty or fifty miles, turns round, and with his rear once more safely guarded, and with a railroad for his supplies, offers to his enemy battle. Though the severe fighting, reported a day or two ago, is unconfirmed, yet there is little doubt that LONGSTREET's retreat has come to an end. Having reached a point where his flank and rear are measurably safe from assaults from the direction of Cumberland Gap, and having direct railroad communication with Richmond, which he can speedily place in order, it is quite likely that he will stop where he is, intrench and await supplies and reinforcements.
