abstract: One of the largest and most imposing funerals witnessed in this City was that of Alderman FROMENT, which took place yesterday afternoon at the English Lutheran Church on Fifteenth-street. About 1 o'clock the procession, consisting of the relatives and friends of the deceased, members of the Common
lead_paragraph: One of the largest and most imposing funerals witnessed in this City was that of Alderman FROMENT, which took place yesterday afternoon at the English Lutheran Church on Fifteenth-street. About 1 o'clock the procession, consisting of the relatives and friends of the deceased, members of the Common Council, representatives of the Grand Lodge of Odd Fellows, Tammany Society, and the chief officers of the Police Department, proceeded to church, where a large number of people had already assembled. The coffin, beautifully decorated with flowers, was borne to the altar, followed by Mr. GUNTHER, Mayor elect, Judge DALY, Comptroller BRENNAN, Supervisor TWEED, Superintendent KENNEDY, City Inspector BOOLE, and others. The funeral sermon, or more properly oration, was delivered by the Rev. Dr. JAMES SCHOUCK, who, after reading from the Bible the words "My thoughts are not your thoughts, neither are your ways my ways, for as the heavens are higher than the earth, so are my ways higher than your ways, my thoughts higher than your thoughts." proceeded to make an application of the text to the occasion. The Doctor illustrated the fact that God's ways are not man's ways in the death of Alderman FROMENT, for had it been optional with the community of which he was so useful a member, he would have lived to the age of a patriarch. God had seen fit to remove him, for what reason none knew -possibly because He wished us to have a higher appreciation of the value of good men, that we might strive the more to emulate them. The Doctor's remarks were listened to with profound attention. At their conclusion, the burial service was read and an opportunity afforded the audience to see the remains. At 2 1/2 o'clock the remains were taken from the church, when the procession was again formed, and proceeded to the interment in Greenwood Cemetery.

abstract: And the Herald--The Presidency
lead_paragraph: SPOILING GOOD GENERALS TO MAKE PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES. -- Nothing can be more admirable than the zeal and sagacity with which our neighbor the Herald is pushing Gen. GRANT for the Presidency. Every editorial article, no matter what may be its subject, winds up with an exhortation to the American people to be sure and elect him. The campaign is carried on with as much vigor as a Ward election, and by very much the same kind of newspaper machinery. "Vote for GRANT" is the closing and climax of every article, just as "Vote early" is in those sparkling paragraphs which adorn and enliven the columns of the party Press on the morning of election day.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Morning Star, we have further advices from New-Orleans. Purser FULLER favors us with a report of a small piracy of the same style as that of the Chesapeake. The schooner Joseph L. Geretz, bound from Metamoras, Nov. 16, for New-York, was captured the second day out by a party of persons, six in number, who shipped as passengers for New-York, from Matamoras. The officers and crew of the schooner were confined on board eight days, when they were put in a small boat, and after ten days floating about, they landed at Sisal, from whence the Captain and supercargo got passage to Havana. It was reported at New-Orleans that the rebels, three or four thousand strong, had made an attack on Natchez, and had been repulsed with a loss of 800 prisoners. Brig.-Gen. WEITZEL came North by the Morning Star. The reported conspiracy and mutiny among the colored troops at Fort Jackson was unfounded. There was no further news from Texas.

abstract: The last performance of the German opera under Mr. CARL ANSCHUTZ, takes place to-night at the Academy of Music. GOUNOD'S opera of "Faust" will be repeated, with Mme. JOHANNSEN in the cast instead of Mr. FARLEY. This will give new importance to the character of Siebel. The performance on Friday was so great a success that there is a uni- ...
lead_paragraph: The last performance of the German opera under Mr. CARL ANSCHUTZ, takes place to-night at the Academy of Music. GOUNOD'S opera of "Faust" will be repeated, with Mme. JOHANNSEN in the cast instead of Mr. FARLEY. This will give new importance to the character of Siebel. The performance on Friday was so great a success that there is a universal feeling of regret that the work was not produced earlier in the season. It might have changed the result of Mr. ANSCHUTZ's experiment. The public and subscribers will, we trust, seize this last opportunity of hearing "Faust" in the language in which it is decidedly heard to the best advantage, should be borne in mind that the performances commence at a quarter to 8 precisely.

abstract: RECONSTRUCTION IN TENNESSEE. -- Steps are likely very soon to be taken in Tennessee to reorganize the local authorities of the State and put the machinery of Government again in motion. Hon. HORACE MAYNARD, Attorney-General of the State, has written a letter on the subject, which advises an election for county and town officers on the first Saturday of March next. The old Constitution, and the laws as they stood in May, 1861, will be the guide; all subsequent acts, being the work of rebels, are regarded and will be treated as null and void. The old Constitution required that every voter should be a "citizen of the United States;" of course he must be one who recognizes his allegiance to the United States, and will take an oath to support the Constitution and obey the laws of Congress. The State Constitution already requires that every person elected to office shall take that oath before entering upon its duties. This will be an important step toward the reestablishment of civil authority in Tennessee, and if properly guarded, cannot be attended by any but good results.

abstract: Yesterday, at twelve o'clock, Major-Gen. BURNSIDE and lady arrived in New-York from East Tennessee. They came by way of Cleveland, Ohio, and on their arrival in the City proceeded to the Fifthavenue Hotel, where they took apartments. When it was known that the late hero of Knoxville had arrived, many persons of distinction made inquiries ...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, at twelve o'clock, Major-Gen. BURNSIDE and lady arrived in New-York from East Tennessee. They came by way of Cleveland, Ohio, and on their arrival in the City proceeded to the Fifthavenue Hotel, where they took apartments. When it was known that the late hero of Knoxville had arrived, many persons of distinction made inquiries respecting his health, and sought an interview with the gallant officer; but after the fatigues of a lengthened journey he declined to see any one until to-day. He will remain for a week, and then proceed to Washington, where he has been ordered to report. As yet the object of his visit to the Capital is not known. He appears in excellent health. Last evening the General granted a short and very agreeable interview to the representatives of the press who called upon him.

abstract: T.B. PETERSON & CO., of Philadelphia, publish twenty-eight different editions of CHARLES DICKENS' works, which they advertise this morning, with the price of each attached. These editions they generously propose to furnish to all ordering them, free of charge, by either express or mail. The prices range from fourteen to forty-five dollars the complete set, bound in substantial cloth. A complete set of Dickens, in plain muslin binding, costs in London $149. In type, paper, &c., the American is fully equal to the English edition. The Philadelphia edition, therefore, has the acceptable element of great cheapness. Another advantage it has over the English: it is wholly uniform in size, whereas an English set of Dickens, consisting of "longs and shorts," (tale 8vos. and squat, stout 12mos.,) never can range uniformly on the bookshelf. Out of twenty-eight editions, ranging at various prices, but at the lowest fully five-sixths cheaper than the books are sold for abroad, every family in this country can possess all the writings of the greatest novelist of the age. They are well adapted for gift-books.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will...
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The number of volunteers who have enlisted in this City during the past week has averaged about 50 per day a falling off of more than one half from the enlistments of the two weeks previous. This is attributed by the Supervisors' Committee to the action...
lead_paragraph: The number of volunteers who have enlisted in this City during the past week has averaged about 50 per day -- falling off of more than one half from the enlistments of the two weeks previous. This is attributed by the Supervisors' Committee to the action of the Government military authorities here, particularly in the matter of the order issued by Gen. HAYS, some ten days ago, forbidding the Provost-Marshals from certifying to the enlistment of any volunteer who did not get the $300 City bounty in his own hands. The motive of Gen. HAYS in issuing the order was most praiseworthy -- being the desire to save volunteers from the fleecing operations of what are called bounty brokers -- but its practical effect has been to lessen the number of recruits more than one-half, and if it is to continue in force, the ultimate result will be to prevent New-York from filling her quota by volunteering within the time allotted by the Government, or within any other reasonable time, A serious question arises here which demands the attention of the authorities at Washington. The City of New-York, it is claimed, is abundantly able o raise her quota by volunteering within the required time, if she is permitted to do it in her own way. In the fore part of last month a petition was presented to the President of the United States, signed by a large number of our most prominent citizens, of which the following is a copy:

abstract: Last night a very handsome compliment was paid to Hon. G. GODFREY GUNTHER, Mayor elect, by the Ball Committee of the Fire Department, of which he is President.
lead_paragraph: Last night a very handsome compliment was paid to Hon. G. GODFREY GUNTHER, Mayor elect, by the Ball Committee of the Fire Department, of which he is President. The ovation was elicited as much by pride in the elevation of a representative man of the Department, as from an appreciation of his public and private worth. The compliment took the shape of a serenade. GRAFFULA's famous Seventh Regiment Band, thirty performers, doing nine pieces. They arrived at the residence of Mr. GUNTHER, No. 145 East Fourteenth-street, about 11 1/2 o'clock, under escort of the Committee. The music was superb. Capt. CAMERON, a most capital officer, was in attendance with some hundred policemen, and the excellent arrangements prevented either rush or crush from the twenty-five to fifty people who assembled beyond the Police lines, the only demonstration being that of applause at the national, patriotic, operatic and miscellaneous airs so admirably performed. About midway of the music, Mr. GUNTHER -- the Mayor-elect of the great City of New-York -- appeared on the balcony of his residence, and made the following address:

abstract: The Court opened yesterday morning at 10 o'clock, and proceeded to try WILLAM CRUISE indicted for an assault with intent to kill on one of the riot day's in July last.
lead_paragraph: The Court opened yesterday morning at 10 o'clock, and proceeded to try WILLAM CRUISE indicted for an assault with intent to kill on one of the riot day's in July last. CRUISE was the keeper of a public-house in the Fifth Ward, and is a Democratic politicion of some notoriety, and has heretofore borne a good character. It is charged that on the 14th of July last, an assault was made upon the premises, No. 11 Worth-street, occupied by a colored family named DERRICKSON. The leader of this assaut is said to have been the prisoner at the bar. The father escaped, but the mother remained and endeavored to protect her children by concealing them under her clothing. One of them she was unable to conceal, and he a boy of thirteen years was horribly beated and his clothing saturated with camphene for the purpose of hanging him, and then setting fire to him. The mob were beaten off and the boy rescued in time to save his life.

abstract: ITALIAN OPERA. -- The king is dead! Long live the king! A sigh for ANSCHUTZ; a shout for MARETZEK. Let the dead past bury its kids; and the living present rush to STEWART's for new ones. For on Wednesday next the Italian opera commences again, and the Academy of Music will be radiant with women's smiles, and robust with men's applause. The ticket-office -- dreary fact of the past, bright promise of the future -- opens to-day. Yea, at 8 o'clock in the morning is it open; even unto 4 o'clock in the afternoon, MARETZEK himself -- redoubtable chief, invincible General -- is here, and his artists, languid with the leisure of three whole days, are eager for the fray. We shall have "Un Ballo in Maschera," my masters, -- latest and greenest of the Verdian group; have it with a superb cast, with good costumes, good scenery, good orchestra, good chorus, good everything. A handful of tickets for your friends. What could be more acceptable at this festive season? Go at 8 or before 4, or you are lost.

abstract: New-York, Bowery, Steuben House, $75,000
lead_paragraph: About 11 1/2 o'clock last evening, a fire broke out in the rear of Nos. 291 and 293 Bowery, known as the Steuben House. The upper portion of both buildings was occupied as the hotel. The lower part of No. 291 was a restaurant and lager-bier saloon. Mr. S. KAPPF was the proprietor. The flames rapidly spread through the two buildings, and, despite the efforts of the firemen, both were soon destroyed. No. 291 was four stories in height, and No. 293 five stories. Messrs. KELSEY & CADY, who occupied No. 293 as a pork-packing establishment, estimate their loss at $35,000. They are insured for $14,000, in the Harmony, Etna, Kings County, Firemens' Trust, of Brooklyn, and other Companies. Mr. KAPPF's loss is over $20,000. The loss on both buildings is about $15,000. The adjoining building, No. 295, occupied by REISSMAN & KAPPES as a tobacco warehouse, was much damaged by water. The upper floors were occupied by tenants. Their furniture was much damaged by water. Premises No. 289 were also considerably damaged by water. The Police were promptly on hand, and among them was Mr. Inspector CARPENTER, who was at the scene immediately after the breaking out of the fire and rendered most effective service. Capt. BROWER and his men, of the Seventeenth Precinct, also rendered valuable aid. Sections of men from the Tenth, Eleventh and Fourteenth Precincts were sent to render assistance, and they aided much in saving property and preserving order.

abstract: On the President's Plan of Reconstruction
snippet: On the President's Plan of Reconstruction
lead_paragraph: Mr. WENDELL PHILLIPS complains of the President's plan of reconstruction, that "it leaves the negro in the hands of the Supreme Court, so far as the federal power is concerned." We should like to know where Mr. PHILLIPS would have him left. White men of all classes and grades, from the President down to the humblest citizen, are "left in the hands of the Supreme Court." That is for them the highest tribunal in the land. Why should the negro claim or expect any other?

abstract: Henry C. Watson vs. Bernard O'Flaherty, alias Barney Williams. -- This is a case previously reported, in which Mr. Watson, the musical and dramatic editor of Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper, paper, is plaintiff, and Barney Williams, the well-known actor, is defendant. The action was brought to recover $10,000 damages for an assault and battery committed by defendant upon plaintiff at Irving Hall, in this City, on the 19th of October last. The action not being defended, judgment was taken, and the case, on motion, was sent to the Circuit to have the damages assessed by a jury. The case coming up yesterday, Mr. Edwin James opened for the plaintiff and gave a statement of the facts as they would appear in plaintiff's testimony. The plaintiff being put upon the stand testified that Mr. Williams invited him, together with Mr. Leslie, to dine with him at his country seat. That when they were through dinner, Mr. and Mrs. Williams left them in an unceremonious manner. These circumstances he related a few days afterward to Mr. Browne, a brother-in-law of Williams, who keeps a saloon called the Green-room, in the rear of Wallack's. On the 19th of October, Williams met Watson at Irving Hall and demanded an explanation of him in regard to what he had said to Browne, charging that he had said something derogatory to the character of Mrs. Barney Williams. Mr. Watson commenced to give this explanation when Williams assaulted him. Quite a number of actors were present in Court, and the defendant was put upon the stand, and gave his version of the story. The testimony of Mrs. Williams was excluded by the Court. After argument by counsel, the Jury retired and shortly returned announcing that they had assessed the damages at $1,000.

abstract: Monitors, the, judged by their Commanders
snippet: Monitors, the, judged by their Commanders
lead_paragraph: There is no more unhappy confusion of all just relations than happens when a problem purely scientific in its nature becomes entangled with selfish interests, partisan claims and personal prejudices. The course of public criticism regarding the monitor iron-clads is rapidly precipitating that question into this unfortunate plight. On the one hand it is claimed that these ships are the embodiment of every naval perfection; that they are invulnerable, invincible and all-conquering; on the other hand it is asserted that they are mere man-traps; that they are utterly unseaworthy, and that so far from being invulnerable, the delicate combinations of mechanical contrivance on which their working depends, render them extremely liable to be damaged in action. Between the two opposing sides it has ceased to be possible for any disinterested man to know rightly what to think in regard to the matter.

abstract: By telegraph from Fortress Monroe, we have a dispatch published in the Richmond papers of the 19th. from Charleston, to the effect that the Ironsides and three monitors, while attempting to pass the obstructions, became entangled, and that...
lead_paragraph: By telegraph from Fortress Monroe, we have a dispatch published in the Richmond papers of the 19th. from Charleston, to the effect that the Ironsides and three monitors, while attempting to pass the obstructions, became entangled, and that the Ironsides will probably have to be abandoned. Two of the monitors were also said to have been badly disabled. This is the result of an attempt probably made by our vessels to pass the obstructions. But the news is by no means credable. Nothing is stated for certain, and we shall probably have to wait for the truth to come through our own sources.

abstract: Both Houses seem to be getting at the important work before them. The Enrollment Act was under consideration in the Senate yesterday. The abolition of the commutation clause encounters such strong opposition that it will probably not prevail. The only amendment adopted by the Senate yesterday was one allowing veterans to reenlist in other branches of the service. Unless there are some very strong limitations or restrictions thrown around this privilege, we earnestly hope the amendment will not become a law. Without such limitations we shall have a complete disorganization of the service, for we all know enough about war, to know that the great desire of many of the infantry soldiers is to change the nature of their service to some other by which they can avoid the long and fatiguing marches on foot. Our cavalry force needs filling up, perhaps, but not at the expense of the infantry. The House, with great unanimity, passed a bill placing at the disposal of the Secretary of War twenty millions of dollars with which to pay the bounties, advance pay, &c., of volunteers now coming forward. This absorbs the twelve millions of dollars received through the operation of the commutation clause.

abstract: Both Boards of the Common Council met at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The Chamber of the Board of Aldermen was draped in mourning, in memento of the late Alderman FROMENT, whose chair was also clothed in black. The Street Commissioner replied to a resolution of...
lead_paragraph: Both Boards of the Common Council met at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The Chamber of the Board of Aldermen was draped in mourning, in memento of the late Alderman FROMENT, whose chair was also clothed in black. The Street Commissioner replied to a resolution of inquiry, that the estimated cost of replacing the piers and removing the hulks of vessels damaged by the recent great fire on West-street, is $71,411. The Comptroller's fortnightly statement of the operations of the Relief Fund showed a disbursement of $61,101 94 during the past fortnight, and a cash balance of $204,714 22. The Mayor's veto of the Mills railroad grant, published in full in the TIMES, was presented, read, and laid over. The Board adjourned to 2 o'clock P.M. to-day.

abstract: Joseph Clark et al. vs. The Steamboat Knickerbocker. This was an action for seamen's wages. The steamboat was employed in running between New-York and Albany, and the libelants were employed on board.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Clark et al. vs. The Steamboat Knickerbocker. -- This was an action for seamen's wages. The steamboat was employed in running between New-York and Albany, and the libelants were employed on board. The point of controversy was as to the jurisdiction of the Court, the claimants insisting that under the decisions of the Supreme Court as to internal commerce the Court had no jurisdiction to enforce the libelants' claim, as the vessel was running between two ports in the same State. The libelants on the other hand claimed that by the old decisions of the Supreme Court, the jurisdiction of the District Courts over such cases has been established, and that the later cases had not excluded their jurisdiction over claims for the wages of seamen, who were otherwise left without any means of enforcing their claims against vessels engaged in such navigation.

abstract: The Military Committee of the House to-day recommended the entire abolition of the distinctions of classes, and the making of the draft from the whole able-bodied male population in the United States. They also voted in their room to oppose every other amendment until more time was allowed for discussion than remained before the holidays. The indications are that the exemption clause will be retained, and that the President will postpone the draft for twenty days after the 6th of January.

abstract: We direct attention to the sale of a remarkable collection of modern paintings formerly in the possession of J. WOLFE, Esq., of this City, which commences to-night (E. SINTZENICH, Auctioneer,) at the old Dusseldorf Gallery, No. 548 Broadway. It embraces some of the best specimens of the English, French, Flemish, German and American schools, ever exhibited in this country. So many rare cabinet gems are not often placed at the disposition of the auctioneer, and connoisseurs would do well to seize the opportunity of illustrating one of the popular schools by adding these treasures to their collections. The sale commences at 12 o'clock to-day and to-morrow (Wednesday.)

abstract: An accident, which was nearly attended with the most fearful results, occurred on the Morris and Essex Railroad, at Newark, on Saturday afternoon. The Morristown Express, which leaves this City, via Hoboken, at 5 P.M., was crossing the bridge over the Passaic, when, from some cause not fully explained, the iron rods supporting the west end of the draw suddenly gave way, causing it to sag nearly two feet. The locomotive passed on to the main part of the bridge, although the cross-ties for several feet were crushed by the great weight thus suddenly brought upon them; but the baggage-car was forced from the track, and the entire side of the smoking compartment was stripped off as if it had been of paper. The three passenger cars attached were also thrown against the side of the draw with great force, and each one of them had its sides crushed in to a greater or less extent, while in the rear car nearly every seat was torn from its fastenings by the violence with which the forward part of the train came against the string pieces of the main part of the bridge. Providentially and miraculously, as it seemed to those on the train, not a single person was killed, and only one passenger received serious bruises; but the impression that part of the train had fallen through the draw, which is thirty or forty feet from the water, and the fear that the rest might follow caused the wildest consternation among the passengers who filled the three cars, until the actual extent of the damage was ascertained. The accident caused serious obstruction of travel, but by the aid of the rolling stock of the Bloomfield Railroad the passengers for Morristown finally reached their destination. Various theories are urged to account for the disaster, one that the bridge-tender neglected to lock the draw properly; another that the structure itself was defective; but as there was no one on the spot to give an authoritative explanation, the result of an official investigation must be awaited. One is as imperatively demanded as if the draw had entirely given away or the locomotive had swerved to the right instead of to the left, in either of which cases it is difficult to see how a most appalling disaster could have been averted.
lead_paragraph: An accident, which was nearly attended with the most fearful results, occurred on the Morris and Essex Railroad, at Newark, on Saturday afternoon. The Morristown Express, which leaves this City, via Hoboken, at 5 P.M., was crossing the bridge over the Passaic, when, from some cause not fully explained, the iron rods supporting the west end of the draw suddenly gave way, causing it to sag nearly two feet. The locomotive passed on to the main part of the bridge, although the cross-ties for several feet were crushed by the great weight thus suddenly brought upon them; but the baggage-car was forced from the track, and the entire side of the smoking compartment was stripped off as if it had been of paper. The three passenger cars attached were also thrown against the side of the draw with great force, and each one of them had its sides crushed in to a greater or less extent, while in the rear car nearly every seat was torn from its fastenings by the violence with which the forward part of the train came against the string pieces of the main part of the bridge. Providentially and miraculously, as it seemed to those on the train, not a single person was killed, and only one passenger received serious bruises; but the impression that part of the train had fallen through the draw, which is thirty or forty feet from the water, and the fear that the rest might follow caused the wildest consternation among the passengers who filled the three cars, until the actual extent of the damage was ascertained. The accident caused serious obstruction of travel, but by the aid of the rolling stock of the Bloomfield Railroad the passengers for Morristown finally reached their destination. Various theories are urged to account for the disaster, one that the bridge-tender neglected to lock the draw properly; another that the structure itself was defective; but as there was no one on the spot to give an authoritative explanation, the result of an official investigation must be awaited. One is as imperatively demanded as if the draw had entirely given away or the locomotive had swerved to the right instead of to the left, in either of which cases it is difficult to see how a most appalling disaster could have been averted.

abstract: On last Friday evening, the novel and interesting occurrence of the celebration of a "Golden Wedding" took place at the Astor House. It was the occasion of the fiftieth wedding anniversary of JOHN and LANEY JANE BOOLE, parents of the City Inspector. About seventy persons sat down to a banquet, which was elegant and complete. At the head of the table, presiding, sat the venerable Dr. JOHN F. GRAY, the family physician. The venerable couple in whose honor was the gathering, were on his right, the eldest son, our City Inspector on the left, and thence to right and left in different gradations the rest of the members of the family. The sister of Mr. BOOLE, Senior, was present, a lady who had reached the unusual age of 90 years, and who now witnessed the reunion of a family comprising over sixty branches. Of fourteen child ten born to the aged couple seven survive, FRANCIS JOHN ACKERMAN BOOLE, the City Inspector, now in his 44th year, being the eldest. Mr. JOHN BOOLE is now 72 years of age; his grandfather reached the rare age of 101 years, and his father the nearly as rare age of 98. Mrs. LANEY JANE BOOLE is 69 years of age. Two of the daughters and four of the sons were present at the banquet, twenty-two grand-children and one great-grandchild. After the enjoyment of the feast kindly sentiments were given and a song, "The Golden Wedding Song," composed for the occasion, was sung by the grandchildren. Thereafter presents were made the aged couple and the evening wound up with a dance, in which all the young and some of the old joined. It was a gathering of unusual pleasure and interest, and long to be remembered. Among the guests on the occasion were Recorder HOFFMAN, the Corporation Counsel, Mr. DEVLIN, Judge LOWE and Senator FIELDS, and letters of regret at inability to attend were read from Gov. SEYMOUR, Comptroller BRENNAN, District-Attorney HALL, and Mr. JOHN CLANCY.

abstract: Durant vs. Delacroix. -- No considerable time elapsed after the three months had expired before the defendant was charged in execution. abstract: MILITARY ARREST AND IMPRISONMENT. -- A rather novel proceeding was developed yesterday, in a hearing before United States Commissioner SERGEANT. A drafted man who was at the barracks, Twenty-second and Wood streets, had an altered note passed upon him at a tavern in the western part of the city, and upon the fact being communicated to Maj. FALLS, in command of the barracks, he sent a guard and had the bartender arrested and taken there. The prisoner was there placed in irons, and kept in custody the remainder of Wednesday, through Wednesday night, and up to 12 o'clock yesterday. The facts were communicated to District-Attorney COFFEY on Wednesday night, and he sent a letter to Maj. FALLS, requesting the handing over of the prisoner to him. This not being done, a writ of habeas corpus was issued by Judge CADWALADER yesterday. Meanwhile, however, Gen. CADWALADER had been informed of the action of Maj. FALLS, and through him the bartender was handed over to the custody of District-Attorney COFFEY.

abstract: The recommendation of the President in regard to encouraging immigration, has not received as yet the public attention which it deserves. He states, what all see to be true, that the nation is in a transitional and peculiar condition, when measures may be advisable, which would not be so in ordinary times. He calls attention to the great dearth of labor
lead_paragraph: The recommendation of the President in regard to encouraging immigration, has not received as yet the public attention which it deserves. He states, what all see to be true, that the nation is in a transitional and peculiar condition, when measures may be advisable, which would not be so in ordinary times. He calls attention to the great dearth of labor in agriculture and the mines, seeing clearly that the especial loss in this war is not so much the destruction and wear of property, as the loss of labor. And yet, he informs us, "tens of thousands of people throng our foreign Consulates," desiring cheap assistance for immigration, and he accordingly asks that Congress would take into consideration the propriety of furthering this immigration by some pecuniary aid.

lead_paragraph: The bark Saxon, of Capetown, Cape of Good Hope, arrived at this port last evening, from Angre Pequina, West Coast of Africa, in charge of ActingMaster E.S. KEYSER, of the United States steamer Vanderbilt. The Snxon was captured by the Vander bilt on the 28th of October, at the above place, about four hundred miles north of the Cape of Good Hope. She has on board part of the cargo of the bark Conrad, which vessel was captured by the privateer Alabama, and afterward converted into the privateer Tuscaloosa. The cargo is principally wool.

abstract: Instructions were received by United States Marshal MURRAY, yesterday, from Washington, directing him not to allow any American vessel to leave this port without a permit signed by him, certifying that the parties on board had passed under his inspection and were properly vouched for. The instructions were received at 2 o'clock in the morning, and are understood to have been the result of a Cabine[???] meeting at midnight on Monday. The Secretary of State was given cha[???] of the matter, and we assured by the Secretaries of War and Navy that every possible aid at their command should be extented to him. Accordingly, Rear-Admiral PAULO[???] received instructions from the Navy Department to station a vessel off the bar at Sandy Hook, and another at Throgg's N[???], with orders to detain every outward-bound American vessel not having a pass duly signed by the United States Marshal, certifying that her passengers and crew had been examined by his officers, and that she was permitted to depart on her voyage.

abstract: In the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, the resolution to purchase MILLS' duplicate equestrian bronze statue of Gen. JACKSON, came up and was lost for want of a three-fourths vote, and afterward it was laid over. The resolution from the Council Board to appoint a Joint Committee to erect a monument over the graves of the Catholic soldiers who have fallen during the war, and are buried in the soldiers' plot in Calvary Cemetery, ...
lead_paragraph: In the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, the resolution to purchase MILLS' duplicate equestrian bronze statue of Gen. JACKSON, came up and was lost for want of a three-fourths vote, and afterward it was laid over. The resolution from the Council Board to appoint a Joint Committee to erect a monument over the graves of the Catholic soldiers who have fallen during the war, and are buried in the soldiers' plot in Calvary Cemetery, at a cost not to exceed $12,000, was laid over under the rule. A resolution to increase the salaries of the Health Wardens and Deputies, and the Street Inspectors to $1,500 a year, was introduced and laid over. The Comptroller reported the receipts into the City Treasury for the week ending on last Saturday to have been $912,269 57; the expenditures during the same time, $1,312,332 69; and the cash balance on hand on that day, $3,075,456. The Board adjourned to 2 o'clock P.M., on Thursday.

abstract: Last Saturday afternoon, a young lady, the daughter of a well-known citizen residing up town, was shopping on Third-avenue, between Fiftieth and Fifty-first-strcets. One of her hands was ungloved, and she wore a very valuable diamond ring, which fact the sequel will show is pertinent to the story. After visiting several stores the lady walked to Forty-ninth-street, passing through it toward the Sixth-avenue. When between the Fifth and Sixth avenues she was checked by a pull on her cloak, and accosted by a young and gentelly-dressed man, who said, pointing to her hand. "I'll take that ring you have on, and your money, and watch it you have one." The lady was, naturally enough, startled and alarmed, and quickened her pace, the villain following and renewing his demand. She told him to leave her, or that he would be delivered to a policeman, when he tauntingly responded "Ha! ha! there's no policeman in sight." The lady hurried on, and he still pursued, reiterating his order for the valuables. On the lady reaching and turning into Sixth-avenue, the thief, deterred by the number of people then met, fled. He evidently had seen the lady on the Third-avenue, had noted the ring, and laid in wait to follow and rob her. The block selected was just the one for his purpose; there are few houses on it, and few passers through. The lady anxiously looked for the appearance of a gentleman during the ruffianly following, from whom she could claim protection, but not one, unfortunately, was on the street, and but two persons, both old ladies, were met. The self-possession of the intended victim was most commendable. This act is about as bold a one as has been recorded; it was perpetrated in broad daylight, in a thoroughfare. Ladies are, by the story of it, cautioned against similar ones, and forewarned to exhibit similar courage and self-possession, to that displayed by the young lady in question.

The lady anxiously looked for the appearance of a gentleman during the ruffianly following, from whom she could claim protection, but not one, unfortunately, was on the street, and but two persons, both old ladies, were met. The self-possession of the intended victim was most commendable. This act is about as bold a one as has been recorded; it was perpetrated in broad daylight, in a thoroughfare. Ladies are, by the story of it, cautioned against similar ones, and forewarned to exhibit similar courage and self-possession, to that displayed by the young lady in question.

abstract: On Tuesday week the Supervisors requested this Committee to make a detailed report of the persons they employ, and what compensation they allow them; what number of claims they had audited; at what amounts; what the original amounts of the claims were: what claims they had rejected, &c. On last Friday it was stated in the Board that the Committee had prepared the desired report, but that it wanted one more signature before it could be presented. whereupon it was suggested and assented to that the report should go over for presentation at the next meeting. This was held yesterday, but the report was not presented. Instead of it, however, the reporters were furnished with the following synopsis of the work of the Committee by their chief clerk Mr. R.C. HUTCHINGS: Number of claims presented, 2,317; number examined, 1,330; number advertised and no appearance made, 207; number reported favorably, 757; audited at $538,525 76; original amount of these claims, $700,359 21; reported unfavorably on 95 claims, amounting to $17,157 93. In addition to this the Committee have examined and reported the pay-rolls of the various regiments on service during the riot, and the bills for rations furnished the military.

abstract: Information received to-night from the Army of the Potomac, says there are no indications of a retrograde movement toward Washington, as has been reported, nor is it believed that the enemy, in their present condition, are able to give us much annoyance. Their cavalry is diminished considerably on our front, and are not equal to the task of making any formidable raid on our base of supplies, owing to the impoverished condition of their horses.

abstract: the Value of each Man
lead_paragraph: Spiritualism has made a recent conquest in the person of Prof. DE MORGAN, of the University of London. A new book just published by Messrs. LONGMAN, entitled From Matter to Spirit, the Result of Ten Years' Experience in Spirit Manifestations, by C.D., is known to be written by the wife of the Professor, who himself contributes a long preface. Prof. DE MORGAN is perhaps the most universally learned, mathematical scholar alive, and is well known as the author of standard works on Formal Logic, the Theory of Probabilities, the Differential Calculus, &c. His conversion is the more remarkable, as he has always been severe in his denunciation, of scientific pretenders, and has exercised in the London journals a sort of police against all squarers of the circle, finders of the longitude, &c. Yet he now "declares himself perfectly convinced that he has both seen and heard, in a manner which should make unbelief impossible, things called spiritual, which cannot be taken by a rational being to be capable of explanation by imposture, coincidence or mistake." From Matter to Spirit is already annouuced for republication.

abstract: Regulations Upon
lead_paragraph: The famous prize Peterhoff yesterday put in commission at the Brooklyn Navy-yard as a thorough man-of-war, having gone through the process of "conversion" in the most successful manner. No one who saw the vessel when she arrived here in charged of the prize officer, could dream of her being turned into so formidable a looking ship as she is to-day. All the mercantile features have been replaced by a regular man-of-war aspect, and the weak timbers have been replaced by very sound and strong ones. When the Petrhoff came to the Navy-yard she was very much out of repair, besides being no more than an ordinary merchant steamer, having very good engines and reputed to be very fast. She was immediately taken in hand by the authorities of the yard, and a survey was held upon her to demonstrate the amount of work to be done on her in effecting her "conversion" into a regular naval vessel. The survey estimate having been approved of workmen were put on her. Her decks were newly laid down, her bulwarks strengthened and braced in the strongest manner, a whole suite of lower apartments put in her, an excellent wardrobe and officers' mess quarters organized, and first-rate accommodations for the crew arranged. Of course this took a long time to effect, and it is only yesterday that the vessel began her career as a man-of-war. The guard of marines marched down to her at 1 o'clock, the crew from the North Carolina went on board at the same house and at a few minutes afterward the Stars and Stripes were hoisted from her peak. She will now receive her coals and provisions and leave for active service in a few days. She has been painted the regulation color and presents the appearance of a regular navy built clipper corvette. She is as sharp forward as the blade of a knife, yet she has excellent beams amidships.

abstract: A Palmer Marble, well known by photographic copies, is now on exhibition at Mr. KNOEDLER'S (GOUPIL) establishment, No. 772 Broadway. It is called "Peace in Bondage," and represents a female figure, with drooping wings and wrists pinioned from behind, looking eagerly and sadly into the future, as if for the glad tidings that are to set her free. The face of the angel is exquisitely earnest, and in
lead_paragraph: A Palmer Marble, well known by photographic copies, is now on exhibition at Mr. KNOEDLER'S (GOUPIL) establishment, No. 772 Broadway. It is called "Peace in Bondage," and represents a female figure, with drooping wings and wrists pinioned from behind, looking eagerly and sadly into the future, as if for the glad tidings that are to set her free. The face of the angel is exquisitely earnest, and in its lines curiously unconventional. The position, too, leaning forward from the trunk of a leafless tree, suggests captivity rather than parados it, and is an ingenious escape from the commonplace appliances of shackles and chains. The execution of the work is characterized by great softness. It will rank amongst the best yet exhibited by this admirable American sculptor.

abstract: on the South and His Position
snippet: on the South and His Position
lead_paragraph: A letter has lately been published, written by Hon. T. BUTLER KING in June last, in refutation of the rumor that he was in favor of reconstruction. Mr. KING, in this letter, "defines his position." He claims to have al ways maintained the right of a State to secede from the Union, and to have urged Georgia to exercise that right upon the election of Mr. LINCOLN. He says he regretted the necessity for such an act, and even hoped, after the ordinance of secession had been adopted, that the Federal Government would adopt such measures as would permit their return. The war, however, put an end to these expectations, and he has sustained it to the utmost of his ability -- having given every male member of his family to the field, and two, who were most dear to him, to a soldier's grave. Mr. KING then proceeds:

abstract: The authorities in this city, and through them those at Washington, have been made acquainted with what is believed to be a rebel plot to seize a bark about to sail from this port. A few days since two gentlemen, on the train from New-York to Philadelphia, were conversing together in regard to the capture of the steamer Chesapeake, when they were interrupted by a female sitting near, and who appeared to be somewhat under the influence of liquor. She interrupted the conversation of the gentlemen by remarking that what they were talking about amounted to nothing in comparison with what was proposed to be done in Philadelphia -- that in Philadelphia there was something more important, as a vessel was about to sail loaded with Government stores, and she was to be captured. The gentlemen paid little heed to what they at first believed to be the insane ravings of the woman, but concluded it would be better to watch her on her arrival in the city. They also took the precaution to inform the Police, and the vessel was watched. The woman, supposed to be in the cars, was seen to go on board the bark A One, a vessel belonging to Portland, Me., but which had been chartered to carry munitions of war to a distant port. It was concluded not to interfere at this stage, as the woman's visit to the vessel gave some color to her boastful story. The bark went to the Navy Yard, where a number of cannon were placed on board as freight for the use of the Navy Department. On Wednesday, the bark left for Wilmington, where she was to receive 3,000 kegs of powder at Dupont's wharf and then proceed on her voyage. After she had left this city, a tug boat containing a number of Philadelphia police officers was sent after her to watch her movements. The instructions were that as soon as the cargo was all on board, the bark was to be boarded, and her papers and crew examined, and if found wrong, brought back to Philadelphia. The captain had not joined the vessel when she sailed from Philadelphia. The result of the examination, has not yet transpired, but we understand that an order has been sent to Wilmington to have the bark sent back to Philadelphia. -- Philadelphia Ledger, Dec. 18.

abstract: Heard, J. V. D.; History of the Sioux War; Trollope, Anthony; Rachel Ray; Thackeray, W. M.; Roundabout Papers; Titcomb, Timothy; Letters to the Jones'
snippet: Heard, J. V. D.; History of the Sioux War; Trollope, Anthony; Rachel Ray; Thackeray, W. M.; Roundabout Papers; Titcomb, Timothy; Letters to the Jones'
lead_paragraph: By what secret magnetic springs, a man such as Mr. TROLLOPE describes himself to be in his American Travels middle-aged, portly, florid, bald-headed, and red-faced, has acquired his inimitable knowledge of the workings of the female heart, it is, we fear, in vain to inquire. That he possesses it no one can deny. Young ladies are to him what mosstroopers were to SCOTT, sentimental highwaymen to BULWER," or man-of-wars-men. to MARYATT. Their hopes, fears, loves, embarrassments, joys, and distresses, form the staple of his stories, and are depicted with the variety of nature itself. No English writer but Miss AUSTIN can be compared to him in this specialite, and even she yields to Mr. TROLLOPE, who is the more gentle, and consequently the truer, artist. Women can scarcely be trusted to portray women; the, sense of power implied in being "behind the scenes" makes them forget their own sex in their triumphant denunciation of offenders. Rachel Ray is a purely domestic, and realistic story. Not a character is introduced, not a sentiment expressed, but what is in agreement with the daily life of a retired English country town. A tale of successful love ruffled only by temporary disturbances, gives no opportunity for vivid interest or excitement. It must pall on the appetites of those who feast on sensation stories, but the quiet truth of the picture, the genial good humor and the fatherly interest which the writer seems to take in the fortunes of his own creations, give Rachel Ray a charm that books of higher aim and more ambitious, pretension too frequently want. If it does not add to, it well supports, Mr. TROLLOPE's well-deserved reputation.

abstract: The "New-England Society in the City of New-York," celebrated the Fifty-eighth Anniversary of their existence, and the Two Hundred and Fortythird Anniversary of the Landing of the Pilgrims in Plymouth, in their usual manner, last evening, by a dinner at the Astor House. lead_paragraph: The "New-England Society in the City of New-York," celebrated the Fifty-eighth Anniversary of their existence, and the Two Hundred and Fortythird Anniversary of the Landing of the Pilgrims in Plymouth, in their usual manner, last evening, by a dinner at the Astor House. About three hundred and twenty persons, including members of the Society and invited guests, sat down at the tables. The President of the Society, Mr. HENRY HURLBUT, presided on the occasion, and on this right sat Rev. Henry Ward Beecher, Hon. John P. Hale, United States Senator from New-Hampshire, Rev. Dr. Weston, Gen. Sickles, Judge Roosevelt, Gen. Dix, Joseph Hoxie and Wm.M. Evarts; while on his left sat Rev. Dr. Vinton, Rev. Dr. Hitchcock, Gen. Burnside, Admiral Farragut, Mayor Opdyke, Gen. Dwight, James T. Brady and John E. Devlin. Among the other guests present were Thurlow Weed, Recorder Hoffman, United States District-Attorney E.D. Smith, Lieut.-Col. Stuart, L. Woodford, of the monitor regiment, Surveyor ANDREWS, and many more. The Marine Band from the North Carolina furnished the music, and among the decorations of the tables were ornamental pieces, representing the Landing of the Pilgrims, the ship May Flower, Temple of Liberty, Equestrian Statue of WASHINGTON, Temple of Justice, etc. A large banner was suspended over the entrance to the dining-hall, on which was inscibed the words of WEBSTER, "Liberty and Union now and forever." Before sitting down to dinner, graced was said by Rev. Dr. VINTON, and after the removal of the cloth Rev. Dr. WESTON briefly returned thanks. The speaking was opened by Mr. HURLBUT, who thanked the members of the Society for the honor conferred by his reelection to the Presidency of the Society for another year, and after alluding to the distinguished guests present, proceeded to read the

abstract: Congress; Discord of the Minority
lead_paragraph: There is a general exclamation of disappointment and disgust among the Opposition journals over the fact that the Opposition Congressmen can concentrate upon nothing. It was bad enough, they protest, that no rally could be made upon one common candidate for Speaker; but this persistent refusal to combine more than sixty or seventy votes upon any Opposition measure or policy is really quite insufferable. What is opposition good for if it can only make such a shabby show as that?

abstract: We publish this morning a very interesting batch of intercepted rebel correspondence, which fell into the hands of the Navy Department last week, through the capture of the blockade-runner Ceres, which was driven ashore at Wilmington and set on-fire by the rebels, but which floated off in a storm which followed, and was secured by our fleet. Before the vessel was burned, a boat's crew from one of our ships boarded her and secured the baggage and papers of Col. C.A.P. LAAFAR, general rebel agent in Europe for the purchase of vessels and war material. Several interesting and important points are disclosed -- among them, that arrangements were making to purchase the prize steamers R.E. Lee and Margaret and Jessie, with the intention of again employing them in running the blockade; that the Wilmington blockade is disastrous to rebel hopes. A letter from W.P. CAMPBELL, of Bermuda, under date of Dec. 2, asserting that "the only boats that came in from Wilmington this moon were the Flora and Gibraltar." J.N. MAFFIT, also, formerly of the United States Navy, in a letter of the 19th of October, says: "The news from the blockade-runners is decidedly bad. Six of the-best boats have recently been caught -- among them the Advance and Eugenie. Nothing has entered Wilmington for one month." There are also several letters, asserting that the French Emperor consents to and patronizes the Matamcras blockade-running. Further disclosures are made, which are said to implicate certain parties in this City, in the business of furnishing aid and comfort to traitors in arms.

abstract: -- Last evening a very elegant Christmas Tree was provided and given to the Sunday School children of St Bartholomew's Church, corner of Great Jones-street and Lafayette-place. The Church was crowded with joyous little ones, and the festivities were carried on with great spirit. A solo, superbly sung by Miss BRAINERD, and excellent organ music by Dr. CLARK W. BRAMES, added to the either attractions. The Congregational Church at Harlem, (Rev. Mr. BOURNE's,) is holding a very successful fair, which will close this evening. The proceeds are to be employed toward furnishing the Church.

abstract: We notice in the proceedings of Congress an application for a railroad from Washington to New-York. We hope that as this matter is again before Congress it will receive the consideration its great importance demands. When the public come to understand how the interest of the whole country is made subservient to a few railroad corporations they will demand that the National...
lead_paragraph: We notice in the proceedings of Congress an application for a railroad from Washington to New-York. We hope that as this matter is again before Congress it will receive the consideration its great importance demands. When the public come to understand how the interest of the whole country is made subservient to a few railroad corporations they will demand that the National Legislature shall exert its power conferred by the Constitution to protect the public against the gross impositions to which they are subjected by State legislation upon subjects with which, by the Constitution, they have no right to interfere.

lead_paragraph: Yesterday "The Ball is Up," was on the lips, in the mouths, in the looks and smiles of old and young of both sexes, and thousands pressed up town to the Central Park lakes and Fifth-avenue Park, to abail themselves of the welcome opportunity for skating. The ice was in fine condition on the Central Park lakes, and the large attendance can be judged by the fact that nearly 4,000 pairs of skates were loaned by the parties licensed for that purpose by the Commissioners, and these in addition to the immense numbers who own ice-skimmers themselves.

abstract: The Asia at Halifax, the Jura at Portland and the Edinburgh at this port, bring us telegraphic news from Europe to the 13th inst., and our files and correspondence to the 10th. In the absence of important political news, the press of England was in a fever of excitement over the mauling match between HEENAN and KING, which was fought on the 10th instant,...
lead_paragraph: The Asia at Halifax, the Jura at Portland and the Edinburgh at this port, bring us telegraphic news from Europe to the 13th inst., and our files and correspondence to the 10th. In the absence of important political news, the press of England was in a fever of excitement over the mauling match between HEENAN and KING, which was fought on the 10th instant, and resulted in favor of the Englishman. The contest continued thirty-five minutes, and twenty-five rounds were fought. HEENAN was shockingly disfigured by the heaay blows of his opponent. The suspected rebel steamer Pampero had been formally seized by the Customs authorities. The death of Lord ELGIN, on the 20th ult., is confirmed. The news of GRANT's success at Chattanooga had caused a great turn in the Confederate Loan. The replies of Russia, Austria, and several minor Powers, to the Emperor's Peace Congress proposition are published, and it is reported that negotiations are going on to determine if the Congress shall meet regardless of England. The Schleswig-Holstein disturbance seemed to be approaching a climax, the Federal Diet threatening to occupy the disputed territory within three days if Denmark persists in non-compliance with the German demands.

abstract: Rebel Intercepted Correspondence
lead_paragraph: -- The intercepted rebel correspondence which we published yesterday has considerable interest and importance, from the evidence it affords that our blockade of the Southern coast is by no means so ineffective as has been sometimes represented. Capt. MAFFIT, who commanded one of the fastest and most successful of the rebel privateers, writes from London in October, giving very discouraging accounts of the blockade-running business. "Nothing," he says, "has entered Wilmington for more than a month," while we were here making ourselves very unhappy over the reports that vessels were constantly carrying enormous cargoes into that port, and that it did not seem to be blockaded at all. Capt. MAFFIT adds that six of the last boats that tried to enter were caught, and that it was not of the slightest use to try the adventure with any steamer that could not run seventeen miles an hour. As late as in December, one WM. P. CAMPBELL, who seems to be a rebel agent in Bermuda, writes that only two vessels had arrived from Wilmington within a month.

abstract: Effect on the War
lead_paragraph: The near approach of repudiation in the Confederacy is hailed with delight with a great many people at the North, in the belief that it will paralyze the resistance of the rebels and so at once put an end to the war. A little consideration will show, however, that this is, to some extent, a mistaken idea. If the whole Confederate currency were burnt up to-day, it would doubtless be a cause of a good deal of chagrin to those who hold large quantities of it; but that class is most probably a very small one. The community at large would not be a whit worse off than before. The land, slaves, crops, machinery, or in other words, the property of the country, would still remain and would still retain its value. The Government notes have no intrinsic value; they rest on nothing and represent nothing, but the ability of the Government to redeem them; but that no importance has been attached to this by the people of the South for a long time, is proved by the depreciation of the paper. The things for which the paper was given in exchange were a real loss, but these have been consumed long ago, and the country has become reconciled to doing without them.
headline: {'main': 'Repudiation at the South Its Effect on the War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Repudiation at the South Its Effect on the War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The superior brightness, vivacity and charm of Italian opera attracted an appropriately brilliant gathering last evening, and inaugurated Mr. MARETZEK's interlineary season with great eclat. VERDI's "Ballo in Maschera" was played with rare spirit. We have rarely heard it given to greater advantage. Signor MAZZOLENI was in fine voice, and sung with that judicious balance of power and intelligent moderation which characterizes this fine artist's best efforts. The applause after the barcarolle in the second act rendered it absolutely necessary to repeat the piece. Mme. MEDORI was received with the approbation which so great an artiste always deserves. She was in admirable voice. The dramatic opportunities of the role were seized, we need scarcely add, with the best of effect. Signor BELLINI, who sometimes disappoints his best admirers, satisfied every one on this occasion. Briefly, the performance was a great success. The singers, without an exception, were in first-rate trim. Signor NUNO presided in the orchestra with marked ability.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The superior brightness, vivacity and charm of Italian opera attracted an appropriately brilliant gathering last evening, and inaugurated Mr. MARETZEK's interlineary season with great eclat. abstract: Yesterday, at noon, the steamship Illinois sailed for Aspinwall, with 560 passengers. According to the instructions of Marshal MURRAY, Deputies BORST, JARVIS and RASBECK went on board, and, as the ship  proceeded down the bay, they made a thorough search for firearms. Among the passengers were...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, at noon, the steamship Illinois sailed for Aspinwall, with 560 passengers. According to the instructions of Marshal MURRAY, Deputies BORST, JARVIS and RASBECK went on board, and, as the ship proceeded down the bay, they made a thorough search for firearms. Among the passengers were found 165 revolvers, 16 rifles and 7 fowling-pieces, which were taken, receipted for, labeled and placed in the custodo of Purser PATTERSON, to be delivered to the claimants on reaching their destination. No difficulty was experienced by the officers, save from the loud-mouthed secessionists, who were locked up in their rooms until the search was over. The whole affair occupied over three hours, and the officers left the vessel at Sandy Hook in a tug sent down by the owners of the ship for their use.

abstract: Both Houses were brief in their doings yesterday, in order to get to the adjournment, which carries them over the Holidays. In the Senate further petitions were received from clergymen, who assert that they have conscientous scruples against bearing arms. The Inspectors of Customs at Philadelphia want their pay increased. Mr. WILSON introduced a sensible bill, providing for a uniform style of ambulances in all the...
lead_paragraph: Both Houses were brief in their doings yesterday, in order to get to the adjournment, which carries them over the Holidays. In the Senate further petitions were received from clergymen, who assert that they have conscientous scruples against bearing arms. The Inspectors of Customs at Philadelphia want their pay increased. Mr. WILSON introduced a sensible bill, providing for a uniform style of ambulances in all the armies. Mr. WADE introduced a bill, which was referred to the Committee on Judiciary, prohibiting members of Congress from acting as counsel in cases where the United States is a party either directly or indirectly. Mr. TRUMBULL's resolution asking for the names of unemployed General officers, was adopted.

abstract: The result of the King and Heenan fight was received yesterday, creating great excitement, and was at first very generally discredited by the partisans of HEENAN. Toward night, however, the doubts yielded, and an acknowledgement of defeat was made, save by a few enthusiasts. Stakes, however,
lead_paragraph: The result of the King and Heenan fight was received yesterday, creating great excitement, and was at first very generally discredited by the partisans of HEENAN. Toward night, however, the doubts yielded, and an acknowledgement of defeat was made, save by a few enthusiasts. Stakes, however, were not delivered up, but will, doubtless, with the confirmation, be handed over to-day. That HEENAN should have been vanquished so easily and so speedily -- that he should have adpoted tactics so different from his old ones -- that he so often threw KING and fell on him, doing no injury -- that he was so dreadfully punished and KING almost unscathed, are asserions that Heenan men found it difficult to believe. They pointed to the fact that HEENAN fought SAYERS two hours and six minutes -- but forgot that for over an hour of that time SAYERS had one of his arms disabled.

abstract: -In common with other New-York journals, we received from the Government Superintendent of Telegraphs a request not to publish the rebel correspondence seized on the prize steamer Ceres, as it was deemed important for the public interest that it should not be disclosed. We acquiesced in the propriety of this request, and should have complied with it, if the question of making the correspondence public had depended upon us. But we found it given at length in the Washington Chronicle, from which we transferred it to our own columns. All the public injury that can be done from its publication is done just as effectually by its appearance in one paper as in a dozen: and we cannot suppose that the Government has any wish to deprive our readers of information which it is quite willing to give to readers of others.
lead_paragraph: -In common with other New-York journals, we received from the Government Superintendent of Telegraphs a request not to publish the rebel correspondence seized on the prize steamer Ceres, as it was deemed important for the public interest that it should not be disclosed. abstract: -- A paragraph in the Boston Traveller says that letters have been received in that City "from one of the officers of Gen. ULLMAN's brigade, captured near Port Hudson, announcing that he is imprisoned in Richmond." This, so far as we can learn, is the only authority for the statement telegraphed yesterday that Gen. ULLMAN himself was the prisoner. We presume that it was not the writer's intention to convey any such idea. A dispatch from Boston, published this morning, corrects the error.

abstract: For once our great Metropolis has allowed the smaller cities to take the initiative, and Chicago and Boston are ahead of us in the Fair line. Ever as ready, however, to follow good example as to set it, our citizens are preparing to hold a Metropolitan Fair for the benefit of the Sanitary Commission, upon a scale hitherto unattempted, and which this City and State alone are capable of accomplishing. Large bodies move slowly, but the forces and elements which have been enlisted in the carrying out of the Metropolitan Fair are such as not only to insure a brilliant success, so far as the quantity and quality of the contributions are concerned, and the consequent pecuniary results, but also will present a spectacle hitherto unequaled in America.

abstract: A meeting of the officers of the Irish Legion was held at the Metropolitan Hotel last evening, to make arrangements to participate in the funeral honors to Brig.-Gen. CORCORAN, Col. MURPHY of the Sixtt-ninth, (in the field,) presided, and a large number of the officers were present. It was resolved that all the officers and privates of the Irish Legion now in New-York attend the funeral.

abstract: -The frigate Niagara, which left the Navy-yard a few days since in search of the Chesapeake, returned yesterday. During the cruise the vessel touched at several ports in Nova Scotia. The officers of the Niagara, ascertaining that the pirate crew had been captured and taken into Halifax, sailed for that harbor, which was reached on the 20th inst., and departed from there for New-York the same day, making the run to this City in 70 hours.

lead_paragraph: From Gen. AVERILL'S Department we have news of a most brilliant achievement by his command, in the destruction of the Virginia and East Tennessee Railroad at Salem, in the Blue Ridge Valley, about seventy miles west of Lynchburgh. Gen. AVERILL penetrated to this point on the 16th inst., and destroyed the bridges and culverts on the road for a distance of fifteen miles. At Salem, three large warehouses were destroyed, containing an immense amount of stores of all kinds, among which were 100,000 bushels of corn, 10,000 bushels of wheat, 2,000 barrels of flour, 2,000 barrels of meat, and many other articles, the loss of which, to the rebels, will be almost irreparable. Gen. AVERILL was opposed, on his return, by six different commands of the enemy, but he cut his way through, and returned with small loss.

abstract: In conformity with the resolutions of the Government, indicated in the order received by Marshal MURRAY, which were published in yesterday's papers, Admiral PAULDING has received orders from the Navy Department to dispatch, as soon as convenient, to the Narrows and Sandy Hook, a fleet of vessels-of-war adapted for the purpose of overhauling and search.
lead_paragraph: In conformity with the resolutions of the Government, indicated in the order received by Marshal MURRAY, which were published in yesterday's papers, Admiral PAULDING has received orders from the Navy Department to dispatch, as soon as convenient, to the Narrows and Sandy Hook, a fleet of vessels-of-war adapted for the purpose of overhauling and searching mercantile ships and steamers leaving the port. No sooner had the orders been received by the Admiral than he immediately sent for the commanding officers of the United States steamers Neptune, Kensington and Peterhoff, and gave them the necessary instructions. The Vicksburgh had gone down to the Narrows on Sunday evening, in company with the Sebago -- the latter gunboat ordered to sea, and the former remaining off the Narrows, where she is at present. The Vicksburgh yesterday overhauled the Government transport Arago and sent her back to the City for a pass, without which she was attempting to leave harbor. The Captain of the Arago thought it was not necessary to be provided with such a document, as he was in the Government service, but the Captain of the Vicksburgh undeceived him on this point. The following is a brief description of the vessels to take the position as stated: The Vicksburgh is a screw propeller, recently purchased from the Neptune Steamship Company with four others. She is a good-sized ship, having a capacity of 926 tons. Her dimensions are: Length, 185 feet; width, 33 1/2 feet, and depth of bold 18 feet. Her engines will enable her to steam very fast, their cylinders being 36 inches in diameter. The vessel was built recently at Mystic, Conn. She is commanded by Commander D.S. BROWNE.

abstract: A correspondent of an evening paper speaks of the recent mutiny among the negro troops at Fort St. Philip, below New-Orleans, as having been caused by the brutality of Lieut.-Col. BENEDICT. Some may, from similarity of names, and the slight difference in rank, suppose that Col. LEWIS BENEDICT, of this State, is the officer referred to. No one who Knows him would be likely to fall into such an error; and this explanation is made for the benefit of those who know nothing of him but the name. The fact is, Col. BENEDICT is at New-Iberia, in West Louisiana, commanding the First brigade. Third division, Nineteenth army corps, under Gen. FRANKLIN, while the affair referred to took place below New-Orleans.

abstract: REQUIRED. We hope that Congress, in considering the Military Bill, and endeavoring to perfect its details, will not overlook one point about which there has been some discussion and some controversy before the Courts. It will be recollected that both here and in other States, there were disturbances of greater or less magnitude, arising from resistance offered by Copperheads to the enrolling officers.
lead_paragraph: REQUIRED. -- We hope that Congress, in considering the Military Bill, and endeavoring to perfect its details, will not overlook one point about which there has been some discussion and some controversy before the Courts. It will be recollected that both here and in other States, there were disturbances of greater or less magnitude, arising from resistance offered by Copperheads to the enrolling officers. In some quarters it went even so far as to involve the murder of the officers, but here, we believe, there was nothing worse than assault and battery. The same principle was involved, however, and the Government felt it necessary to bring the offenders under the arm of the law.

abstract: Officer RHODES, of the Twenty-seventh Precinct, arrested a woman named LIZZIE SMITH, at No. 126 Greenwich-street, at a late hour on Wednesday night. The arrest was made on the complaint of ROBERT JORDAN, of No. 145 Washington-street, who alleges that LIZZIE stole his wallet, containing $40, and, after abstracting the money, she returned the wallet to Mr. JORDAN. The latter, in his complaint made before Justice CONNOLLY, states that he saw the accused take the money from his pocket. LOUIS WAGNER, the proprietor of the house in Greenwich-street, appeared at the Tombs yesterday, for the purpose of advocating LIZZIE's cause, when, to his surprise, he was taken into custody, on the charge of keeping a disorderly house, and held for examination. LIZZIE was committed for trial in default of $500 bail.

abstract: It seems we have not heard the last of the inquiry as to the character and destination of this vessel. Rather would it appear that it is only now emerging into the prominence it is destined to obtain. In connection with it employment is to be supplied to the gentlemen of the long robe.
lead_paragraph: It seems we have not heard the last of the inquiry as to the character and destination of this vessel. Rather would it appear that it is only now emerging into the prominence it is destined to obtain. In connection with it employment is to be supplied to the gentlemen of the long robe. We learn that the issue of those private and preliminary examinations which have been in progress for some time has been that the law advisers of the down have resolved upon instituting a formal complaint and prosecution. Mr. JAMES WEBSTER is agent for the defence, and we understand that a very strong bar has been retained on both sides. It is also said that this is not the only case of the sort likely to become the subject of judicial inquiry in Scotland.

abstract: By last night's mail we received files of Richmond papers to the 22d, inclusive. They are generally devoid of news. Much excitement had been occasioned by AVERILL'S daring raid, and all the accounts of the vast destruction of property by his command are fully confirmed.
lead_paragraph: By last night's mail we received files of Richmond papers to the 22d, inclusive. They are generally devoid of news. Much excitement had been occasioned by AVERILL'S daring raid, and all the accounts of the vast destruction of property by his command are fully confirmed. It was thought at one time that he was endeavoring to reach Danville to liberate the prisoners there. The rebels were confident of capturing him, and declared that if he escaped their cavalry had better be re-organized. Col. STREIGHT had escaped from Libby Prison, but was subsequently recaptured.

abstract: Surveyor ANDREWS having received information that the steamer George Cromwell, which plies between here and New-Orleans, and which was to have sailed yesterday, was going to take out a quantity of contraband goods, detailed several officers in his department to watch her on Wednesday night. Late in the night the officers saw a cart loaded with barrels drive up to the wharf where the steamer lay, when...
lead_paragraph: Surveyor ANDREWS having received information that the steamer George Cromwell, which plies between here and New-Orleans, and which was to have sailed yesterday, was going to take out a quantity of contraband goods, detailed several officers in his department to watch her on Wednesday night. Late in the night the officers saw a cart loaded with barrels drive up to the wharf where the steamer lay, when the barrels were hoisted on board. Before they were put into the hold the officers made their appearanceand ordered them to be put back on the wharf. On examination they were found to contain powder and percussion caps, surrounded with potatoes. Early yesterday morning, Surveyor ANDREWS and his Deputy, Mr. THOS. J. BROWN, boarded the steamer and took possession of her. Soon afterward Marshal MURRAY, with several of his Deputies, visited the steamer in pursuit of some noted characters who were expected to sail on her at 9 A.M. Several of them subsequently came on board and were arrested by the Marshal. The carman who drove the barrels to the steamer had meantime been followed up, and from him it was ascertained that the contraband goods were packed at a well-known house in Cortlandt-street, and that several more barrels were in waiting there to be carted to the steamer, had not the first load been seized. Mr. BROWN, by order of the Surveyor, seized the place in Cortlandt-street, and now holds possession of it. The officers of the steamer are also said to be implicated. The Government authorities are determined to break up the contraband trade with the rebels, which has been carried on to great extent in this City, and this is a good beginning. The persons arrested will have a hearing before a United States Commissioner on Saturday. The steamer belongs to the firm of H.B. CROMWELL & CO.

abstract: The $300 Exemption
lead_paragraph: The proposal to rescind the $300 exemption clause in the bill providing for a National Draft, has called public attention to the subject and led to a much more thorough discussion of it than preceded its original passage. It is by no means certain that the public good demands, or that public sentiment would sustain, the repeal of this clause. Unquestionably very plausible objections may be urged against the exemption, but so they may against every project that can be devised.

abstract: Ambulance Corps, the formation of an
snippet: Ambulance Corps, the formation of an
lead_paragraph: Senator WILSON's bill, organizing a uniform ambulance corps for service in all the Union armies will, if passed, supply a serious defect. The medical department has felt the want of something of this kind ever since the war began, and has made strenuous efforts to have it supplied, but without much success until last August, when Gen. MEADE issued General Order No. 85, supplying it so far as the Army of the Potomac was concerned. We published ten days ago a letter from an "army surgeon," commenting on and explaining the provisions of this order, and so clearly, that it has left us but little to say as regards the details of the system.
