abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The rarest treat of the season is offered by Mr. MARETZEK, who gives to-night, for the third time, GOUNOD'S opera of "Faust." This fine work is the present sensation in musical circles, and people who would have something to talk about when they go home, should see it.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The rarest treat of the season is offered by Mr. MARETZEK, who gives to-night, for the third time, GOUNOD'S opera of "Faust." This fine work is the present sensation in musical circles, and people who would have something to talk about when they go home, should see it. The caste is better than it was last season, in one respect, namely, the Valentine, which will be played by Signor BELLINI. In other respects it is the same; indeed, in other respects it could not be improved.

abstract: Speech at Cooper Institute
lead_paragraph: WENDELL PHILLIPS ought to be the humblest Anti-Slavery man in this country. In all the history of human progress, there never has been a more signal illustration that fanaticism is the worst of all counsellors than his case affords. By his own confession, made on a public platform in this city, he was, for twenty years before this rebellion, an out-and-out disunionist. That is to say, he was laboring for the same end for which JEFF. DAVIS was conspiring. They both were for destroying the Union; and, to all intents and purposes, they both were exactly the same traitors to the country. But WENDELL PHILLIPS was more than that; he was, what JEFF. DAVIS was not, a traitor to his cause. DAVIS was true to Slavery; and it is precisely because he was so that he sought to establish a Confederacy whose corner-stone should be Slavery. PHILLIPS was false to freedom; because he was for surrendering to Slavery, without a struggle, the very confederacy for which it was willing to risk everything.

abstract: The  Christmas Holidays were inaugurated by the usual Christmas Eve celebration at Trinity Church yesterday afternoon. Ringing out with joyous peals of music from harmonious bells, with carols, songs and laughter of happy children, Old Trinity annually...
lead_paragraph: -- The Christmas Holidays were inaugurated by the usual Christmas Eve celebration at Trinity Church yesterday afternoon. Ringing out with joyous peals of music from harmonious bells, with carols, songs and laughter of happy children, Old Trinity annually says to Wall-street. "Christmas is here; Venite Exultemus," and Wall-street closes its ledgers and cash-books and goes home, thinking of the empty stockings hanging by the chimney-side, and how if nature abhors a vacuum, young Wall-street abhors, it too, especially in his Christmas stocking. At 2 1/2 o'clock the Chimes commenced, Mr. JAMES E. AYLIFFE, ringing the following melodies on the Bells: No. 1 -- Fantasia, composed for Trinity Church Chimes, by GEORGE F. BRISTOW. No. 2 -- Christmas Carol, Silent Night, Holy Night. No. 3 -- Evening Bells. No. 4. -- Christmas Carol. No. 5 -- Christmas Carol, The Christmas Tree. No. 6 -- Vesper Hymn. The services in the Church commenced at 3 o'clock, with the Psalms for the 24th day chanted by the choir as usual. At the close of the evening prayer, Mr. CUTLER's carol, "The Christmas Tree," was sung by the children of the Sunday School, Master HOPKINS taking the solo parts. The Rev. MORGAN DIX, Rector of Trinity, then delivered a short address to the children, after which they marched in procession to the Christmas Tree, and each child received a beautiful and appropriate present. The Church was tastefully decorated with evergreens, laurrel, &c., and the Christmas Tree brilliantly illuminated and festooned with ribbons and gifts, attracted a great deal of attention. The Church was crowded to excess by members of the congregation and strangers. The church will be open this morning, services commencing at 11 o'clock.

abstract: -- The children at the Five Points House of Industry are to have their dinner and gifts to-day, as usual, from their old and tried friends. The church, who give the dinner, and the great tree loaded with a present for every one of the hundreds of children connected with the house, are only repeating a benevolence which they have shown for years. It costs something, but they do not think it too much for the happiness it affords to these representatives of the Babe of Bethlehem. The hour of dinner, &c., will be seen in the notice in our columns.

abstract: The United States vs. The Steamer Antona and her Cargo. This vessel was captured off Cape San Blas. Fla., on Jan. 6, 1863, by the United States schooner Kittatinny. The vessel and cargo were appriated to the use of the United States at the appraised value of $76,353.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Steamer Antona and her Cargo. -- This vessel was captured off Cape San Blas. Fla., on Jan. 6, 1863, by the United States schooner Kittatinny. The vessel and cargo were appriated to the use of the United States at the appraised value of $76,353. The process was served by publication, and a claim and answer was filed on behalf of J. and T. Johnson, of Liverpool, as owners of ship and cargo.

abstract: -- The passage of the ordinance giving certain holders of an omnibus grant the right to run cars on the track of the Third-avenue Railroad, brings up the question of City Railroads in a new shape. Mr. MILLS, it seems, held the right to run a line of omnibuses through certain streets. The Third-avenue Railroad Company obtained a grant to lay down a track and run cars over the same route. This interfered with Mr. MILLS very seriously, and he has now obtained the grant to use their track, on paying fair compensation, for the purpose of enjoying his original rights, and saving them from destruction. The Mayor vetoed the ordinance but approved of the main principle involved. He did not believe that any private person or company could have an exclusive right of property in the streets of the City.
lead_paragraph: -- The passage of the ordinance giving certain holders of an omnibus grant the right to run cars on the track of the Third-avenue Railroad, brings up the question of City Railroads in a new shape. abstract: One of the most glorious days of the many glorious ones had this season was that of yesterday, and Christmas came all smiles to meet gladness as well as to create it.
lead_paragraph: One of the most glorious days of the many glorious ones had this season was that of yesterday, and Christmas came all smiles to meet gladness as well as to create it. Santa Claus must have had a busy time over night, and must have been everywhere scattering his gifts with most liberal hand, for there was an acknowledgment on every face that the sly old rogue, the generous old heart, had been and gone and done it, or where he had not that he had intended to, and this was considered all the same, so well disposed was everybody to be contented and happy.

abstract: A Suggestion
lead_paragraph: It is an unfortunate but inevitable law of human society, that the excesses of a good cause destroy respect even for the worth which it contains. The wild theorizings and impracticable ideas of Socialism have prevented the majority of intelligent people from seeing the great principles which lay at its base. No idea has been put forward by modern economists which is so adapted to elevate the laboring classes, and amicably to connect capital and labor, as that of the cooperation of labor. In certain branches of industry in America this principle has been adopted with great success, and our whale-ships, pilot companies, fishing fleets, as well as some manufacturing associations in Massachusetts show how practicable and profitable the idea has been. It is simply that the laborers should have a share in the profits as well as the work, and should combine for the purpose of cheaper purchasing and of mutual protection.
headline: {'main': 'Co-operation of Labor A Practical Suggestion.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Co-operation of Labor A Practical Suggestion.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The holidays are bare of news of a belligerent character. All the armies are quiet. The Army of the Potomac is paying more attention to sutler's supplies, fresh oysters, milk, , than to the enemy. Gen. GRANT'S army is building bridges and railroads. Gen. FOSTER is quiet at Knoxville. From all quarters, there is scarce a ripple to disturb the serene enjoyment of the holidays.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will...
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The remains of Brig.-Gen. MICHAEL CORCORAN arrived in this City at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, and were deposited in state in the Governor's Room, City Hall. The body left Washington at 8 o'clock Thursday evening, immediately on its arrival from Fairfax Court-House, and reached Jersey City a little after 8 A.M. yesterday. In consequence of the uncertainty as to the time of the arrival of the body, the contemplated escort from the Jersey Ferry to the City Hall was dispensed with, and the remains were conveyed from the foot of Cortlandt-street to the Park in a hearse attended only by the officers and soldiers of the Irish Legion, who accompanied the remains from Fairfax Court-House, and the Committee of the Common Council, who went to Washington to meet the body, consisting of Aldermen Ottiwell and Councilmen McConnell, Keenan and Brandon. The officers of the Irish Legion who came on with the body were Col. Melvor, Col. Reid, Col. Flood, Capt. Schuyler, Capt. Coon, Surgeon Nelus, Lieuts. Hughes Van Cortlandt and Beil, Quartermaster Cook, Sergt. Kelly, Corp. Manning, privates Ring, Carroll and Dooley, and a drummer-boy named Wm.P. Teyhan, Brig.-Gen. THOMAS FRANCIS MEACHER and lady, and the widow of Gen. CORCORAN, also came on from Washington in the same train with the escort. During the day a large throng of citizens collected in the City Hall anxious to get a view of the remains, and at 1 o'clock the Governor's Room was opened for an hour to allow the people to look, at the corpse. The body was embalmed before leaving Fairfax Court-house, and presents a very life-like appearance. The body is encased in a handsome oval-topped rose-wood coffin with heavy silver mountings. It will be exposed to public view from 9 o'clock this morning until 3 in the afternoon. Sergt. JOHN KELLY, Corp. MANNING, and privates PATRICK RING, MICHAEL CARROLL and TEYHAN, the drummer boy, were on duty last night as guard of honor. The funeral ceremonies will take place on Sunday, and the remains will be escorted to their last resting place by a full brigade of the New York National Guard, under command of Gen. Sandford. Before the funeral, the remains will, at 8 A.M. to-morrow, be taken to St. Patrick's Cathedral, where, at 9 o'clock, solemn services, according to the rules of the Catholic Church, will be held. At their conclusion, the remains will be reconveyed to the City Hall.

abstract: The past week has been one of an unusually belligerent character. London and England have been in a state of great excitement, caused by three distinct battles, on three widely different fields of contest the battles and victories of Gen. GRANT on the Chickamauga, the great fight between HEENAN and KING, in which the champion of America was most unexpectedly beaten, and the pending battle between Mr. COBDEN and the Times newspaper.

abstract: How to keep up Strength; Union vs. Rebel Plan
snippet: How to keep up Strength; Union vs. Rebel Plan
lead_paragraph: It is a somewhat notable coincidence that, at this moment, both our own authorities and the heads of the rebellion are laboring at the same problem -- namely, to secure the continued services of the troops whose term of enlistment will expire in a few months. But the method of solving this problem in the two cases, furnishes a remarkable illustration of the different spirit governing the two communities. The Union armies will continue their existence by the voluntary reenlistment of our veteran soldiers. And the admirable feature of this is, that it is a spontanous movement, originating in the heart of our armies themselves. It is not the device of official wisdom, and is a great deal better than official wisdom could have devised. The plan was carried to Washington and not sent from there. It is, in fact, the inspiration of the patriotic impulses of our soldiers, and has for months been the theme of camp-fire conversation. At the time when the most serious anticipations were arising in the minds of those who reflected that, just at the time when the Spring campaign would be fairly entered upon, our armies would fall to pieces by the expiration of the term of service, and nothing be left our commanders but masses of raw undisciplined conscripts and substitutes -- it turned out that there was, throughout our armies, the greatest willingness on the part of whole companies, battalions, and even brigades, to enlist for another term, provided they were properly and liberally treated, and allowed to go home as organizations on furlough. There has been more delay than we could have wished in completing a system for giving effect to this patriotic proposal; but Gen. MEADE has at length embodied a plan for the Army of the Potomac which is fair and liberal in its provisions, and in accordance with which the great work of reorganization may be at once begun. This plan provides that where three-fourths of a company or regiment are willing to reenlist, they will be allowed to go home with their arms, equipments, etc., for a furlough of thirty-five days. With entire justice the "three-fourths" of a company or regiment is interpreted in the sense of three-fourths of the men of the organization actually in the field, not including those members who may be prisoners of war, or laid up in the hospitals, etc. In the plan devised for the Western army, these latter were counted in with the three-fourths, and this restriction has proved so distasteful to the men, that the spirit of reenlistment is said to be all but extinguished. We cannot but think this very unwise policy. It would be much better to apply the system adopted in the Army of the Potomac to all our armies in the field. In response to the order of Gen. MEADE, we understand that more than ten thousand men have already come forward to reenlist in accordance with its provisions. We have no doubt that the movement will extend throughout the whole army, and it is fair to anticipate that by Spring, two-thirds of the army will be enrolled for another term of "three years or the war." Nor is this all: no recruiting agents could possibly work with a tithe of the effect of those veteran regiments returned home with their grand traditions, and the emblems of many a glorious field -- each man personally interested in filling up his regiment to the full. These things make the military outlook as brilliant as could well be desired. We shall, in fact, enter upon the Spring campaign with larger armies than we have ever had before; and not only larger, but better disciplined, drilled and furnished with all soldierly qualities.

abstract: Dr. HOGE has been lecturing in Richmond for the benefit of the Young Men's Christian Association. The first two evenings were devoted by the lecturer to a pleasing, conversational account of the social and economical aspects of English life, the appearance of the streets, hotel management, ,  In reporting the first lecture, the Enquirer says:
lead_paragraph: Dr. HOGE has been lecturing in Richmond for the benefit of the Young Men's Christian Association. The first two evenings were devoted by the lecturer to a pleasing, conversational account of the social and economical aspects of English life, the appearance of the streets, hotel management, &c., &c. In reporting the first lecture, the Enquirer says: "Regarding a constitutional monarchy, with its hereditary peerage and laws of primogeniture, as the best possible form of government for England, Dr. HOGE repudiated the idea that such a form of government would be beneficial to us or could by possibility be established in the Confederate States. The constitution of England was the growth of a thousand years, and we might so soon expect to transplant hither an oak which had braved the tempest since the Conquest, as establish a polity whose chief strength was in prestige and prescription."

abstract: -- We are very glad to see that, in reviving the sutler system in the Army of the Potomac, Gen. MEADE has resolved to secure a certain amount of honest practice, by placing the trade under the surveillance of Gen. PATRICK, the efficient Provost-Marshal-General. This is certainly a great deal better than the system of abuses and corruptions that has hitherto characterized this business in the Army of the Potomac, though we think it would have been still better had the sutlers been abolished altogether, and the plan adopted of having the articles sold by these sharpers furnished by the Quartermaster and Commissary Departments. Gen. HALLECK made a recommendation to this effect in his late report. "The entire abolition of the system would," as he justly remarked, "rid the army of the incumbrance of sutler wagons on the march, and the nuisance of sutlers' stalls and booths in camp. It would relieve officers and soldiers of much of their personal expenses, and would improve the discipline and efficiency of the troops in many ways, and particularly by removing from the camps the profligate evils of drunkenness." As this has not been done, it is at least well that some restriction has been placed on the system. There is only too good reason to believe that the cause of the plan not having been adopted long ago, is the patronage headquarters has wielded in the privilege of granting licenses to sutlers. Gen. MEADE has done well in bringing this vile business to an end.

abstract: In nearly every paper we pick up we see advertisements for printers, and yet there were, before the war, more papers printed in the State of Georgia than are now published in the Confederate States. The reason of this is that at least 75 per cent. of the fraternity have been, and are now, in the army. Many of them command brigades, regiments, and companies, and are upon different Generals' staffs, while hundreds of them have met death upon the field of glory. We venture that there is not an office in the South that has not a representative in the field, and many offices were suspended at the commencement of the struggle, in order that the proprietor, editor printers and all might enlist. They are generally men of education and always of superior intelligence, and therefore fully understand the principles they are fighting for, and the hardships disease and death, incident to the life of a soldier. It is not to be presumed that they were actuated by blind fanaticism, or from love of change, or from any other cause than the purest motives of chivalry.

abstract: We  copy from the Boston Advertiser an article on this subject which is well worthy of public attention. The theory has been widely promulgated that the inhabitants of the rebel...
lead_paragraph: -- We copy from the Boston Advertiser an article on this subject which is well worthy of public attention. The theory has been widely promulgated that the inhabitants of the rebel States stand toward the United States Government in the attitude of "alien enemies," and that they may rightfully be treated as such. The position is important on account of the consequences which it involves -- or rather, of the measures which may be founded upon it. Indeed, it has been put forward quite as much to sustain and justify certain proposed plans of action, as by reason of any well-founded faith in its essential soundness.

abstract: OBSERVANCE OF CHRISTMAS IN BROOKLYN.  This holiday was celebrated with the usual spirit yesterday. The places of business were closed, and everybody appeared to be out of doors. The streets were thronged.
lead_paragraph: OBSERVANCE OF CHRISTMAS IN BROOKLYN. -- This holiday was celebrated with the usual spirit yesterday. The places of business were closed, and everybody appeared to be out of doors. The streets were thronged. Thousands repaired to the skating ponds on the outskirts of the city. The Washington, Nassau, Capitoline and Union Ponds were in full blast, and filled with skaters of both sexes. Musical entertainments were given on sereral ponds, and would have been on all if bands could have been procured for the occasion. The numerous free ponds, to be found almost anywhere about the suburbs, were also filled, and all seemed to have a happy time. The Industrial Union Schools presented a lively appearance. The children, anticipating a treat, repaired thither in large numbers, and all were satisfied. Some received skates, others books, and all candies and other good things. There was an interesting time at the Baptist Tabernacle Church, corner of Hicks and Luqueer streets, in the evening. Some years since the children of the neighborhood were gathered together by some benevolent and christian citizens. The school grew in numbers, and at length a church was organized of which the Rev. T. EDWIN BROWN was chosen pastor. The congregation is now in a flourishing condition. The exercises last evening consisted of singing by the children, dialogues and declamation. A quartette of adults sung Christmas carols and Christmas anthems -- the entire musical programme being under the direction of Mr. H.E. MATHEWS, and excellently conducted. The church was finely decorated with evergreens and flags, presenting a very pretty appearance. About one thousand children were present, besides some four hundred grown persons who take an interest in the School, which is under the superintendence of Mr. J.F. DAVIS. The average attendance on Sundays is about eight hundred. A number of presents were given after the exercises were concluded. The Superintendent was presented with a photographic album containing cartes de visite of all the teachers. It cost $30. A panorama of the Holy Land and of battles of the rebellion were given during the evening by Mr. M.R. BROWN, which added greatly to the interest of the occasion. The children were provided with plenty of good things, and all went home satisfied and pleased with the proceedings of the night.

abstract: -- The tenure of power of Gen. BRAGG's successor has been of the briefest. After retaining command of the rebel army of the Southwest for about ten days, Gen. HARDEE, chiefly known as the author of a work on tactics of which he never wrote a word, has in turn given place to Gen. JOE JOHNSTON. The appointment of JOE JOHNSTON is an imitation, in a small way, of the transfer of Gen. GRANT to the command of the Union army of the West -- that is, it is made with a view to concentration. JOHNSTON takes with him the bulk of the ragtag and bobtail army with which he has ever since his fiasco in Mississippi been hovering about the outlying dominions of the war. His chief work will be to try and infuse some spirit and discipline into an army, which, according to all testimony, is as utterly demoralized as men can well be and still hold together. JOE JOHNSTON has the reputation of being one of the ablest officers in the rebel service -- next to LEE, perhaps, the very ablest. He was in chief command at the first battle of the war -- Bull Run -- and led the rebel army in the battles before Richmond until wounded, since which time he has done nothing to speak of.

abstract: Gray's Ferry bridge, spanning the Schuylkill,  and carrying the Baltimore Railroad track, has often been on fire, but the presence of watchmen prevented the spread of the flames. On Thursday it caught fire from sparks of the locomotive...
lead_paragraph: Gray's Ferry bridge, spanning the Schuylkill, and carrying the Baltimore Railroad track, has often been on fire, but the presence of watchmen prevented the spread of the flames. On Thursday it caught fire from sparks of the locomotive of the accommodation train for Wilmington at a quarter past 1 o'clock. The sparks were seen first immediately over the first western pier, under the roof. The employes of the road on the spot set about extinguishing the flames. The fire worked on under the roof in such a manner that they could not reach it. The bridge was wholly of wood. The recent cold weather had dried it like touch-wood. A keen, strong breeze, was blowing. In a little time the germ had increased into a volume of flame beyond extinguishment. That one span was entirely destroyed, together with the house of the "bridge-tender," and a range of fencing.

abstract: ARRESTS FOR COUNTERFEITING AN ATTEMPT TO FLOOD THE CITY WITH SPURIOUS MONEY. On Christmas Eve the counterfeiters were very numerous and very active among the shopkeepers throughout this City and Brooklyn. From all the evidence we can obtain, it appears that the rogues had everything well-arranged for a successful onslaught, and but for the telegraph and the Police they would have bad it all their own way.
lead_paragraph: ARRESTS FOR COUNTERFEITING -- AN ATTEMPT TO FLOOD THE CITY WITH SPURIOUS MONEY. -- On Christmas Eve the counterfeiters were very numerous and very active among the shopkeepers throughout this City and Brooklyn. From all the evidence we can obtain, it appears that the rogues had everything well-arranged for a successful onslaught, and but for the telegraph and the Police they would have bad it all their own way. In the early part of the evening the circulation of the bogus money began, and quite an amount was passed off upon unsuspecting people before the Police were notified. The counterfeits were mainly $2 bills on the Bank of Albion, Orleans County, this State; $5's on HENRY D. BARTO & CO.'s Bank of Trumansburgh, Cayuga County, and $5's on the Clinton Bank, N.Y. The Police made a large number of arrests, the following are reported: PATRICK RYAN and EDMOND BLAKE were taken into custody by Officer BRENNAN, of the Sixth Precinct, charged with passing spurious $5 bills on BARTO & CO.'s Bank to E. MILLER, of No. 54 Chatham-street; also, with passing a $5 bill on the same bank at a saloon, No. 58 Chatham-street, Officer TOWN, of the Fourth Precinct, arrested FREDERICK COOKE for passing a $2 bill on the Bank of Albion to GEO, SCHMIDT, of No. 449 William-street. A large quantity of bad money was found in his possession. GEORGE COLE and THOMAS ALTER were arrested by the Twelfth Precinct Police for passing counterfeit $2 bills on the Albion Bank. JAMES WILSON was taken into custody for attempting to pass $2 bills on the same bank, at No. 170 Eighth-avenue. The prisoners were all committed for examination. Those who have been imposed upon by these counterfeits are requested to call at the Tombs this morning for the purpose of identifying the prisoners.

abstract: Cobden, Richard, and the London Times--Spicy Controversy
snippet: Cobden, Richard, and the London Times--Spicy Controversy
lead_paragraph: -A very spicy controversy has taken place between Mr. COBDEN and that mythical personage, the editor of the London Times, through the medium of the other London journals. It seems the Times was guilty of a gross misrepresentation of Mr. BRIGHT's speech at Rochdale, and directly charged him with having advocated the division of the lands of the rich among the poor. Mr. COBDEN, who spoke at the same place and time with Mr. BRIGHT, takes up the charge in a terribly severe letter to the Times, in which he strips the "impersonal" shield from the editor, and lays bare the "moral cowardice," and "preeminent unscrupulousness" with which the Times has always treated questions of politics and society, shielded by the impenetrable incognito of "The Editor." This letter the Editor of the Times received, and it seems, without reading it, announced in his "notices to correspondents" that it would "appear to-morrow." But upon reading it, or upon second thought, perhaps, "The Editor" decided not to print it, and sent Mr. COBDEN a note, stating his reasons. Mr. COBDEN thereupon addressed a letter to the Daily News, which published it in full. This irritated "The Editor," who sent a copy of his note to Mr. COBDEN to the Editor of the News, with a request to publish, intimating in his missive that Mr. COBDEN acted unfairly in sending the letter to the News without a copy of "The Editor's" reply. We publish both documents, and the reader will see the masterly manner in which Mr. COBDEN exposes the dishonorable practices by which the writers or the editors of the Times, have always mercilessly assaulted persons and projects, and always taken refuge behind the great "impersonal" feature of the paper.

abstract: -- One of the Richmond journals censures very severely the members of Congress and others who denounce the action of the Government. At this "solemn crisis" of their affairs, everything, it reminds them, depends upon unity and harmony of action. "No one," it adds, "in case of shipwreck, has so much to lose" as JEFFERSON DAVIS: and therefore he may be relied on to do everything in his power for the salvation of the country. It may occur to some of the Southern people that this does not necessarily follow. JEFF. DAVIS will undoubtedly do everything he can to secure his own salvation, but that and the salvation of the country, it may be, are not precisely the same thing. The Confederate President is not in the condition most favorable to the exercise of an independent and disinterested judgment as to what the welfare of the country requires. His personal stake in the matter, naturally and inevitably, affects his opinions.

abstract: The performance of "Faust," last evening, was in many respects, one of the best ever given, of any opera, in the Academy of Music. The result of a few performances in Philadelphia was perceptible in the steadiness and certainty of all the artists.
lead_paragraph: The performance of "Faust," last evening, was in many respects, one of the best ever given, of any opera, in the Academy of Music. The result of a few performances in Philadelphia was perceptible in the steadiness and certainty of all the artists. GOUNOD's opera, more than any other, requires absolute clearness in the rendition. The melodies are sometimes of uncertain outline, and always reticent. It is only when the singer has thoroughly mastered them himself that he can lay them in an intelligent way before the audience. This is now the case, and the effect is naturally much improved. The whole performance last night was powerful, clear, and thoroughly enjoyable, but one change was made in the distribution. The part of Valentine, on this occasion, was played by Signor BELLINI, and without disrespect to his predecessor, Signor YPOLITO, we may state that the saliencies of the role -- and in competent hands they are numerous enough -- were rendered with great gusto. The change, we hope, is a permanent one. During the evening several pieces were encored, and the applause was warmer and better distributed than it has been on any previous occasion.

abstract: -- A fairer day never dawned than the Christmas of yesterday, and the extent of social festivity, probably, never was greater. The clear sky, and the bracing, vigorous air, gave zest to all out-door amusements, and added heart and glow to scenes within. Everywhere happiness and pleasure seemed to reign, and there was that in the bright, genial beauty of the day, which seemed to prophesy a speedy return of "peace and good-will toward men" in our own struggling land. There is no one but could take heart anew after such a holiday.

abstract: The Halifax Citizen says  that Lieut. BRAINE was not the real Commander of the Chesapeake. At Grand Manan, Capt. VERNON LOCKE, of Ragged Islands, who has been for some time in the Confederate service, joined the ship, and assumed the command.
lead_paragraph: -- The Halifax Citizen says that Lieut. BRAINE was not the real Commander of the Chesapeake. At Grand Manan, Capt. VERNON LOCKE, of Ragged Islands, who has been for some time in the Confederate service, joined the ship, and assumed the command. BRAINE left the ship either at Shelburne or La Have, and did not return on board. He was in Halifax one or two nights of last week. On the 16th, a warrant was issued for his apprehension, charging him with the crime of piracy and murder, and officers were in pursuit of him. The Citizen, says:

abstract: -- This vigorous and worthy Association give a grand patriotic reunion at the Academy of Music to-night. The patriotic labors of this body have resulted in feeding, clothing and providing for nearly thirty thousand soldiers within the last nineteen months. These men were not all from New-England, but from all States. The Society now finds its Treasury depleted, and its good works diminished in consequence. They appeal to the public, through the medium of an elegant entertainment this evening, to replenish their funds. Let the responses be both numerous and liberal, for what sweeter consciousness of money well spent can there be than the feeling that it is cheering the hearts, relieving the sufferings and encouraging the spirits of the gallant defenders of the American Union? Hon. JAMES T. BRADY will preside and deliver an address. Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER will certainly be present and make one of his eloquent speeches. A stand of colors, from Gov. ANDREW, will be presented to the Association by Col. HOWE, and will be received by W.M. EVARTS, Esq. The band of the Fifth United States artillery will furnish the music.

Its general correspondence, both foreign and domestic, is fresh and full, and its columns are always filled with the latest intelligence from all quarters of the globe. Special attention is paid to market reports and agricultural affairs, by competent editors, and its information in this particular may be relied upon as always correct -- Fishkill Standard.

abstract: A WOMAN BURNED TO DEATH. Late on Friday evening last, the premises No.52 Barrow-street were found to be on fire. The neighbors gave the alarm; and speedily forced open the door of the apartment whence the flames issued. Lying on the floor, completely enveloped in flame, they found Mrs. HANNON, ...
lead_paragraph: A WOMAN BURNED TO DEATH. Late on Friday evening last, the premises No.52 Barrow-street were found to be on fire. The neighbors gave the alarm; and speedily forced open the door of the apartment whence the flames issued. Lying on the floor, completely enveloped in flame, they found Mrs. HANNON, a widow lady, aged about 65 years, the occupant of the room. She was burned in a shocking manner, there being scarcely a vestige of clothing on her person when she was discovered. When the fire was extinguished an examination was made, and life was found to be extinct. It appears that Mrs. HANNON was alone at the time her clothes ignited, and it is, therefore, impossible to say exactly how the accident occurred. There was a large fire in the grate, and it is the belief of those who found her that she fell asleep in her chair, and that sparks from the grate set her dress in flames. An inquest will be held on the body this morning.

abstract: -- The holidays are improved by the Messrs. BRYANT, STRATTON & CO. to hold a Convention of the resident principals of their several Commercial Colleges, now located in seventeen of the leading cities of this country. The convention will be held at the New-York College, corner of Broadway and Twenty-second-street, commencing on Monday, the 28th. The exercises will be of a varied character, having direct reference to the interest of commercial education in this country, and to improvements in the same; and will, no doubt, be productive of beneficial results.

abstract: We have  received reliable information from Fort Garry, that two headmen of Standing Buffalo's band of Sissiton Sioux recently visited Fort Garry, for the purpose of asking the intervention of the British authorities in making peace for them with the Americans.
lead_paragraph: We have received reliable information from Fort Garry, that two headmen of Standing Buffalo's band of Sissiton Sioux recently visited Fort Garry, for the purpose of asking the intervention of the British authorities in making peace for them with the Americans. They represented their people as tired of the war, suffering a great deal from privations, and anxious all of them to make peace. They asserted, too, that their band had been opposed to the war upon the whites, and had only a part fought them in self-defence, none of them having had part in any massacres.

abstract: Taylor, Bayard; Hannah Thurston
lead_paragraph: It is, perhaps, a problem whether the prestige of an established reputation is really an advantage to an author in entering a new field of literature; for while it predisposes his readers in his favor, it, at the same time, raises anticipations not easy to satisfy. Mr. BAYARD TAYLOR has gained a very extended popularity as a descriptive writer, and some success as a poet, and when it was announced that he had a novel in hand, he was able to claim in advance the suffrages of thousands who were disposed to take on trust anything that might come from his pen. Mr. TAYLOR's novel is at length given to the public, and his warmest admirers are fain to confess a disappointment at the result. Hannah Thurston is a notable illustration of the fact that a man may walk up and down the world, and tell what he sees with good success, and yet lamentably trip when he comes to tread the realms of imagination and attempts to give to airy nothings a local habitation and a name. It is lame in its plot, feeble in its characterization, and puerile in its philosophy.

abstract: At the meeting of the Supervisors, yesterday, a resolution, by Mr. BLUNT, was adopted, making the Sunday Dispatch an official county paper the same as the Leader is that is, to publish papers passed by the Board and approved by the Mayor, or passed over his veto.
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Supervisors, yesterday, a resolution, by Mr. BLUNT, was adopted, making the Sunday Dispatch an official county paper the same as the Leader is that is, to publish papers passed by the Board and approved by the Mayor, or passed over his veto. The Comptroller transmitted a statement of a claim he made upon the State Comptroller for a remission of the sum of $2,681 37 of this county's quota of State taxes for 1862-3, on the ground that corrections made to our assessment lists by this Board to the close of July last, reduced the assessment footings $564,500. A copy of Mr. ROBINSON's reply to this claim accompanied the statement. Mr. ROBINSON declines to make the remission claimed, for the reason that the act of 1859 establishing the State Board of Equalization of Assessments requires them to determine the assessment of the various counties on which the State tax shall be levied, and that the amount of taxes levied upon such assessment "shall be raised and collected." Mr. ROBINSON reasons that if a county "makes mistakes in its assessments, it is a matter with which the State has nothing to do." The subject was referred to the Committee on Annual Taxes. An effort to increase the salaries of the City Judge and Surrogate from $5,000 to $6,000 per annum, failed. The Board adjourned to Tuesday, at 2 o'clock P.M.

abstract: -- The late HUGH JENKINS, Esq., by his will dated Sept. 26, 1863, has bequeathed to the Oliver Hibernian Free School $500; to St. Paul's Episcopal Church, (of which he was a member,) $500, and to the Rev. JAS. DOLAN, of St. Patrick Church, for the orphan children under his care, $500. The will has revenue stamps attached amounting to $80, representing an estate of $450,000. By the terms of the will the dwelling houses, Nos. 52 and 54 St. Paul-street, with the furniture, plate, carriage, &c., of the deceased, his country seat "Dunmore," and the income of $40,000, are left to his widow in trust, during her lifetime, and afterward to be divided between his four children. He leaves $30,000 in trust to each of his daughters. Mrs. ELIZABETH ANN HARRISON and Mrs. HENRIETTA O'DONOVAN. The deceased also bequeathed $30,000 to each of his sons, and canceling all their debts on his books, &c., besides to JOHN S. JENKINS, his interest in his business, and requesting BENJAMIN W. JENKINS to invest the above amount in business with his brother. A legacy of $1,000 is left to each of the grandchildren of the deceased, in trust, to be invested until they are of age. To the children of his brother ROBERT, "before provided for," $1,000 each. To Mrs. MARCELLA TODD is left $3,000, absolutely with a request that she will always hare a home with some member of the family. To SAMUEL HAZELHURST, in consideration of faithful services as clerk, $2,500. The remainder of the estate is to be equally divided among his children. His two sons, JOHN STRICKER JENKINS and BENJAMIN WRIGHT JENKINS, are appointed executors and trustees of the various trusts under the will. -- Baltimore Sun, Dec 21.

abstract: The steamship George Washington, Capt. GAWKH, and Mississippi Capt. TALBOT, arrived here yesterday morning, bringing advices from New-Orleans to the 19th inst.
lead_paragraph: The steamship George Washington, Capt. GAWKH, and Mississippi Capt. TALBOT, arrived here yesterday morning, bringing advices from New-Orleans to the 19th inst. The Mississippi brings a number of rebel prisoners, among whom are Maj.-Gen. FRANK GARDNER, commander of Fort Hudson, and the following officers: Aid-de-Camp Alex. Dupree, Col. J.A. Jaquess, Lieut.-Col. M.I. Smith, all of Port Hudson; Capt. J.J. Slocum, Ninth Louisiana cavalry; Capt. Matcemp, Ninth Louisiana cavalry; Capt. J.C. Patterson, Twenty-third Arkansas; H.L.W. Johnson, Fourteenth Arkansas; Lieut. W.B. Burnett, Twelfth Arkansas; J.W. Geer, Tenth Arkansas; J.K. Milan, Seventeenth Arkansas.

abstract: Pay of our Soldiers; Raids--Their Success
snippet: Pay of our Soldiers; Raids--Their Success
lead_paragraph: Our Government ought to make more thorough and effective provision than it has yet done, for the prompt and regular payment of our soldiers. Much has been done to improve their physical condition, and continual agitation has worked some reform in the sanitary arrangement of the camp, but there is a greater reform still to come and that is the reform of the pay-roll. Sooner or later this reform must be achieved, not only with the men, but with the officers. They must be put upon such a basis that they will know to an hour, when they are to receive their pay, and, by creating for them avenues for its use, they must be taught its value. As long as our soldiers are paid at long intervals, so long will they be subject to the incubus of sutlers, and so long will the vice of gambling exist in their midst to a destructive degree. A man kept penniless for months, and then given a sum which, magnified through his penury, seems a mint, must be more than human if he disburses it with judgment and economy. The chances are very strong that it melts rapidly away in dissipation, or is frittered upon objects which, in the poverty that is sure to follow, are parted with for a tithe of their value. This is precisely the position of our soldiers; they receive too much money at one time, and they do not receive it punctually. There is a, wonderful satisfaction to a man who is achieving any kind of labor, in knowing that his recompense is near at hand. He can work with greater spirit, and he can employ his gains to better purpose. There are many who argue that the rule suiting the mechanic or laborer, will not suit the soldier. This is simply nonsense. The same instinct is with them, and it is only a question whether the system shall be organized, and when organized, whether the soldier shall have an opportunity of spending the pay he so fairly earns, without being taxed from one to five hundred per cent. by sutlers, or whether he is to be left to feel that his thirteen dollars per month is really little better in camp than one quarter the amount would be if paid where the avenues for its absorption were open to competition. We are just now entering upon a winter in which there will be little done by the greet armies. It will be an imminent time; a time full of great consequences, even though a time of inaction. If, during this time, anything can be done that will add to the morale of the men, it should be considered, and executed rapidly. The alteration of the manner of paying the men is something that can be done in a day, but the relaxation of discipline that will throw the sutlerism open to competition, will have its opponents in high places, not only among civilians and contractors, who are now growing rich to depletion by it, but by army officers of elevated grades, who, as they are doing very well under the present monopoly, will not see the necessity for a change. And yet the change must come; and we will venture to say that when the hour arrives, it will be hailed by every enlisted man as his millenium, and in the same light by nine-tenths of the commissioned officers.

abstract: The great concern of thoughtful minds, during the prosecution of this war, has been not so much about victory, or about the sequel of victory. That the rebels could be conquered, was more certain than that they could be safely dealt with when conquered.
lead_paragraph: The great concern of thoughtful minds, during the prosecution of this war, has been not so much about victory, or about the sequel of victory. That the rebels could be conquered, was more certain than that they could be safely dealt with when conquered. It was plain that we had a superiority in strength, that had only to be fully and perseveringly exerted, to insure complete military success, sooner or later. The census tables sufficiently showed that. But military success is one thing; civil well-being quite another. There is many a victory in history which was not only profitless, but the very prelude of destruction. It is not victory simply that we fight for. Were that all, we might better ground arms at once. Victory, for its own sake, can gratify only pride or anger. Doubtless these were enlisted to some extent in the contest. Like the pagan deities of old, they mingle in every mortal fight. Yet they are not worthy to have one drop of blood spilt for them. It is patriotism solely that justifies this war. Not the patriotism either that lives in mere impulse. There is, indeed, something good in that, but it has no authority to require these terrible sacrifices. That can come only from the higher patriotism which has its seal in reason, and which looks "fore and after." We fight not merely because we feel, but because we think -- because it is our deliberate judgment that our country can be saved through fighting, and only through fighting. The conviction is a sound one. Peace with the rebels, without disruption and ruin, is impossible. But the safety is to be gained through fighting, not merely by fighting. Conquest of the rebels is needful, but it is not all that is needed. Unless the conquest shall be supplemented by a right civil policy, the Union, even with the conquest, will be left in a condition hardly worth the saving. It is just this doubt whether that policy might be found, and recognized, and adopted, that has particularly troubled reflecting men. It is just this belief that it has been found, and that with general consent it will be used -- it is just this, we say, that has done more than all things to consolidate faith in the salvation of the Union into positive assurance.

abstract: The village of Kingsville, in the County of Essex, contains at present, in addition to its usual population, a number of "skedaddlers" and deserters from the American army, many of whom prefer hanging round the bar-rooms of Canada to serving their country in the field. Among the last-named class was an individual whom, for the sake of distinction, we shall call SAM. He came to Kingsville some two months ago, and, not long after his arrival, formed a matrimonial connection with a Rose-y daughter of the village -- said connection to last during "three months, or for the war." Matters went on pleasantly for some time, and would, no doubt, have continued to do so if the fine weather had lasted, but the recent "cold snap" put an end to it in rather an unexpected manner. SAM, finding that his habiliments, although comfortable enough in the region of Vicksburgh, were not proof against the chilling influence of a snow-storm, determined to send his temporary wife off to purchase warmer clothing, and, accordingly, dispatched her to Detroit, giving her $40 for the purpose. After enjoying herself for a day or two in that city, she wrote to him that she could not make a selection, and advising him to come up and choose for himself, saying, at the same time, that he need not have the least fear for his safety, as she had made every inquiry and found there was no one on the lookout for deserters, &c., &c. SAM believed every word she wrote, and, anxious to rejoin her, took the first stage for Windsor, and, on arriving there, at once crossed over to Detroit. In the meantime, Miss ROSEY had had an interview with the Provost-Marshal, and, ascertaining that she would be entitled to receive $30 for delivering up a deserter, had posted that functionary as to her friend's anticipated movements. He according had two of his deputies to watch the ferry-landing, and SAM had been ashore but a few minutes when he was nabbed and marched off to safe quarters. "Phancey his pheelinx," as Jeemes would say. His betrayer, as soon as she found her game secured, called at the Captain's office and received the money. Then, without as much as calling on SAM to say good bye, she posted off for Kingsville, where she arrived $70 better off than when she left it. Great was the commotion among the deserter's friends when the facts became known, and dire the threats of vengeance, which, however, will not likely be carried out.

abstract: European Congress, the Proposed
lead_paragraph: Earl RUSSELL'S rejoinders to M. DROUYN DE LHUYS have not, it seems, settled the question of the Congress. NAPOLEON is still bent on realizing his idee, if possible. The more so, probably, because of Madam VICTORIA'S contumacy. He is reported, indeed, to be negotiating with "various European States" on the propriety of convoking the Congress "without England." Should he succeed, however, in arranging for its convocation, it may chance that other great Powers will be absent therefrom as well as "perfide Albion." Despite the courteous tone of the first replies of Russia, Austria and Prussia, is it quite certain that they will ultimately give in their adhesion? As they begin, like England, by demanding definitions and explanations, may they not end, like her, by declining to have hand, act, or part in the matter? The notes of these Powers are merely introductory, and contain nothing conclusive. Before the Czar can return a final answer, he must have "a categorical list of the debatable questions." Ere the Kaiser can reply definitely, he must see "the bases and programme of the deliberations." While the Prussian King cannot make up his mind till his Imperial Brother shall have "communicated to him his views respecting preliminaries." Now, simple and reasonable as these requisitions appear, they place NAPOLEON in a most awkward dilemma. There is really in them more than meets the eye. They are intimations to his French Majesty of the conditions on which the said Powers will consent to attend; and yet they impose on him the necessity of clearly defining the terms of the compact. He can, of course, overcome their several objections to his scheme, by making the concessions which he knows each secretly desires. He can propitiate the Czar and the Prussian King, by narrowing down the Polish question to a discussion of Poland's rights under the Treaty of Vienna, and he can conciliate the Kaiser by engaging to keep the Venetian question out of Court. But what would the Poles and Italians think of such tergiversation? Or, how could NAPOLEON afterward affirm that his proposed Congress would be equal to its task?

abstract: RECRUITING FOR THE FEDEBAL ARMY IN CANADA. -- We hear complaints from all parts of the country, of American agents inducing our young men, by offers of fabulous wages, &c., to go into the States to chop wood and work in the factories, and after getting them over the lines, using coercion to make them join the army. This course of procedure is highly reprehensible, and is a direct breach of the law of nations. On the frontier, in Stanstead County, one means resorted to is to get the individual intoxicated; induce him to cross the lines, and shortly he finds himself sober under the kind care of an American recruiting officer, and duly enrolled in the American army! We learn that in many instances our own citizens act as accomplices in this nefarious business. To this latter class of persons we would give warning that in future they will be watched, arrested and punished. We would refer them particularly to some late decisions in our Courts in this District. -- Waterloo (L.C.) Advertiser.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamships George Washington and Mississippi, at this port yesterday, we have New-Orleans advices to the 19th inst. There was no stirring news, but affairs in Texas were very encouraging.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamships George Washington and Mississippi, at this port yesterday, we have New-Orleans advices to the 19th inst. There was no stirring news, but affairs in Texas were very encouraging. Large numbers of the people were giving in their adhesion to the Union. Gen. WASHBURNE was moving upon Indianola and Lavacca, and would probably occupy them without resistance. It was believed that our troops would soon concentrate at San Antonio for the final attack upon MAGRUDER. The health of the troops was good.

abstract: Louisiana Free State Convention; Negroes Admitted to Free State Convention
snippet: Louisiana Free State Convention; Negroes Admitted to Free State Convention
lead_paragraph: We notice, in our latest intelligence from New-Orleans, that a free State Convention has recently been held in Louisiana, at which a delegation of colored men were admitted to seats. Who called this Convention, and who composed it, we are not aware; nor have we any distinct statement of the precise object of its deliberations. t is quite safe to assume, however, that neither its members nor their constituents have been for any very long time citizens of Louisiana. They are probably men from the North, whom the tide of war has drifted into that State either as political speculators, or as social missionaries, and who deem the present a fitting opportunity for reforming the institutions of the South upon their own models. We infer from this brief statement of their action in convention, that they regard colored men as on a footing of equality, in all respects, with the whites, and that they intend to make the practical recognition of this equality the corner-stone of that new social edifice which they aim to erect in the Southern States.

abstract: For some months the public has been looking forward to the launch of the great ocean iron-clad Dictator. The first attempt to Launch her, almost a month ago, failed; the second attempt has succeeded, and she now floats proudly upon the water.
lead_paragraph: For some months the public has been looking forward to the launch of the great ocean iron-clad Dictator. The first attempt to Launch her, almost a month ago, failed; the second attempt has succeeded, and she now floats proudly upon the water. Notwithstanding the fact that no tickets were issued, and that admission was confined to a few naval officers and the representatives of the press, the precincts of the vast ship-house, in which the vessel was built, were on Saturday crowded to excess. The launch was to take place at 10 o'clock, but long before that hour 13th street, as far as 9th avenue, was thickly studded with persons wending their way to the river. The harbor also presented a very animated appearance. Hundreds of crowded small boats plied to and fro, and the decks of all the mercantile vessels, near the wharf, were alive with spectators. The steamer Fargo was literally crammed with people, who shouted and cheered for hours before the ceremony. Conspicuous among the assembly was Capt. ERICSSON, who, for the first time, we believe, witnessed the launch of one of his vessels. We also noticed the Assistant Secretary of the Navy, (Fox,) Commodore STORER, Admiral GREGORY, Chief-Engineers STIMERS, ROBIE and LAWTON, C. GODFREY GUNTHER, Esq., Mayor elect of this City, Capt. WORDEN and many others. The vessel was launched quite unexpectedly to all -- sliding from her ways when the workmen had knocked away the blocks till within 50 feet of her stem. This occurred at 9 1/2 o'clock, and Mrs. GRISWOLD, who had been deputed to christen her, not being present, a workman seized the bottle of wine, smashed it across her bows, and named her the Dictator. The constructors announced the launch a perfect success.

abstract: An accident occurred last night at Bristow Station. A train of ten cars, from Brandy Station for Alexandria, owing to the switch being placed the wrong way, ran on to the side track, and on reaching the end of it, the locomotive and four cars were thrown down an embankment a distance of eight feet. Two men on the top of a car, and another inside were killed, and six or seven persons were wounded.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sunday, Dec. 27.

abstract: A report of the removal of J.W. HOWES, Esq., from the office of Vice-Consul at Montreal, which impugned Mr. HOWES' loyalty, proves to be utterly groundless. Mr. HOWES resigned his office some time time ago, while he commanded, as he does still, the perfect, confidence of Consul-General GIDDINGS both as to his capacity and loyalty.

abstract: At 9 o'clock yesterday morning the remains of the late Gen. CORCORAN, which had been lying in state for the past two days in the Governor's room at the City Hall, were conveyed to St. Patrick's Cathedral, Mulberry-street; in order for the Solemn High Mass requiem to be said over them. Long before the hour appointed, the Cathedral was crowded to its utmost limits, in consequence of which the doors had to be closed against the constantly increasing throng. On the arrival of the body at the Mott-street entrance of the Cathedral it was at once borne to the centre of the middle aisle, and placed upon a raised dais, with six candles around it. The solemn and impressive ceremonies -- made more so by the Cathedral being draped in black -- of the High Mass requiem was then performed by Very Rev. WILLIAM STARRS. V.G., assisted by Deacon Father EUGENE MCGUIRE. Sub-Deacon Rev. Dr. MCSWEENEY, Master of the ceremonies, and Rev. FRANCIS MCNIERNLY. Secretary to Archbishop HUGHES. At the conclusion of Mass, Rev. WM. STARRS delivered an oration, of the most feeling and impressive nature, eulogistic of the deceased.

abstract: Hecnan-Sayers Prize Fight, The
lead_paragraph: It is all very well for newspapers to publish full details of prize-fights, and then read the public long moral homilies on the shocking taste which requires the publication of such demoralizing literature. And it is, perhaps, quite natural that they should seek excuses or palliations for what they regard as a grave public evil. One writer thinks that the interest in these fights is due to the admiration felt for the self-denial which leads prize-fighters to submit to the long and severe training which these contests require. Another finds his explanation in the universal applause which pluck extorts whenever shown.
headline: {'main': 'The Late Prize-Fight in England.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Late Prize-Fight in England.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Gerrit Smith's Address at Montreal
lead_paragraph: GERRIT SMITH has been doing the country excellent service in Montreal. He delivered an address there not long ago, in which he set forth the posi tion of the Government with admirable clearness and justice, and demolished all the sophistries which have been dragged into the service of the rebel cause. He was interrupted constantly and very rudely, as indeed it seems to be impossible for an English or Canadian assembly to listen calmly to any speeches which do not echo their own opinions; but he replied in every instance with perfect self-command, and in the most direct and, pointed manner, to his questioners. Mr. SMITH took the same ground here which he had held throughout, --insisting that the war was waged for the preservation of the Union and not for the extinction of Slavery; and that this cause was one which should command the sympathy of every intelligent lover of human rights throughout the world.

abstract: The following, cases have been argued within the last few days:  No. 5 (Original Docket.)--The Dubuque and Pacific Railroad Company vs. Edwin C. Litchfield, Plaintiff.-- The plaintiff, a citizen of the State of New-York, brought an action in the District Court of the United ...
lead_paragraph: The following, cases have been argued within the last few days: No. 5 (Original Docket.)--The Dubuque and Pacific Railroad Company vs. Edwin C. Litchfield, Plaintiff.-- The plaintiff, a citizen of the State of New-York, brought an action in the District Court of the United States for the District of Iowa to recover possession of a section of land, and verdict and judgment were rendered for him. The defendants brought the case to the Supreme, Court of the United States, by writ of error, and the judgment of the Court below was reversed, (23 Howard, p. 66.) After that decision the plaintiff applied to the Court, below for a new trial, at the October term, 1860. The mandate of the Supreme Court not having then been filed in the Court below, that Court held the motion under advisement until the October term, 1861, when, having first entered judgment for the defendants in accordance with the mandate, it granted the plaintiff's application and ordered a new trial. The defendants took exception to that ruling and now move the Supreme Court for a peremptory order on the Court below to enter judgment in accordance with the mandate, and to cancel and set aside the order for a new trial.

lead_paragraph: We have published a very sharp correspondence recently had between Mr. RICHARD COBDEN and the Editor of the London Times, which has considerable interest beyond the circle of the parties immediately concerned. It has a bearing on the relations of the newspaper Press to public men and their public action, and serves to illustrate certain characteristics of public sentiment in this country as well as in England.

abstract: The steamship Atlantic, from Aspinwall Dec. 16, arrived at this port Saturday. She brings the important intelligence that actual hostilities had broken out between the Republics of Ecuador and the United States of Colombia.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Atlantic, from Aspinwall Dec. 16, arrived at this port Saturday. She brings the important intelligence that actual hostilities had broken out between the Republics of Ecuador and the United States of Colombia. The Ecuatorians had actually invaded Colombia, and captures the small town of Tumaco without resistance. Gen. FLORES, with the Ecuatorian army, 6,000 strong, was already in motion, and had announced his intention to attack MOSQUERA's forces at Pasto, at once. The latter was concentrating his forces for battle, and it was thought his army would number 10,000 men. Much excitement existed in the Republics. Among the Atlantic's passengers is Ex-President BARRIOS and lady, of San Salvador.

abstract: Military criticism and responsibity
lead_paragraph: A great deal of the public criticism, of what is sometimes sneeringly called "Washington strategy," and which has lately been reopened with fresh energy on the occasion of the publication of the report of the General-in-Chief, appears to receive a false direction from mistaken notions as to the true functions of the central military authorities. These tunctions are necessarily of a general order, comprehending the plan of the war as a whole, the indication of the grand military objectives and lines of operation, and such a distribution and marshaling of the forces as will best tend to gain the aim proposed. The practical conduct of campaigns and battles is, as a matter of equal necessity, left with the General in the field. We may say -- using the terms in a sense which, though not strictly accurate, is sufficiently so for an enlarged conveyance of our meaning -- that to the central military authorities belong strategical, and to commanders in the field tactical combinations.
headline: {'main': 'Military Responsibility and Military Criticism.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Military Responsibility and Military Criticism.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- Some of the statements in the New-York papers about the robbery of Treasury notes by CORNWALL are extravagant. One paper states that the amount of money taken by him will amount to over one hundred thousand. We learn to-day that it will not exceed forty thousand, nearly all of which was promptly restored by CORNWALL who had it in his trunk at his house. Upon CORNWALL's guilt being made certain, he was invited into a room where there were four officers of the Treasury, one of whom, Mr. CHITTENDEN, the Register, plainly told him what had been discovered, and advised him to state the whole truth.
lead_paragraph: -- Some of the statements in the New-York papers about the robbery of Treasury notes by CORNWALL are extravagant. abstract: Company A, Second United States Regulars, (colored,) arrived in this City on Saturday evening, in the Daniel Webster, from Folly Island, Charleston Harbor. They are now quartered at the Park Barracks, where they will remain until the sailing of the next steamer for New-Orleans, whither they are going to join their regiments.
lead_paragraph: Company A, Second United States Regulars, (colored,) arrived in this City on Saturday evening, in the Daniel Webster, from Folly Island, Charleston Harbor. They are now quartered at the Park Barracks, where they will remain until the sailing of the next steamer for New-Orleans, whither they are going to join their regiments. The officers of the company are JOHN WILDER, Captain; GEO. JANNEY, First Lieutenant, and WM. JACKSON, Second Lieutenant -all white. This was one of the first contraband companies of soldiers that was raised for the army. It is the same company that was marching through the streets of Norfolk at the time Surgeon SANBORN was shot by Dr. WRIGHT. The men are mostly from Virginia and North Carolina, and were nearly all slaves at the commencement of the rebellion. The company numbers 101 men, and has been in service over six months. They are all black as men can well be, exhibit good drill, and utmost obedience to command.

abstract: The United States steamer Massachusetts arrived at Fortress Monroe yesterday morning, fiftyfour hours from Charleston Bar, with two hundred and forty discharged men, forty-four sick and sixteen rebel prisoners, captured on the rebel steamer Cheatham. The Massachusetts has on board a portion of the rebel obstructions from Charleston harbor, forwarded to Washington by Admiral Dahlgren.
lead_paragraph: The United States steamer Massachusetts arrived at Fortress Monroe yesterday morning, fiftyfour hours from Charleston Bar, with two hundred and forty discharged men, forty-four sick and sixteen rebel prisoners, captured on the rebel steamer Cheatham. The Massachusetts has on board a portion of the rebel obstructions from Charleston harbor, forwarded to Washington by Admiral Dahlgren. The Massachusetts brings no news. Nothing of importance had occurred since the sailing of the last steamer. There had been but little firing between the land batteries the last few days. The Ironsides and monitors were all lying safe at their anchorages. There was no present prospect of active operations.

abstract: INCREASE OF BOUNTY IN JERSEY CITY. -- A special meeting of the Common Council of Jersey City was called on Saturday evening last, to take into consideration the raising of the bounty to $350, the same as is paid in Newark. It was stated that by increasing the bounty to the above-named sum, the balance of the quota could be raised from New-Jersey regiments now in the field in the course of a week. A resolution was acordingly adopted making the sum to be paid hereafter $350, and agents will be dispatched to the army with authority to recruit men.

abstract: The recruiting headquarters at Lafayette Hall, which is said to be conducted in the interest of Gen. SPINCLA, has commenced a system of filling up the ranks that goes a little ahead of the bounty brokers.
lead_paragraph: The recruiting headquarters at Lafayette Hall, which is said to be conducted in the interest of Gen. SPINCLA, has commenced a system of filling up the ranks that goes a little ahead of the bounty brokers. This system is nothing less than the kidnapping of colored men who happen to be passing the Headquarters, and who are seized by the collar and dragged without ceremony into the rear of the building, when they are put in a pen and by fright induced to sign their names to writings which bind them as enlisted soldiers. On Friday, a colored man named JOHN ALEXANDER, who is employed in the office of the Headquarters of the colored regiment, at No. 350 Fourth-street, was passing by Lafayette Hall, when he saw an aged colored man seized in the manner described, and stopping to ascertain the cause of such a proceeding, he too was seized and forced back into the pen at the point of the bayonet. On his demanding to know by what right he was thus treated, he was told that it was "none of his d_____d business, and that niggers had better keep their mouths shut." The officer who claimed to be in charge, and who was dressed in United States uniform, gave orders that if ALEXANDER attempted to escape from the pen to "run him through with a bayonet." After finding out where ALEXANDER was employed, they concluded that it would not be safe to detain him over night, and so let him go. After getting out, he told his story to his employers, and complaint was at once made to Gen. DIX. On Saturday, Gen. DIX sent an officer to Lafayette Hall to arrest the parties who had perpetrated the outrage, but they were not to be found. ALEXANDER says there were several other colored men confined there while he was detained, who said they had been kidnapped in the same manner. It is said that Gen. SPINOLA has received authority from the War Department to recruit, independent of the Provost-Marshals, who have no control over his operations.

abstract: Literary Items
lead_paragraph: --Few merely literary announcements have given more general satisfaction than Messrs. CROSBY NICHOLS' notice of the change in the editorship of the North American Review. The names of the new conductors, Prof. JAMES RUSSELL LOWELL and CHARLES ELIOT NORTON, are accepted as a guarantee of the new spirit that will be infused into this veteran periodical--always respectable indeed under its late editor, Dr. PEABODY, but scarcely equal to the wants of the time, in vigor of tone and decided expression of opinion on the great topics of the day, whether in theology, politics, science, or social life. The North American was commenced nearly fifty years ago, and is only six years younger than the London Quarterly, which began in 1804. Its founder, and first editor, was WM. TUDOR, and the first number appeared in May 1815. It has, at various times, been under the management of ALEXANDER and EDWARD EVERETT, JARED SPARKS, Dr. PALFREY, Prof. BOWEN and the retiring editor. Dr. PEABODY. Its high character has been uniformly maintained, and scarcely a literary man of note can be named who has not occasionally contributed to its pages. Volumes I. to IX., forming the first series, partook somewhat of the character of a magazine, and BRYANT's first poem, Thanatopsis, originally appeared there. These early volumes are now excessively scarce, and complete sets of the Review are of rare occurrence and command a very high price.

abstract: The weather was propitious for Mr. MARETZEK'S matinee on Saturday, and the house was handsomely filled with a surging and ever-shifting sea of crinoline, bonnets and feathers. MOZART'S opera of "Don Giovanni" was played, and several persons-- mostly from the country--listened to it. The cast was unexceptionable, especially of the female roles. Mr. MARETZEK presided in the, orchestra, and everything under that gentleman's able direction passed off to the complete satisfaction of the audience.
lead_paragraph: The weather was propitious for Mr. MARETZEK'S matinee on Saturday, and the house was handsomely filled with a surging and ever-shifting sea of crinoline, bonnets and feathers. MOZART'S opera of "Don Giovanni" was played, and several persons-- mostly from the country--listened to it. The cast was unexceptionable, especially of the female roles. Mr. MARETZEK presided in the, orchestra, and everything under that gentleman's able direction passed off to the complete satisfaction of the audience. To-night PETRELLA's very successful and popular opera of "Ione" will be given. It is the last night but one of Mr. MARETZEK's season. Holiday people should remember that fact.

abstract: THE CONTRACTS FOR CLEANING THE STREETS.-- The Brooklyn Board of Contracts last week awarded contracts for cleaning the streets of the Fourth and Fifth Wards, at more than double the rates paid last year, thereby proving that the city cannot be kept in even a passably decent condition for the sums heretofore paid for doing the work.
lead_paragraph: THE CONTRACTS FOR CLEANING THE STREETS.-- The Brooklyn Board of Contracts last week awarded contracts for cleaning the streets of the Fourth and Fifth Wards, at more than double the rates paid last year, thereby proving that the city cannot be kept in even a passably decent condition for the sums heretofore paid for doing the work. Mayor WOOD having requested the Board to lay over the contracts for the remaining Wards until after the 1st of January, they agreed to do so. The price for keeping the streets clean will then be increased, the economical plan abandoned, and contractors required to perform their duty, or receive no money.

abstract: The colored regiment which is being raised in this City, under the auspices of the Union League Club, has already over 500 men in camp at Riker's Island. This regiment is to belong to the regular army, and is numbered the Twentieth. It is the first colored regiment raised in this State, and the colored recruits enlisting in any part are to be assigned to it.
lead_paragraph: The colored regiment which is being raised in this City, under the auspices of the Union League Club, has already over 500 men in camp at Riker's Island. This regiment is to belong to the regular army, and is numbered the Twentieth. It is the first colored regiment raised in this State, and the colored recruits enlisting in any part are to be assigned to it. The Union League Club are to have the naming of the line officers, and several have already been sent on to Washington for examination. The recruits for this regiment receive the State bounty of $75 and the City bounty of $300 the same as white volunteers, but do not receive any bounty from the United States Government. The enlistments for the regiment number about 25 daily. Over 40 have enlisted from Poughkeepsie. A great many complaints come to the headquarters of the regiment, No. 350 Fourthstreet, from the volunteers who have been sent to Riker's Island, that they have been swindled out of their bounty. This is particularly the case with the volunteers who have enlisted in the Spinola brigade. The Committee of the Union League Club pay $10 premium to any person bringing a recruit, as the Government premium does not apply to colored volunteers.

abstract: THE FULTON MONUMENT.--It seems to be decided that the FULTON Monument be erected in Trinity Church Yard, but this is meeting, though it may be uselessly, with decided opposition. No more unsuitable place could have been selected, if the design is to keep the memory of the great inventor before the people.
lead_paragraph: THE FULTON MONUMENT. -- It seems to be decided that the FULTON Monument be erected in Trinity Church Yard, but this is meeting, though it may be uselessly, with decided opposition. No more unsuitable place could have been selected, if the design is to keep the memory of the great inventor before the people. People do not go down Broadway as far as Wall street; men immersed in business do, and they have neither time nor disposition, when so immersed, to recognize FULTON's or any other monument. Greenwood would be a great deal better; Jersey City quite as good a location. It is presumable the monument is designed to be seen. Bow many readers can mention, notwithstanding the interest that can be afforded on passing Trinity Church Yard, a single matter of interest? How many who pass it daily know to whom the monument, close to Broadway, is erected in memory of? Let the committee test this among those in the vicinity.
