abstract: Winthrop, John; Life and Letters, by R. C. Winthrop
snippet: Winthrop, John; Life and Letters, by R. C. Winthrop
lead_paragraph: By this noble volume Mr. WINTHROP is worthily acquitting himself of the debt he owes to a long and unblemished line of ancestors, as the heir of their reputation, derived from honored deeds in their country's service, and the inheritor of a good name, prominent among the really historic ones inscribed on the annals of America. The life of a gentleman of station, born in the stirring year of the Spanish Armada, and occupying various positions of responsibility and credit in the times of CHARLES I. and the early Puritans, must always be of interest, where the particulars are derived mainly from his own authority, as in the present instance; but how much is that interest heightened when the subject of the biography stands in the relation to a mighty country that JOHN WINTHROP, a preacher of the Pilgrim band and first Governor of Massachusetts, occupies towards the United State of the present day. The deified heroes of antiquity were no others than as this man was -- and in Greece temples would have been built to the fame of the leader under whose auspices the ocean was crossed and the foundations of empire laid widely and deeply on a foreign strand. The volume opens with a charming picture of the rural village of Groton, in Suffolk, where the author -- the seventh descendant of its ancient lords -- visited the cradle of their race with pure reverence. Existing documents and family papers enable him to trace satisfactorily the life of JOHN WINTHROP in his native land through a manhood not unchequered with cares, but on the whole fortunate and prosperous, until he set sail in 1630 from the country he was not again to revisit, although nineteen years of active life remained to him in the region so fervently adopted by him, to the exclusion of past interests and associations. This period will form the subject of a similar volume to the present one, which ends with the embarkation for America of WINTHROP and his companions.

abstract: TWO DARING BURGLARIES IN THE EIGHTEENTH WARD. Between 2 and 3 o'clock on Monday morning, some burglars forced the front basement door of Mr. NICHOLAS FISHER'S residence, No. 148 East Nineteenth-street.
lead_paragraph: TWO DARING BURGLARIES IN THE EIGHTEENTH WARD. Between 2 and 3 o'clock on Monday morning, some burglars forced the front basement door of Mr. NICHOLAS FISHER'S residence, No. 148 East Nineteenth-street. They proceeded to the upper floors, and, after lighting the gas, they set to work searching for valuables. Mr. SANDS, a grandson of Mr. FISHER, hearing the noise, went into the hall and cried out, "Who's there?" One of the burglars thereupon advanced and threatened to blow young SANDS' brains out if he did not keep quiet. The latter then raised a window and cried, "Watch!" "burglars!" "murder!" &c., At this moment one of the gang fired a pistol at him, but without doing any injury. No policeman was within hearing, and the burglars, after stealing clothing and jewelry to the amount of over $100, escaped. About an hour later, the same band of burglars entered the dwelling-house of Mr. HENRY N. SQUIRES, No. 176 East Fifteenth-street, by bursting in a front basement window. Here they also lighted the gas, and made diligent search for plunder. They made their escape with a pair of valuable lace curtains. Mrs. S. was awakened by them during the time they were ransacking the house, but she was fearful that if she gave her husband notice, he would rush upon them and be shot. No arrests have yet been made.

lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many or which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

lead_paragraph: -- We are glad to find that, notwithstanding the desperate condition of monetary affairs, and the dilapidation of military matters in rebeldom, they can nevertheless get up a laugh in Richmond occasionally. We see that Rev. Dr. HOGE is reported by the Richmond press as having "moved the mirth of his hearers" in the last lecture of several which he delivered before the Young Men's Christian Association there. The subject of their mirth was not indigenous to the soil, but came from foreign lands and ran the blockade with Dr. HOGE himself.

abstract: The reluctant testimony of the rebel press at home and rebel agents abroad gives us at length the assurance of a perfect blockade of the Southern coast.
lead_paragraph: The reluctant testimony of the rebel press at home and rebel agents abroad gives us at length the assurance of a perfect blockade of the Southern coast. We say a perfect blockade, not merely an "effective" blockade. That even foreign malice has been compelled to acknowledge we have kept up from the start. But a blockade may be quite "effective," within the legal definition of the term -- that is, may be so real and stringent as to make it hazardous to attempt to run it -- and yet be very far from practically complete.

abstract: PATREEL's opera is an established favorite with our public. It is always sure to draw forth abundance of applause, and to be listened to attentively to the highly pyrotechnic end. The admirable distribution of the solo parts among Mr. MARETZEK's fine artists is probably one reason why the work is popular. It is almost impossible to hear Signor MAZZOLENI to greater advantage. Signor BIACHI has a splendid role. It was written for him, and is entirely within the best part of his voice. Mme. MEDORI sings and acts with the greatest spirit, and SULZER, as the slave, has one of the two roles in which she is absolutely good. The performance last evening gave complete satisfaction to those present.

abstract: Public attention is called to the advertisement in relation to the draft, of the A.A. Provost-Marshal General of New-York. The names of all those who have been enrolled are printed in pamphlet form, each Ward making one pamphlet, and are now exposed to view and for the inspection of the public at the following places, viz.: At the headquarters of the Provost-Marshal of each district; at every Police Station in each district, and at each of the places where the polls were held at the recent election. Persons who are enrolled may appear before the Board of Enrollment of their respective districts and claim to have their names stricken from the list if they can show to the satisfaction of the Board that they are not, and will not be at the time fixed for the next draft, (Jan. 5, 1864,) liable to military duty on account of Alienage, Non-residence, Unsuitableness of Age, or Manifest Permanent Physical Disability. The time fixed for hearing such cases will expire on the 5th day of January, 1864. After the draft takes place no excuses will be heard on account of the above-mentioned four causes.

abstract: Our military successes in Arkansas promise to be the least substantial fruit of the presence of the Union forces. Since the rebel power in that State was broken, not less than seven thousand citizens have voluntarily come in to Little Rock and taken the oath of allegiance. And as the best proof of the sincerity of their loyalty, five thousand have joined the Union army and are now in the ranks fighting the rebels. The same happy result has attended, the Union arms wherever they have tapped the territory of the rebellion. In fact, we have now in the Union army soldiers from almost every revolted State -- from (not to mention Kentucky and Missouri) Virginia, North Carolina, Tennessee, (two full brigades,) Alabama, Georgia, Louisiana, Arkansas; and Gen. BANKS is now forming a couple of regiments of loyal Texans. And in this count we mean white troops exclusively. All over Arkansas there is an active, earnest desire to reorganize the State under loyal auspices; and it will not, be surprising should this State be the first of the "way ward sisters" to wheel into line. While there was much complaint at the ill-judged policy of the Arkansas expedition from a purely military point of view, such substantial fruit may well cover a multitude of military sins.

abstract: -- On Thursday evening, the atmosphere being unusually dry and clear, some interesting experiments were made upon the line of the American Telegraph Company, whose wires, by the steady progress of our arms, now reach from the borders of Maine to Chattanooga, Tenn., but a short distance from the upper limits of Georgia. The lines from Portland, Boston and New-York were connected with Philadelphia, Louisville and Chattanooga, and the operators at both ends were in instant commanication with each other, exchanging friendly greetings, congratulations upon recent Union triumphs, &c., &c. It was proposed to make a connection with Salt Lake, in distant Utah, which would have been accomplished if the operators there had been fully posted as to the time assigned for the experiment. -- Boston Traveller. Dec. 19.

abstract: The London Times affords an excellent illustration of the truth of the old proverb, that "A man convinced against his will is of the same opinion still."
lead_paragraph: -- The London Times affords an excellent illustration of the truth of the old proverb, that "A man convinced against his will is of the same opinion still." It did not want to believe that BRAGG had actually been driven from his intrenchments before Chattanooga by Gen. GRANT; but the proofs of the exploit were apparently so strong and overwhelming, that it was at last compelled to admit the fact, although it did so reluctantly and grudgingly. But the "Thunderer" is coming back to its old ground. In its issue of Dec. 14, it reviews our military "situation," complains of the indecisiveness of our battles, expresses a little mild surprise at the satisfaction and confidence displayed by the "Northern people," and adds complacently:

abstract: By to-morrow, or next day, the first NewYork regiment from the army of the Potomac, that has reenlisted for the war, in accordance with the provisions of Gen. MEADE'S order, will reach home on its furlough of thirty-five days.
lead_paragraph: -- By to-morrow, or next day, the first NewYork regiment from the army of the Potomac, that has reenlisted for the war, in accordance with the provisions of Gen. MEADE'S order, will reach home on its furlough of thirty-five days. The regiment is the Sixth New-York cavalry, Col. DEVINS. We may expect others in brisk succession, and we have no doubt the presence of these veterans will give recruiting a fillip, such as has not been witnessed since the grand days of the uprising -- for no recruiting sergeants could possibly work with a tithe of the effect of these war-tried heroes. If the day has gone by for public receptions and military parades, we have still no doubt that our people will find the means of showing, by private honor and welcome, a just appreciation of the patriotic impulses that prompt our reenlisting veterans.

abstract: The account of the Engineer of the New-Orleans steamer Geo. Cromwell, on Thursday last, and the arrest of several parties implicated in the contraband trade with the rebels, has already been published. The names of the parties arrested and the specific ...
lead_paragraph: The account of the Engineer of the New-Orleans steamer Geo. Cromwell, on Thursday last, and the arrest of several parties implicated in the contraband trade with the rebels, has already been published. The names of the parties arrested and the specific charges against them have been withheld by the Government authorities until yesterday, when it was announced that among them were Hon. H. SEGUR, formerly Minister to the United States from the Government of San Salvador, and his wife and maidservant. Also, Mr. G.F. CAUTY, a merchant of this City, and Mr. D. PEREZ, of San Salvador. Mr. SEGUR and Mr. PEREZ were arrested on board the Geo. Cromwell, where they had embarked for New-Orleans. Mr. CAUTY was not going out in the steamer, but was discovered to be intimate with the suspected parties, and was arrested as he was about bidding them adieu. On the person of Mrs. SEGUR was found a bill of lading for fifty Kegs of lard, which had been shipped on board the British bark Circassian. On Friday the Kegs of lard were seized, and in them were found one thousand navy revolvers. In the personal baggage of Mr. SEGUR and Mr. PEREZ were also found revolvers and rifle and pistol cartridges. In the bosom of Mrs. SEGUR and of her maid-servant were also found revolvers, and even the children belonging to the family had the same articles concealed about their clothing. The parties were all taken to For Lafayettee on Sunday. Several other parties, including the firm in Cortlandt-street, at whose house the barrels containing powder were packed which were seized on the Geo. Cromwell, have also been arrested, but their names are withheld for the present.

abstract: At a meet  ing held last evening, the Railroad Committee to whom was referred the matter of regulating the various railroad companies, submitted an ordinance in regard to the same, a former ordinance upon the same subject having been vetoed by the Mayor.
lead_paragraph: At a meeting held last evening, the Railroad Committee to whom was referred the matter of regulating the various railroad companies, submitted an ordinance in regard to the same, a former ordinance upon the same subject having been vetoed by the Mayor. The first section provides that conductors and drivers on all the Brooklyn railroad routes shall take out licenses in April of each year. Section two imposes a fine of ten dollars on each conductor and driver for not taking out a license. Section three fixes the license fee at one dollar. Section four compels the conductors and drivers, when requested, to bring the cars to a full stop in setting down and taking up passengers. Section five makes it the duty of the railroad companies to designate, conspicuously within the car, the number of passengers such car is capable of accommodating with a seat. No riding on the platform is to be permitted, and no person beyond the number such car is capable of accommodating with a seat shall be required to pay fare. This section met with considerable opposition, and a motion was eventually carried to refer the matter back to the Committee for modification, until tomorrow (this evening.) The subject is then to be brought up under the head of special order. The same Committee reported in favor of permitting the South Brooklyn and Bergen-street Railroad Company to change their route from Sackett-street, between South and Hoyt streets, to Degraw-street, between the same streets, and from Hoyt-street, between Sackett and Degraw streets, to Smith-street, between the same streets. Laid over until next meeting. The Mayor sent in a communication vetoing the resolution heretofore passed, which directs the cancelment of taxes on the Hay Scales Farm, on the ground that the Board has no legal power in the premises. Another effort was made to elect a Water Commissioner, but without result. The name of Mr. JOHN H. FUNK was presented, and the vote stood 11 yeas to 8 nays. It requires a two-thirds vote to elect.

abstract: -- Two men named JACOB DAY and ABRAHAM GREENLEAF, were taken before Judge POPE, of Hoboken, yesterday, on a charge of highway robbery. It appears that on the morning of the 25th, at 1 o'clock, a man named LARABEE was returning home from cutting evergreens in the vicinity of Seacaucus, when he was met by the accused parties, together with three other men, who beat him most unmercifully, and then nobbed him of a wallet containing $16 50. The prisoners were arrested by Capt. MONK, of the Hoboken Police. The Judge refused to accept bail, and they were committed in jail for trial.

abstract: We are very glad to learn that in the construction of the new monitors great heed has been paid to the all-important element of speed. This has been one of the chief radical defects of those that have hitherto been built. None of them, we believe has ever been able to exceed four knots an hour. This, of course, renders them utterly useless as rams -- a function which in the service to which they were orignally designed, namely, harbor defence, is of prime importance. But the new monitors, furnished with, powerful engines, will make triple or quadruple the speed of the old monitors those of the Tecumseh type having a speed of twelve; arid those of the Dictator type of fifteen knots an hour.

abstract: Gen. BUTLER has already put a new phase upon the matter of the exchange of prisoners. He has already succeeded in rescuing five hundred of our men from filth and starvation in Richmond.
lead_paragraph: Gen. BUTLER has already put a new phase upon the matter of the exchange of prisoners. He has already succeeded in rescuing five hundred of our men from filth and starvation in Richmond. But it is now reported that the rebels will not proceed with the exchange unless our Government abandons all the questions in controversy and recognizes the rebel law of retaliation against black troops and their white officers. It is also said that the rebels refuse to treat with Gen. BUTLER on any question, because of JEFF. DAVIS' proclamation of last year, denouncing him as an outlaw. This position is very ridiculous, as they already have treated with him, receiving communications, medicines, and five hundred of their own men at his hands. Gen. BUTLER has adroitly thrown the responsibility of an utter refusal to proceed with the exchange upon the rebel authorities, and compelled them to assign most ridiculous reasons therefor -- reasons which they will have to abandon whenever Gen. BUTLER takes his next step.

abstract: -- Coroner HANLEY, of Hudson City, held an inquest yesterday upon the body of a young girl named LOUISA SENZ, who died Sunday night from the effects of burns. Deceased was employed in J.R. DAY's match manufactory, and on Saturday, while walking across the floor, ignited some matches by stepping upon them, which set fire to her clothing, and before it was extinguished received burns which subsequently caused her death. A verdict of accidental death was rendered.
lead_paragraph: -- Coroner HANLEY, of Hudson City, held an inquest yesterday upon the body of a young girl named LOUISA SENZ, who died Sunday night from the effects of burns. abstract: The steamer Olympus, from Liverpool, Dec. 16, arrived yesterday morning, bringing three days' later European advices.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Olympus, from Liverpool, Dec. 16, arrived yesterday morning, bringing three days' later European advices. Two more American merchantmen are reported to have been destroyed off Java Head by the pirate Alabama on the 16th of November -- one was the bark Amanda, of Maine, and the other the clipper ship Winged Racer, of New-York. Both vessels were homeward bound from the East Indies with valuable cargoes. The circumstances connected with the alleged enlistment of 15 Irishmen on board the United States gunboat Kearsage, at Cork, were being privately investigated by the police and Customs officials at Queenstown. The London Times correspondent at Richmond points to the fact that the blockade is now so vigorous that access to the Confederate coast is both dangerous and difficult. The powerful 50-gun iron-clad frigate Minotaur was launched on the Thames on the 12th inst. The Holstein question remained in a threatening condition. England had officially notified Denmark that in case her integrity should be threatened by the Germanic Confederation she would find her an ally on whose assistance she could depend. The Frankfort Diet on the 14th voted 17,000,000 thalers for the expenses of the Federal Executive

abstract: The fortune of LONGSTREET'S column is the greatest puzzle of the war. It is a perfect mystery how he continues to subsist his force; for rich though the great Virginia and Tennessee valley is, it has alread been drained by two months' occupancy of BURNSIDE'S army.
lead_paragraph: The fortune of LONGSTREET'S column is the greatest puzzle of the war. It is a perfect mystery how he continues to subsist his force; for rich though the great Virginia and Tennessee valley is, it has alread been drained by two months' occupancy of BURNSIDE's army. He is entirely without base of supplies or lines of communication. To add to the embarrassment of his situation. AVERILL has cut off all possibility of his drawing supplies from Lynchburgh or Richmond. He cannot possibly rejoin the rebel army at Dalton; for GRANT is in his way; and he has a march of four hundred miles over the horrible roads of the season into Virginia. While giving the column and its commander credit for every imaginable energy, pluck and perseverance, it is impossible to conceive how it can fail to be almost utterly broken and used up -- its transportation destroyed and its artillery and materiel abandoned. A very short period now must decide LONGSTREET's fate.

abstract: Mayhew, Henry; Boyhood of Luther
lead_paragraph: This little work has qualities which make it more worthy of attention than is obvious on the surface, where it appears to be an ordinary juvenile book. It is the result of a special tour made by the author to each of the places where LUTHER's youthful life was spent, and of a thorough examination of all ancient sources of information relating to his early career. Much new and interesting matter is thus brought forward relative to the Reformer and his family, which had escaped the researches of professed historians, and a strong light is thrown on the various conflicting influences that concurred to make LUTHER the man that the world found him, when the moment of action had arrived. It is impossible to recommend the work too highly to all who feel an interest in the subject.

abstract: Christmas Day, Mr. STANTON visited the soldiers in Stanton Hospital, Washington, and made them a brief speech. He said: Soldiers, I hope that when the next anniversary of the day you are now celebrating occurs, that this war will be ended, and you will have returned to your homes and your firesides. When you shall have so returned, you will be considered as honored guests of the nation. You have periled your lives upon the battle-field, or you have suffered in camps from the ravages of disease incidental to great armies. But whether you have been wounded or been attacked by sickness, you are equally entitled to consideration at the hands of your country. If you have been wounded in battle, or suffer from sickness contracted in the service of your country, I will see that you have a proper reward given you.

abstract: --We are informed that ABEL STEARNS, of Los Anglos, lost about 7,000 head of cattle, through want of food, during the last few months. That gentleman is presumed to be the largest stock and land owner in the United States. He owns this year 48,000 cattle, besides 9,000 calves. His lands are embraced in twenty-one grants, containing, it is estimated, over 540,000 acres. All these grants have been confirmed to Mr. STEARNS, except one which is now pending before Judge HOFFMAN. They were all acquired by purchase. The well-known Temascal tin mine, which may some day rival even the New-Almaden in value, belongs to Mr. STEARNS. It is embraced in one of the grants which was confirmed last week to him. Mr. STEARNS is a native of Massachusetts. He came to California in 1823, and has resided in this country ever since. He is a warm supporter of the Union party, and to a great extent by his influence the Secessionists of the southern counties have been kept back and out of office. -- San Francisco Bulletin, Nov. 18.

abstract: admission of ordering rams from England
snippet: admission of ordering rams from England
lead_paragraph: It will be remembered that at the time of the excitement about the building of the rams in England and France, the rebel agents, together with Messrs. LAIRD & CO., tried to palm them off as being designed for this or that potentate. The "Emperor of China" was made to father one or more of these pachydermous monsters. "The King of Egypt" also came in for one or two more, and the bastard progeny were even baptized with Turkish names, such as El Massoun, &c., to make the cheat the more complete. Meanwhile nobody doubted for a moment that they were really designed for the rebels. And of this we have now direct testimony from the rebel Secretary of the Navy, MALLORY, who in his report roundly acknowledges the corn. He confesses that by order of JEFF. DAVIS he dispatched several agents to England and France "to contract for eight iron-clad rams for the purpose of breaking the blockade." Five were to be built in England and three in France. But, "owing to the unfriendly construction of her neutrality laws" (neutrality in the case of iron-clad rams is rather good of MALLORY) "the ones built in England were not allowed to depart," while those built in France were subjected to so many official visitations that he has "sent orders to have the work on them stopped." Though this acknowledgment does not add the assurance of a straw to what was before the moral certainty of everybody, it is well enough to have the cat let out of the bag at once. We now know exactly what the "Emperor of China" looks like. He has hollow cheeks and high cheek-bones, wears a stovepipe hat and Yankee coat (rather rusty and the worse for wear), and is the very counterfeit presentment of that ornament of the "Rogue's Gallery," JEFFERSON DAVIS.

abstract: The November number of this standard Scientific Journal closes the thirty-sixth volume. Prof. DANA opens the the number with two papers, one on the parallel relations of the classes of Vertebrates, and on some characteristics of the Reptilian Birds, and another on the "Classification of animals based on the principle Cephalization." This last is the first of a series on the same subject. The other articles are, by Professor LOOMIS on "Vibrating Waterfalls;" a letter from Sir W.E. LOGAN to Mr. JOACHIN BARRANDE, on the "Rocks of the Quebec Group at Point Levis;" a novice of CHAUVENNT's Manual of Spherical and Practical Astronomy; on "The Prairie Flats and Barrens of Southern Illinois," by HENRY ENGELMANN, and "On the Earth's Climate in Palozoic Times," by T. SPERRY HUNT, Mr NICKLES' correspondence is of more than usual interest, and the scientific summary is as full and valuable as ever.

abstract: DAMAGE OVER $15,000. Between 8 and 9 o'clock last evening a fire occurred in the three-story brick building situated on the northwest corner of Marketstreet and Water-street. Before the flames could be extinguished the entire buliding and contents were destroyed.
lead_paragraph: -- DAMAGE OVER $15,000. -- Between 8 and 9 o'clock last evening a fire occurred in the three-story brick building situated on the northwest corner of Marketstreet and Water-street. Before the flames could be extinguished the entire buliding and contents were destroyed. It was occupied as a storehouse for bay and straw by Messrs. TITUS, FRAZKE & TITUS. It was a large establishment, extending about 150 foot on Water-street, and more than that distance on Market-street. They estimate their damage at over $6,000 on stock, and are insured for $1,500 in the Montauk Insurance Company. The building was known as No. 88 Market-street. The flames extended to the upper stories of the four-story brick building No. 86, also occupied by Messrs. TITUS & CO. as a feed-store. Their loss here, by fire and water, is over $5,000 on stock; slightly insured. Both the buildings were owned by the estate of ABRAHAM WILLET, and are fully insured. The estimated damage on them is between $4,000 and $5,000. The origin of the fire is not known.

abstract: Mallory's report of rebel navy
lead_paragraph: MALLORY's REPORT OF THE REBEL NAVY. -- In another column will be found the full report of the rebel Secretary of the Navy, of which we have hitherto had only fragmentary portions. It will be found a very interesting document. Mr. MALLORY states that "the operations of this branch of the Confederate service have been chiefly confined to preparations for ridding our waters of the enemy's vessels now blockading our seaports;" but as we have yet to hear that the blockade of any of "our seaports" has yet been raised, the' inference is that they have utterly failed in their main purpose; and as, according to the last Message of Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, it is only a "paper blockade," this failure tells badly for the rebels. If, however, there is not much that is encouraging in this direction, Mr. MALLORY finds great solace in the exploits of the rebel cruisers. The Florida has, it seems, during the past year, destroyed vessels and property "amounting to several millions," while the Alabama (SEMMES) "has captured upward of ninety vessels, seventy of which were destroyed, the others being either bonded or released." The acknowledgment of the construction of iron-clad steam rams in England and France, already commented upon, is made in the most explicit terms. But although the British Government's "unfriendly construction of its neutrality laws" has put a stopper on "the Emperor of China's" rams, yet Mr. MALLORY tells us that another and larger one has been built, and that, in regard to her, "precautions have been taken sufficient to exempt her from the fate of her consorts." Those building in France had been subjected to so many official visitations that he forwarded instructions to cease operations upon them " until the result of negotiations now pending shall permit our agent to resume work upon them." These are little items that our authorities will doubtless have an eye to. Mr. MALLORY speaks affectingly of the "proud spirit of our officers chafing at the inaction they are compelled to endure;" but he sees in prophetic vision a grand future for the rebel navy. When they get their "six turreted iron-clads," their eight rams and their " hundred small wooden gunboats," they will no doubt have a great navy. But for the present it is all in the "future in rus."

abstract: There are no more unfortunate travelers, now-a-days, than those who reside in New-Jersey and are compelled to depend on the Morris and Essex Railroad to reach this City. Since its contract with the New-Jersey Railroad expired, and it commenced running ever the Hoboken extension, irregularity has been the rule, and regularity the exception. Trains run apparently to suit the convenience of the conductors, and the time-tables which were issued two or three months ago have probably been consigned to the archives of the New-Jersey Historical Society as interesting relics of the past. Now and then the tedium of delay is broken in upon by some hair-breadth escape from a startling disaster, such as that which occurred on the bridge over the Passaic a few days ago, when three hundred passengers were nearly plunged into me river by the partial giving way of the draw; but these little excitements are not so agreeable that their repetition is called for. All kinds of hypotheses are urged to account for this chronic nits-management. Some say that the necessity of running upon a single track between Newark and Hoboken is the cause of all the delays and accidents; others that the Railroad Company has not enough rolling stock to accommodate the travel which has been suddenly thrown upon its hands, and that in due time the evil will be remedied by the addition of sundry mythical, locomotives. Others still assert that a little energy and attention to business on the part of those nominally charged with the management of the road would go far to set matters straight, and those who persistently assert their belief in the existence of a superintendent, for no individual exercising the prerogatives of that officer is ever to be found when his presence is needed, say that his hands are so tied by the Directors that he is virtually powerless to apply the obvious remedies. Amid all these conjectures one thing is certain -- that complaints enough can be heard in the course of a single trip over the Road in question to disturb the slumbers of all those who are justly responsible for so much mismanagement, if each individual concerned only appropriated his own share. Unless a change is speedily made, real estate in that section of New-Jersey which has depended upon this Road will rapidly depreciate, and then, perhaps, the stockholders will begin to institute investigations into the mismanagement of their property. Such a movement would be most opportune, for the present Directors evidently labor under the impression that they are the masters of the public, and not its servants.

abstract: Discriminating Neutrality
lead_paragraph: The British Government has seen fit to hedge round its interpretation of maritime neutrality with restrictions, in the case of the Bahamas, with extraordinary stringency, and among our European news this morning will be found a dispatch from the Duke of Newcastle to the Governor of the Bahamas that draws the bands still tighter. In the original rules, touching the reception of the war vessels of either belligerent, defined by Earl RUSSELL in his dispatch dated Jan. 31, 1862, (republished by us in another column,) it was directed that no ship-of-war or privateer belonging to either belligerent should be permitted to enter or remain in the port of Nassau, or in any other port, roadstead or waters of the Bahama Islands, except by special leave of the Lieutenant-Governor, or in case of stress of weather. Now, doubts having arisen as to whether a belligerent ship-of-war or privateer should obtain the permission of the local authorities before entering the ports, roadsteads or waters of the Bahama out-islands when the Governor was not present, it is the object of the Duke of Newcastle's late note, under date of Oct. 6, to state that at the out-islands, as at Nassau, the special leave of the Governor himself is required, unless in cases of grave emergency and real necessity and distress. In such cases, as, for instance, where a sailing vessel is dismasted, or an accident happens to the machinery of a steam vessel, the vessel may enter by leave of a resident officer to whom the Governor shall have given authority to admit her. But such officer must receive copies of the regulations of the 31st January, 1862, and his especial attention must be called to the limits of the authority delegated, and to that clause in the regulations in which it is directed that vessels entering under stress of weather, or by special leave, shall be required to put to sea as soon as possible.

abstract: -- It is almost too late in the day to recommend the sewing-machine as a useful article in a family. No well-regulated household is without one. This question settled, the next thing to do is to select the one best suited to your requirements. Both of the editors of the Home Journal have long had the Grover & Baker machine in their households, and can speak from experience. We therefore have no hesitation in saying that we like this machine, and for the following reasons: First -- It is more simple, durable and less liable to derangement than others. Second -- It sews from ordinary spools, and no rewinding of thread is necessary. Third -- It sews with equal facility all fabrics, the most delicate and the heaviest, and with all kinds of thread, silk, cotton or linen. Fourth -- Its seam is so strong and elastic that it never breaks. Fifth -It fasters both ends of the seam by its own operation. Sixth -- Its seam, though cut at every sixth stitch, remains firm, and neither runs nor ravels in wear. But, besides the above qualities to recommend the "Grover & Baker," it has a faculty which no other machine possesses; it makes beautiful embroidery without any change of arrangement. Having come to the conclusion as to which machine to purchase, we would ask what more noble or handsomer holiday gift could be selected? Nothing could possibly be more acceptable in a house where it has not yet been introduced. It not only saves money and time, but is certain to preserve the health and very often the temper of the "gude wife." -- New-York Home Journal.

abstract: The article in Monday's TIMES in regard to a "kidnapping" of a negro at Lafayette Hall, is denied by Gen. SPINOLA and his Staff. We give them the benefit of the denial, and assert that the information was received from the headquarters of the negro regiment, No. 350 Fourth-street, and that ALEXANDER, one of the colored men alleged to have been kidnapped, was one of the informants. We learn also from the headquarters of Gen. DIX, that an officer was sent to arrest the parties charged as guilty of the kidnapping, but that they were not to be found. There is no disposition to reflect upon Gen. SPINOLA or his division. He is presumed not to be responsible for all the acts in detail of his subordinates, but on half an hour's attempt yesterday, at his headquarters to ascertain the facts of the case, all that could be ascertained was that "it was not so." The officers of the guard on Thursday and Friday deny the statement in toto, and yet another officer states that there was a colored man taken charge of on Thursday, who was a recruit, and that ALEXANDER, the colored man referred to in the article of Monday, interfered, and was arrested and held for such interference. The officers disclaim entirely any cognizance or countenance of acts such as were complained of, and allege that in all cases coming to their knowledge the remedy and rebuke are promptly applied. If rests with the officers of the negro regiment to substantiate the statement made to our reporter.

abstract: On Saturday MORGAN L. FILKINS, of Albany, Captain in the One Hundred and Seventy-seventh (Albany) New-York Volunteers, (Member of Assembly elect.) arrived in this City from New-Orleans, on...
lead_paragraph: On Saturday MORGAN L. FILKINS, of Albany, Captain in the One Hundred and Seventy-seventh (Albany) New-York Volunteers, (Member of Assembly elect.) arrived in this City from New-Orleans, on the Mississippi, having in his charge nineteen of the bodies of members of the regiment who had fallen before Fort Hudson, or died in the Department of the Gulf from illness. Sixteen bodies he had sent in advance on the Merrimac, which arrived earlier last week, and they were at once forwarded to Albany.

abstract: The Re d'Italia, the new Italian iron-clad recently launched at W.H. WEBB'S shipyard, met with an accident yesterday morning about 1 o'clock, which may prove disastrous to the vessel. The circumstances of the mishap are briefly as follows. Saturday afternoon the Re d'Italia, left her dock in Hobo ken, having on board a large number of invited...
lead_paragraph: The Re d'Italia, the new Italian iron-clad recently launched at W.H. WEBB'S shipyard, met with an accident yesterday morning about 1 o'clock, which may prove disastrous to the vessel. The circumstances of the mishap are briefly as follows. Saturday afternoon the Re d'Italia, left her dock in Hobo ken, having on board a large number of invited guests, for the purpose of a trial trip. It was thought at the time the vessel would steam but a few miles down the Bay and return before nightfall. It appears, however, the Captain of the ship was disposed to give his visitors something of a voyage, and after taking on a board a coast pilot steered for Barnegat light. Nothing more was heard of the vessel until the arrival of the dispatch, early yesterday morning, announcing the accident that befell her. It seems everything had gone on pleasantly during the voyage up to the time when a question was raised between the officers of the ship, the pilot and some of the seafaring guests concerning the whereabouts of the vessel. The Captain, believing he understood the coast, gave orders for soundings, which were improperly reported to him. About 1 o'clock, while the convivolities incident to trial trips had not been entirely dispensed with, the ship suddenly grounded. A scene of considerable confusion followed. Efforts were made relieve the vessel and get her off, but without avail. In this connection, it should be stated that previous to the stranding of the ship one of her engines became disabled and for some time she was propelled by one engine only, assisted by her sails. These circumstances may be considered fortunate for the vessel and aid board, for, had she been going it full speed at the time she struck, the most disastrous consequences might have followed. As soon as it became apparent that the ship could not be got off without assistance signal guns were fired, which brought to the beach most of the citizens of Fresh Pond a small place about two miles north of the main hotels on Long Branch. An underwriter's agent, who live out a short distance from the spot where the vessel stranded, made his appearance soon after the signal-guns were fired, and at once dispatched a team to the Government house at Station No. 3 to procure a surf-boat. In the meantime, those on board the Re d'Italia were made acquainted with their exact locality and the preparations that were being made for their safety. Shortly before 3 o'clock the surf-boat arrived, when a difficulty arose who should man it. This was soon settled by the volunteering of five old surfmen named CHAS. H. VALENTINE, BORDEN WEST, ABRAHAM LIPPINCOTT, ELIJAH DISBROW and WILLIAM MAIHAN. The first desperate attempt of these brave men to reach the ship failed. As soon as their boat was fairly afloat, it was struck by a wave and sent whirling back to the shore. The surfmen finding that it was impossible to reach the vessel from a point immediately opposite her took their boat a considerable distance further south, and again launched it. This time they were successful, and after a half hour's have pulling reached the vessel. They did not attempt to board her, but at once offered their services for the rescue of the passengers. Previous to the arrival of the boat, however, it had been ascertained by the wrecked pleasure party that they were comparatively safe, and learning they were off Wardellic Beach, stuck fast in the sand, in a strong [???], they all, except an officer bearing dispatches to the Italian Consul and two other gentlemen, concluded to remain on board until morning. The surfmen, accordingly after finding no further assistance was required, pulled their boat to the shore, which they did not reach until nearly daylight. The citizens on Wardellic Beach showed a commendable disposition to render assistance, should any be needed. They were constantly on the alert doing everything that would have been required of them had the vessel proved a total wreck. Conspicuous among the number who were the most assiduous in their endeavors to launch the surf-boat, and who rendered other valuable aid were the brothers HERBERT and EDWARD WARDELL.

abstract: The steamship Adriatic, at St. Johns, N.F., brings us telegraphic advices from Europe to the 22d inst., and the Hammonia and City of Manchester, at this port, put us in possesion of our foreign correspondence and files to the 16th. The news is interesting. Synopses of President LINCOLN'S Message and Proclamation...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Adriatic, at St. Johns, N.F., brings us telegraphic advices from Europe to the 22d inst., and the Hammonia and City of Manchester, at this port, put us in possesion of our foreign correspondence and files to the 16th. The news is interesting. Synopses of President LINCOLN'S Message and Proclamation of Amnesty had reached England, and were variously commented on by the journals. The offer of peace is generally considered impracticable in its conditions. The situation of affairs puzzles and mystifies the editors exceedingly. It is stated on the authority of the Liverpool Post, that Lord LYONS has hazarded a prediction to Earl RUSSELL that the war will end in three mouths, because of the exhaustion of the rebels. The message of JEFF. DAVIS was generally regarded by the press as evincing no signs of yielding on the part of the South. The rebel government are said to have made full provision to meet the payment of the 75,000 sterling Cotton Loan Bonds to be drawn for in March. Employes in the dockyard at Sheerness had been stringently dealt with by the British Admiralty, for connivance in fitting out the Rappahannock for the Confederates, and the names of persons connected with the Naval Reserve, who have served on any rebel vessels, have been stricken from the list, and their privileges forfeited. It was rumored that the Duke of Newcastle was about to resign his position of Secretary of State on account of ill-health. Our Paris correspondence gives important information concerning the building and litting out of rebel war vessels in French ports, and the measures which have been adopted by our Minister, Mr. DAYTON, to prevent their departure, from which it is likely that the rebel plans to get up a navy in that quarter will be defeated. Mr. SUPERVILLE, the new rebel Envoy to France, had arrived at Paris, it was said, with a mission to notify the French Government of the recognition by the Confederacy of the Empire of Mexico, and to try to persuade NAPOLEON to recognize the South in return for that acknowledgment. There is little change in the Schleswig-Holstein affair, but it was supposed that Denmark would not forcibly oppose the Federal Execution.

abstract: Cobden, Richard, and the Times' Anonymous Newspaper Writing
snippet: Cobden, Richard, and the Times' Anonymous Newspaper Writing
lead_paragraph: Mr. COBDEN's quarrel with the London Times is bringing up in England once more the much debated topic of the anonymity of, articles in the press. Mr. COBDEN, and nearly every other man who has passed long years in public strife, and is daily undergoing the rude buffetings of political controversy, is greatly annoyed at having any comments made upon his public doings by writers whose names are not revealed. The reason of this is quite obvious. There have been few, if any public men, in any country or in any age, equal to the task of discussing any question upon its merits solely, and without any reference, tacit or expressed, to the qualities or antecedents of his opponents or critics. No matter what the subject may be, however elevating, however sacred, however far removed from the passions, prejudices and interests of everyday life, nobody who deals with it ever seems wholly able to dismiss from his mind the personality of those taking an opposite view of it. This is true of religion and of philosophy; no wonder it is true of politics. The odium theologicum has been for we know not how many centuries a synonym for the bitterest rancor, and there have been few quarrels more envenomed than those arising from differences of opinion upon points of metaphysics and natural philosophy. A recent volume of the Peaks, Passes and Glaciers tells of the violent quarrel and separation in Switzerland of two intimate friends who came over from America to travel in Europe together, owing to an irreconcilable difference of opinion upon the glacier theory. In short, whenever an ardent man -- and all prominent men in every walk of life are ardent men -- discovers that an opinion differing from his own has been promulgated upon a subject in which he is much interested, his first and strongest desire, before devoting himself to a consideration of the arguments by which it is supported, is to discover who the author is and to get at him. All this is simply human and natural. We are none of us spiritual enough to be able to deal contentedly with abstractions alone. Both truth and error have to take a concrete form before we can either love or hate them as they deserve. Each is to have a man behind it, before it can be properly assailed or defended.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- Mr. MARETZEK's last performance takes place this evening -- the opera being GOUNOD's "Faust." The great popularity of the work, its admirable caste and fine mise-en-scene, will insure a splendid attendance. Mr. MARETZEK and troupe leave for Boston to-morrow, and will not return until February. It is, therefore, the last holiday chance. The interest of the performance will be enhanced by the fact, that the Arion Society will take part in the Soldiers' Chorus of the fourth act. An accession of so many fine manly voices will give the fullest effect possible to this favorite morceau.

abstract: how it works
lead_paragraph: EDWIN H. EWING was long known as one of the ablest lawyers in Tennessee. When the President issued his requisition upon the States for seventy-five thousand men, after the bombardment of Sumter, Mr. EWING united with JOHN BELL, NEIL S. BROWN, BAILE PEYTON, and half a dozen of the other leading men of the State, in a public address sustaining Gov. HARRIS in refusing to furnish the two regiments required of their State. Five days afterward, he addressed, with JOHN BELL, a great popular gathering in Nashville, and declared, as we find reported at the time that "the Union between the North and the South was at an end forever, and he had no hope of its restoration. He regarded this as a war of subjugation, and would never consent to such a domination as was attempted to be established over us." We see it now stated that this same EDWIN H. EWING has expressed his readiness to accept amnesty on the conditions of the President's Proclamation, and freely urges the same step upon his friends.

abstract: What shall it be? What will best redeem the past, and be a good omen for the future? What souvenir will have the most potent charm; touch most deeply the heart; live sweetest in the memory; not be cast aside after receiving the due meed of admiration, but be ever present in the daily routine of life; speak of a happy New Year and a tender thoughtfulness? Among other things we suggest a WHEELER & WILSON's Sewing Machine. It will bring sunshine, perfect sunshine, into many dark hours. A thing of use and beauty is a joy forever. Into every perfect line of stitching, so magically wrought by that swift, glittering needle, will be twined tender remembrances of the donor's thoughtfulness. -- Express.

abstract: The United States vs. The Sloop D. Sargent  This vessel was captured March 12, 1863, off Galveston, by the Kittatinny. The vessel was sent into New-Orleans as unseaworthy, and being valued there, on appraisal, at $1,500, was left there and her ...
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Sloop D. Sargent This vessel was captured March 12, 1863, off Galveston, by the Kittatinny. The vessel was sent into New-Orleans as unseaworthy, and being valued there, on appraisal, at $1,500, was left there and her cargo sent to this port for condemnation. A claim and answer was filed on behalf of Peter Morrill, as owner, in which he claimed that there was no war between the United States and any other people or nation, whereby any forfeiture of the vessel had been incurred; and that no blockade of any port existed or was known to the claimant whereby the vessel or cargo was liable to condemnation.

abstract: Chronology for 1863
lead_paragraph: 1. THE EMANCIPATION PROCLAMATION OF PRESDENT LINCOLN, DECLARING SLAVES IN THE INSURRECTIONARY STATES AND DISTRICTS FOREVER AND HENCEFORWARD FREE, issued....The battle of Murfreesboro, Tenn., commenced Dec. 31, 1862, continued. The engagement opened at dawn by Gen. ROSECRANS. The battle was hotly contested, and the losses great on both sides....The rebel guerrilla MORGAN defeated in Kentucky....Emancipation Jubilee of the negroes at Hilton Head, S.C...The rebel Gen. FORREST defeated at Hunt's Cross Roads, Tenn., by Gen. SULLIVAN....Galveston, Texas, recaptured by the rebels, who also took the steamer Harriet Lane. The steamer Westfield was blown up by its commander to prevent it from falling into the hands of the rebels....Gen. BUTLER and Staff arrived in New-York City from New-Orleans....Charges preferred against the New-York Police Commissioners for illegal action in making arrests for treason, &c.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The closing night of the opera gave us a performance of many encores and of such hearty appreciation and comely enjoyment, that every one regretted that it was not the first ...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The closing night of the opera gave us a performance of many encores and of such hearty appreciation and comely enjoyment, that every one regretted that it was not the first representation of a season instead of the last. That "Faust" is destined to become the most popular opera of the modern Italian repertoire, is indicated in the increasing murmur of applause which is heard in all art circles, and prefigured in every performance by fresh points of public approbation. The encores last night "broke out" in new places. Perhaps that was owing to a very manifest disposition to encore everything -- a disposition which was only regulated by the stubborn determination of Mr. MARETZEK to bring the performance to an end, and go to Boston. On the first night, it will be remembered, many of the best morceaux were passed over in silence. The change from then to now is noticeable as an indication of a decided familiarity with the music on the part of the public; for the public, rank and file was represented last night. And as this familiarity increases so will the popularity of the opera. If the cruel exigency of losing money -- without which operatic management would be a sham and an imposition -- did not compel Mr. MARETZEK to travel to Boston, he might, we are persuaded, play "Faust" here for a considerable season, and with profitable and otherwise astounding results to the exchequer.

abstract: The Free State Convention; the Louisiana Convention
snippet: The Free State Convention; the Louisiana Convention
lead_paragraph: In our comments upon the recent admission of a colored delegation to seats in a Free State Convention of Louisiana, we assumed that the Convention was mainly made up of Northern men. A correspondent, more familiar with the members than we are, corrects this assumption in another column. He states that several of the leading men in the Convention are gentlemen who have lived a long time in New-Orleans, and who occupy a high personal and social position in that city. They have long been active in opposition to Slavery, and in asserting the rightful equality before the law of negroes and whites. They are men of principle, and maintain what they believe to be the cause of justice with great firmness, intelligence and self-denial.

abstract: Prizes and Sailors
lead_paragraph: -- Some short time ago we published the proceedings of a meeting of sailors in this City, in which the slowness of the payment of prize money was spoken of as a reason why there were so much fewer enlistments in the navy than is desired. And within a few days a letter has been published from a sailor on board the Florida, inquiring why the proceeds of the schooner Hattie, a prize captured by the Florida in last June, were not yet distributed. We publish this morning the decision of the Court in the case of the Hattie, which will furnish the desired information. It appears that she was brought in here and a decree of forfeiture rendered against her and her cargo by default in July last. Up to that time the proceedings had been rapid enough to satisfy any one. But this rate of progress was not kept up. For some reason or other the proceeds were not distributed, and now, in December, the former owners of the vessel apply to the Court, by consent of the District-Attorney, stating that the schooner was formerly theirs, but was taken from them by the privateer Retribution, and the Court, accordingly, directs the restoration to the owners of the vessel, or rather of her proceeds, she having been sold, on payment of one-eighth of her value as salvage. So that in this case the delay has been productive of good to the loyal former owners of the vessel, and no sailor will regret that they have thus been enabled to get their property back again. With regard to the cargo, no such results have followed, and the seamen of the Florida might perhaps rightfully complain that so long a time has elapsed before the settlement of the cargo, if that could have been closed up independently of the vessel. But as the case stood, that could not be done.

abstract: --The Richmond journals received yesterday publish some additional correspondence between Gens. HITCHCOCK and MEREDITH and the rebel Commissioner OULD, but nothing of a later date than Nov. 28. The question is still left by these letters involved in the unsettled difficulties concerning the paroles at Gettysburgh, Vicksburgh, Port Hudson, and various other places. The public should not forget, in regard to the Union prisoners paroled at Gettysburgh, that they were never received, as required by the cartel, "with the consent of the opposing commander in the field" -- never "reduced to actual possession" at all, as required, but turned loose, to find their way into our lines. It is further a matter of history that, during the battle of Gettysburgh, Gen. LEE sent a flag-of-truce to arrange for burying the dead, succoring the wounded, and exchanging prisoners, which was promptly refused by Gen. MEADE. Now the rebels insist upon offsetting these invalid paroles, made in violation of the cartel, against the valid paroles made by Gens. GRANT and BANKS at Vicksburgh and Port Hudson, made according to the express terms of the cartel, which provides that paroles and exchanges in the field shall only be valid when mutually agreed upon by the commanders of the opposing armies. In addition, and in further violation of the cartel, the rebels insist upon counting all the paroles given by such guerrillas as MORGAN, RICHARDSON, and others, in their raids, as valid, though not a prisoner was reduced to the condition of "actual possession," as required by the cartel. If the illegal paroles at Gettysburgh were the only ones claimed by the enemy, our Government could afford to allow them, under protest, for the sake of our suffering men now in Southern prisons. But this is not the only false claim of the enemy. The rebel authorities are trumping up every imaginable shadow of a claim to a prisoner, and firmly insist upon setting off such claims against the immense number of actual captives we have in our hands. The makeshifts, subterfuges, dishonesty and tyrannical legislation of the rebels are now simply symbolical of the utter desperation of their hopeless work of rebellion. The final collapse grows nearer and surer with every struggle and gasp of the wretches now devoting themselves to rule and ruin.
lead_paragraph: --The Richmond journals received yesterday publish some additional correspondence between Gens. HITCHCOCK and MEREDITH and the rebel Commissioner OULD, but nothing of a later date than Nov. 28. The question is still left by these letters involved in the unsettled difficulties concerning the paroles at Gettysburgh, Vicksburgh, Port Hudson, and various other places. The public should not forget, in regard to the Union prisoners paroled at Gettysburgh, that they were never received, as required by the cartel, "with the consent of the opposing commander in the field" -- never "reduced to actual possession" at all, as required, but turned loose, to find their way into our lines. It is further a matter of history that, during the battle of Gettysburgh, Gen. LEE sent a flag-of-truce to arrange for burying the dead, succoring the wounded, and exchanging prisoners, which was promptly refused by Gen. MEADE. Now the rebels insist upon offsetting these invalid paroles, made in violation of the cartel, against the valid paroles made by Gens. GRANT and BANKS at Vicksburgh and Port Hudson, made according to the express terms of the cartel, which provides that paroles and exchanges in the field shall only be valid when mutually agreed upon by the commanders of the opposing armies. In addition, and in further violation of the cartel, the rebels insist upon counting all the paroles given by such guerrillas as MORGAN, RICHARDSON, and others, in their raids, as valid, though not a prisoner was reduced to the condition of "actual possession," as required by the cartel. If the illegal paroles at Gettysburgh were the only ones claimed by the enemy, our Government could afford to allow them, under protest, for the sake of our suffering men now in Southern prisons. But this is not the only false claim of the enemy. The rebel authorities are trumping up every imaginable shadow of a claim to a prisoner, and firmly insist upon setting off such claims against the immense number of actual captives we have in our hands. The makeshifts, subterfuges, dishonesty and tyrannical legislation of the rebels are now simply symbolical of the utter desperation of their hopeless work of rebellion. The final collapse grows nearer and surer with every struggle and gasp of the wretches now devoting themselves to rule and ruin.

abstract: The dullness which now characterizes the stock market, and the general indisposition to buy or sell at this particular period, renders a list of quotations unnecessary. It is proper to remark, however, that, so far as indicated by the limited transactions of the past few days, prices have undergone no material change, except of Confederate bonds, which have declined under the influence of the schemes of financial ...
lead_paragraph: The dullness which now characterizes the stock market, and the general indisposition to buy or sell at this particular period, renders a list of quotations unnecessary. It is proper to remark, however, that, so far as indicated by the limited transactions of the past few days, prices have undergone no material change, except of Confederate bonds, which have declined under the influence of the schemes of financial relief projected in the Confederate Congress. The eight per cent. bonds are now quotable at $105@$112 and interest; the seven per cents. at $101 and interest. The amount of business in securities will continue light until some days after the 1st of January, when the large sums disbursed in the shape of interest and dividends will create a renewed demand for bonds and stocks.

abstract: Carriage Presentation to
lead_paragraph: Last evening a very handsome compliment was paid to Mr.GUNTHER, Mayor-elect, by a number of his personal friends. During the afternoon they sent to his stable, in Fourteenth street, a very costly and beautiful coupe, one of the handsomest that JOHN R. LAWRENCE, carriage-maker, ever built. This was wholly unexpected to Mr. GUNTHER, and he was in no little uncertainty as to where it came from until he was waited on, about 8 P.M., by a committee and invited to visit the St. James Hotel, at Twenty-sixth-street and Broadway. Here, on entering the parlor, he found some sixty of his personal friends assembled, and was welcomed most warmly. Before he had time to recover from his surprise, he was addressed by RICHARD M. HARRINGTON, Esq., as follows:

abstract: The great Gen. AVERILL has gone not "up the spout," but back into his den. Cast your eye upon a map, and I'll tell you how he went and how he came. He came from New Creek, a depot on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, in the County of Hardy, along ...
lead_paragraph: The great Gen. AVERILL has gone not "up the spout," but back into his den. Cast your eye upon a map, and I'll tell you how he went and how he came. He came from New Creek, a depot on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, in the County of Hardy, along the western base of the Shenandoah Mountains, through Covington to Salem, burnt things generally, and returned over nearly the same route. IMBODEN seized the gap where the Parkersburgh turnpike crosses the Shenandoah, and prevented a raid on Staunton. AVERILL left five hundred men to hold IMBODEN there, and pushed on toward Salem. That General could not pursue without uncovering Staunton -- the force threatening nearly equaling his own. Gen. LEE was informed of the situation of affairs.

abstract: We publish this morning a complete diary of the important military events of the year which ends to-day. It discloses hardly more than a third as many battles fought, as in the year which preceded. Indeed, one cannot survey the record without being struck with surprise at the fewness of the actual conflicts, ...
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning a complete diary of the important military events of the year which ends to-day. It discloses hardly more than a third as many battles fought, as in the year which preceded. Indeed, one cannot survey the record without being struck with surprise at the fewness of the actual conflicts, considering the immense forces under arms. The Army of the Potomac, though it has often marched and countermarched, has only fought, in force, the battles of Chancellorsville and Gettysburgh. All its other engagements were by small detachments, and hardly rank above skirmishes -- and even these were very few in number. The Army of the Cumberland have scarcely fought except at Stone River and Chickamauga; and at Chattanooga after being consolidated with the Army of the Mississippi. The Army of the Mississippi did little actual fighting, except in the week's battles which preceded the investment of Vicksburgh, and at Chattanooga. The Army of the Gulf has been engaged, with its main force, only at Port Hudson; all its other fighting has been only in small bodies, and attended with comparatively little bloodshed. The Army of the Ohio has scarcely fired a musket, save at Knoxville the other day, in repelling LONGSTREET; and, being fortified as they were, they settled that affair with very little loss of life. The Army of North Carolina has had no general fight; that of South Carolina scarcely any fight at all excepting at Fort Wagner, and there only three or four regiments were actually engaged.

abstract: Monitors, the Armaments of the
lead_paragraph: The ordnance officer of the monitor Patapsco has furnished a transcript from his record of the expenditures of shot, shell, and powder by that vessel during her period of service of less than a year. The armament of the Patapsco is one 8-inch rifle and one 15-inch Dahlgren (smooth bore). The record shows that up to Nov. 4 this monitor expended, for the 8-inch rifle, 44 tons plus 640 pounds of shot, or altogether, 109,200 pounds. Expenditure of powder for rifle gun, 14,970 pounds. For her 15-inch gun she expended 7 tons plus 1,430 pounds, or 17,130 pounds of shot. Expenditure of powder for 15-inch gun, 12,095 pounds. A very simple calculation from these data, shows that the 8-inch rifle has fired 541 rounds (109,200 pounds of shot, divided by 200, which is the weight of each shot;) while the 15-inch gun has fired but 43 times -- (17,130 pounds of shot, divided by 400, which is the approximate weight of the shot of the 15-inch gun;) that is, more than twelve rounds have been fired from the 200-pounder rifle for every one from the 15-inch Dahlgren. This is a striking illustration of the comparative practical value and efficiency of these two types of guns, placed side by side in the turret of the same monitor. We believe there are at this moment but three 8-inch rifles in the armament of the total monitor fleet. And such is the incomprehensible policy governing the Ordnance Bureau of the naval service, that the new monitors are being armed with the Dahlgren 15-inch exclusively; and this in face of the fact that their commanders have begged to be allowed one rifle at least. It is the universal testimony of naval men that three-fourths of the inefficiency of the monitors is owing to their defective armament.

abstract: -- The loyal people of the reclaimed States of the South seem to have an especial admiration for the NEW-YORK TIMES, if we may judge thereof by the number of journals that are being started in the South of the same name as our own. Only a few weeks ago we chronicled the appearance of the New-Orleans Times -- a paper modeled in every respect upon its New-York prototype. We now also have the Newbern Times, an elegant sheet from the Old North State; and these are to be immediately followed by the Nashville Times, which we have no doubt will likewise do honor to its name.

abstract: Our losses by the enemy gaining possession of East Tennessee, says a correspondent of the Atlanta Intelligencer, are incalculable. We are not only deprived of the vast flour mills of that country, which previously supplied the whole army, but also of vast machine shops and depots, which we had extensively organized at Knoxville. Beside this, we are now entirely cut off from the coal, iron and copper mines of that region, which were worth millions to us. The copper rolling mills at Cleveland, which was superintended by Col. PEET, the Government agent, and which were burnt by the enemy, formerly turned out 6,000 pounds of copper per day. Over three millions of pounds had been delivered to the Government. This was the only copper rolling mill in the country, and which kept us supplied in copper for caps and cannon. This is among our losses by the battle of Chattanooga, which are spoken of as merely resulting in a few thousand men and thirty-eight cannon.
